description: The CompTIA Project+ show is for business professionals who need to assist in coordinating projects or manage small projects. It is not specifically geared toward the IT field but projects in general. A viewer of the show in addition to persona study will gain knowledge and skills required to assist in planning and managing a small-to-medium-size project. He or she will understand the project life cycle, learn steps to ensure appropriate communication, manage resources and stakeholders, and learn techniques to maintain project documentation used to support the completion of projects. The show helps prepare CompTIA Project+ candidates with least 12 months of total experience in leading, managing, directing, and/or participating in small-to-medium-size projects for examination.

The show helps prepare CompTIA Project+ candidates with least 12 months of total experience in leading, managing, directing, and/or participating in small-to-medium-size projects for examination.  __This course has been CAQC'd and qualifies for CEU credits. [Click here](https://itpro.tv/comptia-partnership) to get an exam voucher discount.__
name: CompTIA Project+ (2016)
subtitle: Project Management

episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:06.160 --> 00:00:08.518
Hello, thank you for watching ITProTV.

2
00:00:08.518 --> 00:00:15.367
I'm here to introduce you to the CompTIA
project plus exam for PK 004.

3
00:00:15.367 --> 00:00:20.300
What we hope to do is tell you a little
bit more about the exam details.

4
00:00:20.300 --> 00:00:22.280
To talk about the exam objectives,
a little bit, and

5
00:00:22.280 --> 00:00:25.380
to show you what we'll be
covering in our show, as well.

6
00:00:25.380 --> 00:00:27.460
So, let's go ahead and, get started.

7
00:00:27.460 --> 00:00:30.970
If you want to learn more details about
the exam, the easiest place to go,

8
00:00:30.970 --> 00:00:33.130
of course, is to the CompTIA website.

9
00:00:33.130 --> 00:00:35.140
Let me show you what I'm talking about.

10
00:00:35.140 --> 00:00:38.293
If you go ahead and
type in your favorite browser,

11
00:00:38.293 --> 00:00:42.652
this particular link right here
certification.comptia.org that

12
00:00:42.652 --> 00:00:46.651
automatically brings you pretty
much to this page right here.

13
00:00:46.651 --> 00:00:50.815
And you'll see as you hover over it,
it's very sensitive you'll click on

14
00:00:50.815 --> 00:00:55.773
certification and then, once you actually
select certifications, you can scroll down

15
00:00:55.773 --> 00:01:00.180
and see all of the different CompTIA
certifications that there are.

16
00:01:00.180 --> 00:01:04.730
We, though, we're gonna be
focusing in on CompTIA Project+.

17
00:01:04.730 --> 00:01:06.636
So I'm simply gonna
click on the link there.

18
00:01:06.636 --> 00:01:09.140
And it's gonna say,
Click For More Details.

19
00:01:09.140 --> 00:01:13.380
As I do so, that will help me
to focus in on CompTIA Project+.

20
00:01:13.380 --> 00:01:17.330
And this exam code, it says PK0-003.

21
00:01:17.330 --> 00:01:20.033
You're probably wondering, hey that's
kind of a little bit tricky there.

22
00:01:20.033 --> 00:01:24.650
And the reason why is that both exams
are actually still valid right now.

23
00:01:24.650 --> 00:01:28.020
Now as I scroll through here,
I'm gonna scroll down.

24
00:01:28.020 --> 00:01:29.360
And even though there's an overview and

25
00:01:29.360 --> 00:01:32.800
it talks about what this is to help
you measure the skills for, and

26
00:01:32.800 --> 00:01:37.810
why you would choose to sit for this exam,
we're gonna look at the exam details.

27
00:01:37.810 --> 00:01:40.270
Because you've already chosen to sit for
this exam, and

28
00:01:40.270 --> 00:01:42.240
you're now in preparation mode.

29
00:01:42.240 --> 00:01:46.258
And you'll notice, it actually that it
does have both exam details going on.

30
00:01:46.258 --> 00:01:52.330
So, the PK0-003 is still valid, but
as of this particular date that you see,

31
00:01:53.330 --> 00:01:57.330
the PK0-004, is also available as well.

32
00:01:57.330 --> 00:02:01.660
So we're gonna focus in on this
left-hand column just at the beginning.

33
00:02:01.660 --> 00:02:03.860
Now, when you start taking a look,
there, of course,

34
00:02:03.860 --> 00:02:07.860
is the exam description, telling you
that the focus of the exam has changed

35
00:02:07.860 --> 00:02:11.170
a little bit since the earlier
edition of the exam.

36
00:02:11.170 --> 00:02:13.340
And then as we scroll down through here,

37
00:02:13.340 --> 00:02:17.560
notice that this is what we want to focus
in on for some of the exam details.

38
00:02:17.560 --> 00:02:20.000
You are gonna see a maximum, okay, and

39
00:02:20.000 --> 00:02:23.960
the key here is the word,
maximum, of 95 questions.

40
00:02:23.960 --> 00:02:27.267
So that does mean that you may
actually get less than 95.

41
00:02:27.267 --> 00:02:30.760
You shouldn't ever get
more than 95 questions.

42
00:02:30.760 --> 00:02:32.620
But, just saying that, right?

43
00:02:32.620 --> 00:02:34.030
Before you take the exam,

44
00:02:34.030 --> 00:02:37.500
make sure you always come back
to the web page and verify it.

45
00:02:37.500 --> 00:02:41.510
This number can change and CompTIA does
stress that, that they can change these

46
00:02:41.510 --> 00:02:44.500
numbers or these details at
any time that they choose to.

47
00:02:44.500 --> 00:02:49.180
So as of the recording of this
entire show that we're about to see,

48
00:02:49.180 --> 00:02:50.850
that is what you're gonna see here, okay?

49
00:02:50.850 --> 00:02:55.290
So it's gonna be about 95 questions or
somewhere around there.

50
00:02:55.290 --> 00:02:58.261
Notice that they include
of course multiple choice,

51
00:02:58.261 --> 00:03:00.890
as well as multiple response questions.

52
00:03:00.890 --> 00:03:04.670
Drag and drops, so that means you have
to place things in specific order, or

53
00:03:04.670 --> 00:03:06.570
in an arrangement that they choose.

54
00:03:06.570 --> 00:03:12.107
And the passing score is a 710
based on a scale of 1 to 900.

55
00:03:12.107 --> 00:03:16.314
The recommended experience is at
least a year of cumulative project

56
00:03:16.314 --> 00:03:19.880
management experience or
the equivalent education.

57
00:03:19.880 --> 00:03:23.330
Now that doesn't mean that you've had
to have managed an entire project

58
00:03:23.330 --> 00:03:27.780
by yourself, but at least have had
that project management experience.

59
00:03:27.780 --> 00:03:33.080
Currently in US dollars the exam
pricing is about $294 but

60
00:03:33.080 --> 00:03:35.430
make sure you do take
a look at this link and

61
00:03:35.430 --> 00:03:38.420
check out the area that you're in
wherever you are in the world and

62
00:03:38.420 --> 00:03:43.450
that will help you out as well to make
sure you get the proper pricing tube.

63
00:03:43.450 --> 00:03:48.424
You are also going to be testing normally
through a Pearson VUE testing center, so

64
00:03:48.424 --> 00:03:51.245
wherever you're local
center is going to be.

65
00:03:51.245 --> 00:03:55.647
Make sure you do know where that is and
that you arrive there about 15 minutes

66
00:03:55.647 --> 00:03:58.219
early, before you get
into the exam itself so

67
00:03:58.219 --> 00:04:02.320
that they can get all the processing
done that they need to.

68
00:04:02.320 --> 00:04:05.860
Now, what about details on the exam and
where can I find that so

69
00:04:05.860 --> 00:04:08.270
that I can study a bit more effectively.

70
00:04:08.270 --> 00:04:11.430
Well, the great thing is,
it's right here on the website as well.

71
00:04:11.430 --> 00:04:14.750
As I scroll down over on
the right-hand side, notice

72
00:04:14.750 --> 00:04:18.640
right here it says you can get these
sample questions and exam objectives.

73
00:04:18.640 --> 00:04:22.010
And you simply of course fill out
the information that you want and

74
00:04:22.010 --> 00:04:23.890
if you want sample questions
it'll show you some.

75
00:04:23.890 --> 00:04:26.600
If you don't, just simply uncheck that and

76
00:04:26.600 --> 00:04:30.520
then of course tell them your training
status and when plan on taking it and

77
00:04:30.520 --> 00:04:33.410
whether or not you want to be
informed of special promotions.

78
00:04:33.410 --> 00:04:35.550
Now it doesn't sound like anything big,
but

79
00:04:35.550 --> 00:04:39.650
you may get discount vouchers if you
see this sometimes so it does happen.

80
00:04:39.650 --> 00:04:43.760
I went ahead and downloaded the latest
objectives that we have, so

81
00:04:43.760 --> 00:04:48.530
if I click on this tab, you'll see here is
what the objectives normally look like.

82
00:04:48.530 --> 00:04:51.600
So they'll come to you in a the form
of a PDF that you can print off, but

83
00:04:51.600 --> 00:04:53.240
here's the latest exam objectives and

84
00:04:53.240 --> 00:04:58.720
always go to the website itself to verify
that you do have the latest edition.

85
00:04:58.720 --> 00:05:02.410
As we scroll on through here, it will kind
of go through some of the same things that

86
00:05:02.410 --> 00:05:07.150
we've just talked about but a little
bit more detail on the exam itself.

87
00:05:07.150 --> 00:05:09.180
So, notice they give you
all the information.

88
00:05:09.180 --> 00:05:11.210
The same thing that we've
just talked about here.

89
00:05:11.210 --> 00:05:16.868
The key for you, again, is to make sure
you pay attention to that exam number.

90
00:05:16.868 --> 00:05:21.650
PK0-004 is pretty much the key here.

91
00:05:21.650 --> 00:05:25.720
Now, what are we going to
actually see on the exam?

92
00:05:25.720 --> 00:05:29.860
Well right here, you gonna see that it's
actually divided into four different areas

93
00:05:29.860 --> 00:05:31.860
and their not equally weighted.

94
00:05:31.860 --> 00:05:38.415
The first part the project basics itself
takes up nearly 40% of the the exam.

95
00:05:38.415 --> 00:05:42.495
So make sure you do focus heavily
on those project basics, and

96
00:05:42.495 --> 00:05:46.165
understand those fundamentals that
you need to in project management.

97
00:05:46.165 --> 00:05:48.675
The same thing with the project
constraints in which

98
00:05:48.675 --> 00:05:51.385
you'll need to go over those
details on how do you actually

99
00:05:51.385 --> 00:05:54.620
put in the limits that you
want on your project as well.

100
00:05:54.620 --> 00:05:58.260
And then of course, how do you manage
change and the communication process?

101
00:05:58.260 --> 00:06:00.190
Another quarter of the exam.

102
00:06:00.190 --> 00:06:03.580
And finally, some of the project tools and
documentations.

103
00:06:03.580 --> 00:06:08.240
Now for the show that we are about
to continue and produce for

104
00:06:08.240 --> 00:06:14.070
you right here at ITProTV, we will be
going over every single one of these

105
00:06:14.070 --> 00:06:19.170
exam objectives that you see right here to
ensure that you do get maximum coverage.

106
00:06:19.170 --> 00:06:23.120
Now, viewing the videos by themselves
is not gonna be sufficient.

107
00:06:23.120 --> 00:06:25.270
You'll have to put in some homework time.

108
00:06:25.270 --> 00:06:26.830
Make sure that you go ahead and

109
00:06:26.830 --> 00:06:31.100
you try and put them into a scenario
that you'll understand and know and

110
00:06:31.100 --> 00:06:34.370
make sure you wrestle with these
concepts a little bit more.

111
00:06:34.370 --> 00:06:37.260
So you'll see on the very
basics here they'll cover

112
00:06:37.260 --> 00:06:41.380
kind of the same things here,
project roles, responsibilities.

113
00:06:41.380 --> 00:06:45.050
Some of the different standard project
phases in which you'll go through, and

114
00:06:45.050 --> 00:06:50.800
of course even some of the cost control,
organizational structures, and scheduling.

115
00:06:50.800 --> 00:06:55.270
As well as, they've added in, of course,
Agile methodology in here for us.

116
00:06:55.270 --> 00:06:58.640
And as you continue to go on through,
you'll see more and more of that.

117
00:06:58.640 --> 00:07:01.210
Going through the project constraints,
we'll actually slow down and

118
00:07:01.210 --> 00:07:05.160
take some good detailed looks at some
of these different project constraints.

119
00:07:05.160 --> 00:07:08.000
And this is where we're giving
something else here too,

120
00:07:08.000 --> 00:07:10.770
which is this phrase right here,
given a scenario.

121
00:07:10.770 --> 00:07:13.740
So do not think that
the multiple choice questions

122
00:07:13.740 --> 00:07:16.930
are always just gonna be
about you picking just one.

123
00:07:16.930 --> 00:07:20.180
You have to actually take a look at
the scenario, understand the context

124
00:07:20.180 --> 00:07:23.830
to be able to answer completely and
wholly what needs to be done.

125
00:07:23.830 --> 00:07:26.910
Don't read into the questions too much,
but make sure

126
00:07:26.910 --> 00:07:31.800
when you answer the question, you answer
fully the entire question itself.

127
00:07:31.800 --> 00:07:34.040
Same thing with the Communication and
Change Management,

128
00:07:34.040 --> 00:07:35.790
in which will go over strategy.

129
00:07:35.790 --> 00:07:39.573
As well as, of course, the details that
we need in terms of communication, and

130
00:07:39.573 --> 00:07:43.355
finally you actually end up seeing, as I
scroll down here into the project tools

131
00:07:43.355 --> 00:07:47.549
and documentations, we'll take a look at
these different tools and documentations.

132
00:07:47.549 --> 00:07:51.915
And we'll talk about them, make sure you
have a good understanding of that as well,

133
00:07:51.915 --> 00:07:55.090
as we continue throughout
this particular show.

134
00:07:55.090 --> 00:07:59.820
So if you are getting prepared and you
are saying, hey, I need some details and

135
00:07:59.820 --> 00:08:04.451
I need to learn more about getting for
the Project+ exam itself,

136
00:08:04.451 --> 00:08:08.130
well ITProTV will have
the show right here for you.

137
00:08:08.130 --> 00:08:10.444
So if you're ready get started,

138
00:08:10.444 --> 00:08:14.500
check this out in the very next
video following this show.

139
00:08:14.500 --> 00:08:19.892
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Cherokee and Ronnie explain the differences between the two exams.
episodes.title: Comparing PK0-003 vs PK0-004
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:03.269 --> 00:00:06.184
Welcome, if you're searching for
all things CompTIA Project+,

2
00:00:06.184 --> 00:00:07.860
you're in the right place.

3
00:00:07.860 --> 00:00:12.116
In this particular short segment,
we're gonna go ahead and

4
00:00:12.116 --> 00:00:16.288
cover the differences
between the PK0-003 exam, and

5
00:00:16.288 --> 00:00:21.220
we'll look at the new updated
objectives for the PK0-004 exam.

6
00:00:21.220 --> 00:00:24.562
With us, to help go into detail,
we have Sir Ronnie Wong, thank you for

7
00:00:24.562 --> 00:00:26.120
being with us today, Ronnie.

8
00:00:26.120 --> 00:00:26.760
>> Well thank you for

9
00:00:26.760 --> 00:00:30.650
having me back as we take a look at
just some basic comparisons here.

10
00:00:30.650 --> 00:00:34.810
Now if you've been studying for the
previous edition of the exam, you probably

11
00:00:34.810 --> 00:00:37.890
found it a little bit overwhelming
in terms of the amount of material.

12
00:00:37.890 --> 00:00:41.130
And that was because they were really
preparing you to become what they thought

13
00:00:41.130 --> 00:00:47.050
was a good senior manager on a project
that you would end up managing.

14
00:00:47.050 --> 00:00:51.124
So they kind of put themselves in
a comparison with the idea of actually you

15
00:00:51.124 --> 00:00:54.030
actually becoming
a senior project manager.

16
00:00:54.030 --> 00:00:57.130
So that was the focus and
the scope of everything that they did.

17
00:00:57.130 --> 00:01:00.980
And so you went over a lot of details in
terms of the way that the planning went

18
00:01:00.980 --> 00:01:05.240
out, and all the actual incredible amounts
of formulas that you had to learn, and

19
00:01:05.240 --> 00:01:09.190
details in terms of WBS,
and so many other things.

20
00:01:09.190 --> 00:01:11.110
Well, with the newer exam objectives,
though,

21
00:01:11.110 --> 00:01:14.520
they've changed the scope of this
because they realized that there was

22
00:01:14.520 --> 00:01:18.600
already another certification that
really held that place very well.

23
00:01:18.600 --> 00:01:21.690
Which, of course, is the PMP exam instead.

24
00:01:21.690 --> 00:01:26.130
So what they did is they said, look, let's
focus in instead on the idea here of being

25
00:01:26.130 --> 00:01:30.350
more of an assistant to a project
manager that might be working.

26
00:01:30.350 --> 00:01:31.900
So let me show you what I'm talking about,
and

27
00:01:31.900 --> 00:01:34.160
here's where they've changed
the focus on the exam.

28
00:01:34.160 --> 00:01:36.860
So on my computer,
I've actually listed three different

29
00:01:36.860 --> 00:01:40.200
areas in which you'll see here,
or different roles, okay?

30
00:01:40.200 --> 00:01:42.670
One as a junior project manager, and

31
00:01:42.670 --> 00:01:45.470
you can see where they might
actually be in charge of a project.

32
00:01:45.470 --> 00:01:48.530
But this time,
small to medium size projects here,

33
00:01:48.530 --> 00:01:52.050
where they actually end up managing
a lot of different things.

34
00:01:52.050 --> 00:01:52.940
But overall though,

35
00:01:52.940 --> 00:01:56.850
they will still end up reporting
to a senior project manager, okay?

36
00:01:56.850 --> 00:02:01.560
With previous experience, you also see
the idea of that project coordinator,

37
00:02:01.560 --> 00:02:04.820
okay, who actually does help out with
the project management itself, but

38
00:02:04.820 --> 00:02:07.293
manages to coordinate
all of the resources and

39
00:02:07.293 --> 00:02:10.570
ensures that everything happens
when it actually needs to happen.

40
00:02:10.570 --> 00:02:12.220
And then, of course, the scheduler here,

41
00:02:12.220 --> 00:02:15.390
too, who really does manage
the overall schedule.

42
00:02:15.390 --> 00:02:19.100
And to understand those ideas and
those concepts of project management

43
00:02:19.100 --> 00:02:22.340
are really helpful,
even at the most basic levels.

44
00:02:22.340 --> 00:02:26.280
So that is where it comes down
to the big differences between

45
00:02:26.280 --> 00:02:30.560
the previous iteration on the exam,
the 003, and

46
00:02:30.560 --> 00:02:36.080
also the 004 as the focus and the audience
that they're trying to address.

47
00:02:36.080 --> 00:02:40.660
So what you'll see as a big difference
here in terms of the content is that even

48
00:02:40.660 --> 00:02:45.770
though in the 004 we cover kind
of the most basic formulas, a lot

49
00:02:45.770 --> 00:02:50.280
of the advanced and more complex formulas
are essentially not going to be covered,

50
00:02:50.280 --> 00:02:54.240
because they know that you're probably
heading on to a more advanced type of

51
00:02:54.240 --> 00:02:56.500
project management certification.

52
00:02:56.500 --> 00:02:59.470
So that's where you do see
the differences there.

53
00:02:59.470 --> 00:03:04.385
Also, you tend to see where you're gonna
take a look at the idea of planning, and

54
00:03:04.385 --> 00:03:09.155
it really does seem like that we don't
go into the execution and controlling,

55
00:03:09.155 --> 00:03:12.556
and even the closing phase of
the project management and

56
00:03:12.556 --> 00:03:17.434
the learning phase of project management,
too much inside of the PK-004.

57
00:03:17.434 --> 00:03:21.330
So, let's talk about the differences
then in terms of the exam.

58
00:03:21.330 --> 00:03:23.900
Okay, so
we take a look at my screen one more time.

59
00:03:23.900 --> 00:03:27.280
We'll see the actual comparison
differences in the domain objectives.

60
00:03:27.280 --> 00:03:31.040
And you'll notice right away that what
they've done is they have reduced this

61
00:03:31.040 --> 00:03:35.275
to actually taking away at least one of
the actual objective domains here, okay?

62
00:03:35.275 --> 00:03:39.690
Whereas before there were five,
now they've focused it in on

63
00:03:39.690 --> 00:03:44.440
pretty much just really project basics,
where they've actually taken the idea of

64
00:03:44.440 --> 00:03:49.430
each individual process group, or
the idea of phases instead, and

65
00:03:49.430 --> 00:03:53.340
now they've turned them into just
saying overall project basics.

66
00:03:53.340 --> 00:03:57.131
Understanding the idea of just
regular project constraints, and

67
00:03:57.131 --> 00:04:01.810
then communication and change management,
as well as documentation and tools.

68
00:04:01.810 --> 00:04:06.612
You won't notice that over here on
the earlier iteration, every single one of

69
00:04:06.612 --> 00:04:10.688
those phases really had their own
particular domain objectives,

70
00:04:10.688 --> 00:04:14.530
which meant that you covered
them in much more detail.

71
00:04:14.530 --> 00:04:18.130
And that is because they wanted you
to understand those process groups

72
00:04:18.130 --> 00:04:21.570
incredibly well, which is great,
because that's something that we needed.

But they realized that they were

74

which was not what they

75
00:04:27.880 --> 00:04:31.260
So instead, they've kind of
hit a more basic market here.

76
00:04:31.260 --> 00:04:34.350
And saying hey, if you've been

77
00:04:34.350 --> 00:04:38.520
recommended idea of at least 12 months of

78
00:04:38.520 --> 00:04:42.030
being a part of a project, and needing
to understand project management because

79
00:04:42.030 --> 00:04:45.090

80
00:04:45.090 --> 00:04:48.750
or a coordinator, here's

81
00:04:48.750 --> 00:04:53.500
So essentially, when it comes down to it,

83

87

So if you are one of those people,

88

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee cover project properties and help explain the differences between a project and a program. Ronnie defines Projects as a temporary endeavor to create a unique product, service or result whereas programs refers to an ongoing effort that is repetitive and follows existing procedures. They also discuss  what a project as part of a portfolio is and how it can be beneficial. Whether it be categorizing a landscaping service to developing a java program for a website make sure you feel comfortable understanding and identifying  the differences of a project versus program.
episodes.title: Explain Project Properties

success in the future we need to.

>> Yeah, looking at those tangible

episodes.description: In this episode you will find Cherokee and Ronnie diving into the many Roles and Responsibilities covered on CompTIA's Project+ exam. You will see the roles of Sponsor and Champion and even learn how certain roles be combined depending on the size of the organization or Project team. Other Roles covered here include Project Managers and Stakeholders. Understanding the essential roles and responsibilities of each title will be an integral part of defying a well organized Project team.
episodes.title: Understand Roles and Responsibilities

00:13:54.260 --> 00:13:58.790
So when you start seeing this, really,
when it comes down to the functionality of

250
00:13:58.790 --> 00:14:02.533
what they manage, they start by
managing the scope, the time, and

251
00:14:02.533 --> 00:14:07.196
the resources of the project by putting it
into that idea of the project plan, okay,

252
00:14:07.196 --> 00:14:10.041
and seeing everything that
needs to be done there.

253
00:14:10.041 --> 00:14:12.280
That's what they actually end up doing.

254
00:14:12.280 --> 00:14:16.560
They're massaging all these elements
together within those constraints of time

255
00:14:16.560 --> 00:14:22.470
requirements and cost to try and get
the overall temporary endeavor done, okay?

256
00:14:22.470 --> 00:14:27.637
And at the most basic level, they manage
the quality assurance that the project

257
00:14:27.637 --> 00:14:31.410
is getting done at the requirements
that it actually needs to be done at.

258
00:14:31.410 --> 00:14:34.630
And it's not just done because
we completed something.

259
00:14:34.630 --> 00:14:38.990
And then they are absolutely
responsible for whatever is created.

260
00:14:38.990 --> 00:14:42.490
So even though the project
sponsor himself owns it,

261
00:14:42.490 --> 00:14:46.071
the project manager is ultimately
responsible for the quality, and

262
00:14:46.071 --> 00:14:51.070
for the time, and for
the cost of the overall project himself.

263
00:14:51.070 --> 00:14:54.190
So there's a lot that goes on with
the idea of the project manager.

264
00:14:55.440 --> 00:14:59.000
>> Okay, great, I see another
term we have here is stakeholder.

265
00:14:59.000 --> 00:15:03.700
Ronnie, you explained this to us a few
moments ago, but just to kind of reiterate

266
00:15:03.700 --> 00:15:07.220
and cover that term, how would you
go ahead and define stakeholder?

267
00:15:07.220 --> 00:15:11.940
>> Well, this is where the terminology is
kinda fuzzy and doesn't really make sense

268
00:15:11.940 --> 00:15:15.010
if you haven't been dealing in
the realm of project management.

269
00:15:15.010 --> 00:15:17.110
Everybody always puts it in these terms.

270
00:15:17.110 --> 00:15:21.100
A stakeholder is someone, okay,
he, she, whatever it might be,

271
00:15:21.100 --> 00:15:23.200
okay, that has a vested interest.

272
00:15:23.200 --> 00:15:27.690
And that's the term that always bothered
me, vested interest in the project, okay?

273
00:15:27.690 --> 00:15:30.717
Now that idea of vested interest,
what do you think that means, Cherokee?

274
00:15:30.717 --> 00:15:34.005
>> Well, see, when I trained for
project management,

275
00:15:34.005 --> 00:15:36.789
it was with a different
certificate agency.

276
00:15:36.789 --> 00:15:41.718
And the way I was taught was that
basically anyone who would be

277
00:15:41.718 --> 00:15:45.779
affected by the overall
outcome of that project,

278
00:15:45.779 --> 00:15:50.628
whether it be employees,
customers, the shareholders.

279
00:15:50.628 --> 00:15:55.966
And even depending on the scope of your
project, it could even be the public.

280
00:15:55.966 --> 00:16:00.912
>> Right, so anyone who is affected by
it could potentially be a stakeholder in

281
00:16:00.912 --> 00:16:01.929
your project.

282
00:16:01.929 --> 00:16:06.306
And that's normally what you do mean when
you start taking a look at the overall

283
00:16:06.306 --> 00:16:08.600
realm of the project itself.

284
00:16:08.600 --> 00:16:11.560
But stakeholders a lot of times, right,

285
00:16:11.560 --> 00:16:17.210
they are the ones who are responsible for
the project work getting done, okay.

286
00:16:17.210 --> 00:16:21.700
Now, you can have stakeholders that have
a vested interest in two particular ways.

287
00:16:21.700 --> 00:16:22.870
One, of course, is negatively.

288
00:16:22.870 --> 00:16:25.430
And the other one,
of course, is positively.

289
00:16:25.430 --> 00:16:26.600
Normally, on project management,

290
00:16:26.600 --> 00:16:30.490
we mean the positive idea here,
not always the negative idea.

291
00:16:30.490 --> 00:16:32.330
But normally,
that's who we're talking about.

292
00:16:32.330 --> 00:16:36.030
If somebody has a vested interested
in that project being completed,

293
00:16:36.030 --> 00:16:41.630
that means that they absolutely have
put some time into that project.

294
00:16:41.630 --> 00:16:44.410
Whether it was because they
offered their own expertise

295
00:16:45.470 --> 00:16:48.640
into the insights of how
that project is to be done.

296
00:16:48.640 --> 00:16:53.330
Or they may have actually went ahead and
put up some money to help that

297
00:16:53.330 --> 00:16:58.080
project get started, or get carried
through in that particular portion and

298
00:16:58.080 --> 00:17:03.400
they expect a return from that or
it could be actual effort that they put.

299
00:17:03.400 --> 00:17:08.520
In other words, they're part of a team
which is now again part of the actual

300
00:17:08.520 --> 00:17:12.330
overall project, which needs to get
done so that their company can get paid.

301
00:17:12.330 --> 00:17:15.280
You name it,
they become a stakeholder as well just by

302
00:17:15.280 --> 00:17:18.460
the very fact that they're
doing work on the project, too.

303
00:17:18.460 --> 00:17:24.310
So in that sense they have a very real way
of doing things that can really affect us,

304
00:17:24.310 --> 00:17:29.440
the very fact is a project stakeholder
regardless of how small it can be,

305
00:17:29.440 --> 00:17:32.050
can really affect the overall
project steering,

306
00:17:32.050 --> 00:17:35.080
now in a positive way, hopefully,

307
00:17:35.080 --> 00:17:38.380
that's what the majority especially if
I'm the project manager I want you to do.

308
00:17:38.380 --> 00:17:41.110
But the very fact is,
Cherokee mentioned something.

309
00:17:41.110 --> 00:17:45.630
That even the public could actually be
considered a stakeholder in my project,

310
00:17:45.630 --> 00:17:48.430
and what if they don't want
my project to come through?

311
00:17:48.430 --> 00:17:52.130
They can literally be the people that
steers my project to the point where

312
00:17:52.130 --> 00:17:53.530
it just has to end.

313
00:17:53.530 --> 00:17:57.150
Because nobody else wants it,
even though I might want it.

314
00:17:57.150 --> 00:18:00.490
It might be something that actually
ends because that particular stakeholder

315
00:18:00.490 --> 00:18:04.590
has a vested interest in not,
in that project either not completing, or

316
00:18:04.590 --> 00:18:06.410
not even taking place at all.

317
00:18:06.410 --> 00:18:08.140
>> Yeah and
the internet's really even shaped that.

318
00:18:08.140 --> 00:18:11.439
Have you seen a lot of those web sites
where they have those start-up companies,

319
00:18:11.439 --> 00:18:12.554
and they have to go ahead and

320
00:18:12.554 --> 00:18:15.853
get x amount of contributors to the public
to go ahead and support their project,

321
00:18:15.853 --> 00:18:18.457
to even purchase the supplies to
go ahead and continue to do so.

322
00:18:18.457 --> 00:18:21.236
>> Yeah, and to me,
that's a little bit unusual.

323
00:18:21.236 --> 00:18:21.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because,

324
00:18:21.940 --> 00:18:24.170
you can't, you know,
you hate to say this, right?

325
00:18:24.170 --> 00:18:27.586
Where does the money go if all of
a sudden, now, you have another group that

326
00:18:27.586 --> 00:18:31.061
says look, here's 10,000 people
that contributed a dollar each and

327
00:18:31.061 --> 00:18:33.686
all of a sudden, you go,
well, I needed 15,000.

328
00:18:33.686 --> 00:18:35.430
Where does the money
actually end up going?

329
00:18:35.430 --> 00:18:37.770
What ends up happening to that
money if it doesn't do anything?

330
00:18:37.770 --> 00:18:40.060
And a lot of times, you just don't know.

331
00:18:40.060 --> 00:18:44.360
So the idea that somebody can have a
vested interest in your project is great,

332
00:18:44.360 --> 00:18:45.910
but when you start thinking about it for

333
00:18:45.910 --> 00:18:49.960
your project management ideas, you always
think about it in terms of, at least for

334
00:18:49.960 --> 00:18:52.170
me, concretely,
the way that I always do it.

335
00:18:52.170 --> 00:18:56.460
As they invest time in my project,
they invest money into my project,

336
00:18:56.460 --> 00:19:00.700
they put any type of work to help me,
to get that project successful,

337
00:19:00.700 --> 00:19:04.530
that's normally who I think about as
being a stakeholder in my project and

338
00:19:04.530 --> 00:19:06.680
that's important to make, okay?

339
00:19:06.680 --> 00:19:11.643
So, even if they offer me at least
a modicum of advice as a subject matter

340
00:19:11.643 --> 00:19:14.639
of expert and
I told them what I was I doing.

341
00:19:14.639 --> 00:19:17.950
And they're like,
here's what I'd like to see you do, okay?

342
00:19:17.950 --> 00:19:22.440
Even that statement unto itself means that
that person has now actually invested some

343
00:19:22.440 --> 00:19:25.450
interest in my project,
which helps me to succeed.

344
00:19:25.450 --> 00:19:30.170
I would consider them a vested interest
in the project and a stakeholder.

345
00:19:30.170 --> 00:19:31.810
And all these are actually very important.

346
00:19:31.810 --> 00:19:34.590
Because remember, a project stakeholder,

347
00:19:34.590 --> 00:19:38.270
not necessarily just a simple one
even though it could be, okay.

348
00:19:38.270 --> 00:19:41.490
Such as a project sponsor,
he's a stakeholder in the project, right.

349
00:19:41.490 --> 00:19:45.190
Project manager is if
a project sponsor says look,

350
00:19:45.190 --> 00:19:48.710
I don't want this project to succeed,
the project will never get off its ground.

351
00:19:48.710 --> 00:19:50.440
Okay, it's just not going to happen.

352
00:19:50.440 --> 00:19:53.210
So even though he might actually
be the original sponsor

353
00:19:53.210 --> 00:19:54.170
he may choose-
>> You're fired-

354
00:19:54.170 --> 00:19:56.500
>> After a while, yeah he's fired or

355
00:19:56.500 --> 00:19:58.460
you're fired or whatever it might be.

356
00:19:58.460 --> 00:20:00.940
If you're a project manager and
you decide to quit,

357
00:20:00.940 --> 00:20:04.810
well remember there's ramifications for
the rest of the project that goes on to.

358
00:20:04.810 --> 00:20:08.527
So everybody that's a stakeholder
normally likes the idea of status quo,

359
00:20:08.527 --> 00:20:10.680
likes the idea of positive pushes.

360
00:20:10.680 --> 00:20:13.190
But it doesn't mean it
always happens as well.

361
00:20:13.190 --> 00:20:16.760
So there's a lot of different roles that
we're actually seeing right here just

362
00:20:16.760 --> 00:20:17.600
as we begin.

363
00:20:17.600 --> 00:20:19.070
>> And thank you for
explaining those, Ronnie.

364
00:20:19.070 --> 00:20:21.975
I think you did a really great job
defining those roles and their

365
00:20:21.975 --> 00:20:26.070
responsibilities but I think let's gonna
go ahead and wrap it for this episode.

366
00:20:26.070 --> 00:20:30.890
So thank you guys for tuning in with us
today and I'm Cherokee Boose, signing off.

367
00:20:30.890 --> 00:20:32.325
And I'm Ronnie Wong.
>> Have a great day.

368
00:20:35.540 --> 00:20:39.802
[MUSIC]

369
00:20:39.802 --> 00:20:43.184
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: Ronnie and Cherokee continue to cover the individual responsibilities of each Role within a Project. In this episode you will understand what a Project Coordinator does and how that differs from previously covered roles such as Sponsor and Champion. You will also, look at the tasks which define a Scheduler, the Project Team and even a PMO (Project Management Office).
episodes.title: Understand Roles and Responsibilities Part 2

WEBVTT

We've just wrapped up talking about some

8

And in this episode we're

>> [LAUGH]
>> Thank you for being with us, Ronnie.

13

>> Well, thank you for having me on the
show as we continue on taking a look at

00:00:43.170 --> 00:00:46.230
some of these different roles and
responsibilities.

15
00:00:46.230 --> 00:00:48.750
We're moving on to, well,
just some additional

00:00:48.750 --> 00:00:51.990
roles that we have to understand that
you're normally gonna end up finding.

17

And this is really one of
the roles that the CompTIAProject+

examination is really designed to help
validate the skills and knowledge for,

20
00:01:04.660 --> 00:01:08.440
Now, Cherokee, when we hear about
the idea of a project coordinator,

00:01:08.440 --> 00:01:12.550
what terms come to your mind
when you hear coordinator.

22
00:01:12.550 --> 00:01:17.720
>> Perhaps scheduling, and adhering
to certain deadlines and timelines?

23
00:01:17.720 --> 00:01:19.700
Yeah, that's exactly what it sounds like,

24
00:01:19.700 --> 00:01:21.630
is that there's something
that needs to be coordinated.

25
00:01:21.630 --> 00:01:24.030
In other words,
needs to be arranged and danced or

26
00:01:24.030 --> 00:01:28.240
whatever it might be that two things
are gonna have to come together at least

27
00:01:28.240 --> 00:01:31.070
to make sure that everything
is actually getting done.

28
00:01:31.070 --> 00:01:35.720
And that's the same thing that's really
true about accomplishing a project

29
00:01:35.720 --> 00:01:38.620
successfully at the very end,
is that it's not so

30
00:01:38.620 --> 00:01:43.650
much about an incredible micromanagement
as much as it's about bringing

31
00:01:43.650 --> 00:01:48.580
all of these different forces that
are in play, into some type of dance or

32
00:01:48.580 --> 00:01:51.980
symphony or organization that

33
00:01:51.980 --> 00:01:53.650
Now when I talk about
these different elements,

34
00:01:53.650 --> 00:01:58.140
right, we're really talking about the
constraints that we have on our project.

35
00:01:58.140 --> 00:02:01.200
The idea of understanding what
the requirements are of the project.

36
00:02:01.200 --> 00:02:03.980
The idea of understand that
we're under a time limit and

37
00:02:03.980 --> 00:02:10.100
that there is a cost value associated that
all these elements have to come together.

38
00:02:10.100 --> 00:02:13.230
And normally it requires the idea
of what we call a project

39
00:02:13.230 --> 00:02:15.270
coordinator is what we have here.

40
00:02:15.270 --> 00:02:18.356
So that is where we want
to begin is in this idea.

41
00:02:18.356 --> 00:02:22.350
Now, when we start talking about it
remember that we rarely take a look at

42
00:02:22.350 --> 00:02:25.821
the idea of a project sponsor as
well as the idea of the manager,

43
00:02:25.821 --> 00:02:29.380
the project manager itself and
the actual stakeholder itself.

44
00:02:29.380 --> 00:02:32.320
So there's a lot going on when
we start to take a look on

45
00:02:32.320 --> 00:02:33.540
>> It does sound like a lot is going on,

46
00:02:33.540 --> 00:02:35.130
we've got all these different roles.

47
00:02:35.130 --> 00:02:38.640
And so, Ronnie could you please tell
me exactly what needs to happen,

48
00:02:38.640 --> 00:02:43.100
what needs to transpire for that
actual project to be accounted for and

49
00:02:43.100 --> 00:02:45.230
considered to be complete.

50
00:02:45.230 --> 00:02:48.220
>> When you start to take a look at it,
right, and the project itself,

51
00:02:48.220 --> 00:02:52.680
you can kind of compare the idea of
the project coordinator's role and

52
00:02:52.680 --> 00:02:56.470
responsibilities to what we would call
something like an air traffic controller.

53
00:02:56.470 --> 00:03:00.780
Or even the idea of some
type of professional juggler

54
00:03:00.780 --> 00:03:03.420
that keeps everything
in the air at one time.

55
00:03:03.420 --> 00:03:06.090
And that's what you have when you
talk about air traffic control and

56
00:03:06.090 --> 00:03:07.440
you talk about a juggler.

57
00:03:07.440 --> 00:03:09.450
Everything that's actually in play,

58
00:03:09.450 --> 00:03:14.440
right, is all good until something goes
wrong and that's were the coordination

59
00:03:14.440 --> 00:03:18.410
comes in to make sure that everything is
actually proper in a way that needs to be.

60
00:03:18.410 --> 00:03:21.590
Now when you don't have that,
I'm gonna use the juggler example cuz

61
00:03:21.590 --> 00:03:25.140
the other examples really bad here,
is if the juggler,

62
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:29.340
professional juggler drop something
the need thing about that juggler is that,

63
00:03:29.340 --> 00:03:33.230
even though he might drop something it's
very easy for somebody to go ahead and

64
00:03:33.230 --> 00:03:36.830
pick up something and toss it back in,
and he could continue to juggle.

65
00:03:36.830 --> 00:03:41.550
But the idea here is that somebody
has to have those skills and

66
00:03:41.550 --> 00:03:45.910
that particular set of skills and
determination to make it work.

67
00:03:45.910 --> 00:03:49.330
And so that's what we wanna focusing
on is, what are those responsibilities,

68
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:52.800
like Cherokee's talking about,
to make it work out here.

69
00:03:52.800 --> 00:03:56.238
The main particular role, okay, and

70
00:03:56.238 --> 00:03:59.880
duty of somebody that's gonna
be the project coordinator,

71
00:03:59.880 --> 00:04:05.740
he is there to ultimately support the
project manager in multiple ways, okay.

72
00:04:05.740 --> 00:04:10.840
First and foremost of course is
functional coordination of the project.

73
00:04:10.840 --> 00:04:12.430
Now when I say that what does that mean?

74
00:04:12.430 --> 00:04:17.010
That means that a lot of times you're
gonna have multiple project teams that

75
00:04:17.010 --> 00:04:23.000
are going to be competing for resources
at times, for the amount of dollars

76
00:04:23.000 --> 00:04:27.410
that they need, for whatever might be
scheduling time on a particular machine.

77
00:04:27.410 --> 00:04:32.240
You name it, that what has happened is
that somebody needs to keep that common

78
00:04:32.240 --> 00:04:36.980
idea of coordinating when these things
are to happen so that nobody is actually

79
00:04:36.980 --> 00:04:40.990
cheated out of any particular time that
they need to finish up what they need.

80
00:04:40.990 --> 00:04:46.250
But it has to be, again, scheduled, it has
to kind of be managed in that way as well.

81
00:04:46.250 --> 00:04:49.380
The other thing here is
proper documentation.

82
00:04:49.380 --> 00:04:53.400
The project manager may work
on a ton of documentation but

83
00:04:53.400 --> 00:04:55.170
he may not know where everything is.

84
00:04:55.170 --> 00:04:59.430
The coordinator is the one that
can pull out the information

85
00:04:59.430 --> 00:05:04.810
that needs to be there at the time when
it's needed, when it's requested as well.

86
00:05:04.810 --> 00:05:09.000
So proper backup and documentation,
as well as administrative support for

87
00:05:09.000 --> 00:05:11.230
the entire project is gonna be,

88
00:05:11.230 --> 00:05:15.290
normally on the responsibility
of the project coordinator.

89
00:05:15.290 --> 00:05:19.920
Now, notice that in this particular role,
they don't have to know an extreme

90
00:05:19.920 --> 00:05:25.460
amount of project management details or
every skill that a project manager has.

91
00:05:25.460 --> 00:05:29.560
But has at least to know the basics and
the fundamentals of project management,

92
00:05:29.560 --> 00:05:33.380
just like what we're talking about
here in the CompTIAProject+.

93
00:05:33.380 --> 00:05:35.830
So they have to have something like this.

94
00:05:35.830 --> 00:05:39.930
They also need to have that ability
of understanding how to schedule, and

95
00:05:39.930 --> 00:05:42.500
the idea of time management is a big one.

96
00:05:42.500 --> 00:05:46.930
And ultimately at the end, they have to
have the foundations of being able to do

97
00:05:46.930 --> 00:05:51.980
some quality checks that need to go on if
we have deliverables that come around too.

98
00:05:51.980 --> 00:05:56.900

So it's something that you do want to
make sure that if your company has one,

321
00:18:48.050 --> 00:18:51.540
you check that out, cuz that's gonna be
the best resource for you as well, okay?

322
00:18:52.640 --> 00:18:56.390
Also along with that project management
office, depending on what type of project

323
00:18:56.390 --> 00:19:00.180
you're on, you might find out that you're
not the one that set the deliverable.

324
00:19:00.180 --> 00:19:03.060
They're the ones that set what
you're actually going to deliver.

325
00:19:03.060 --> 00:19:07.590
So be aware, you go in as a project
manager and they say, here it is Cherokee.

326
00:19:07.590 --> 00:19:09.610
Here's the project you're
gonna be working on, okay.

327
00:19:09.610 --> 00:19:12.665
Here's what we expect you to deliver,
here's what we expect you to do.

328
00:19:12.665 --> 00:19:15.500
And you can go well who
the heck came up with this?

329
00:19:15.500 --> 00:19:16.890
And they're gonna say we did.

330
00:19:16.890 --> 00:19:19.760
And that's it, you're working for
their company, so

331
00:19:19.760 --> 00:19:21.380
it's not that you have to decide that.

332
00:19:21.380 --> 00:19:25.000
So as a project manager you may not
actually have to go through the majority

333
00:19:25.000 --> 00:19:28.220
of the initiation phase of your project.

334
00:19:28.220 --> 00:19:29.910
Or they've actually already
decided that for you,

335
00:19:29.910 --> 00:19:33.080
so they set up everything in that sense.

336
00:19:33.080 --> 00:19:35.350
They provide for
us key areas of governance.

337
00:19:35.350 --> 00:19:38.410
In other words, they're the overseers
of your particular project.

338
00:19:38.410 --> 00:19:42.870
You are in charge, you are able to do
everything that you need to do, but

339
00:19:42.870 --> 00:19:45.830
when it comes down to
the governance of that project,

340
00:19:45.830 --> 00:19:48.910
that's where you're gonna find
guidelines for regulations.

341
00:19:48.910 --> 00:19:52.490
They may also hold the key performance
indicators that we tend to actually look

342
00:19:52.490 --> 00:19:56.690
for, to verify that our project is
still on time, on task, and on budget.

343
00:19:57.910 --> 00:20:00.650
They may provide additional resources and
tools.

344
00:20:00.650 --> 00:20:03.650
When you go,
this is what I need to get done, and

345
00:20:03.650 --> 00:20:05.830
you might go,
I don't know of anything that does that.

346
00:20:05.830 --> 00:20:08.130
It could be the project
management office says,

347
00:20:08.130 --> 00:20:09.650
here's what you need to get that done.

348
00:20:10.680 --> 00:20:11.370
And they tell you,

349
00:20:11.370 --> 00:20:13.880
here's how you requisition it,
here's how you do this, and

350
00:20:13.880 --> 00:20:18.250
it helps you do that without you having to
figure out the entire process by itself.

351
00:20:18.250 --> 00:20:22.560
It can even go into the areas of you,
as a project manager,

352
00:20:22.560 --> 00:20:24.755
saying, here's the consequences
of it not being done.

353
00:20:24.755 --> 00:20:28.220
Non-performance, you name it,
whatever it can be.

354
00:20:28.220 --> 00:20:30.100
Documentation that you have to keep.

355
00:20:30.100 --> 00:20:32.920
They're the ones that are gonna have all
that documentation if you need to fill

356
00:20:32.920 --> 00:20:33.850
out forms,

357
00:20:33.850 --> 00:20:37.520
if you need to follow templates to ensure
that you're doing the proper worksheets.

358
00:20:37.520 --> 00:20:39.280
You name it, it's going to help you out.

359
00:20:39.280 --> 00:20:42.360
You might be wondering why do we
need all this if I'm working for

360
00:20:42.360 --> 00:20:44.300
a big company that has all
the resource int he world?

361
00:20:45.370 --> 00:20:49.055
Even big companies don't have every
single resource on this planet.

362
00:20:49.055 --> 00:20:53.360
They always have to actually depend on
the very fact that there's a pool of

363
00:20:53.360 --> 00:20:55.150
project managers that they have.

364
00:20:55.150 --> 00:20:57.780
Maybe a pool of resources
that they depend on.

365
00:20:57.780 --> 00:21:00.910
And those even have to be

366
00:21:00.910 --> 00:21:03.896
So you've got to realize that
there's a lot more to it, for

367
00:21:03.896 --> 00:21:07.662
a large organization that actually has
a small pool instead of just a single

368
00:21:07.662 --> 00:21:09.361

369
00:21:09.361 --> 00:21:12.243
In other words you're going to do every

370
00:21:12.243 --> 00:21:15.163
So there's a lot of
different types of roles and

371
00:21:15.163 --> 00:21:19.112
responsibilities out there that
you're likely to encounter.

372
00:21:19.112 --> 00:21:22.040
It doesn't mean that you're gonna
encounter every single one every time you

00:21:22.040 --> 00:21:23.170
work on a project.

374
00:21:23.170 --> 00:21:26.540
But just kind of realize that you're
gonna see at least some of these

375
00:21:26.540 --> 00:21:29.630
as you actually start into your career
in terms of project management.

376
00:21:29.630 --> 00:21:31.380
>> Yeah,
that was my next question, Ronnie.

377
00:21:31.380 --> 00:21:34.552
You've covered the essentials,
the ones that Comptia wants us to know.

378
00:21:34.552 --> 00:21:39.277
But then I was going to ask you if we
always had to have those particular roles

00:21:39.277 --> 00:21:40.340
filled.

380
00:21:40.340 --> 00:21:44.757
And then also If we have a particular

00:21:44.757 --> 00:21:49.656
specific to our industry, or
environment could we add additional, and

382
00:21:49.656 --> 00:21:52.083
then delegate roles in that sense.

383
00:21:52.083 --> 00:21:53.500
>> Yeah, you're gonna have to, right?

384
00:21:53.500 --> 00:21:57.290
So everything that we've talked about

385
00:21:57.290 --> 00:22:00.930
staple of roles that you'll generally see.

386
00:22:00.930 --> 00:22:05.370
As your project grows more complex,
you'll need to add additional roles in.

387
00:22:05.370 --> 00:22:07.491
If your particular project, actually,

00:22:07.491 --> 00:22:10.348
is more technically specific
to something that you do.

389
00:22:10.348 --> 00:22:13.609
Well, you'll find out that there may

00:22:13.609 --> 00:22:16.612
you actually have that help to

391
00:22:16.612 --> 00:22:20.330
Or help to guide you along a little bit

392
00:22:20.330 --> 00:22:23.680
And it also of course depends on
the way that your company is set up for

00:22:23.680 --> 00:22:25.550
how projects take place.

394
00:22:25.550 --> 00:22:28.080
You name it,
you're gonna see that as well.

395
00:22:28.080 --> 00:22:32.240
Now, as far as all these roles go,
just remember that not everything

00:22:32.240 --> 00:22:37.190

00:22:37.190 --> 00:22:40.530
And what I mean by that is that you
might find out like in a small company

nobody says that there's
a project actually even going on.

I know that's weird,

They may not even officially

And you become this kind of

But it can happen without any real titles

00:23:15.112 --> 00:23:16.068

like you mentioned earlier I think you

>> Yeah, you'll see that especially

But in those companies that really say,

Is it good that they do?

Yes, and you might be wondering why?

Well, remember that not everybody's

And so you might find that during

00:23:57.089 --> 00:24:00.648
Well, if somebody isn't officially

All that it's just because of the way

the project ourselves and we don't ever

00:24:48.090 --> 00:24:51.490
And so you'll see, to tell you
the truth it kinda boils down to

The very fact is, it's a show,

00:25:34.625 --> 00:25:38.175
>> Yeah, it actually does end up being

So just kind of realize that a lot

So, you know, it's like I said,
I didn't say Cherokee,

So, some companies work well like that,

ITPro.TV is actually one

00:26:24.810 --> 00:26:28.802
And that's because we've worked together

00:26:28.802 --> 00:26:31.730
Cherokee is relatively new, but

00:26:31.730 --> 00:26:33.210
>> I've known you guys for a long time.

00:26:33.210 --> 00:26:36.550
>> Yeah, she's worked around us for

00:26:36.550 --> 00:26:40.510
But at the same time, it's because

00:26:40.510 --> 00:26:44.590
what you will see in terms of teams and
team building, that we have this trust and

00:26:44.590 --> 00:26:47.870
respect enough to be able to do so

00:26:47.870 --> 00:26:49.860
And so you will see that.

00:26:49.860 --> 00:26:54.290
So in everything that we said here,

00:26:54.290 --> 00:26:55.300

00:26:55.300 --> 00:26:58.840

00:26:58.840 --> 00:27:01.190
Ronnie, I think you did a great job there.

00:27:05.670 --> 00:27:07.400

00:27:07.400 --> 00:27:08.420

00:27:09.450 --> 00:27:10.481

episodes.description: Having methodic approach to a project will provide a plethora of benefits. A haphazard approach may overlook details and leave many gaps as well as cause waste. Ronnie and Cherokee cover the Standard Project Phases in a detailed fashion. First, they look at the Initiation phase. In this phase you determine activities that lead to the Project's authorization. You will also learn about many tools to assist you thru this phase. The tools include a project charter, business case, high-level scope as well as identifying high-level risks.
episodes.title: Distinguish Standard Project Phases Part 1

episodes.description: This episode sheds light on the second project phase, Planning. Here you will see the value of creating a schedule, capitalizing on your resources as well as using many tools to help get achieve a successful plan. Ronnie shows an example of  a Work Breakdown Structure in addition to highlighting the importance of the Project Manager in this phase.
episodes.title: Distinguish Standard Project Phases Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee discuss the Execution and Monitoring phases and explain how they may be occurring in tandem. Ronnie encourages resource identification, including utilizing helpful tools. Your project plan may even be the most beneficial tool in addition to some other useful activities such as: Team Development, Quality Assurance, Established Communications, Schedule Variances as well as Project Plan Updates.
episodes.title: Distinguish Standard Project Phases Part 3

episodes.description: This episode Ronnie and Cherokee look at the last 2 phases of a project. Ronnie explains what is involved in the finality of a project. Will the project be concluded or rejected? Tune in to find out! But wait! There is more... in addition to the optional training implemented in the closing phase CompTIA specifically defines one final phase for training. Once activities such as: The project sign off, archiving, debriefing, releasing resources, and all contracts are closed we can finally call it a day and move on to the next project.
episodes.title: Distinguish Standard Project Phases Part 4

episodes.description: Perplexed when managing a project budget? Then look no further! Ronnie and Cherokee look at some great ways to help your project budget stay on track. We learn the difference between your actual versus planned budget and how that  can really be beneficial. Ronnie also encourages us to account for all payments and expenses via total project cost calculations. We also learn how to prevent premature budget exhaustion with tools such as expenditure tracking and reporting as well as burn rate calculations.
episodes.title: Identify Cost Control Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.405
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2

I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.548 --> 00:00:08.278
[MUSIC]

00:00:08.278 --> 00:00:12.183
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

>> Welcome to another Project+
episode here at ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:15.647 --> 00:00:18.570
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.570 --> 00:00:23.990
Today we're gonna be looking at how
to identify our cost control basics.

8
00:00:23.990 --> 00:00:26.410
And that's something I could
definitely use some help with.

9
00:00:26.410 --> 00:00:28.798
Today we have Ronnie Wong with us,
he's gonna go ahead and

10
00:00:28.798 --> 00:00:30.460

11

Thank you Ronnie.

12
00:00:31.290 --> 00:00:32.650

13
00:00:32.650 --> 00:00:37.662
As we continue on with some of the CompTIA
Project+ episodes here on this show.

14
00:00:37.662 --> 00:00:41.160
We want to take a look especially,
about the idea of cost control.

15
00:00:41.160 --> 00:00:43.700
And you might be wondering,
why do we need center in on this.

00:00:43.700 --> 00:00:47.260
Well remember that project management
itself really revolves around

17

three separate constraints.

18
00:00:49.020 --> 00:00:52.380
One of course is the requirements,
the other is time, and

19
00:00:52.380 --> 00:00:55.020
the third one is cost itself.

20
00:00:55.020 --> 00:01:00.220
So, we make sure that as project managers
that we are constantly on top of the cost

because if we don't what ends
up happening is fairly simple.

The project can quickly start to, again,

exceed how much we actually

24

And when we talk about the idea of excess,
we're not talking about spending $10 or

25
00:01:15.456 --> 00:01:18.310
$15 over what we thought
the project would be.

26
00:01:18.310 --> 00:01:22.650
Sometimes this turns into thousands of
dollars, if not even more than that, and

27
00:01:22.650 --> 00:01:24.840
time starts slipping, and you name it.

28
00:01:24.840 --> 00:01:28.430
So keeping control of our cost
is really going to be important.

29
00:01:28.430 --> 00:01:32.840
And what we want to do here,
especially when we start taking a look at

30
00:01:32.840 --> 00:01:37.720
the CompTIA Project+ is that we
wanna understand at least what

31
00:01:37.720 --> 00:01:43.410
are some of those basic cost
controls that we wanna keep in mind.

32
00:01:43.410 --> 00:01:46.930
So what do we normally need
to determine when we start to

33
00:01:46.930 --> 00:01:48.570
think about something like this?

34
00:01:48.570 --> 00:01:52.670
Well we wanna make sure that as we
are overseeing and as we are managing,

35
00:01:52.670 --> 00:01:55.700
of course,
all the different project expenses.

36
00:01:55.700 --> 00:01:59.908
And trying to do everything that we can
to make sure that we're on top of it.

37
00:01:59.908 --> 00:02:04.010
Is that we're really just trying to
determine really one overall goal.

38
00:02:04.010 --> 00:02:08.395
Which, of course,
is gonna be total project cost itself.

39
00:02:08.395 --> 00:02:09.502
When I say that, what do I mean?

40
00:02:09.502 --> 00:02:15.200
I mean accounting essentially for every
penny that is spent upon that project.

41
00:02:15.200 --> 00:02:17.380
Whether we're talking
about human resources or

42
00:02:17.380 --> 00:02:19.330
whether we're talking
about material resources.

43

There are a lot of different tools,

269
00:14:24.940 --> 00:14:28.140
especially even pie graphs are great,
pie charts are great for that.

270
00:14:28.140 --> 00:14:29.160
So you can use colors, and

271
00:14:29.160 --> 00:14:34.280
you're like look there's the little,
the car section of my circle there.

272
00:14:34.280 --> 00:14:39.940
>> Yeah, now expenditure tracking
really is where accountants come in,

273
00:14:39.940 --> 00:14:41.820
the people that love to crunch numbers.

274
00:14:41.820 --> 00:14:43.940
They're really good at
this to help you go,

275
00:14:43.940 --> 00:14:47.560
look Ronnie, don't get me wrong,
here's how much money you had,

276
00:14:47.560 --> 00:14:52.650
but this is what's happening right
now is I'm showing that on the track.

277
00:14:52.650 --> 00:14:55.550
In other words, of whatever curve
that they were measuring off,

278
00:14:56.680 --> 00:14:59.240
that you're spending too
much money too fast.

279
00:14:59.240 --> 00:15:02.570
Now, let's take a look at this and
we'll talk about that idea in a moment.

280
00:15:02.570 --> 00:15:06.595
So, what we're actually taking a look at
here, is that this actually works as long

281
00:15:06.595 --> 00:15:09.079
as everything is coming in
the way that it needs to.

282
00:15:09.079 --> 00:15:11.932
So, the problem that we have
with something like this,

283
00:15:11.932 --> 00:15:13.456
even in the actual spending.

284
00:15:13.456 --> 00:15:18.900
Is that we don't know if everybody, is
reporting the information that they need.

285
00:15:18.900 --> 00:15:22.800
So it could be that example,
that I just talked about right here.

286
00:15:22.800 --> 00:15:27.150
The very fact is everything looks good,
until now the accountant says,

287
00:15:27.150 --> 00:15:27.960
everything's great.

288
00:15:27.960 --> 00:15:33.480
But now, he says, Cherokee hasn't turned
in her expenditures, for two weeks.

289
00:15:33.480 --> 00:15:36.758
Well, now all of the sudden,
it becomes a little bit more challenging,

290
00:15:36.758 --> 00:15:40.013
because that means I don't really
know where I am in terms of expenses.

291
00:15:40.013 --> 00:15:42.378
So this particular line right here,

292
00:15:42.378 --> 00:15:46.270
could actually be higher at one
place than I actually think,

293
00:15:46.270 --> 00:15:50.639
and that means I spent more money,
at one particular point in time.

294
00:15:50.639 --> 00:15:54.750
Than I really need to, and that might
actually end up hurting a little bit out.

295
00:15:54.750 --> 00:15:58.590
Here, as we're trying to finish
up some of those projects too.

296
00:15:58.590 --> 00:16:02.007
So we really need to make sure
that the expenditure reports,

297
00:16:02.007 --> 00:16:03.817
from our people that actually.

298
00:16:03.817 --> 00:16:07.319
Authorize to do expenditures,
right, are actually coming in.

299
00:16:07.319 --> 00:16:10.750
And it's a very important process
to ensure that all this works and

300
00:16:10.750 --> 00:16:12.920
flows in the way that we want to.

301
00:16:12.920 --> 00:16:16.424
If we have a very tight budget and
a very tight timeline and

302
00:16:16.424 --> 00:16:20.074
you have to actually set that
up to where to tell the people,

303
00:16:20.074 --> 00:16:22.848
these expenses need to be turned in daily,
or

304
00:16:22.848 --> 00:16:27.538
they need to be turned in at the beginning
of the week, whatever it might be.

305
00:16:27.538 --> 00:16:31.987
>> Or perhaps if you have a limit for
approvals, say, anything over $200,

306
00:16:31.987 --> 00:16:34.256
it needs to have so and so's approval.

307
00:16:34.256 --> 00:16:36.133
So that you don't have any surprises.

308
00:16:36.133 --> 00:16:37.930
>> Yeah, and
that's actually a great point to make.

309
00:16:37.930 --> 00:16:39.060
So, you might go ahead and

310
00:16:39.060 --> 00:16:43.010
just set a trigger here where,
if you need to do this, then do that.

311
00:16:43.010 --> 00:16:47.700
But, overall though, whatever it is
that reporting has to go on, okay?

312
00:16:47.700 --> 00:16:50.330
Now, I was just mentioning
what can happen though is,

313
00:16:50.330 --> 00:16:52.260
once you actually figure this out, right?

314
00:16:52.260 --> 00:16:56.640
You might find out that what really helps
you out here is something that's going to

315
00:16:56.640 --> 00:17:01.370
show you whether you're actually
spending money at a normal rate or

316
00:17:01.370 --> 00:17:04.130
whether you're spending it too fast or
whether you're spending it too slow.

317
00:17:04.130 --> 00:17:06.271
You might go,
can we possibly spend it too slow?

318
00:17:06.271 --> 00:17:06.907
Yes.
>> [LAUGH ]

319
00:17:06.907 --> 00:17:08.003
>> You possibly can,

320
00:17:08.003 --> 00:17:10.819
because it can also show
a few different things.

321
00:17:10.819 --> 00:17:14.925
So, let me kind of show you at least
some different definitions that we have

322
00:17:14.925 --> 00:17:16.370
to point out here, okay?

323
00:17:16.370 --> 00:17:20.240
There is something in project management
that we call a Burn Rate, okay?

324
00:17:20.240 --> 00:17:24.690
Now, this is different, we're gonna
talk about agile methodology in

325
00:17:24.690 --> 00:17:28.970
a couple of episodes from now,
where you're gonna hear the term,

326
00:17:28.970 --> 00:17:33.630
the idea here of the story burn,
or something like that.

327
00:17:33.630 --> 00:17:36.460
But this is not the same as that,
that's called a burn down,

328
00:17:36.460 --> 00:17:37.390
is what that one's called.

329
00:17:37.390 --> 00:17:41.440
This is called a Burn Rate, so, I wanna
make sure that we don't confuse those,

330
00:17:41.440 --> 00:17:43.670
because they are two different things,
okay?

331
00:17:43.670 --> 00:17:48.230
The idea of the Burn Rate, you don't
have to memorize these formulas so

332
00:17:48.230 --> 00:17:52.390
much here, but you do need to
understand what we're talking about.

333
00:17:52.390 --> 00:17:57.186
The very fact is what can happen
is that the actual expenditures

334
00:17:57.186 --> 00:18:01.990
actually might be higher than
what we have planned for.

335
00:18:01.990 --> 00:18:06.530
So, we normally take something what's
called the actual cost, which is AC here,

336
00:18:06.530 --> 00:18:09.940
and then the Earned Value which is,
of course, the expected value,

337
00:18:09.940 --> 00:18:13.130
how much we're expecting that we've
spent at this particular point.

338
00:18:13.130 --> 00:18:16.290
So, when we do a ratio
of those two things,

339
00:18:16.290 --> 00:18:19.600
what we might end up seeing here
is what we call the Burn Rate.

340
00:18:19.600 --> 00:18:24.480
So, when we do that ratio here,
and we get a greater than one,

341
00:18:24.480 --> 00:18:28.960
it normally tells you right away that,
at this particular point,

342
00:18:28.960 --> 00:18:35.350
the budget is being spent faster than
originally planned, but notice that I

343
00:18:35.350 --> 00:18:41.250
only call it an indicator that
the project may finish over the budget.

344
00:18:41.250 --> 00:18:42.480
So, it is very possible.

345
00:18:42.480 --> 00:18:44.430
It doesn't always mean that, okay?

346
00:18:44.430 --> 00:18:46.700
It means, at that point in time,
it looks like that it may.

347
00:18:47.830 --> 00:18:52.350
Notice if it's less than one, it means
that it may finish under the budget,

348
00:18:52.350 --> 00:18:57.580
cuz it means you're spending the money
slower than you possibly can as well,

349
00:18:57.580 --> 00:18:58.760
then it's there.

350
00:18:58.760 --> 00:19:02.960
And so, at this point, it may finish
under budget, it's always a possibility.

351
00:19:02.960 --> 00:19:06.720
If it equals to one, that means it's
being spent originally as planned, and

352
00:19:06.720 --> 00:19:09.510
should finish on budget as well, okay?

353
00:19:09.510 --> 00:19:12.236
So, those are the ideas that
we need to keep in mind.

354
00:19:12.236 --> 00:19:15.985
Now, Cherokee, normally when I think
about this because of, really,

355
00:19:15.985 --> 00:19:19.932
the way that I manage my money,
under budget always sounds better, right?

356
00:19:19.932 --> 00:19:23.795
>> I know, I'm looking at this diagram,
and I'm just learning,

357
00:19:23.795 --> 00:19:28.027
I'm, my checking account is probably
Burn Rate greater than two.

358
00:19:28.027 --> 00:19:28.580
>> Greater than two.

359
00:19:28.580 --> 00:19:29.261
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK].

360
00:19:29.261 --> 00:19:30.736
That's a little high, yeah.

361
00:19:30.736 --> 00:19:34.384
That means you spent the money, and now
you're trying to account for it somehow.

362
00:19:34.384 --> 00:19:37.216
Yeah [LAUGH] so, so at this point,
you can see some of that.

363
00:19:37.216 --> 00:19:41.320
So, let me show you an example here then,
of how this works out.

364
00:19:41.320 --> 00:19:42.840
So, let me go ahead and do this.

365
00:19:42.840 --> 00:19:46.020
I'm gonna use simple numbers,
because well, that's me here.

366
00:19:46.020 --> 00:19:50.290
So, normally you might see these two
as being the formulas, the bottom

367
00:19:50.290 --> 00:19:55.228
one is probably what you'll see more
often, top one, that's probably more of

368
00:19:55.228 --> 00:20:00.960
the PMBOK idea here, where you just take
one divided by the Cost Performance Index.

369
00:20:00.960 --> 00:20:03.340
Well, how do you get
the Cost Performance Index?

370
00:20:03.340 --> 00:20:07.450
Actual cost divided by the Earned Value,
okay?

371
00:20:07.450 --> 00:20:10.432
So, let's say that you get Earned Value,
and you get the actual cost here.

372
00:20:10.432 --> 00:20:12.314
I just put $50,000 in US dollars,

373
00:20:12.314 --> 00:20:14.696
as far as what I was expecting
to spend at that point.

374
00:20:14.696 --> 00:20:17.717
>> So Ronnie, when you say earned value,
are you saying,

375
00:20:17.717 --> 00:20:21.074
would that be equivalent to a ROI,
or a return on investment?

376
00:20:21.074 --> 00:20:22.145
>> Not yet.

377
00:20:22.145 --> 00:20:22.834
>> Okay.

378
00:20:22.834 --> 00:20:25.104
>> So, this is actually just saying,

379
00:20:25.104 --> 00:20:28.746
here's how much we expected
to spend up into this point.

380
00:20:28.746 --> 00:20:29.978
>> Okay.
>> How much we believe,

381
00:20:29.978 --> 00:20:32.030
from everything that we've done,
here it is.

382
00:20:32.030 --> 00:20:36.500
Here's our earned value, here's what we've
actually expended to that point, okay?

383
00:20:36.500 --> 00:20:38.250
So, then you go ahead and
you divide it up.

384
00:20:38.250 --> 00:20:39.780
And there it is, I get 1.5, okay?

385
00:20:41.190 --> 00:20:46.140
Well, if that's true, that actually tells
me something here, that more than likely

386
00:20:46.140 --> 00:20:49.930
I'm starting to head towards trouble
as far as being an indicator,

387
00:20:49.930 --> 00:20:52.780
that I'm actually over budget
at that point and time.

388
00:20:52.780 --> 00:20:57.283
That may not matter to you at this point,
but you might find out later on it does.

389
00:20:57.283 --> 00:20:59.362
So you go, I was expecting
to see something like this.

390
00:20:59.362 --> 00:21:00.350
No big deal, but

391
00:21:00.350 --> 00:21:05.151
if you actually have this figure show up
and set up a point you're not expecting,

392
00:21:05.151 --> 00:21:10.200
that's when it gets a little bit more
into the dangerous area here, okay?

393
00:21:10.200 --> 00:21:14.049
Now, when I was talking here about
why this is very important is that,

394
00:21:14.049 --> 00:21:17.899
because we planned everything out,
according to what we were talking

395
00:21:17.899 --> 00:21:20.859
about earlier here,
according to our project plan.

396
00:21:20.859 --> 00:21:23.536
Oop, let me see if I can zoom in again,
just so

397
00:21:23.536 --> 00:21:25.801
that we can see this a little bit more.

398
00:21:25.801 --> 00:21:28.580
Try it again, just a little bit, okay.

399
00:21:28.580 --> 00:21:32.200
So, just when we start to
take a look at this, okay?

400
00:21:32.200 --> 00:21:36.520
Believe it or not, doing the under
the budget, or the over the budget.

401
00:21:36.520 --> 00:21:40.260
Neither of those two are actually
really good for us, okay?

402
00:21:40.260 --> 00:21:42.340
And you might be wondering well,

403
00:21:42.340 --> 00:21:46.370
why is coming in under budget
not a good thing, okay?

404
00:21:46.370 --> 00:21:48.900
Well, it's not a good thing
if you don't understand why

405
00:21:48.900 --> 00:21:50.790
it hasn't come under budget.

406
00:21:50.790 --> 00:21:52.692
Over budget can be caused by many things,
right?

407
00:21:52.692 --> 00:21:56.332
Normally, overexpending
is really the big one.

408
00:21:56.332 --> 00:22:00.150
In other words, something actually costing
more than it should, at any point in time,

409
00:22:00.150 --> 00:22:03.505
whether a service, whether you had to
hire more people, that's never a good

410
00:22:03.505 --> 00:22:06.938
thing because it means you didn't account
for it the way that you needed to do.

411
00:22:06.938 --> 00:22:11.188
But under-expenditures,
if you don't know why it happened,

412
00:22:11.188 --> 00:22:16.069
more than likely it means somebody has
again made this ad hoc decision away

413
00:22:16.069 --> 00:22:20.640
from your project plan to say,
you wanna know something?

414
00:22:20.640 --> 00:22:23.930
I don't care that Ronnie says I need
to use a number six here, okay?

415
00:22:23.930 --> 00:22:28.190
We're gonna go with a number four instead,
because it's behind the wall,

416
00:22:28.190 --> 00:22:28.800
it doesn't matter.

417
00:22:28.800 --> 00:22:30.020
Now, I don't care what
you're talking about,

418
00:22:30.020 --> 00:22:32.238
but just kinda think about it that way,
right?

419
00:22:32.238 --> 00:22:37.530
They decided to do some
cost savings there without

420
00:22:37.530 --> 00:22:40.540
notifying the project management
team that things have changed.

421
00:22:40.540 --> 00:22:45.246
Well, what if that particular thing
that we're actually having to put number

422
00:22:45.246 --> 00:22:50.025
sixes in requires that for load bearing,
or requires it because it's actually

423
00:22:50.025 --> 00:22:53.187
some type of regulation that
it needs to be in there.

424
00:22:53.187 --> 00:22:54.533
Well now, what does that mean?

425
00:22:54.533 --> 00:22:57.460
That means, even though it
actually came in under budget,

426
00:22:57.460 --> 00:23:00.400
we now have to go back to our project and
do what?

427
00:23:00.400 --> 00:23:01.640
Fix it.

428
00:23:01.640 --> 00:23:05.570
We literally have to tear that thing
out again, put in the right stuff, and

429
00:23:05.570 --> 00:23:08.720
now we've expended twice
on that one thing.

430
00:23:08.720 --> 00:23:13.240
And so, under budget may actually indicate
that either a corner was cut at some

431
00:23:13.240 --> 00:23:16.500
point, or it could indicate
that somebody's being really

432
00:23:16.500 --> 00:23:18.780
efficient at everything that's going on.

433
00:23:18.780 --> 00:23:20.650
But usually, you plan for
these things, and

434
00:23:20.650 --> 00:23:23.690
what you wanna find out is,
on either side, right?

435
00:23:23.690 --> 00:23:26.419
Whether over budget or under budget,

436
00:23:26.419 --> 00:23:32.060
that everything is actually gonna be
justified in some way, somehow, okay?

437
00:23:32.060 --> 00:23:34.762
Ideally, everything should be on budget.

438
00:23:34.762 --> 00:23:38.943
And so,
the Burn Rate helps us determine how

439
00:23:38.943 --> 00:23:43.250
fast we're expending the money versus not.

440
00:23:43.250 --> 00:23:46.930
So, you wanna take a look at these and
these are, by far, the most basic things.

441
00:23:46.930 --> 00:23:50.920
So, let's go ahead and make sure that
we understand at least the four or

442
00:23:50.920 --> 00:23:55.050
five different things that we want to
normally have a control over, okay?

443
00:23:55.050 --> 00:23:59.460
So, as far as the basic cost,
as far as your projects go, right?

444
00:23:59.460 --> 00:24:02.690
We wanna make sure that we know now to
determine the overall total cost of

445
00:24:02.690 --> 00:24:06.470
the project, and this is how we
do it is by accounting for, well,

446
00:24:06.470 --> 00:24:10.090
all the payments and
all the expenditures of our project, okay?

447
00:24:10.090 --> 00:24:14.796
And we need that at the very beginning
to help us to determine our baseline,

448
00:24:14.796 --> 00:24:18.220
about when that cost is
also gonna be expended.

449
00:24:18.220 --> 00:24:21.637
Normally, when you see this, as far as
in a chart form, like I'm showing you,

450
00:24:21.637 --> 00:24:24.100
you'll always see that
kind of s shaped graph.

451
00:24:24.100 --> 00:24:28.762
Because there's always

452
00:24:28.762 --> 00:24:33.646
a beginning which you're

453
00:24:33.646 --> 00:24:38.086
not spending a lot, but

454
00:24:38.086 --> 00:24:44.524
then during the execution phase,

455
00:24:44.524 --> 00:24:49.408
it's always gonna kind of

456
00:24:49.408 --> 00:24:54.736
angle up very suddenly, and

457
00:24:54.736 --> 00:25:00.064
then level off at the top, so

458
00:25:00.064 --> 00:25:05.836
you always see that idea of that

459
00:25:05.836 --> 00:25:11.608
kind of s shaped graph as well,

460
00:25:11.608 --> 00:25:18.050
or chart when you see it, okay?

461
00:25:18.050 --> 00:25:18.730
And the key there,

462
00:25:18.730 --> 00:25:22.590
of course, is making sure that we're
right on budget as much as possible.

463
00:25:22.590 --> 00:25:24.655
So, there's a lot that goes on here,

464
00:25:24.655 --> 00:25:27.444
just even in the most basic
of our cost management.

465
00:25:27.444 --> 00:25:29.967
>> Yes, thank you for
giving us those examples, Ronnie.

466
00:25:29.967 --> 00:25:31.752
I think I was able to go ahead and

467
00:25:31.752 --> 00:25:36.286
understand how to come up with my total
project cost by looking at my baseline,

468
00:25:36.286 --> 00:25:40.819
and I did a find my budget, and then
also implementing expenditure tracking,

469
00:25:40.819 --> 00:25:45.421
and even expenditure reporting, and
of course, my favorite, the burn rate,

470
00:25:45.421 --> 00:25:49.590
to help even identify if we're
spending money at too rapid of a rate.

471
00:25:49.590 --> 00:25:53.840
So, thank you very much for that Ronnie,
and thank you guys for joining us today.

472
00:25:53.840 --> 00:25:58.480
Stay tuned for some more great
Project+ episodes coming this way.

473
00:25:58.480 --> 00:26:00.245
Signing off, I'm Cherokee Boose.

474
00:26:00.245 --> 00:26:00.975
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

475
00:26:00.975 --> 00:26:03.267
>> Have a great day.

476
00:26:03.267 --> 00:26:08.839
[MUSIC]

477
00:26:08.839 --> 00:26:11.135
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.
