00:25:44.690 --> 00:25:48.540
And then of course, as you start moving
towards stronger and stronger, notice that

465
00:25:48.540 --> 00:25:53.019
now you may even have high authority, and
now you have your own budget to deal with.

466
00:25:54.050 --> 00:25:56.911
And then you actually
have full-time resources.

467
00:25:56.911 --> 00:26:01.480
Ultimately here, in a projectized
environment, notice that you have

468
00:26:01.480 --> 00:26:06.410
total authority, a lot of times, to do
what you need to as a project manager.

469
00:26:06.410 --> 00:26:09.180
And that your particular role here and

470
00:26:09.180 --> 00:26:14.760
all the support staff you need is really
dedicated to your management as well.

471
00:26:14.760 --> 00:26:19.780
And all organizations tend to kind of
break down into these types of structures

472
00:26:19.780 --> 00:26:21.560
when they're larger organizations.

473
00:26:21.560 --> 00:26:25.300
Now you may wonder, are we really
gonna have to break this down?

474
00:26:25.300 --> 00:26:26.740
Well in real life, right,

475
00:26:26.740 --> 00:26:29.790
you're gonna find yourself fitting
into one of these generic roles.

476
00:26:29.790 --> 00:26:32.130
Now there's specialized
ones that are out there.

477
00:26:32.130 --> 00:26:36.120
But overall though, if you actually do
find yourself in a weak-matrixed one, so

478
00:26:36.120 --> 00:26:38.440
kind of remember,
your authority's fairly limited there.

479
00:26:38.440 --> 00:26:40.930
If you're actually in a projectized one,
and

480
00:26:40.930 --> 00:26:43.470
you're the project manager,
you'll have full control.

481
00:26:43.470 --> 00:26:49.560
So there's a big range of
authority that you have,

482
00:26:49.560 --> 00:26:51.800
as well as control of your resources.

483
00:26:51.800 --> 00:26:54.990
And that's what it really boils down to,
depending on the organization you're

484
00:26:54.990 --> 00:26:58.760
working with and that's a great chart
you have provided for us there Ronnie.

485
00:26:58.760 --> 00:27:01.630
>> It really just explains everything
that we've covered so far.

486
00:27:01.630 --> 00:27:05.430
We see your different organizational
structures as well as the authority that's

487
00:27:05.430 --> 00:27:07.950
associated with each one
of those types there.

488
00:27:07.950 --> 00:27:10.370
So, it's a good stopping point for today.

489
00:27:10.370 --> 00:27:13.980
Thank you Ronnie for being with us and
thank you guys so much for tuning in.

490
00:27:13.980 --> 00:27:14.920
I'm Cherokee Boose.

491
00:27:14.920 --> 00:27:15.750
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

492
00:27:15.750 --> 00:27:16.864
>> Signing off, have a great day.

493
00:27:18.378 --> 00:27:24.311
[MUSIC]

494
00:27:24.311 --> 00:27:27.662
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee dissect a work breakdown structure in addition to covering the purposes and benefits to having one. They convey the importance to decomposition, or breaking down the scope into workable components to help estimate duration, allocate resources and assign costs. We create different levels of our WBS during decomposition. We see the top level as the project, the 2nd sub level as work units and lower levels being called work package levels. Ronnie also shows us an example of a WBS dictionary to help us understand how to decipher a WBS without having to rely on interpretations of the document.
episodes.title: Execute and Develop a Project Schedule
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:02.682
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.682 --> 00:00:08.305
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.305 --> 00:00:12.266
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.266 --> 00:00:15.276
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.276 --> 00:00:17.480
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.480 --> 00:00:21.730
Today we're continuing with our
Project+ CompTIA certification.

7
00:00:21.730 --> 00:00:26.560
We're gonna be looking at how to
execute and design a project schedule.

8
00:00:26.560 --> 00:00:29.210
And the title of this episode does
look a little transposed, but

9
00:00:29.210 --> 00:00:30.505
that's how CompTIA calls that out.

10
00:00:30.505 --> 00:00:31.585
Isn't that right, Ronnie?

11
00:00:31.585 --> 00:00:33.994
>> It really is,
we're taking a look at executing and

12
00:00:33.994 --> 00:00:36.134
developing that idea
of a project schedule.

13
00:00:36.134 --> 00:00:39.745
So we are actually gonna talk about,
of course, development first, and

14
00:00:39.745 --> 00:00:42.731
then we'll talk about execution
in just a little bit, too.

15
00:00:42.731 --> 00:00:44.866
Now, when we begin to take a look, well,

16
00:00:44.866 --> 00:00:48.294
remember that we're still in
the planning phases of our project.

17
00:00:48.294 --> 00:00:50.503
And initiation,
even though we've talked about it and

18
00:00:50.503 --> 00:00:52.153
we've really summarized those things.

19
00:00:52.153 --> 00:00:55.996
But overall, though, we need to begin
by taking a look, very seriously,

20
00:00:55.996 --> 00:00:58.880
at the idea of, well, a project schedule.

21
00:00:58.880 --> 00:01:02.680
And when it comes down to it, this is
where we start to actually take things

22
00:01:02.680 --> 00:01:05.580
that we would have learned
in that initiation phase,

23
00:01:05.580 --> 00:01:10.430
such as understanding the project scope
itself, and now breaking that scope.

24
00:01:10.430 --> 00:01:13.978
In other words, what we hope to see at
the end of the project now down into,

25
00:01:13.978 --> 00:01:15.870
well, workable units.

26
00:01:15.870 --> 00:01:20.415
So that is what we actually need to talk
about today because, well, a lot of times,

27
00:01:20.415 --> 00:01:24.340
if we're actually beginning our career
in project management, we may be told,

28
00:01:24.340 --> 00:01:25.730
here's what we need, okay?

29
00:01:25.730 --> 00:01:27.100
And now you're sitting there wondering,
well,

30
00:01:27.100 --> 00:01:29.270
how do I get to that point to do that?

31
00:01:29.270 --> 00:01:31.320
And that's what we're
actually going to talk about,

32
00:01:31.320 --> 00:01:35.670
a big concept that we call the WBS,
or the work breakdown structure.

33
00:01:35.670 --> 00:01:38.650
>> So Ronnie, what is the purpose
of a work breakdown structure?

34
00:01:38.650 --> 00:01:43.440
>> Well, the work breakdown structure
really does help us to make sure that we

35
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:47.300
can take that idea,
the entire project scope, and

36
00:01:47.300 --> 00:01:51.590
really break it down into workable and
manageable units, okay?

37
00:01:51.590 --> 00:01:54.790
So let's take a look at my screen
as we help to answer that question.

38
00:01:54.790 --> 00:01:57.790
And I hate putting just a bunch
of words beside my head here so

39
00:01:57.790 --> 00:01:58.900
that you can see them.

40
00:01:58.900 --> 00:02:01.710
But there's just so
many concepts that it's very difficult,

41
00:02:01.710 --> 00:02:05.010
if you don't seem them, that you're
gonna kind of get lost in them, as well.

42
00:02:05.010 --> 00:02:09.030
So first and foremost, at least for
you as a project manager, okay,

43
00:02:09.030 --> 00:02:13.930
it really gives you a graphic display
of the entirety of the project scope.

44
00:02:13.930 --> 00:02:17.513
Scopes are normally written
in sentences and, of course,

45
00:02:17.513 --> 00:02:21.681
then paragraphs to give you an idea
of what they hope to expect to see.

46
00:02:21.681 --> 00:02:25.916
And maybe even a rough diagram of what
they believe that the product should turn

47
00:02:25.916 --> 00:02:26.860
out to be.

48
00:02:26.860 --> 00:02:30.120
The unusual thing here on the deliverable
end, what we might find out is, later on

49
00:02:30.120 --> 00:02:33.580
as we go through the project, it won't
look exactly like the original drawing.

50
00:02:33.580 --> 00:02:35.790
It just never does sometimes, okay?

51
00:02:35.790 --> 00:02:37.930
But that's at least the first
thing that we have.

52
00:02:37.930 --> 00:02:40.110
Now you might be wondering,
why is that important?

53
00:02:40.110 --> 00:02:42.920
Because it's important for
us to now be able to take that and

54
00:02:42.920 --> 00:02:47.600
put it down into something that we can
see that can be manageable units, okay?

55
00:02:47.600 --> 00:02:52.860
Now, when we do so, what will also happen,
okay, is that at the end of

56
00:02:52.860 --> 00:02:57.720
us working through this idea of creating
a work breakdown structure, it will

57
00:02:57.720 --> 00:03:03.350
also give us inputs then to all of these
other types of activities that we see.

58
00:03:03.350 --> 00:03:07.750
Okay, so the work breakdown structure
allows us now to be able to plan out

59
00:03:07.750 --> 00:03:15.430
the idea of a duration of some type of
project, or even a part of a project.

60
00:03:15.430 --> 00:03:19.390
Now, when I talk about the idea of
the duration, we're not specifically

61
00:03:19.390 --> 00:03:24.390
mentioning the idea here of
how long something will take,

62
00:03:24.390 --> 00:03:29.720
as far as the overall beginning and
end so much.

63
00:03:29.720 --> 00:03:34.450
But how long will a particular task
take us is what we actually need to do.

64
00:03:34.450 --> 00:03:37.180
So sometimes we might be told,
here's what you need to create,

65
00:03:37.180 --> 00:03:39.070
Ronnie, you need to create a chair.

66
00:03:39.070 --> 00:03:42.410
Okay, we all know that there's
many different types of chairs,

67
00:03:42.410 --> 00:03:45.390
but how do I know how long
that's going to take?

68
00:03:45.390 --> 00:03:49.190
I may not have ever had that before,
so I may consult with some experts.

69
00:03:49.190 --> 00:03:51.230
I may actually go and talk to a carpenter.

70
00:03:51.230 --> 00:03:54.280
And I may go, all right, here's how long
it should take me to develop a chair.

71
00:03:54.280 --> 00:03:56.080
In other words,
be able to actually estimate.

72
00:03:56.080 --> 00:03:59.160
Well, a work breakdown structure
should allow us to do that.

73
00:03:59.160 --> 00:04:02.680
And the whole goal behind it is to say,
all right, we need to make

74
00:04:02.680 --> 00:04:06.660
sure that we can manage whatever we're
assigned in manageable units, and

75
00:04:06.660 --> 00:04:09.100
in realistic units of time, as well.

76
00:04:09.100 --> 00:04:12.300
So being able to estimate activity
durations is a very important

77
00:04:12.300 --> 00:04:15.870
part of what we do to try and
help out with that.

78
00:04:15.870 --> 00:04:19.814
So you might find out that activities,
as far as their time goes,

79
00:04:19.814 --> 00:04:22.753
it normally is broken up,
in terms of duration,

80
00:04:22.753 --> 00:04:28.160
into minutes that something could go on,
into, of course, hours then, days, weeks.

81
00:04:28.160 --> 00:04:33.151
And heck, months, even years at times,
what the overall duration of a particular

82
00:04:33.151 --> 00:04:36.018
part of your project may
actually end up being.

83
00:04:36.018 --> 00:04:39.564
So you have to be able to come up with
some type of estimate if you're ever gonna

84
00:04:39.564 --> 00:04:42.320
accomplish it in a realistic way, okay?

85
00:04:42.320 --> 00:04:46.100
The other thing that it helps us to do
is determine what we call the idea of

86
00:04:46.100 --> 00:04:48.060
work effort here, okay?

87
00:04:48.060 --> 00:04:52.777
Now, work effort has to do with the fact
that we might find out through the work

88
00:04:52.777 --> 00:04:57.641
breakdown structure that there are certain
tasks that can be done, actually,

89
00:04:57.641 --> 00:05:02.527
a lot quicker than what we think, as we
actually assign more resources to them.

90
00:05:02.527 --> 00:05:05.832
Or, they're only gonna get done
in a particular amount of time,

91
00:05:05.832 --> 00:05:08.970
regardless of how many resources
we assign to them, as well.

92
00:05:08.970 --> 00:05:12.550
And what we're talking about there is
that there are what we call effort-driven

93
00:05:12.550 --> 00:05:13.970
types of tasks.

94
00:05:13.970 --> 00:05:16.720
And then there's what we call
non effort-driven tasks.

95
00:05:16.720 --> 00:05:20.110
Now, if you haven't heard that term before
and you're new to project management,

96
00:05:20.110 --> 00:05:23.830
well, let's go ahead and try and give
you an example of an effort-driven task.

97
00:05:23.830 --> 00:05:27.090
So Cherokee, let's take this for
example, okay?

98
00:05:27.090 --> 00:05:31.136
That I am told by our head chef,
whoever that is,

99
00:05:31.136 --> 00:05:34.705
that I'm going to be peeling 50 pounds.

100
00:05:34.705 --> 00:05:37.764
Okay, let's make it 100
pounds to make them nice,

101
00:05:37.764 --> 00:05:41.640
even numbers, 100 pounds of onions,
okay, by myself.

102
00:05:41.640 --> 00:05:46.340
And when I do that and I'm trying to
estimate how much time it might take me,

103
00:05:46.340 --> 00:05:50.970
well, in this particular
effort of trying to

104
00:05:50.970 --> 00:05:56.370
have 100 pounds of onions peeled back and
everything that I need to,

105
00:05:56.370 --> 00:06:00.010
I might guess that it might take me,
let's say, four hours altogether.

106
00:06:00.010 --> 00:06:01.381
I don't know how long it
would actually take me, but

107
00:06:01.381 --> 00:06:02.357
let's say it's four hours, okay?

108
00:06:02.357 --> 00:06:06.511
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, in that sense, I've now estimated

109
00:06:06.511 --> 00:06:13.090
a duration for that entire task, but it
can be an effort-driven task in this way.

110
00:06:13.090 --> 00:06:14.855
Let's say that as Cherokee walks by,

111
00:06:14.855 --> 00:06:18.400
I realize that she's just kind of
wondering about what she should be doing.

112
00:06:18.400 --> 00:06:23.250
So I hand her a knife and I go, Cherokee
help me peel these 100 pounds of onions.

113
00:06:23.250 --> 00:06:24.170
And she's going to love me for

114
00:06:24.170 --> 00:06:27.050
it because she's gonna smell
like onions afterwards, anyways.

115
00:06:27.050 --> 00:06:30.005
So when she does that, well,
what should end up happening?

116
00:06:30.005 --> 00:06:34.320
Well, if this is an effort-driven task,
essentially, we split.

117
00:06:34.320 --> 00:06:36.960
Okay, in all reality,
it may not be a split,

118
00:06:36.960 --> 00:06:39.567
but let's say that in theory-
>> What are you trying to say

119
00:06:39.567 --> 00:06:40.227
here, Ronnie?

120
00:06:40.227 --> 00:06:42.771
>> Well, what I may say is that
you may be faster than I am, okay?

121
00:06:42.771 --> 00:06:43.336
>> Uh-huh.

122
00:06:43.336 --> 00:06:44.967
>> So you may actually end
up peeling more than I am.

123
00:06:44.967 --> 00:06:47.835
But in the way that we calculate this out,
right,

124
00:06:47.835 --> 00:06:51.521
it may mean that what we probably
will do is that Cherokee will end

125
00:06:51.521 --> 00:06:56.250
up peeling 50 pounds of it and
I'll end up peeling 50 pounds of it.

126
00:06:56.250 --> 00:07:00.684
Now, if that's true, and I said 100 pounds
is gonna take me four hours, right,

127
00:07:00.684 --> 00:07:03.067
well, now I have two
people working on that.

128
00:07:03.067 --> 00:07:09.138
Well, my duration of the task itself
is going to shorten into two hours,

129
00:07:09.138 --> 00:07:11.160
instead of four.

130
00:07:11.160 --> 00:07:13.840
So in other words, what should have
accomplished in four hours because one

131
00:07:13.840 --> 00:07:17.440
person is working on it now
is actually accomplished in

132
00:07:17.440 --> 00:07:20.090
two hours because two people
are working on it instead.

133
00:07:20.090 --> 00:07:23.620
And you might be wondering, well,
why is it that if the overall work

134
00:07:23.620 --> 00:07:27.340
itself is four hours long,
how can it be accomplished in two hours?

135
00:07:27.340 --> 00:07:30.432
Well, remember that I'm putting
in two hours of work and

136
00:07:30.432 --> 00:07:34.660
Cherokee is putting in two hours of work,
but we're doing it simultaneously.

137
00:07:34.660 --> 00:07:38.537
That still equals four hours of
overall work that needs to be done.

138
00:07:38.537 --> 00:07:42.044
But because we've divided it over,
well, two resources instead of one,

139
00:07:42.044 --> 00:07:44.112
that's where we can shorten the duration.

140
00:07:44.112 --> 00:07:47.205
An effort-driven task
normally can do that, okay?

141
00:07:47.205 --> 00:07:50.895
Now, the other one that's probably more
common than what we realize, which is,

142
00:07:50.895 --> 00:07:53.582
let's take, for an example,
a non effort-driven task.

143
00:07:53.582 --> 00:07:57.983
Okay, now in our studios, our brand new
studios that we've actually just moved

144
00:07:57.983 --> 00:08:02.710
into, there's a lot of painting that
went on inside of these studios, okay.

145
00:08:02.710 --> 00:08:05.360
Every wall inside of our studios is black.

146
00:08:05.360 --> 00:08:07.700
And we've got some different
sound insulation and

147
00:08:07.700 --> 00:08:11.580
some foam up, but
it was painted black overall.

148
00:08:11.580 --> 00:08:15.400
Now in this particular instance here,
why is this not considered and

149
00:08:15.400 --> 00:08:16.940
effort driven task?

150
00:08:16.940 --> 00:08:18.990
Well it depends on how many
people you have assigned to.

151
00:08:18.990 --> 00:08:21.150
But let's say one person
was assigned to this.

152
00:08:21.150 --> 00:08:24.930
Well we can't go ahead and put on
a second coat until the first coat dries.

153
00:08:24.930 --> 00:08:27.260
It doesn't matter how many
people you have painting, right?

154
00:08:27.260 --> 00:08:29.460
So let's say we have six people painting.

155
00:08:29.460 --> 00:08:32.430
Well, now they've painted the entire wall.

156
00:08:32.430 --> 00:08:36.240
Well, it's not like they can go around and
put a second coat on that immediately.

157
00:08:36.240 --> 00:08:38.730
They still have to wait for it to dry.

158
00:08:38.730 --> 00:08:41.040
You could pay for six people to wait for

159
00:08:41.040 --> 00:08:44.300
the wall to dry before
they put a second coat or

160
00:08:44.300 --> 00:08:48.660
you could say hey let's get the other guys
to paint all the rest of the rooms here.

161
00:08:48.660 --> 00:08:50.070
And then by the time we get done,

162
00:08:50.070 --> 00:08:52.500
maybe we'll be able to put
up a second coat then.

163
00:08:52.500 --> 00:08:55.824
So sometimes you have to wait, and it
doesn't matter how many people you assign

164
00:08:55.824 --> 00:08:59.509
to the resources, there's gonna be time in
between when something like that happens.

165
00:08:59.509 --> 00:09:02.965
Construction's actually a good example
of some of these and actually of both of

166
00:09:02.965 --> 00:09:06.059
these, where you might have some that
where the more people that help,

167
00:09:06.059 --> 00:09:08.500
the better it's gonna be but
let's say that here it is.

168
00:09:08.500 --> 00:09:12.380
You're waiting for a foundation to
be poured before anything can start.

169
00:09:12.380 --> 00:09:13.300
Well, that's it.

170
00:09:13.300 --> 00:09:17.050
Everybody has to wait on that
truck as the foundation's poured.

171
00:09:17.050 --> 00:09:20.380
So you can have everybody there on day
one when there's no foundation and

172
00:09:20.380 --> 00:09:21.710
nothing's being poured.

173
00:09:21.710 --> 00:09:22.840
You can be paying them all.

174
00:09:22.840 --> 00:09:25.890
But they're still gonna have to wait
until that foundation's poured.

175
00:09:25.890 --> 00:09:28.500
And of course, cured,
dried and ready to go up.

176
00:09:28.500 --> 00:09:31.120
And so you still have to
wait on something like that.

177
00:09:31.120 --> 00:09:34.060
So breaking this down
right by using the word

178
00:09:34.060 --> 00:09:36.690
Breakdown Structures is
really gonna help us out.

179
00:09:36.690 --> 00:09:38.310
Now, these remaining two here, okay,

180
00:09:38.310 --> 00:09:41.900
it actually helps us to figure out how
many resources that we have and then,

181
00:09:41.900 --> 00:09:46.080
of course, ultimately how much money we're
going to budget for something like this.

182
00:09:46.080 --> 00:09:49.150
As we start to use this as well, okay.

183
00:09:49.150 --> 00:09:52.750
Now we wanna make sure that
also what is very clear here.

184
00:09:52.750 --> 00:09:57.710
Is that because this is a graphical
display of the project scope itself.

185
00:09:57.710 --> 00:10:01.570
This helps us to understand
that what we have

186
00:10:01.570 --> 00:10:05.870
inside of the work breakdown structure
really is what's involved in the project.

187
00:10:05.870 --> 00:10:09.490

489
00:26:53.170 --> 00:26:56.740
Task B cannot finish until task A starts.

490
00:26:56.740 --> 00:26:58.420
>> It sounds pretty obvious there.

491
00:26:58.420 --> 00:26:59.110
>> It does?

492
00:26:59.110 --> 00:27:00.980
Yeah, that sounds, I was gonna say,
all right Cherokee,

493
00:27:00.980 --> 00:27:02.610
I'm gonna put you on the spot then.

494
00:27:02.610 --> 00:27:05.430
No, yeah,
this one is a very difficult one, okay.

495
00:27:05.430 --> 00:27:07.710
So much so that most people
don't even really count this.

496
00:27:07.710 --> 00:27:12.290
But it is one of the ones that you
can actually end up seeing as well.

497
00:27:12.290 --> 00:27:15.740
But there's no real good
description of this particular one.

498
00:27:15.740 --> 00:27:19.060
And even examples of something
like this are very hard to find.

499
00:27:19.060 --> 00:27:22.480
So much so that all of the examples
that I found just were so

500
00:27:22.480 --> 00:27:26.060
technically mentally
jumping through the hoops.

501
00:27:26.060 --> 00:27:29.060
I couldn't even tell you how
to explain it in that sense.

502
00:27:29.060 --> 00:27:32.320
I can't even think about a time when that
would actually happen where I would say

503
00:27:32.320 --> 00:27:35.590
all right,
I can't really finish until you begin.

504
00:27:35.590 --> 00:27:37.610
But you can see it sometimes, right?

505
00:27:37.610 --> 00:27:41.190
The very fact is it might
be programming of some sort

506
00:27:41.190 --> 00:27:43.400
that you might follow logic like this.

507
00:27:43.400 --> 00:27:47.540
Now look, my work can't begin,
or can't really finish up.

508
00:27:47.540 --> 00:27:50.510
I can't really finish my job
until you begin to work on yours.

509
00:27:52.180 --> 00:27:55.620
I don't see how that would affect me,
but that's usually the idea.

510
00:27:55.620 --> 00:28:00.146
Some type of programming language
that goes on and looping and stuff.

511
00:28:00.146 --> 00:28:03.589
And that's where you tend to have these
loops that have to do all of the stuff

512
00:28:03.589 --> 00:28:04.430
that it has to do.

513
00:28:04.430 --> 00:28:06.890
But so it is very possible, but

514
00:28:06.890 --> 00:28:10.000
it's not one of the very common
ones that you'll end up seeing.

515
00:28:10.000 --> 00:28:12.000
So just realize that
that can be done there.

516
00:28:12.000 --> 00:28:14.970
Now, when you start to take
a look at this, right?

517
00:28:14.970 --> 00:28:19.216
Setting up dependencies are kind of neat.

518
00:28:19.216 --> 00:28:23.345
Because all I have to do inside of
Microsoft Project here is that I can

519
00:28:23.345 --> 00:28:28.110
select task number 4, and
then I go to the Predecessor tab here.

520
00:28:28.110 --> 00:28:32.660
And when I do that,
this is where I can come in and

521
00:28:32.660 --> 00:28:35.630
choose, well, any of those
options that are available to me.

522
00:28:35.630 --> 00:28:37.460
Say here's exactly how I want it to go.

523
00:28:37.460 --> 00:28:39.107
>> Nice.
>> Do I want it to be Finish-to-Start,

524
00:28:39.107 --> 00:28:41.376
Start-to-Start, Finish-to-Finish,
Start-to-Finish?

525
00:28:41.376 --> 00:28:41.980
>> And now we know what they mean, yay!
[LAUGH] >> Yeah, and

526
00:28:41.980 --> 00:28:43.510
now you know what they
mean at the same time.

527
00:28:43.510 --> 00:28:44.170
>> Yeah.

528
00:28:44.170 --> 00:28:47.110
>> So
you can actually set those things up.

529
00:28:47.110 --> 00:28:50.330
The key for you is at least
understanding the very basics.

530
00:28:50.330 --> 00:28:55.080
But if you do need to set them up and
that's the way that you have to.

531
00:28:55.080 --> 00:28:58.990
So you'll actually end up seeing that you
can change those relationships to help you

532
00:28:58.990 --> 00:29:01.270
to manage your schedule
a little bit better.

533
00:29:01.270 --> 00:29:05.630
So setting up predecessors or
dependencies, even though CompTIA kinda

534
00:29:05.630 --> 00:29:08.890
separates those out in what we
actually end up calling them.

535
00:29:09.950 --> 00:29:13.499
There's plenty of different project
software that may do it a little bit

536
00:29:13.499 --> 00:29:14.264
differently.

537
00:29:14.264 --> 00:29:18.155
But just understand that that's,
probably more than anything,

538
00:29:18.155 --> 00:29:22.947
you'll need to make a decision or a choice
in which of those you would choose if they

539
00:29:22.947 --> 00:29:26.380
tell you here's what the requirement is,
right?

540
00:29:26.380 --> 00:29:29.822
That which one shows this,
and you just gotta know.

541
00:29:29.822 --> 00:29:33.080
So just take what we've taught
here just a little bit.

542
00:29:33.080 --> 00:29:36.940
And be able to try and
apply it into your realm of thinking and

543
00:29:36.940 --> 00:29:39.860
see if the analogy fits for
you, and that's the way to go.

544
00:29:39.860 --> 00:29:42.430
>> Well, Ronnie, thank you for
showing us that software and

545
00:29:42.430 --> 00:29:46.480
explaining how we can actually integrate
those terms, our dependencies and

546
00:29:46.480 --> 00:29:50.400
our predecessors into the actual
tools that we have available for us.

547
00:29:50.400 --> 00:29:52.460
There's a lot that we've
covered in this episode, but

548
00:29:52.460 --> 00:29:54.090
I still think there's more to come.

549
00:29:54.090 --> 00:29:57.670
So, for those of you at home, please
stay tuned for an additional episode.

550
00:29:57.670 --> 00:30:01.860
I think this will go ahead and
create a part three for our execute and

551
00:30:01.860 --> 00:30:05.230
develop our project schedules.

552
00:30:05.230 --> 00:30:07.630
Thank you for tuning in today,
I'm Cherokee Bouse

553
00:30:07.630 --> 00:30:08.530
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

554
00:30:08.530 --> 00:30:09.689
>> Signing off, have a great one.

555
00:30:11.349 --> 00:30:17.260
[MUSIC]

556
00:30:17.260 --> 00:30:22.390
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode you will take a close look at three types of task dependencies in addition to sequencing and prioritizing tasks. Ronnie demonstrates how to manually calculate and determine the critical path. Lastly, we see the difference between quality and governance gates.
episodes.title: Execute and Develop a Project Schedule Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:02.184
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.184 --> 00:00:08.234
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.234 --> 00:00:12.286
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.286 --> 00:00:14.991
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:14.991 --> 00:00:17.115
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.115 --> 00:00:19.834
Today we're gonna be
continuing our Project+.

7
00:00:19.834 --> 00:00:24.800
And our show here is going to specifically
focusing on how to execute and

8
00:00:24.800 --> 00:00:27.480
design our project schedules.

9
00:00:27.480 --> 00:00:29.730
If you've been following along,
you know we've been looking at that for

10
00:00:29.730 --> 00:00:33.240
the past two episodes, but there are still
some details that we want to cover.

11
00:00:33.240 --> 00:00:37.350
And with us today we have Mr. Ronnie Wong
to go ahead and head up those details.

12
00:00:37.350 --> 00:00:38.190
Thank you.

13
00:00:38.190 --> 00:00:41.510
>> Well, thank you again for having me on
the Project+ Show as we continue on to

14
00:00:41.510 --> 00:00:45.800
take a look at some of these details
in developing our project schedule.

15
00:00:45.800 --> 00:00:49.960
Now, when we took a look before, we were
talking about the idea of predecessors and

16
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:50.970
dependencies.

17
00:00:50.970 --> 00:00:55.621
We showed you how you can use a tool like
Microsoft Project to really kind of rail

18
00:00:55.621 --> 00:00:59.923
in, or fence in, all those details
that we need to as a project manager,

19
00:00:59.923 --> 00:01:01.921
to have them all in one location.

20
00:01:01.921 --> 00:01:06.582
Even though we talked about the idea
of the predecessor relationship,

21
00:01:06.582 --> 00:01:11.087
we briefly mentioned the idea here,
of course, dependencies, and

22
00:01:11.087 --> 00:01:13.430
that they really go hand in hand,.

23
00:01:13.430 --> 00:01:16.298
And we need to cover a few more
details on dependencies and

24
00:01:16.298 --> 00:01:20.120
then move on to other topics to help us
to determine what we call, of course,

25
00:01:20.120 --> 00:01:24.469
the critical path, which is something that
we'll really kind of have to focus in on.

26
00:01:24.469 --> 00:01:28.490
So we actually have those
details ahead of us, as well.

27
00:01:28.490 --> 00:01:31.690
So let's go ahead and take a look
at what we're talking about, then.

28
00:01:31.690 --> 00:01:36.450
And here we're just going to take a look
at the idea here of some dependencies.

29
00:01:36.450 --> 00:01:40.490
And then we'll talk about what's
actually on our screen, as well.

30
00:01:40.490 --> 00:01:44.860
So whenever we have a task that's actually
ahead of us, what we're gonna end up

31
00:01:44.860 --> 00:01:48.020
seeing here is we're gonna talk
about the idea of early starts and

32
00:01:48.020 --> 00:01:51.580
early finishes, and then late starts and
late finishes, as well.

33
00:01:51.580 --> 00:01:55.390
And we'll move this into
that realm of the diagram.

34
00:01:55.390 --> 00:01:59.230
Now, before we get here, we need to
just take a little bit of time and

35
00:01:59.230 --> 00:02:02.820
focus in on dependencies
just a little bit more.

36
00:02:02.820 --> 00:02:06.230
So let's go ahead and
talk about those as well, okay?

37
00:02:06.230 --> 00:02:08.060
Now, when it comes down to dependencies,

38
00:02:08.060 --> 00:02:11.820
we showed you how you can create those
types of predecessor relationships.

39
00:02:11.820 --> 00:02:15.002
But the problem that you and
I might have is how do we know what's

40
00:02:15.002 --> 00:02:18.377
actually a dependent relationship,
and what isn't one, okay?

41
00:02:18.377 --> 00:02:22.011
Well, there's actually multiple types of
dependencies that you should be aware of.

42
00:02:22.011 --> 00:02:26.890
And that will help to allow you,
then, so say, all right, here's how,

43
00:02:26.890 --> 00:02:31.718
as I set up these predecessors,
what is dependent upon that task doing?

44
00:02:31.718 --> 00:02:35.630
And so we need to at least
logically talk about that.

45
00:02:35.630 --> 00:02:36.900
So in terms of dependencies,

46
00:02:36.900 --> 00:02:39.990
there's actually three different types
that we have to worry about, okay.

47
00:02:39.990 --> 00:02:43.300
The first one is what we
call a mandatory dependency.

48
00:02:43.300 --> 00:02:47.680
And a mandatory type of dependency
is really when it actually depends

49
00:02:47.680 --> 00:02:51.620
on the type of work that's
actually being done, okay.

50
00:02:51.620 --> 00:02:53.330
So in this particular sense,

51
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:57.800
work has to actually be completed
before another one gets started.

52
00:02:57.800 --> 00:03:01.090
Well, in that sense,
that means, hey, we really are.

53
00:03:01.090 --> 00:03:06.560
It's not an idea of I want
it to actually be where this

54
00:03:06.560 --> 00:03:10.950
finishes before this, it really has to
actually be done before I can continue on.

55
00:03:10.950 --> 00:03:13.720
So let's give an example in
terms of construction, okay.

56
00:03:13.720 --> 00:03:16.570
I wanna go ahead and
frame up my house, okay,

57
00:03:16.570 --> 00:03:20.690
but I don't have a foundation poured
that a frame can be built on.

58
00:03:20.690 --> 00:03:23.640
Well, in that sense,
that's a mandatory dependency.

59
00:03:23.640 --> 00:03:27.700
That means before I can proceed
framing up the framework for

60
00:03:27.700 --> 00:03:33.000
a house that I might want to build,
the foundation must be finished, and must

61
00:03:33.000 --> 00:03:37.790
be poured and everything must actually be
completely cured the way that it has to.

62
00:03:37.790 --> 00:03:41.250
So that's an example of
a mandatory type of dependency.

63
00:03:41.250 --> 00:03:42.570
Now, there's also, of course,

64
00:03:42.570 --> 00:03:46.310
what we call a discretionary
type of dependency, as well.

65
00:03:46.310 --> 00:03:50.945
In terms of discretionary dependency,
this is some type of procedure driven or

66
00:03:50.945 --> 00:03:53.200
process driven dependencies.

67
00:03:53.200 --> 00:03:56.700
Now, I mentioned this before
in a previous episode, but

68
00:03:56.700 --> 00:04:01.070
we can go back to something like this
where it might be regulatory, as well.

69
00:04:01.070 --> 00:04:04.920
So in this example, I've actually
used a friend of mine that used to

70
00:04:04.920 --> 00:04:09.700
build cabinets for private airplanes.

71
00:04:09.700 --> 00:04:13.620
And even though he could actually
build all of those cabinets, and

72
00:04:13.620 --> 00:04:18.420
then install them into 100 airplanes
at a time, he always had to wait.

73
00:04:18.420 --> 00:04:21.670
After he finished building
either the cabinet or

74
00:04:21.670 --> 00:04:26.350
the top surface of that cabinet, he had
to wait until the inspector came by and

75
00:04:26.350 --> 00:04:29.830
inspected it, and
just simply signed off on a sheet.

76
00:04:29.830 --> 00:04:34.900
If he didn't get that sign-off, he was
not able to move on to the next step.

77
00:04:34.900 --> 00:04:37.900
Well, it's not that the signing
off did anything, right.

78
00:04:37.900 --> 00:04:41.150
It was just signing a sheet of paper,
it didn't actually do anything for

79
00:04:41.150 --> 00:04:43.100
the work being progressed along.

80
00:04:43.100 --> 00:04:47.680
But it was one of the discretionary
dependencies that airplane manufacturers

81
00:04:47.680 --> 00:04:51.690
say, look, every single thing,
right, cuz you're up in the air.

82
00:04:51.690 --> 00:04:54.510
You have to follow these procedures, and
they wanted to make sure that everything

83
00:04:54.510 --> 00:04:58.700
was inspected as it went
together on that airplane.

84
00:04:58.700 --> 00:05:00.747
So that was a discretionary
type of dependency, okay.

85
00:05:02.400 --> 00:05:07.165
We also have, then, external dependencies
that we have to also begin to understand,

86
00:05:07.165 --> 00:05:08.230
as well.

87
00:05:08.230 --> 00:05:11.838
Now, external dependencies are things
that are beyond our control.

88
00:05:11.838 --> 00:05:16.890
Okay, so when we start taking a look at
the idea of external dependencies that we

89
00:05:16.890 --> 00:05:22.990
have, well, let's go back to that
example of the construction, okay.

90
00:05:22.990 --> 00:05:29.270
So here it is, I bought my piece of land,
and now I am ready to frame up my house.

91
00:05:29.270 --> 00:05:32.945
The problem that I have, I already told
you, is I don't have the foundation ready.

92
00:05:32.945 --> 00:05:36.788
It's actually not there, so I need to
wait for the foundation to be poured.

93
00:05:36.788 --> 00:05:41.014
So I go and I call whoever actually
pours foundation and I say, all right,

94
00:05:41.014 --> 00:05:43.893
I want a foundation to be
poured right now, okay.

95
00:05:43.893 --> 00:05:48.388
And they tell me, well, Ronnie,
we can pour a foundation,

96
00:05:48.388 --> 00:05:54.720
whatever size you need, but I need 24
hours in advance before I can do that.

97
00:05:54.720 --> 00:05:57.690
Or I might need 48 hours in advance,
whatever it might be,

98
00:05:57.690 --> 00:06:00.650
before I can come out and
pour the foundation that you want.

99
00:06:00.650 --> 00:06:02.840
Well, that's an external dependency.

100
00:06:02.840 --> 00:06:05.950
In other words, I can't do anything
because I'm actually dependent upon what?

101
00:06:05.950 --> 00:06:11.120
That person saying I can deliver it either
right now or I can deliver it in 24 hours.

102
00:06:11.120 --> 00:06:14.790
So in that sense, it's not anything you
can control, it's pretty much the way that

103
00:06:14.790 --> 00:06:17.570
they have it, and so
you might have to depend on those.

104
00:06:17.570 --> 00:06:20.150
So each one of those,
knowing whether it's a discretionary,

105
00:06:20.150 --> 00:06:24.720
a mandatory or even the idea
here of an external dependency,

106
00:06:24.720 --> 00:06:27.180
is what's gonna really help
you set those predecessors up.

107
00:06:27.180 --> 00:06:30.360
>> Yeah, and being able to identify
those dependencies ahead of time.

108
00:06:30.360 --> 00:06:33.210
I mean,
you're aware of any potential obstacles,

109
00:06:33.210 --> 00:06:36.500
you're just getting a heads up so
you're not blindsided by any of these.

110
00:06:36.500 --> 00:06:39.320
>> Yeah, and it really is,
it's something that we definitely

111
00:06:39.320 --> 00:06:43.938
need to be aware of before we actually
get into the execution stage of things.

112
00:06:43.938 --> 00:06:47.170
Because if it's at the execution stage and
we're now worrying about dependencies

113
00:06:47.170 --> 00:06:50.200
then, while not in the planning stage,
we're gonna find ourselves

114
00:06:50.200 --> 00:06:53.470
really behind the eight ball and
we're not gonna know what to expect.

115
00:06:53.470 --> 00:06:55.920
Now, the other things, of course,
are fairly business like

116
00:06:55.920 --> 00:06:58.370
types of things that we have to worry
about in terms of scheduling, as well.

117
00:06:58.370 --> 00:07:01.290
And then we'll get into
the critical path method.

118
00:07:01.290 --> 00:07:06.240
One, of course, is understanding what the
sequence of tasks that have to be done.

119
00:07:06.240 --> 00:07:08.250
And that's where understanding
the predecessor and

120
00:07:08.250 --> 00:07:10.690
the dependency relationships
really do help.

121
00:07:10.690 --> 00:07:13.870
But also understanding the time schedule.

122
00:07:13.870 --> 00:07:16.820
In other words, what is the overall
time schedule that you have?

123
00:07:16.820 --> 00:07:19.270
You might find out something
that your sequence is different,

124
00:07:19.270 --> 00:07:24.770
if you actually are given a deadline and
say here's when it has to be completed by.

125
00:07:24.770 --> 00:07:28.314
You might actually sequence things a
little bit differently to get you to that

126
00:07:28.314 --> 00:07:31.655
point where you know you can complete
everything by that deadline date.

127
00:07:31.655 --> 00:07:35.579
Or it could be that they say,
look, here it is.

128
00:07:35.579 --> 00:07:38.477
We want to make sure that
you begin by this date, so

129
00:07:38.477 --> 00:07:43.050
that we'll have it at some future date
that we believe is gonna happen, okay.

130
00:07:43.050 --> 00:07:46.773
So you might schedule things out a little
bit differently if you start from a start

131
00:07:46.773 --> 00:07:47.605
date, instead.

132
00:07:47.605 --> 00:07:52.273
And then say let me figure this out in the
planning stage of how long this is gonna

133
00:07:52.273 --> 00:07:54.558
take, and I can give you an estimate.

134
00:07:54.558 --> 00:07:57.506
Well, that's a little bit
different in the way that

135
00:07:57.506 --> 00:08:00.592
you're gonna sequence your
tasks to get things done.

136
00:08:00.592 --> 00:08:04.576
So when you use some type of project
management information system,

137
00:08:04.576 --> 00:08:08.930
you end up seeing where they
allow you to schedule from both.

138
00:08:08.930 --> 00:08:12.140
But once you do that you're now setting
into your schedule what they call

139
00:08:12.140 --> 00:08:17.340
of course a hard constraint, if you're
doing it from a project end date instead.

140
00:08:17.340 --> 00:08:21.320
And that means everything has to actually
have a particular type of constraint

141
00:08:21.320 --> 00:08:26.460
called a finish on date, in other words
it has to actually be done this way for

142
00:08:26.460 --> 00:08:28.860
everything to be completed by this date.

143
00:08:28.860 --> 00:08:31.700
So you'll see it's one of the hardest
constraints that you can work with

144
00:08:31.700 --> 00:08:35.430
because it means everything else has to be
set around that to make everything work.

145
00:08:35.430 --> 00:08:38.390
So there's a lot of things that go on when
you start taking a look at the idea of

146
00:08:38.390 --> 00:08:42.800
sequencing of tasks as well,
as well as the prioritizing of tasks too.

147
00:08:42.800 --> 00:08:46.910
So in terms of scheduling,
there's a lot of considerations because

148
00:08:46.910 --> 00:08:50.240
you are literally scheduling so
many moving parts, so

149
00:08:50.240 --> 00:08:55.260
many different pieces, so many elements
you have to consider in terms of time.

very end once you spent all the money for

00:33:22.470 --> 00:33:26.150
your project and now you're company is
down, well, it could be hundreds of

609
00:33:26.150 --> 00:33:29.840
thousands of dollars as well for a small
company, I'd say $50,000 to $60,000 and

610
00:33:29.840 --> 00:33:34.730
you worked on the whole project and now
somebody says, this is not up to snuff.

611
00:33:34.730 --> 00:33:36.360
Well, what happens to all the money?

612
00:33:36.360 --> 00:33:38.530
You can't recoup that very easily.

613
00:33:38.530 --> 00:33:39.770
So setting up what we call,

614
00:33:39.770 --> 00:33:43.450
of course, quality gates says, here's what
we're going to do, a quality inspection.

615
00:33:43.450 --> 00:33:45.070
And then, we'll decide whether or

616
00:33:45.070 --> 00:33:47.590
not we're actually proceeding
on with what we need to.

617
00:33:47.590 --> 00:33:49.580
It's very important.

618
00:33:49.580 --> 00:33:52.640
Because if we don't have
these quality checks,

619
00:33:52.640 --> 00:33:56.690
we could produce a dud at the end and
say, well, I did all the work for it.

620
00:33:56.690 --> 00:33:58.930
You still owe me to finish that.

621
00:33:58.930 --> 00:34:01.820
Somebody I know says, you did all
the work but I'm not paying you for

622
00:34:01.820 --> 00:34:03.670
that because I don't like it at all.

623
00:34:03.670 --> 00:34:04.890
That would be terrible.

624
00:34:04.890 --> 00:34:08.100
So setting up quality gates
is actually a very good thing

625
00:34:08.100 --> 00:34:10.240
that can be put in place
that checks on the quality.

626
00:34:11.500 --> 00:34:17.660
The same idea is pretty much identical in
terms of governance gates but this time

627
00:34:17.660 --> 00:34:22.600
It is how we've actually chosen for
that procedure to go on.

628
00:34:22.600 --> 00:34:25.020
So this is more procedural and this sense.

629
00:34:25.020 --> 00:34:27.680
So what we want to do is we want
to actually know whether or

630
00:34:27.680 --> 00:34:33.570
not the management is still actually
involved in what we do here.

631
00:34:33.570 --> 00:34:38.339
So this actually gives us certain times
within our particular project instead,

632
00:34:38.339 --> 00:34:42.910
that says, look, somebody can say I
don't really agree with this anymore.

633
00:34:42.910 --> 00:34:46.233
Whether it's legislative
at this particular point,

634
00:34:46.233 --> 00:34:49.530
whether it's management,
client's signing off.

635
00:34:49.530 --> 00:34:50.920
Whatever it might be.

636
00:34:50.920 --> 00:34:55.650
That we just don't have everything that
we need, and in the project, as well.

637
00:34:55.650 --> 00:35:00.050
So both of these types of gates
here are really just saying

638
00:35:00.050 --> 00:35:02.900
there's different types of markers
that we need to make sure of, and

639
00:35:02.900 --> 00:35:06.790
what we don't want again is that the very
end of the project for somebody to find

640
00:35:06.790 --> 00:35:11.550
and say, we should have scrapped that
two weeks ago and we just chose not to.

641
00:35:11.550 --> 00:35:14.960
So it allows us to stop it at any
point without expending anymore money,

642
00:35:14.960 --> 00:35:17.860
and these are really good ideas.

643
00:35:17.860 --> 00:35:22.010
So setting those gates up during planning,
I'm saying here's where I want to check,

644
00:35:22.010 --> 00:35:24.860
is actually a manager's best friend,
because it allows him,

645
00:35:24.860 --> 00:35:28.760
if everything's not working, the way that
it needs to, that he can now go ahead and

646
00:35:28.760 --> 00:35:33.130
cut off that particular point and move
on to a different project that he needs.

647
00:35:33.130 --> 00:35:36.470
So setting these gates up are great
ways to actually provide very good,

648
00:35:36.470 --> 00:35:40.640
solid metrics and a point that says
I'm accountable up to this point and

649
00:35:40.640 --> 00:35:43.290
then after that we're done
if we actually need to be or

650
00:35:43.290 --> 00:35:46.335
I'm continuing on with the management
of this project as well.

651
00:35:46.335 --> 00:35:49.025
So that's what we talked about when we
take a look at governance gates as well as

652
00:35:49.025 --> 00:35:49.955
quality gates.

653
00:35:49.955 --> 00:35:50.765
>> Well, thank you Ronnie,

654
00:35:50.765 --> 00:35:54.055
for explaining that to us and everything
else you've covered in this episode.

655
00:35:54.055 --> 00:35:59.222
We've taken a look at our dependencies,
our mandatory, our discretion, external.

656
00:35:59.222 --> 00:36:03.617
We also looked at how to prioritize in
sequence tasks in addition to determining

657
00:36:03.617 --> 00:36:04.739
our critical path.

658
00:36:04.739 --> 00:36:06.887
So I think we're good to go for
this episode.

659
00:36:06.887 --> 00:36:09.095
Thanks so much for tuning in today.

660
00:36:09.095 --> 00:36:10.943
I'm Cherokee Boose
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

661
00:36:10.943 --> 00:36:11.487
>> Signing off.

662
00:36:11.487 --> 00:36:14.144
Have a great one.

663
00:36:14.144 --> 00:36:19.718
[MUSIC]

664
00:36:19.718 --> 00:36:23.366
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee explain Agile Methodology Basics. We learn the importance of swiftly evolving to changing needs. We look at the Iterative approach and see the defacto of a two week sprint creating workable smaller goals. We also look at Sprint planning.
episodes.title: Identify Agile Methodology Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.009 --> 00:00:05.250
Welcome to ITPRO.TV, I'm your host

2
00:00:05.250 --> 00:00:12.302
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]
you're watching ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:12.302 --> 00:00:15.292
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITPPRO.TV,

4
00:00:15.292 --> 00:00:17.050
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

5
00:00:17.050 --> 00:00:20.590
Today we're gonna be looking
at CompTIA's Project+.

6
00:00:20.590 --> 00:00:25.330
Specifically we'll be identifying our
agile basics for our methodology.

7
00:00:25.330 --> 00:00:27.310
So we have with us today Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:27.310 --> 00:00:29.570
Ronnie, thank you for being with us today.

9
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:30.360
Where do we start?

10
00:00:30.360 --> 00:00:32.430
How do we learn these methods?

11
00:00:32.430 --> 00:00:36.070
>> Well when we start to take a look
at the idea of using agile methodology,

12
00:00:36.070 --> 00:00:39.970
one of the things that we wanted to begin
with is you might be wondering why?

13
00:00:39.970 --> 00:00:42.460
If you've come from
the world of programming and

14
00:00:42.460 --> 00:00:46.400
that you've understand kind of
the benefits of the agile method.

15
00:00:46.400 --> 00:00:49.650
But if you come from the world
of project management outside

16
00:00:49.650 --> 00:00:53.540
of the IT world a lot of times, you'd
probably go, wait a minute, that's so

17
00:00:53.540 --> 00:00:58.110
different than anything that we've talked
about in terms of project management.

18
00:00:58.110 --> 00:01:00.900
So, when you start talking about
the idea of just project management, so

19
00:01:00.900 --> 00:01:04.330
we'll do a basic comparison here and
then we'll show you a diagram that I

20
00:01:04.330 --> 00:01:07.190
hope will help to explain it
a little bit better as well.

21
00:01:07.190 --> 00:01:08.730
So, when you start talking
about project management,

22
00:01:08.730 --> 00:01:10.746
remember the phases that we
tend to go through, right?

23
00:01:10.746 --> 00:01:14.400
The initiation,
the planning, the execution,

24
00:01:14.400 --> 00:01:16.390
as well as the controlling
kind of going hand in hand.

25
00:01:16.390 --> 00:01:19.540
And then we have the closing and
in CompTIA land, we also have, of course,

26
00:01:19.540 --> 00:01:22.400
the training which ends everything, okay?

27
00:01:22.400 --> 00:01:24.080
But in all of those stages,

28
00:01:24.080 --> 00:01:28.380
the way that it's designed is that
one stage builds upon the next.

29
00:01:28.380 --> 00:01:32.460
So the closing actually builds upon what
we've actually done in the execution and

30
00:01:32.460 --> 00:01:33.910
the controlling stage.

31
00:01:33.910 --> 00:01:38.000
Execution and controlling builds upon what
we actually did in the planning stage.

32
00:01:38.000 --> 00:01:42.850
Planning, of course, builds upon and
expands on the initiation stage as well.

33
00:01:42.850 --> 00:01:45.750
So that at the very end,
you get this big gigantic product, okay?

34
00:01:45.750 --> 00:01:50.150
Which is really what we hope is that
our project really does deliver through

35
00:01:50.150 --> 00:01:54.300
on that unique result, product or
even a service that we have.

36
00:01:54.300 --> 00:01:57.030
And that everything's
gonna be satisfactory.

37
00:01:57.030 --> 00:02:01.590
Well, the problem that we have in terms of
just regular project management is that as

38
00:02:01.590 --> 00:02:06.920
effective as it is,
it doesn't really lend itself to

39
00:02:06.920 --> 00:02:12.390
changes that may happen over time during
the project at any particular point.

40
00:02:12.390 --> 00:02:15.730
If you want to make changes in project
management in the way that we've talked

41
00:02:15.730 --> 00:02:20.130
about so far, it's easier to make
changes in the initiation phase,

42
00:02:20.130 --> 00:02:23.130
it's easier to make changes
during the planning phase.

43
00:02:23.130 --> 00:02:25.780
Once you get into
the execution phase though,

44
00:02:25.780 --> 00:02:28.910
that's when changes now become burdensome.

45
00:02:28.910 --> 00:02:30.195
They become complex,

46
00:02:30.195 --> 00:02:34.045
they become things in which you
would rather not have to deal with.

47
00:02:34.045 --> 00:02:36.175
>> Yeah, we even saw where we
might have to go ahead and

48
00:02:36.175 --> 00:02:38.663
submit those changes to
a change advisory board.

49
00:02:38.663 --> 00:02:41.875
>> Yeah, sometime a change advisory
board that is usually what ends up

50
00:02:41.875 --> 00:02:43.135
happening there.

51
00:02:43.135 --> 00:02:46.845
And so what starts to happen is that you
start to realize something that a lot of

52
00:02:46.845 --> 00:02:51.530
small projects,
changes like that might be incredibly

53
00:02:53.570 --> 00:02:58.520
a hassle to you, but you might still be
told, you're still gonna have to do it.

54
00:02:58.520 --> 00:02:59.760
I still want that in there.

55
00:02:59.760 --> 00:03:01.750
I don't care what it takes,
you still need to do it.

56
00:03:01.750 --> 00:03:05.120
Add then you find out that you really do
have to kind of go, all right, well, for

57
00:03:05.120 --> 00:03:08.030
us to do that we have to re-tool something
else or we actually have to reshape

58
00:03:08.030 --> 00:03:12.820
something that we did six weeks ago to
make sure that element gets included in.

59
00:03:12.820 --> 00:03:17.320
So instead, what has started to happen in
the realm of project management is simple,

60
00:03:17.320 --> 00:03:20.780
is that they started looking at other
areas that were highly technical in terms

61
00:03:20.780 --> 00:03:22.740
of their processes that they did, and

62
00:03:22.740 --> 00:03:26.930
they chose the idea of
agile types of management.

63
00:03:26.930 --> 00:03:31.110
And this is normally done in the software
realm, in the developer realm,

64
00:03:31.110 --> 00:03:35.970
because of how easily they're able
to take on changes and they don't

65
00:03:35.970 --> 00:03:40.290
take on long term planning in the way that
regular project management talks about it.

66
00:03:40.290 --> 00:03:44.410
So, let's take a look at a diagram that
will help us to figure this out so

67
00:03:44.410 --> 00:03:46.250
that we can see a little
bit more graphically and

68
00:03:46.250 --> 00:03:49.320
hopefully it will stick into your mind and
do this, okay?

69
00:03:49.320 --> 00:03:54.210
So, the way that agile works is that
they compare everything to the way

70
00:03:54.210 --> 00:03:56.070
that we used to do things, right?

71
00:03:56.070 --> 00:03:58.620
So if you're developing
some type of software,

72
00:03:58.620 --> 00:04:01.500
the traditional approach is simple,
you do analysis, and

73
00:04:01.500 --> 00:04:05.430
then you design the software, then you
start actually coding the software,

74
00:04:05.430 --> 00:04:09.330
in other words doing the work, ultimately
testing it at the very end here,

75
00:04:09.330 --> 00:04:11.396
you end up with the software
that somebody requested, okay?

76
00:04:12.560 --> 00:04:16.850
Now notice how everything actually
depends on the other thing before.

77
00:04:16.850 --> 00:04:22.150
I can't test anything unless I've already
gone through analysis, design and coding.

78
00:04:22.150 --> 00:04:26.620
I can't code anything if I haven't
designed anything and I haven't done

79
00:04:26.620 --> 00:04:31.340
analysis that helps me to figure out
what it is I'm actually coding for.

80
00:04:31.340 --> 00:04:35.900
So, when you start doing that, the real
test is that deliverable at the end.

81
00:04:35.900 --> 00:04:38.072
Whether or not that product,
that software,

82
00:04:38.072 --> 00:04:40.031
actually works the way that we want it to.

83
00:04:40.031 --> 00:04:42.706
So, in that same way,
it's like project management, right?

84
00:04:42.706 --> 00:04:46.407
The initiation, the planning,
the execution, the controlling, and

85
00:04:46.407 --> 00:04:47.560
then the closing, and

86
00:04:47.560 --> 00:04:52.240
then of course, the testing there when
you add in the CompTIA language, right?

87
00:04:52.240 --> 00:04:55.770
Then at the end you have that product,
you have everything that you want.

88
00:04:55.770 --> 00:04:59.740
But this is where it becomes
difficult when changes happen, right?

89
00:04:59.740 --> 00:05:05.010
If you're in the middle of coding and
now the sponsor of your project says,

90
00:05:05.010 --> 00:05:08.790
hey, here is an extra
element I want you to add in.

91
00:05:08.790 --> 00:05:12.100
Well, remember, you've already designed
what it's supposed to look like.

92
00:05:12.100 --> 00:05:14.680
You've already designed what
you think is the end and

93
00:05:14.680 --> 00:05:18.780
what you agreed upon with that
sponsor that's the end, okay?

94
00:05:18.780 --> 00:05:21.190
And so, all of this designing
may have actually taken,

95
00:05:21.190 --> 00:05:24.090
let's say, four to six weeks to design.

96
00:05:24.090 --> 00:05:25.780
And now you're three
weeks in the coding and

97
00:05:25.780 --> 00:05:28.940
now somebody says,
I need you to add this in there.

98
00:05:28.940 --> 00:05:32.310
Well, now, you can't just go, well,
I'm just gonna add that in later on and

99
00:05:32.310 --> 00:05:33.900
we'll just continue testing.

100
00:05:33.900 --> 00:05:36.570
You might actually find yourself
having to start all over

101
00:05:36.570 --> 00:05:39.170
before you can get to that point again.

102
00:05:39.170 --> 00:05:44.120
The way that agile actually does this
is a little bit different in this way.

103
00:05:44.120 --> 00:05:47.710
Agile says, look,
here's what we want to do instead, okay?

104
00:05:47.710 --> 00:05:52.720
There is no long-term
planning as a requirement.

105
00:05:52.720 --> 00:05:53.850
Now what does that mean?

106
00:05:53.850 --> 00:05:57.130
Does that mean they don't wanna
see the software that they wanna

107
00:05:57.130 --> 00:05:58.270
develop at the very end?

108
00:05:58.270 --> 00:06:00.290
No, that's not what they mean.

109
00:06:00.290 --> 00:06:05.190
What they mean, instead, is that they work
in smaller workable units in this way.

110
00:06:05.190 --> 00:06:07.410
That they plan a little bit, and they say,

111
00:06:07.410 --> 00:06:11.750
what's actually gonna help us to have our
first step to give us the overall product?

112
00:06:11.750 --> 00:06:15.407
And then they work on that as hard as they
can and then they work on the next step.

113
00:06:15.407 --> 00:06:20.307
And what they really end up accomplishing
at the very end is they have the product,

114
00:06:20.307 --> 00:06:24.567
the software that they want,
not because they were all working towards

115
00:06:24.567 --> 00:06:28.614
the end result in that way, but
that everybody along the project was

116
00:06:28.614 --> 00:06:32.306
working on smaller projects that
ended up as a result of that,

117
00:06:32.306 --> 00:06:36.520
the result of those ended up adding
up into the entire project itself.

118
00:06:36.520 --> 00:06:41.600
So in everything that they do, you take a
look at it in a vertical manner this way.

119
00:06:41.600 --> 00:06:45.970
Let me see if I can emphasize that a
little bit more for the first step there.

120
00:06:45.970 --> 00:06:53.220
The bolder green line indicates that when
we begin to start working at this point,

121
00:06:53.220 --> 00:06:57.050
we just go, all right, how do we subdivide
up what this big gigantic project is

122
00:06:57.050 --> 00:07:01.430
gonna be into smaller,
workable chunks here and smaller goals?

123
00:07:01.430 --> 00:07:06.600
And then we do an analysis for each one
of those particular workable units.

124
00:07:06.600 --> 00:07:12.330
And then we design, and we code, and
we test right there before we move on.

125
00:07:12.330 --> 00:07:15.660
>> So Ronnie, if we look at our
smaller workable chunks here,

126
00:07:15.660 --> 00:07:19.740
is there any kind of set duration, or
any kind of recommendations that you have?

127
00:07:19.740 --> 00:07:21.640
>> Well, yes and no, right?

128
00:07:21.640 --> 00:07:24.600
Like anything else, it depends on
the world that you're working.

129
00:07:24.600 --> 00:07:29.330
In the software development world, usually
these particular smaller chunks are done

130
00:07:29.330 --> 00:07:32.520
in particular time units that are set,
right?

131
00:07:32.520 --> 00:07:36.680
So normally one to four weeks,
depending on how large the project is.

132
00:07:36.680 --> 00:07:40.380
By default, I wanna say de facto instead,
not by default.

133
00:07:40.380 --> 00:07:45.259
De facto, most software development teams
that tend to work in this manner of agile,

134
00:07:45.259 --> 00:07:47.833
at least from what I
could actually find out,

135
00:07:47.833 --> 00:07:51.526
it's about a two-week split is
what they end up working out as.

136
00:07:51.526 --> 00:07:56.676
So what can we accomplish in ten days of
workable time that will give us at the end

137
00:07:56.676 --> 00:08:01.687
result here, we take a look at my screen
again That unit that we really want.

138
00:08:01.687 --> 00:08:05.510
We want some type of deliverable
at the end of each one of these.

139
00:08:05.510 --> 00:08:10.236
Now, the thing that makes this different,
because we don't plan for the entirety

140
00:08:10.236 --> 00:08:14.304
of the whole project, is at the end
of this we might find out something.

141
00:08:14.304 --> 00:08:17.544
We now go back and
after testing we might find out,

142
00:08:17.544 --> 00:08:21.340
Ronnie you got software that's a dud,
it doesn't work.

143
00:08:21.340 --> 00:08:24.214
Well, it didn't mean that I
worked the whole time, and

144
00:08:24.214 --> 00:08:25.689
now I have to start all over.

145
00:08:25.689 --> 00:08:28.438
It means on that particular
unit I worked and

146
00:08:28.438 --> 00:08:32.688
now I might need to actually go back
in and start all over if I need to.

147
00:08:32.688 --> 00:08:35.619
Or I might find out through testing that
I've got a portion of code that's bad.

148
00:08:35.619 --> 00:08:38.419
Well then I just jump
back in the coding and

149
00:08:38.419 --> 00:08:42.670
I re-run that process in that
loop again until we get it right.

150
00:08:42.670 --> 00:08:47.380
Now, once it's actually done,
we can then move on to that second unit.

151
00:08:47.380 --> 00:08:49.767
And it's there that you start
the same process again.

152
00:08:49.767 --> 00:08:51.945
And this is why it's
actually called agile,

153
00:08:51.945 --> 00:08:53.900
because it willingly accepts changes.

154
00:08:53.900 --> 00:08:57.783
Somebody adds something in during
the design stage, during the coding stage.

155
00:08:57.783 --> 00:09:02.030
Well, you just simply start that process
over again, and then you still end up with

156
00:09:02.030 --> 00:09:06.106
that smaller unit that you're really
heading a goal towards, to help you out.

157
00:09:06.106 --> 00:09:08.307
And so each process is really that loop,

158
00:09:08.307 --> 00:09:12.581
or it actually leads onto the second stage
which gives us a smaller unit again,

159
00:09:12.581 --> 00:09:16.030
third, fourth, fifth,
however many that there are.

160
00:09:16.030 --> 00:09:20.207
And at the end, the result of all
those small projects is what gives us

161
00:09:20.207 --> 00:09:23.533
the overall project itself and
is what we really want.

162
00:09:23.533 --> 00:09:28.730
So, the nature of agile is what is
considered the iterative approach.

00:09:34.797 --> 00:09:37.857
Well, this is what we mean here when

00:09:37.857 --> 00:09:41.899
Instead of saying, the way that

00:09:41.899 --> 00:09:43.319
We had said that a project has what?

A definite beginning and
a definite end, but

Well remember that in project management

Time, scope, and cost, if you kind

Usually there's one of those
elements that is considered kind

00:10:10.392 --> 00:10:14.971

the unchanging constant that we have.

The project sponsor really

the two variables that we really

00:10:33.515 --> 00:10:37.590

00:10:37.590 --> 00:10:40.581
Now, in in the way that

It says this, it says look, time and

00:10:54.193 --> 00:10:55.930

And so, that's what allowed you

So now,

There's a particular time element

it's a two week what they call a sprint

So that idea of a sprint is

Now along with this type of approach

So, when we start to take a look at them

Time and money.

So that's why we have to expect and

The other thing of course is

The great thing is you

Those teams, if they were together for

387
00:21:55.575 --> 00:21:57.397
>> So what's so
special about this backlog?

00:21:57.397 --> 00:22:00.938
You say that they love it, but
could you explain that a little bit more?

389
00:22:00.938 --> 00:22:04.747
>> It's because it really is something
that they don't have to guess what needs

00:22:04.747 --> 00:22:05.578
to be done next.

391
00:22:05.578 --> 00:22:09.449
If you now have the entirety of everything

00:22:09.449 --> 00:22:11.865

393
00:22:11.865 --> 00:22:15.949
What it means is your particular

00:22:15.949 --> 00:22:17.827
you don't have to assign them.

395
00:22:17.827 --> 00:22:20.355
You better work on this task,
you better work on this task,

396
00:22:20.355 --> 00:22:21.628
you better work on this task.

397
00:22:21.628 --> 00:22:24.459
They can look at it at the list and go,
here is what I'm gonna start working on.

398
00:22:24.459 --> 00:22:27.270
Here is what I'm gonna start working on,
here is what I'm gonna start working on.

399
00:22:27.270 --> 00:22:30.570
Cherokee gets finished
before I do on mine.

00:22:30.570 --> 00:22:33.324
She didn't have to sit around and

00:22:33.324 --> 00:22:34.650
tell her what to do next, why?

402
00:22:34.650 --> 00:22:36.078
Because we have a backlog.

403
00:22:36.078 --> 00:22:40.305
So Cherokee simply goes into the backlog

405
00:22:44.989 --> 00:22:49.124
Here's three items left in this particular

00:22:49.124 --> 00:22:52.602
Cherokee can pick from those items and
say, here it is.

407
00:22:52.602 --> 00:22:56.269
I've done mine, I'm gonna go ahead and
start working on this.

408
00:22:56.269 --> 00:22:59.704
So they love it because it does give
them that ability to work through that,

409
00:22:59.704 --> 00:23:00.589
if they choose to.

410
00:23:00.589 --> 00:23:03.815
Now don't get me wrong,
you might find out that your Scrum master,

no Cherokee.

00:23:06.597 --> 00:23:08.440
>> [LAUGH]
>> I need you to work on this now.

413
00:23:08.440 --> 00:23:11.933
But at times if it really
is a self directed team.

00:23:11.933 --> 00:23:14.639
>> Yeah, this is really where
that motivation comes into play.

415
00:23:14.639 --> 00:23:18.880
>> Yeah, cuz it's like what we've talked
about this before too that if we really

00:23:18.880 --> 00:23:23.393
enjoy the topics that we're teaching it's
like we have a little bit more in there.

417
00:23:23.393 --> 00:23:24.043
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

418
00:23:24.043 --> 00:23:26.891
>> And it's not that we're just competent,

419
00:23:26.891 --> 00:23:30.547
we like everything that we teach, but
there are areas that we're really good at.

420
00:23:30.547 --> 00:23:31.480
>> Or passionate about, yeah.

421
00:23:31.480 --> 00:23:32.801
>> Or passionate about.

422
00:23:32.801 --> 00:23:36.527
So that's the idea here,
is that if we have projects like that,

00:23:36.527 --> 00:23:40.184
it really does motivate us to be
able to work on things that might

00:23:40.184 --> 00:23:43.579
actually be incredibly productive
in that sense as well.

425
00:23:43.579 --> 00:23:46.254
So when you start seeing
this type of backlog,

00:23:46.254 --> 00:23:50.384
there's usually two basic methodologies
here on the backlog, okay?

00:23:50.384 --> 00:23:53.695
One is that work is pulled from

that is the idea of what we

00:23:56.815 --> 00:23:58.664
Okay, so
that's where Scrum really does come in.

00:23:58.664 --> 00:23:59.887
It says, all right, here it is.

431
00:23:59.887 --> 00:24:01.160
You only pull from this section here.

00:24:01.160 --> 00:24:05.178
But there's also other methodologies
that also come into play.

00:24:05.178 --> 00:24:08.369
You might hear about Kanban,
which is essentially saying, all right,

00:24:08.369 --> 00:24:10.210
we'll just continue to add to this list.

00:24:10.210 --> 00:24:14.390
And you pull from it as things
actually develop along the way, too.

436
00:24:14.390 --> 00:24:17.891
You name it, it's always there to when
you start talking about this iterative

437
00:24:17.891 --> 00:24:18.750
approach as well.

438
00:24:19.930 --> 00:24:23.870
The other thing about for
us here in Agile and in terms of Scrum.

439
00:24:23.870 --> 00:24:27.120
Now you might go,
why did he start talking about Scrum?

440
00:24:27.120 --> 00:24:33.170
Well, Agile really bases itself on this
idea of this Scrum technique as well.

441
00:24:33.170 --> 00:24:37.540
And what we call sprints, which is,

00:24:37.540 --> 00:24:39.710
But those are the terms

443
00:24:39.710 --> 00:24:44.098
too, is what we call continuous

444
00:24:45.400 --> 00:24:47.850
Because of the way that we
are working through this and

00:24:47.850 --> 00:24:51.690
that iterative approach, right,
we have the ability to stop and

00:24:51.690 --> 00:24:55.560

00:24:55.560 --> 00:24:58.280
So changes are integrated

00:24:58.280 --> 00:25:00.430
easily because of those integrations.

00:25:00.430 --> 00:25:01.900
And we can now go on, is this good?

450
00:25:01.900 --> 00:25:04.610
And someone goes, no, that wasn't

00:25:04.610 --> 00:25:08.550
It's easier to make, what, small changes
along the way than to go at the very end,

452
00:25:08.550 --> 00:25:11.820
and now you look at it and
go that's terrible.

453
00:25:11.820 --> 00:25:13.790
I don't even wanna touch it.

00:25:13.790 --> 00:25:15.260
The whole thing that you have.

455
00:25:15.260 --> 00:25:18.050
So just kind of realize,
that is a part of it.

456
00:25:18.050 --> 00:25:22.250
Now just because I said there isn't

doesn't mean that there

00:25:26.450 --> 00:25:29.570
So there is actually some

00:25:29.570 --> 00:25:33.928
But a lot of times you actually do have
to think about the idea of what we call

00:25:33.928 --> 00:25:38.120
sprint planning, okay,
is really what it's called.

461
00:25:38.120 --> 00:25:42.520
But in CompTIA land,
they also call it Scrum planning as well.

462
00:25:42.520 --> 00:25:46.510
So you may hear those two terms
that you will end up finding out.

463
00:25:46.510 --> 00:25:49.404
>> Something that I have heard
before also was the Kanban method,

464
00:25:49.404 --> 00:25:50.920
is that similar there?

465
00:25:50.920 --> 00:25:55.720
With the manufacturing and
keeping all the products in their bins and

00:25:55.720 --> 00:25:58.450
keeping the stock highly available,
things like that.

467
00:25:58.450 --> 00:26:00.060
>> Yeah, that's the same idea,

468
00:26:00.060 --> 00:26:03.440
is that somebody instead
actually continues to realize.

469
00:26:03.440 --> 00:26:07.088
The example that Cherokee is giving
us is to make sure that we have

00:26:07.088 --> 00:26:10.550
all those products that
are necessary to be updated.

471
00:26:10.550 --> 00:26:14.060
So that we don't run out of them

472
00:26:14.060 --> 00:26:18.820
So it is very possible that we have
those things in place to go ahead and

473
00:26:18.820 --> 00:26:19.620
go realize that.

474
00:26:19.620 --> 00:26:22.880
And we have an automatic backlog that
actually helps us to fill up, and

475
00:26:22.880 --> 00:26:25.388
to actually pull and do the things

476
00:26:26.780 --> 00:26:30.210
All right, now when we start
talking about that sprint, right,

00:26:30.210 --> 00:26:32.420
the things that need to be in place here.

478
00:26:32.420 --> 00:26:34.790
We've gotta make sure that we actually
understand what's actually gonna be

00:26:34.790 --> 00:26:39.130
expected for us, as well as the overall
goals that we have here, okay.

480
00:26:39.130 --> 00:26:42.720
When you set up a sprint then,
okay, now this is where we

00:26:42.720 --> 00:26:46.020
have to go back to my screen just

482
00:26:47.160 --> 00:26:50.450
Estimate how long it
will actually take for

483
00:26:50.450 --> 00:26:53.260
us to actually work through each story,

484
00:26:53.260 --> 00:26:53.848
So here it is.

485
00:26:53.848 --> 00:26:57.181
This is now where we're starting
to schedule out things, okay.

486
00:26:57.181 --> 00:27:01.710
We now need estimates of how this
is going to end up happening, okay.

487
00:27:01.710 --> 00:27:04.930
We then set priorities, and
then we start the work as well for

00:27:04.930 --> 00:27:08.010
the iterations that we
actually have in place.

00:27:08.010 --> 00:27:11.610
So here for the planning,

00:27:11.610 --> 00:27:14.970

What are we actually

00:27:21.820 --> 00:27:24.740

00:27:24.740 --> 00:27:29.410
Now when I say that, you might actually

00:27:29.410 --> 00:27:31.950
But what you want for your team is this.

00:27:31.950 --> 00:27:37.810
You wanna be able to have them say

00:27:37.810 --> 00:27:43.680

00:27:43.680 --> 00:27:47.690
So that way when somebody asks, Cherokee,

We also wanna make sure that the backlog
that we had is normally designed for

00:28:02.640 --> 00:28:04.950
our particular sprint as well, okay.

00:28:04.950 --> 00:28:08.880
And so usually along with the idea of
the sprint and the prioritization,

00:28:08.880 --> 00:28:13.490

00:28:13.490 --> 00:28:17.150
And then, of course, the idea that of what

00:28:17.150 --> 00:28:19.240
the user story that we're

508
00:28:19.240 --> 00:28:23.058
And then ultimately, right,

00:28:23.058 --> 00:28:27.120
this is something that's

510
00:28:27.120 --> 00:28:29.610
You, as the project manager,

00:28:33.450 --> 00:28:35.880
But because of the way that
everything came together and

it's a self-organized type of team.

00:28:38.240 --> 00:28:43.530
The working team is the one that tells you

00:28:43.530 --> 00:28:46.050
You don't get to tell them,

project managers love to say, here's how

And so it's the team members

It's not an arbitrary decision by somebody

00:29:11.000 --> 00:29:12.970
what we actually have in place.

00:29:12.970 --> 00:29:15.810
So just kind of realize
that there are multiple

00:29:15.810 --> 00:29:18.606
units that we actually

00:29:18.606 --> 00:29:21.710
And realize when we start to take a look

00:29:21.710 --> 00:29:25.860

00:29:25.860 --> 00:29:30.880
So here it is, we're kind of

00:29:30.880 --> 00:29:34.930

00:29:34.930 --> 00:29:36.580

You understand the waterfall

00:29:40.870 --> 00:29:42.850
And then some of the elements

00:29:42.850 --> 00:29:45.690
These are actually key terms that you

00:29:45.690 --> 00:29:46.730

535
00:29:48.130 --> 00:29:50.320
>> I think that about wraps it up for

536
00:29:50.320 --> 00:29:51.840
We've been able to go ahead and

00:29:51.840 --> 00:29:55.990
look at our identifying or
agile basic methodologies.

538
00:29:55.990 --> 00:30:00.080
You introduced us to the concept

00:30:00.080 --> 00:30:04.460
it is to choose a really qualified team to

540
00:30:04.460 --> 00:30:07.230
You were also able to go ahead and show us

541

how a backlog is useful in this particular

00:30:12.240 --> 00:30:14.180
How we're really just

544
00:30:18.590 --> 00:30:21.370
Moving forward we're gonna be

00:30:21.370 --> 00:30:23.880
So stay tuned,

00:30:23.880 --> 00:30:26.442

00:30:26.442 --> 00:30:27.647

00:30:27.647 --> 00:30:28.575

00:30:28.575 --> 00:30:30.389

00:30:30.389 --> 00:30:36.920

00:30:36.920 --> 00:30:40.033

episodes.description: This episode kicks off with a Definition and diagram of SCRUM Meetings to help you see the usefulness of these brief, daily ,standup meetings. Remember SCRUM meetings should have each team member  gives a status update that should include what they have done, what they plan to do next, and address any issues they are facing. We also see how to utilize burndown charts to help keep the project on a steady course. Lastly, SCRUM retrospective is defined as reviewing how well the team works together.
episodes.title: Identify Agile Methodology Basics Part 2

00:03:05.560 --> 00:03:09.140
More than anything else, they're not
supposed to last any longer than about 10,

58
00:03:09.140 --> 00:03:11.080
15 minutes at the max.

59
00:03:11.080 --> 00:03:14.060
And they are by nature stand up meetings.

60
00:03:14.060 --> 00:03:17.420
So you don't sit down and
kind of get rested and comfortable.

61
00:03:17.420 --> 00:03:18.660
The goal is simple, right?

62
00:03:18.660 --> 00:03:21.350
It's to bring that energy
to that meeting and say,

63
00:03:21.350 --> 00:03:24.310
here is everything we've
accomplished yesterday.

64
00:03:24.310 --> 00:03:29.000
Here's what I'm doing next, and I may
need help in getting this done today.

65
00:03:29.000 --> 00:03:31.700
And somebody normally says,
yeah just see me after the meeting and

66
00:03:31.700 --> 00:03:32.980
we'll get that straightened out.

67
00:03:32.980 --> 00:03:38.040
Whatever it might be those are pretty
much the key goals here, is that their

68
00:03:38.040 --> 00:03:43.480
stand up because as soon as that meetings
over we want work to really begin.

69
00:03:43.480 --> 00:03:45.580
And the same thing even with
our own stand up meetings.

70
00:03:45.580 --> 00:03:47.300
That's the goal and desire.

71
00:03:47.300 --> 00:03:52.550
So we borrowed from the scrum idea and
the agile method to try and make sure

72
00:03:52.550 --> 00:03:56.180
that we start off every day right and that
everybody understands what's going on.

73
00:03:56.180 --> 00:03:57.350
But now that our company has grown.

74
00:03:57.350 --> 00:04:01.320
It becomes larger than kind of a small
team in which everything can get done

75
00:04:01.320 --> 00:04:05.500
that way, where everybody can say all
these things in 10 to 15 minutes.

76
00:04:05.500 --> 00:04:08.960
And sometimes these particular
topics that we have to cover,

77
00:04:08.960 --> 00:04:13.410
they may be very diverse and they at least
help us to understand what's going on.

78
00:04:13.410 --> 00:04:15.600
But in normal Scrum meetings, right?

79
00:04:15.600 --> 00:04:19.960
We wanna make sure that those three
events are always happening as well.

80
00:04:19.960 --> 00:04:24.100
Now along with this, of course,
is who tends to attend Scrum meetings?

81
00:04:24.100 --> 00:04:26.930
Well first and foremost,
every team member.

82
00:04:26.930 --> 00:04:29.060
Why?
Because they are the ones that are doing

83
00:04:29.060 --> 00:04:30.400
the work, itself.

84
00:04:30.400 --> 00:04:33.630
So it's very important that
they have this opportunity

85
00:04:33.630 --> 00:04:37.450
to allow everybody to know what the
progress is on work that they're doing.

86
00:04:37.450 --> 00:04:38.255
>> And Ronnie,
>> For them.

87
00:04:38.255 --> 00:04:40.805
>> One thing you mentioned
earlier was collaboration.

88
00:04:40.805 --> 00:04:43.525
Let's say,
there's an obstacle that I am facing and

00:04:43.525 --> 00:04:48.085
maybe someone on my team has experience
with overcoming that obstacle in the past.

90
00:04:48.085 --> 00:04:49.505
This seems like a good opportunity for

91
00:04:49.505 --> 00:04:51.835
them to kind of chime in and
help out their teammates.

92
00:04:51.835 --> 00:04:53.015
>> Yes, it really is.

93
00:04:53.015 --> 00:04:57.495
And the key here again in this type of
meeting is not that all of the sudden this

00:04:57.495 --> 00:05:01.290
is what Cherokee does As well Ronnie, let

00:05:01.290 --> 00:05:06.040
That's not what that means for, it's to

00:05:06.040 --> 00:05:09.120
And that way Cherokee can

00:05:09.120 --> 00:05:10.350

00:05:10.350 --> 00:05:14.710
>> Have a breakaway meeting unto
yourselves as far as that goes and

99
00:05:14.710 --> 00:05:16.590
then help out at that point.

100
00:05:16.590 --> 00:05:20.710
But it really is, it's about status,
it's about the idea that I may need help.

101
00:05:20.710 --> 00:05:24.680
And then getting the help that they

102
00:05:24.680 --> 00:05:25.940
If you stop and do this for

00:05:29.580 --> 00:05:34.380
It turns in to a whole another

00:05:34.380 --> 00:05:36.705

00:05:36.705 --> 00:05:39.560

00:05:39.560 --> 00:05:40.250

00:05:40.250 --> 00:05:42.110
It's just about impossible.

00:05:42.110 --> 00:05:45.550
So it's really key that we

00:05:45.550 --> 00:05:48.210
So every team member

111
00:05:48.210 --> 00:05:49.760
But the way that we keep this going,

112
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:53.050
instead of it turning into something

113
00:05:53.050 --> 00:05:56.140
this brainstorming meeting,

00:05:56.140 --> 00:05:57.388

00:05:57.388 --> 00:05:59.690
And then Cherokee brings up another one,

00:05:59.690 --> 00:06:03.010

00:06:03.010 --> 00:06:05.050
You have a leader of this meeting.

00:06:05.050 --> 00:06:08.420
And typically that is

00:06:08.420 --> 00:06:11.480
Does that sound like a title

00:06:11.480 --> 00:06:12.565
A scrum master.
