00:06:12.565 --> 00:06:15.150
>> [LAUGH] Sounds like a little dingy or

00:06:15.150 --> 00:06:16.200
>> [LAUGH]
>> But you know what?

00:06:16.200 --> 00:06:19.380
If you need someone to keep

00:06:19.380 --> 00:06:22.290

125
00:06:22.290 --> 00:06:24.100
>> Yeah, and so, this particular idea,

00:06:24.100 --> 00:06:27.910

00:06:30.450 --> 00:06:32.690

00:06:32.690 --> 00:06:34.990
And if you do need help make sure

00:06:34.990 --> 00:06:37.730
it doesn't have to happen

00:06:37.730 --> 00:06:40.450
Also, you may end up

00:06:40.450 --> 00:06:42.130
Now, not always.

00:06:45.080 --> 00:06:46.480
Then, yes.

00:06:46.480 --> 00:06:50.910
The reason why is that you may
have questions where you want or

00:06:50.910 --> 00:06:53.410

00:06:53.410 --> 00:06:55.820

00:06:55.820 --> 00:06:59.610
And then afterwards, they're there to

00:06:59.610 --> 00:07:03.750
And now instead of them having to sit down

00:07:03.750 --> 00:07:07.140
David, whoever might be,

00:07:07.140 --> 00:07:10.490
At this point with the product

00:07:10.490 --> 00:07:11.990
the hear the questions.

143
00:07:11.990 --> 00:07:14.310
They understand what
question they may have.

144
00:07:14.310 --> 00:07:17.620
And now when it comes down

00:07:17.620 --> 00:07:20.740
They may say well,
I'm here to answer those questions and

00:07:20.740 --> 00:07:23.330

147
00:07:23.330 --> 00:07:27.960
In that way, you have all the information

148
00:07:27.960 --> 00:07:32.010
So, those are really important
meetings because they happen daily and

149
00:07:32.010 --> 00:07:36.170
it ensures that everybody is able
to start on the right track.

00:07:36.170 --> 00:07:43.210
So that they either are getting set to

151
00:07:43.210 --> 00:07:47.650
Or they get the help that they need to
overcome whatever obstacle they're facing.

152
00:07:47.650 --> 00:07:49.570
So that's why these meetings
are very important.

153
00:07:49.570 --> 00:07:54.815
If we just wait and go, we'll handle
that at Monday's weekly status meeting,

154
00:07:54.815 --> 00:07:56.712

155
00:07:56.712 --> 00:07:59.454
So daily meetings are very
much a part of it, and

156
00:07:59.454 --> 00:08:02.275
we try to keep them short
because usually for us.

00:08:02.275 --> 00:08:05.296
If you don't, meetings tend to
degrade into just, you know,

158
00:08:05.296 --> 00:08:08.090
well here's what I did this weekend,
here's what I did.

159
00:08:08.090 --> 00:08:09.310
And so, instead,

00:08:09.310 --> 00:08:12.660
it's all about the focus, making

161
00:08:12.660 --> 00:08:16.680
And you tend to treat it like a very good,
very mini pep rally where you go,

00:08:16.680 --> 00:08:18.930
all right, everybody let's

00:08:18.930 --> 00:08:20.730
And continue to go on your way.

164
00:08:20.730 --> 00:08:24.970
So in that sense they are really

165
00:08:24.970 --> 00:08:29.106
So part of that basic methodology is also
doing these types of meetings as well,

166
00:08:29.106 --> 00:08:29.683
Okay?

167
00:08:29.683 --> 00:08:30.689
>> Awesome.

168
00:08:30.689 --> 00:08:34.490
Alright, now, there's one other thing

00:08:34.490 --> 00:08:36.420
That's part of our objectives
that we need to cover,

00:08:36.420 --> 00:08:39.420
but there's probably something

171
00:08:39.420 --> 00:08:42.420
Which is what we call a burn down chart,
okay.

172
00:08:42.420 --> 00:08:44.960
Now you might be wondering what
the heck is a burn down chart about.

173
00:08:44.960 --> 00:08:49.220
Well if you remember when we talked about
the idea of sprints and the backlog.

174
00:08:49.220 --> 00:08:55.110
Well it's not enough that we just know
what is actually needing to be done.

175
00:08:55.110 --> 00:08:57.890
We need to be able to put those
not only into a timeline but

176
00:08:57.890 --> 00:09:00.190
to prioritize them as well.

177
00:09:00.190 --> 00:09:03.100
And to able to assign weight and
value to them so

178
00:09:03.100 --> 00:09:06.920
that we can measure our
performance against them.

179
00:09:06.920 --> 00:09:08.390
And the way that Scrum does it and

180
00:09:08.390 --> 00:09:12.410
the way that Agile does it is in
creating what we call a burn down chart.

181
00:09:12.410 --> 00:09:15.920
Let me show you an example what
I'm talking about here, okay.

182
00:09:15.920 --> 00:09:19.940
So here on my machine I
have a very basic chart.

183
00:09:19.940 --> 00:09:25.450
I tried not to go insanely too complex for
my sake more than anything else.

00:09:25.450 --> 00:09:29.380
But let's say that over here on
the left-hand side, here is my

00:09:29.380 --> 00:09:34.990

the project that I am about to begin.

186
00:09:34.990 --> 00:09:38.840
So we're going to create objectives list
in what we're calling markdown here.

187
00:09:38.840 --> 00:09:40.710
Okay?
We're going to break the objectives down

00:09:40.710 --> 00:09:41.510

00:09:41.510 --> 00:09:45.380
Let's just take for

00:09:45.380 --> 00:09:48.050
We prepare whatever written

00:09:48.050 --> 00:09:51.670
We research any additional
materials that we may need to and

00:09:51.670 --> 00:09:55.250

00:09:55.250 --> 00:09:59.840
Okay, now when we start to talk about

00:09:59.840 --> 00:10:04.000
Notice that what we have to do, is we have

195
00:10:04.000 --> 00:10:06.560

each one of those tasks.

196
00:10:06.560 --> 00:10:11.560
And then, the sprints that allow us to

00:10:11.560 --> 00:10:16.590
And remember that sprints typically

00:10:16.590 --> 00:10:17.670
Doesn't mean it has to be that.

00:10:17.670 --> 00:10:21.950
It could be two hours long if you want it

200
00:10:21.950 --> 00:10:25.460
to understand that each one of these

201
00:10:25.460 --> 00:10:30.190
And I've labelled them 1 through 5 just
like I have right here, as well, okay.

202
00:10:31.200 --> 00:10:37.050
So then, from that point what you do is

00:10:37.050 --> 00:10:41.300
Now, I use very small numbers here,

00:10:41.300 --> 00:10:44.910
And then I said breakdown
the objectives into show segments and

00:10:44.910 --> 00:10:47.140
I actually have ten points here.

00:10:47.140 --> 00:10:50.770
And so I have a range,
let's say, of one to ten points.

00:10:50.770 --> 00:10:53.560
And these are arbitrary, however

Ten, for me, being a fairly difficult task

00:11:02.270 --> 00:11:06.040

based on what we call effort, right.

00:11:08.300 --> 00:11:08.860

>> So for

me creating the objectives list and

paste from the official

00:11:14.830 --> 00:11:16.980
And I can create those in

00:11:16.980 --> 00:11:19.570
So if I now how to get to them and

00:11:19.570 --> 00:11:24.150

So for me that's a fairly easy task.

But then breaking those objectives

And, Cherokee knows because

Cherokee's done a four part show with

At least, I see that Ronnie's having

00:11:49.770 --> 00:11:52.140
So for me,
that's a little bit harder to actually do.

00:11:52.140 --> 00:11:55.320
So, I gave it 10 points and
then preparing the actual

00:11:55.320 --> 00:11:59.710
notes which required of course typing

00:11:59.710 --> 00:12:02.050
Researching, if there's any topic,

00:12:02.050 --> 00:12:05.460
I know kind of the basics of it,

00:12:05.460 --> 00:12:08.390
I actually research that, and

00:12:08.390 --> 00:12:10.050

00:12:10.050 --> 00:12:11.760
I may also give it those points as well.

00:12:11.760 --> 00:12:14.510
Now, you're probably wondering like,

00:12:14.510 --> 00:12:16.650
You gave everything ten points except for

00:12:16.650 --> 00:12:20.110
Well, that's so that I could keep

But once you do this,

00:12:22.570 --> 00:12:24.560
Now you don't have to do it like I did.

You can do this inside of Excel and

00:12:27.830 --> 00:12:31.430
But essentially,

00:12:37.380 --> 00:12:42.110
Now, when I start to work through

I can actually go ahead and

00:12:46.800 --> 00:12:55.293
Now, let me do, this is 2, And then.

I'm just gonna copy this over,

I found out something

00:13:14.590 --> 00:13:18.670
And then at some point in time,

00:13:18.670 --> 00:13:19.520

00:13:22.120 --> 00:13:24.790
Cuz I'm not, and

00:13:24.790 --> 00:13:27.990

So now notice, that means here's my

00:13:57.750 --> 00:14:01.210
Well now, all of a sudden,

00:14:04.870 --> 00:14:07.730

00:14:13.620 --> 00:14:16.380
Okay?
Now, you might be saying

00:14:16.380 --> 00:14:17.960

00:14:17.960 --> 00:14:21.660
Well, the burn down chart

00:14:21.660 --> 00:14:26.610

00:14:34.820 --> 00:14:35.940

That's supposed to be ten weeks in time,

00:14:39.720 --> 00:14:43.460
And I should only expend

00:14:43.460 --> 00:14:47.190
While I start to realize something

00:14:47.190 --> 00:14:51.620
If I add all this up, and here it is,
I am only on week number eight.

283
00:14:51.620 --> 00:14:56.170
I'm doing something, now that's
a little bit insane here but on week

284
00:14:56.170 --> 00:14:59.810
number eight of doing all of this to get
it ready for the shows that are coming up.

285
00:14:59.810 --> 00:15:02.520
I've already spent 42 points.

286
00:15:02.520 --> 00:15:05.390
Well, I start to realize
something at this point here.

287
00:15:05.390 --> 00:15:08.140
I'm not done with the project and

288
00:15:08.140 --> 00:15:12.090
that means I have at least
a lot more work effort to go.

289
00:15:12.090 --> 00:15:17.830
So, I am either going to burn through
the stories a lot slower than I need to,

290
00:15:17.830 --> 00:15:21.350
which means it's gonna put
me behind schedule, okay?

291
00:15:21.350 --> 00:15:24.360
Or I might find out

292
00:15:24.360 --> 00:15:29.030
that I burn through it a lot faster where
all of a sudden I actually start to do it.

293
00:15:29.030 --> 00:15:31.300
And now, I actually go ahead and

294
00:15:31.300 --> 00:15:35.160
everything is done in a span
of time very quickly instead.

295
00:15:36.230 --> 00:15:41.180
And let's say that what ended
up happening here is that

296
00:15:41.180 --> 00:15:45.410
these things really kind of just
got squished together instead.

297
00:15:46.680 --> 00:15:49.680
So now, here it is,
we're on week seven of ten.

298
00:15:49.680 --> 00:15:52.540
And I went through all 42 points and
I still have two weeks left.

299
00:15:52.540 --> 00:15:56.257
Well, I kinda realize something here
that it did take me 42 weeks but

300
00:15:56.257 --> 00:15:57.896
now I'm ahead of time as well.

301
00:15:57.896 --> 00:16:01.678
So it gives us that ability then,
when we start to take a look at the idea,

302
00:16:01.678 --> 00:16:05.770
the burn down A chart to see how quickly
we're actually going through all those

303
00:16:05.770 --> 00:16:08.560
requirements or we're doing it too slowly.

304
00:16:08.560 --> 00:16:11.670
And then we bring that up inside
our daily meetings to say,

305
00:16:11.670 --> 00:16:13.550
all right well why are we behind on this?

306
00:16:13.550 --> 00:16:15.870
Why aren't we actually
doing what we need to?

307
00:16:15.870 --> 00:16:18.540
And then you can actually
do it the other way too.

308
00:16:18.540 --> 00:16:23.600
So, sometimes you end up finding out that
something didn't take you as long but

309
00:16:23.600 --> 00:16:26.470
that yet, you're still not burning
through the way that you need to.

310
00:16:26.470 --> 00:16:28.740
Let's say that this is five points and

311
00:16:28.740 --> 00:16:31.640
then this actually ended
up being five points here.

312
00:16:31.640 --> 00:16:32.550
And now you go, wait a minute.

313
00:16:32.550 --> 00:16:34.590
There's supposed to be
42 points of effort.

314
00:16:34.590 --> 00:16:37.760
Either I'm not putting as much
time into what I need to and

315
00:16:37.760 --> 00:16:40.670
I'm burning through all
the stories again but

316
00:16:40.670 --> 00:16:43.450
I'm still not actually getting
the amount of work I need.

317
00:16:43.450 --> 00:16:47.630
So, it's a quick graphical way for
you to be able to tell that, or for

318
00:16:47.630 --> 00:16:52.220
the scrum master to be able to tell that,
and be able to help to kind of redirect

319
00:16:52.220 --> 00:16:54.680
that energy and
that focus to where it needs to be.

320
00:16:54.680 --> 00:16:55.780
>> I like this concept-
>> So these are very important.

321
00:16:57.120 --> 00:17:00.340
>> Doesn't look too unfamiliar to us,
because you showed us a method in which

322
00:17:00.340 --> 00:17:03.840
we could go ahead and plan out our
budget in a very similar way, so.

323
00:17:03.840 --> 00:17:04.650
>> Yeah, right.

324
00:17:04.650 --> 00:17:08.080
It kind of all falls in the same way
because there we actually talked about

325
00:17:08.080 --> 00:17:12.530
the idea of burn rate instead where we've
talked about how much money is spent,

326
00:17:12.530 --> 00:17:16.840
and if we take that ratio right of actual
money spent versus the earned value,

327
00:17:16.840 --> 00:17:18.690
and the ratio is greater than one,

328
00:17:18.690 --> 00:17:22.640
well then we know we've actually
spent too much money too quickly.

329
00:17:22.640 --> 00:17:23.770
If there's less,

330
00:17:23.770 --> 00:17:26.600
that means we didn't spent enough
in the time that we needed to.

331
00:17:26.600 --> 00:17:30.330
The goal there is actually have a ratio
of one to one where earned value and,

332
00:17:30.330 --> 00:17:32.470
of course, actual cost are the same.

333
00:17:32.470 --> 00:17:35.748
So this does work along that same formula
and if I remember right, in that show I

334
00:17:35.748 --> 00:17:38.976
said you got to be careful here because
later on we're going to talk about burn

335
00:17:38.976 --> 00:17:42.329
down charts which we think is gonna be
the same, but it's not exactly the same.

336
00:17:42.329 --> 00:17:46.636
>> So don't get those two terms confused,
but they have a very similar,

337
00:17:46.636 --> 00:17:49.849
they help you identify any
kind of time management or

338
00:17:49.849 --> 00:17:53.734
if you're over budget under
budget with either money or time.

339
00:17:53.734 --> 00:17:58.378
>> Yup and that brings us to our last
of our basics that we need to talk

340
00:17:58.378 --> 00:18:03.367
about as well which is what is called
the scrum retrospective I can't

341
00:18:03.367 --> 00:18:05.880
actually say the word correctly.

342
00:18:05.880 --> 00:18:08.910
Let me make sure I'm saying that,
yeah scrum retrospective.

343
00:18:08.910 --> 00:18:12.610
Now when I say scrum retrospective
you may go I've never heard of that.

344
00:18:12.610 --> 00:18:17.250
And the reason why is that most
project management books and

345
00:18:17.250 --> 00:18:21.040
you know software designer books
that go through this type of method

346
00:18:21.040 --> 00:18:23.940
they call them Sprint retrospectives.

347
00:18:23.940 --> 00:18:25.700
This is a fairly important part

348
00:18:27.150 --> 00:18:31.360
of dealing in the method of
using Agile methodology here.

349
00:18:31.360 --> 00:18:36.883
This is the time where you can actually
start to implement changes in the overall

350
00:18:36.883 --> 00:18:42.700
team behavior itself, and the the team
culture itself it needs to be.

351
00:18:42.700 --> 00:18:44.390
Now what do I mean by that?

352
00:18:44.390 --> 00:18:47.570
Well, the story then in
the retrospectives are not so

353
00:18:47.570 --> 00:18:53.310
much about what needs to be done
in terms of the backlog okay?

354
00:18:53.310 --> 00:18:58.970
In this type of retrospective the focus
is on how the team is working together.

355
00:19:00.330 --> 00:19:07.010
And the focus is on how the team members
actually individually work themselves.

356
00:19:07.010 --> 00:19:08.310
Now, why is that important?

357
00:19:08.310 --> 00:19:10.250
Well in that two week sprint right,

358
00:19:10.250 --> 00:19:15.800
everything has to gel together to
make that deliverable possible.

359
00:19:15.800 --> 00:19:20.570
So, what you may do is that there may
be a point in time in which you go,

360
00:19:20.570 --> 00:19:23.800
you know,
I just noticed something about Ronnie.

361
00:19:23.800 --> 00:19:27.150
Every 15 minutes he does
this weird thing and

362
00:19:27.150 --> 00:19:31.480
it's causing him to delay and
I need to help him out by saying,

363
00:19:31.480 --> 00:19:35.080
this is actually an extra step that you're
adding in that we really don't need.

364
00:19:35.080 --> 00:19:38.500
So in that particular time, during
the retrospective meeting, remember,

365
00:19:38.500 --> 00:19:41.080
we're not talking about
the tasks that need to be done.

366
00:19:41.080 --> 00:19:43.410
We all know what the tasks
that need to be done, but

367
00:19:43.410 --> 00:19:44.560
now we're really trying to do what?

368
00:19:44.560 --> 00:19:48.270
We're trying to help each other,
okay, by saying,

369
00:19:48.270 --> 00:19:51.960
here's what needs to be done
a bit more efficiently, okay?

370
00:19:51.960 --> 00:19:55.490
Here's how we are working together,
or how we aren't working together.

371
00:19:55.490 --> 00:19:59.110
If one reason or another,
Ronnie is just being a primadonna.

372
00:19:59.110 --> 00:20:00.890
Hopefully that doesn't happen, ever.

373
00:20:00.890 --> 00:20:04.390
But Ronnie is just being
a primadonna.about this, it is that time

374
00:20:04.390 --> 00:20:09.335
during that meting where the scrum master
can say we need to deal with this now and

375
00:20:09.335 --> 00:20:10.965
let's make sure we get this on hand.

376
00:20:10.965 --> 00:20:14.165
>> So Ronnie, would I go ahead and
wait until after that two-week duration,

377
00:20:14.165 --> 00:20:15.765
that sprint has been completed?

378
00:20:15.765 --> 00:20:18.935
Or if I saw a problem that was
happening and I wanted to address

379
00:20:18.935 --> 00:20:22.575
it immediately could I just go ahead and
call for one of these meetings?

380
00:20:22.575 --> 00:20:25.835
>> And once again,
you wouldn't call for it yourself.

381
00:20:25.835 --> 00:20:27.250
It's not like a time out.

382
00:20:27.250 --> 00:20:29.415
>> [LAUGH]
>> You tend to go to your scrum master and

383
00:20:29.415 --> 00:20:33.970
say we need to change this and then that's
when you do call for or he calls for

384
00:20:33.970 --> 00:20:37.230
a meeting and it could be during the
middle of that project where you call for

385
00:20:37.230 --> 00:20:38.660
this retrospective.

386
00:20:38.660 --> 00:20:41.520
And you say here's what I'm
noticing is that Ronnie keeps

387
00:20:41.520 --> 00:20:45.320
repeating this process over and
it's delaying us in getting things done

388
00:20:45.320 --> 00:20:49.882
because he keeps doing it like four times
instead of the you know, once or twice or

389
00:20:49.882 --> 00:20:54.440
Ronnie keeps holding everything so
that we actually have to wait on him.

390
00:20:54.440 --> 00:20:57.540
Whatever it might be,
it's something that has to be addressed.

391
00:20:57.540 --> 00:20:59.950
And so,
the big difference between that, and

392
00:20:59.950 --> 00:21:01.440
what we're talking about
in a daily meeting.

393
00:21:01.440 --> 00:21:04.580
Daily meetings are about
what has to be done, right?

394
00:21:04.580 --> 00:21:07.230
This meeting is really
about how is it done?

395
00:21:07.230 --> 00:21:11.210
How is it that Ronnie's working on this,
and then how is he gelling in with

396
00:21:11.210 --> 00:21:15.100
the actual team members, And
is it working or is it not?

397
00:21:15.100 --> 00:21:17.210
If it is working, then fine.

398
00:21:17.210 --> 00:21:21.330
If some tweaks need to be done, this is
the time for you to think about that and

399
00:21:21.330 --> 00:21:26.170
make sure that we go ahead and we adjust
them before we continue on with the work.

400
00:21:26.170 --> 00:21:28.330
And now Cherokee is pulling her hair out,

401
00:21:28.330 --> 00:21:33.390
because Ronnie is still doing the same
old pattern and he is not changing, and

402
00:21:33.390 --> 00:21:36.535
it's now not only driving Cherokee nuts,
but everybody else on the team.

403
00:21:36.535 --> 00:21:38.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's driving them nuts.

404
00:21:38.060 --> 00:21:40.020
And they just,
they won't say anything, okay?

405
00:21:40.020 --> 00:21:41.680
And they won't say anything about it.

406
00:21:41.680 --> 00:21:44.770
But the idea of what Agile says is,

407
00:21:44.770 --> 00:21:48.190
if we need to we'll have
a meeting on it very quickly, why?

408
00:21:48.190 --> 00:21:52.830
Because Agile is designed for us to be
able to change if we need to very quickly.

409
00:21:52.830 --> 00:21:55.590
And we offer as much help
as we need to quickly.

410
00:21:55.590 --> 00:22:00.160
We don't tell to get rid of people just
because they, you know, they're different.

411
00:22:00.160 --> 00:22:04.060
We tend to try and go all right, remember
what we're focused in on and here's some

412
00:22:04.060 --> 00:22:07.970
of the changes that really need to be done
so that we can be a bit more efficient or

413
00:22:07.970 --> 00:22:11.230
to help Ronnie out because he's really
falling behind on these tasks and

414
00:22:11.230 --> 00:22:14.010
that's really what the idea
of the retrospective's about.

415
00:22:14.010 --> 00:22:18.540
So just kind of realize that Agile
is a very good possibility for us.

416
00:22:18.540 --> 00:22:23.250
As far as considering another methodology,
besides the waterfall methodology.

417
00:22:23.250 --> 00:22:28.440
It's just one of many, but it is the one
that the CompTIA Project+ does call out.

418
00:22:28.440 --> 00:22:31.900
So make sure you take a look at the basics
that we've just been talking about.

419
00:22:31.900 --> 00:22:33.210
>> Yes thank you so much Ronnie.

420
00:22:33.210 --> 00:22:35.410
We've been able to go ahead and
look at those scrum meetings,

421
00:22:35.410 --> 00:22:36.670
those daily stand ups.

422
00:22:36.670 --> 00:22:40.810
We also took a look at how they differ
from our actual scrum retrospective

423
00:22:40.810 --> 00:22:46.150
meetings and we also saw your burn down
methodology where we had our effort points

424
00:22:46.150 --> 00:22:50.120
and how they were important in helping
manage the effort that's put forth for

425
00:22:50.120 --> 00:22:51.890
these individual sprints.

426
00:22:51.890 --> 00:22:55.440
So, stay tuned guys, we have a lot
more Project+ coming your way.

427
00:22:55.440 --> 00:22:57.600
Thank you for tuning in,
I'm Cherokee Boose.

428
00:22:57.600 --> 00:22:58.700
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

429
00:22:58.700 --> 00:23:00.854
>> Signing off.

430
00:23:00.854 --> 00:23:06.530
[MUSIC]

431
00:23:06.530 --> 00:23:10.215
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Cherokee and Ronnie talk about Resource management. First Ronnie delineates between Human, Equipment and Material resources. Next we learn how to identify shared or dedicated resources. Ronnie shows some tools to help us prevent resource shortage and over-allocation to prevent utilizing benched resources.
episodes.title: Explain Resource Management Roles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:01.909
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm you host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:01.909 --> 00:00:08.960
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.960 --> 00:00:10.782
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.782 --> 00:00:16.860
>> Welcome to another CompTIA Project Plus
episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.860 --> 00:00:18.684
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.684 --> 00:00:24.780
In this episode, we're gonna be looking at
explaining our project management roles.

7
00:00:24.780 --> 00:00:26.790
And here to help us with that, we have Mr.

8
00:00:26.790 --> 00:00:29.040
Ronnie Wong, thank you for
being here today Ronnie.

9
00:00:29.040 --> 00:00:32.160
>> Well thank you for having me back on
this show as we continue on to take a look

10
00:00:32.160 --> 00:00:34.550
at more of the CompTIA Project Plus.

11
00:00:34.550 --> 00:00:38.780
Especially in the area of
resource management roles.

12
00:00:38.780 --> 00:00:43.350
Now, we have to actually be very careful
here, as we now have everything ready for

13
00:00:43.350 --> 00:00:47.530
the planning stages, we've gotta remember
that, the schedule is not enough for

14
00:00:47.530 --> 00:00:49.410
us to keep everything on track.

15
00:00:49.410 --> 00:00:55.440
We also need to have an understanding of
the way that resources are actually used,

16
00:00:55.440 --> 00:00:59.560
and how we can actually assign them and
manage them a bit better.

17
00:00:59.560 --> 00:01:01.366
So that's
>> What type of resources might we

18
00:01:01.366 --> 00:01:02.136
encounter?

19
00:01:02.136 --> 00:01:05.435
>> That's a great question here so
as we start to take a look right,

20
00:01:05.435 --> 00:01:09.346
that we have multiple resources you've
got to remember that every resource

21
00:01:09.346 --> 00:01:11.180
is not gonna to be the same.

22
00:01:11.180 --> 00:01:15.170
So, what we'd like to thank in project
manifestation while we're new at it,

23
00:01:15.170 --> 00:01:20.750
is that a project that we're assigned
to write has a fresh can of resources.

24
00:01:20.750 --> 00:01:22.760
It's like we open the door and

25
00:01:22.760 --> 00:01:27.790
then everything is actually a fresh and
real and I have everything that I need.

26
00:01:27.790 --> 00:01:31.230
What you're gonna end up finding out
in reality, the majority of the time,

27
00:01:31.230 --> 00:01:32.800
not gonna say every time.

28
00:01:32.800 --> 00:01:37.080
Is that you rarely have everything that
you need during the planning stage, and

29
00:01:37.080 --> 00:01:39.550
that means there's a lot of things
that have to get coordinated and

30
00:01:39.550 --> 00:01:40.690
gathered together.

31
00:01:40.690 --> 00:01:44.110
And the types of resources that we tend
to have to deal with are things like,

32
00:01:44.110 --> 00:01:46.430
what we call, material resources.

33
00:01:46.430 --> 00:01:49.460
It's equipment as well as human resources,
too.

34
00:01:49.460 --> 00:01:53.520
And then we have sub-varieties of each one
of those that we have to realize, okay?

35
00:01:53.520 --> 00:01:56.253
But let's make sure we go over an
explanation of what each one of those are.

36
00:01:56.253 --> 00:01:59.490
They're fairly self-explanatory, but
let's make sure we understand why they're

37
00:01:59.490 --> 00:02:02.130
actually that important
that we keep track of them.

38
00:02:02.130 --> 00:02:04.590
First, when we talk about
the idea of equipment,

39
00:02:04.590 --> 00:02:06.940
that's kind of the easiest one, okay.

40
00:02:06.940 --> 00:02:09.870
Equipment is something that
we tend dash to use, and

41
00:02:09.870 --> 00:02:13.440
we're able to reuse again in our project,
okay.

42
00:02:13.440 --> 00:02:16.770
So that's actually very good, that's
something that we like to have on hand.

43
00:02:16.770 --> 00:02:19.780
Because having the right
equipment at the right time

44
00:02:19.780 --> 00:02:24.650
allows us to go to accomplish our project
task, well, in a very timely manner and

45
00:02:24.650 --> 00:02:27.710
usually in a fairly cost
efficient manner as well.

46
00:02:27.710 --> 00:02:31.270
There is also, of course,
material resources.

47
00:02:31.270 --> 00:02:35.830
Now, when you compare equipment
resources versus material resources

48
00:02:35.830 --> 00:02:40.630
in this sense well, the difference
here is that material resources tend

49
00:02:40.630 --> 00:02:44.060
to be consumed during your project.

50
00:02:44.060 --> 00:02:45.590
So you may find out, let's say for

51
00:02:45.590 --> 00:02:50.320
example, if you're in the construction
realm of managing a project.

52
00:02:50.320 --> 00:02:53.382
What you may have to actually do
is you may have to buy lumber.

53
00:02:53.382 --> 00:02:59.570
I was trying to think of the right word,
I couldn't remember what it was, right.

54
00:02:59.570 --> 00:03:03.200
So you may actually have to buy
lumber to build, the actual

55
00:03:03.200 --> 00:03:06.860
project of a home that your construction,
or whatever it might be, okay.

56
00:03:06.860 --> 00:03:09.880
What that resource is gonna
be used up in the building.

57
00:03:09.880 --> 00:03:11.970
So that resource is not gonna
be available next week,

58
00:03:11.970 --> 00:03:15.230
you might have to buy more resources,
to actually compensate for that.

59
00:03:15.230 --> 00:03:18.270
If you're pouring a foundation,
it's the idea of something like concrete.

60
00:03:18.270 --> 00:03:20.090
It's gonna be used as a consumable.

61
00:03:20.090 --> 00:03:22.830
As you start to do this,
other things are also conceivable.

62
00:03:22.830 --> 00:03:25.910
Usually, we don't track it down to this
level, but if you want to you can.

63
00:03:25.910 --> 00:03:31.890
Things like nails that somebody might
actually be using inside of that.

64
00:03:31.890 --> 00:03:36.236
Of caulk for
installing other things here, right.

65
00:03:36.236 --> 00:03:39.400
A wallpaper, glue, and
all these are consumables and

66
00:03:39.400 --> 00:03:41.290
things that we don't tend to think about.

67
00:03:41.290 --> 00:03:43.260
But they are actually gonna be used up.

68
00:03:43.260 --> 00:03:47.230
And then of course there is finally
the realm of human resources.

69
00:03:47.230 --> 00:03:49.830
Which is normally where we tend to spend

70
00:03:49.830 --> 00:03:53.570
the majority of our time when we
start talking about resources.

71
00:03:53.570 --> 00:03:57.870
Cuz that is by far the most complex

00:03:57.870 --> 00:04:01.700
Because those things, those particular

Always variable in many factors,

So there's a lot of

78
00:04:18.630 --> 00:04:21.960

00:04:21.960 --> 00:04:24.736
Those are, by far, the most generic

00:04:24.736 --> 00:04:25.539
>> [LAUGH] Ronnie,

if you choose to, right?

00:04:50.260 --> 00:04:52.730
that you're actually saying I

to actually try and maintain that is sort

00:05:07.450 --> 00:05:10.540
in trying to keep track,
it really is, it's more like that.

00:05:10.540 --> 00:05:11.070
Can it be done?

00:05:11.070 --> 00:05:12.750
Yeah.
Because people play fantasy football and

00:05:12.750 --> 00:05:15.760

this in their heads.

00:05:15.760 --> 00:05:17.885
I couldn't do this if you

00:05:17.885 --> 00:05:20.250
a program to do it but other people can.

00:05:20.250 --> 00:05:23.550
So, you can keep track of it that way,
okay, if you chose to.

100
00:05:23.550 --> 00:05:26.550
But the breakdown that we also
have with those resources,

101
00:05:26.550 --> 00:05:30.390
right, is not just the very
fact that they exist and

00:05:30.390 --> 00:05:34.580
what I've talked about as far as their

00:05:34.580 --> 00:05:38.710
But it's also the very fact that
resources, as far as a project goes,

00:05:38.710 --> 00:05:43.060

general types of resources.

00:05:43.060 --> 00:05:46.360
And they're actually considered

00:05:46.360 --> 00:05:48.340
shared resources at this point.

00:05:48.340 --> 00:05:51.940
So you do need to pay attention when

00:05:51.940 --> 00:05:54.220
So Cherokee, just for a moment here.

00:05:54.220 --> 00:05:57.150

00:05:57.150 --> 00:05:59.010

00:06:00.320 --> 00:06:01.040
>> Yeah.

113
00:06:01.040 --> 00:06:02.390
I think so.

00:06:02.390 --> 00:06:04.380
If I were a dedicated resource,

00:06:04.380 --> 00:06:07.880
then I would just have one particular

00:06:07.880 --> 00:06:12.070
I wouldn't have to worry about splitting

117
00:06:12.070 --> 00:06:15.930
>> That sounds exactly right, so
right there is fairly easy so,

118
00:06:15.930 --> 00:06:20.160
this is one of those things that,

119
00:06:20.160 --> 00:06:23.780
When something like this happens

00:06:23.780 --> 00:06:26.080
let's talk about why these

121
00:06:26.080 --> 00:06:28.560

00:06:28.560 --> 00:06:30.390
Dedicated is the easy one, and

00:06:30.390 --> 00:06:34.180
this is what Cherokee was pointing at,
it was dedicated that means

00:06:34.180 --> 00:06:39.180

00:06:39.180 --> 00:06:44.030

00:06:44.030 --> 00:06:44.740

00:06:44.740 --> 00:06:46.940
And this includes things
like human resources.

128
00:06:46.940 --> 00:06:50.660
If somebody is assigned to your project
team and they are a dedicated resource,

129
00:06:50.660 --> 00:06:54.450
that means you can rely on them for

00:06:54.450 --> 00:06:59.600
So if you assign them to an eight-hour

00:06:59.600 --> 00:07:04.200

00:07:04.200 --> 00:07:08.050

00:07:08.050 --> 00:07:13.900
not individual resources like humans, but

134
00:07:13.900 --> 00:07:16.080
>> Yeah.
It really can because there's a lot of

135
00:07:16.080 --> 00:07:18.490
things that don't come into to

136
00:07:18.490 --> 00:07:22.780
play when we start assigning things like

00:07:22.780 --> 00:07:26.100
Dedicated resources we have to

00:07:26.100 --> 00:07:30.680

00:07:30.680 --> 00:07:32.990

00:07:32.990 --> 00:07:35.710

00:07:35.710 --> 00:07:39.520

00:07:39.520 --> 00:07:41.700
You can run them for a good, long while.

00:07:41.700 --> 00:07:44.420
But there also needs to be
downtime in-between for

00:07:44.420 --> 00:07:46.000
maintenance and for other things.

00:07:46.000 --> 00:07:47.310
But if anything else, right, for

00:07:47.310 --> 00:07:50.720
that engine to actually have
times of rest periods as well.

00:07:50.720 --> 00:07:53.076
We talk about that because

00:07:53.076 --> 00:07:56.131
If not, you will wear out the equipment

149
00:07:56.131 --> 00:07:59.508
that piece of equipment will end up

00:07:59.508 --> 00:08:00.922

00:08:00.922 --> 00:08:03.809
So, when you start talking

00:08:03.809 --> 00:08:08.880
I need this particular piece of equipment

00:08:08.880 --> 00:08:11.169
Well, it can happen, okay?

00:08:11.169 --> 00:08:14.155
But for you to do that,
you really need two pieces of equipment.

Say, why?

156
00:08:15.015 --> 00:08:17.460
Why would I need two pieces of equipment?

157
00:08:17.460 --> 00:08:20.890
Because when,
especially in example like the generator,

158
00:08:20.890 --> 00:08:25.820
all right, If your generator is not

159
00:08:25.820 --> 00:08:29.000
that means you have to bring it down for

00:08:29.000 --> 00:08:31.540
So, when you do that, and

00:08:31.540 --> 00:08:35.200
you have to have a second one there and

162
00:08:35.200 --> 00:08:39.960
>> Yeah ,and the same goes, rings true for
any kind of, if you think about a website.

00:08:39.960 --> 00:08:42.954
Okay, a web server, and
if you have an additional web server for

00:08:42.954 --> 00:08:45.519
the high availability,
same concept applies there.

165
00:08:45.519 --> 00:08:49.970
Yeah, no doubt that in the IT world,

00:08:49.970 --> 00:08:52.044
See, this is where we come

00:08:52.044 --> 00:08:53.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> She's always focused on IT,

00:08:53.700 --> 00:08:55.860

cuz that's where I love too.

00:08:55.860 --> 00:08:59.570
But I came from the diesel mechanicing

00:08:59.570 --> 00:09:03.940

00:09:03.940 --> 00:09:09.920
So, when we were doing Hurricane Katrina

00:09:09.920 --> 00:09:13.680

And the only way we could

00:09:20.320 --> 00:09:22.660
With that little cheap

00:09:22.660 --> 00:09:26.550

00:09:26.550 --> 00:09:28.100
So, you didn't just go ahead and do that.

If you need to bring it down,

00:09:36.862 --> 00:09:38.810

00:09:38.810 --> 00:09:40.070

it is about making sure that happens

00:09:43.630 --> 00:09:47.460
So, dedicated resources, as much as

00:09:47.460 --> 00:09:49.330
you really can't to a point.

Same thing with human resources.

So, in a typical work week with human

00:09:55.340 --> 00:09:57.670
you might think, eight hours a day,

on a traditional standard type of project,
40 hours of work, right?

00:10:01.970 --> 00:10:05.380
if you assign them to that
in your project plan for

00:10:05.380 --> 00:10:08.630
40 hours of work you're not gonna
get 40 hours of work out it.

00:10:08.630 --> 00:10:10.750
You might wonder, why not?

00:10:10.750 --> 00:10:15.680
You said that the 100% Of their and

00:10:15.680 --> 00:10:18.530
But there's other things
that also go on in

00:10:18.530 --> 00:10:21.460

So let's take for an example instead

Inter-project related communications,okay?

200
00:10:35.070 --> 00:10:38.560
Updating the project plan, or
updating their particular portion

00:10:38.560 --> 00:10:39.560
>> Checking their emails

202
00:10:39.560 --> 00:10:40.380
>> Checking emails

>> Going through that morning meeting

00:10:42.170 --> 00:10:44.250
>> Yeah, all that kind of stuff, right?

And that adds up over that week and
now you said you're suppose to put in 40

00:10:48.570 --> 00:10:52.620
hours, but Ronnie when your turned in

you only turned in about 33 hours
Well that's not bad, because what we

00:10:57.470 --> 00:11:02.200

00:11:02.200 --> 00:11:03.690
And you do,
you need to make allowances for

00:11:03.690 --> 00:11:07.960

00:11:11.530 --> 00:11:15.650
So dedicated resources are great

00:11:15.650 --> 00:11:19.100
But you can't use them 100% of the time,

00:11:19.100 --> 00:11:22.460
Then of course there are what

00:11:22.460 --> 00:11:23.630
Just like what Cherokee was saying,

00:11:33.070 --> 00:11:37.320
When you start thinking about this and

For a shared resource in the sense, think

If this is a shared type of human resource

This is where Cherokee and

our intra-project or

00:12:32.040 --> 00:12:34.550
So let's say that somebody messes this up.

That's why the negotiation's

The problem is, if we try to negotiate and

>> [LAUGH]
>> No.

Don't worry about that.

00:12:51.850 --> 00:12:52.440
But, overall, though,

00:12:52.440 --> 00:12:53.960
that's what we're also thinking about,

00:12:53.960 --> 00:12:54.620

Okay?

00:12:54.620 --> 00:12:56.580
Now even though we're just

00:12:56.580 --> 00:12:58.690
the same thing has to be with equipment.

So, let's say it's the same thing here.

There is a piece of equipment

Well, this too has to be negotiated and

00:13:07.970 --> 00:13:11.730

Ronnie is gonna need this many

Well now, I can't go back to Cherokee and

Cherokee's gonna go not only

00:30:56.078 --> 00:30:58.459
That resource is

We are talking about personnel management and ways to find solutions to conflicts that may arise. Ronnie and Cherokee also discuss formal and informal team building activities. The topic of team selection is addressed and carried over to the next episode.
episodes.title: Explain Resource Management Roles Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:03.448
>> Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2

[CROSSTALK]
>> Live from San Francisco [CROSSTALK]

3

[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.346 --> 00:00:12.187
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.187 --> 00:00:15.112
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.112 --> 00:00:17.198
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.198 --> 00:00:20.537
In this episode, we're gonna be
continuing on a part two for

8
00:00:20.537 --> 00:00:22.830
explaining resource management.

9
00:00:22.830 --> 00:00:27.750
We're gonna be looking at forming,
storming, norming, performing, adjourning.

10
00:00:27.750 --> 00:00:31.313
And no, we're not rapping, we're actually
diving deeper into that resource

11
00:00:31.313 --> 00:00:34.307
management and we're gonna be
looking at personnel management.

12
00:00:34.307 --> 00:00:37.390
And who better to help us with
that than Mr. Ronnie Wong.

13
00:00:37.390 --> 00:00:39.180
Thank you for
being with us here today, Ronnie.

14
00:00:39.180 --> 00:00:39.960
>> Well, thank you for

15
00:00:39.960 --> 00:00:43.880
having me back on the show as we continue
on with our project plus show here.

16
00:00:43.880 --> 00:00:48.080
We're now taking a look into that
exciting realm of personnel management.

17
00:00:48.080 --> 00:00:49.000
That's right.

18
00:00:49.000 --> 00:00:51.746
We've already talked in that episode one,
right,

19
00:00:51.746 --> 00:00:55.650
that part one of resource management,
where we've talked about equipment, and

20
00:00:55.650 --> 00:01:00.180
material, and even a little bit of
human resource types of management.

21
00:01:00.180 --> 00:01:01.944
But when it comes down to it,

22
00:01:01.944 --> 00:01:06.282
what's gonna also end up happening
is as you bring people together for

23
00:01:06.282 --> 00:01:11.156
your project that you have in hand,
you're gonna have to realize something.

24
00:01:11.156 --> 00:01:14.550
That not everybody's worked on a project
before, and it could be that way.

25
00:01:14.550 --> 00:01:17.410
Not everybody's actually ready to
do everything that they need to.

26
00:01:17.410 --> 00:01:21.876
So you're gonna have to actually deal
with more than just the idea of resource

27
00:01:21.876 --> 00:01:24.640
availability and
allocation very many times.

28
00:01:24.640 --> 00:01:28.040
And now what you're talking about is
multiple people coming together and

29
00:01:28.040 --> 00:01:31.380
we have to be able to get all
those different personalities,

30
00:01:31.380 --> 00:01:36.790
all the other things that they're used
to doing to work together as a team.

31
00:01:36.790 --> 00:01:38.570
And that is what we're
really talking about.

32
00:01:38.570 --> 00:01:41.965
And so there's some challenges there,
that we really need to get through.

33
00:01:41.965 --> 00:01:44.480
>> Ronnie, what are those big challenges
that you're talking about there?

34
00:01:44.480 --> 00:01:47.826
With the team building, it seem there
could be potentially room for quite a few.

35
00:01:47.826 --> 00:01:50.910
There's a lot of different challenges,
and not all of them are,

36
00:01:50.910 --> 00:01:52.828
of course, just personality-based.

37
00:01:52.828 --> 00:01:54.845
But especially [LAUGH] if
you're working with me,

38
00:01:54.845 --> 00:01:57.040
they're probably going
to be personality-based.

39
00:01:57.040 --> 00:02:01.200
But overall, though, what you tend to see
is there's actually location challenges.

40
00:02:01.200 --> 00:02:05.690
If your project is large and you now
actually have to manage multiple location

41
00:02:05.690 --> 00:02:10.130
sites because of how big your project is,
remember that means coordination efforts

42
00:02:10.130 --> 00:02:14.760
between those projects to actually carry
on in what you also have to be able to do.

43
00:02:14.760 --> 00:02:18.490
Also realizing the resource allocation
when you're working with full and

44
00:02:18.490 --> 00:02:20.220
part time resource as well,

45
00:02:20.220 --> 00:02:23.685
may also have to be considered
when you realize that there it is.

46
00:02:23.685 --> 00:02:27.310
You're on the weekend and what you don't
have access to is full time resources.

47
00:02:27.310 --> 00:02:28.860
You have access to only part-time

48
00:02:28.860 --> 00:02:30.890
resources that are actually
willing to work.

49
00:02:30.890 --> 00:02:34.460
And then you might even have
the difference between technical people

50
00:02:34.460 --> 00:02:37.262
that are really very good
at what they're doing, and

51
00:02:37.262 --> 00:02:41.190
then non-technical people that are more
administrative support as well.

52
00:02:41.190 --> 00:02:42.350
And realizing you're not gonna be

53
00:02:42.350 --> 00:02:45.628
able to assign some of those to technical
challenges that you have on hand.

54
00:02:45.628 --> 00:02:50.460
Temporary, you know ideas that you have
instead of someone that's actually

55
00:02:50.460 --> 00:02:51.810
gonna come in and do a lot.

56
00:02:51.810 --> 00:02:55.360
They may come in just for a specific part,
and you name it, there's all of that.

57
00:02:55.360 --> 00:02:58.780
So what we have to be able to do is
understand that there's the challenge of

58
00:02:58.780 --> 00:03:00.480
just those things.

59
00:03:00.480 --> 00:03:04.260
But the key for us, especially if we're
going to be doing project management,

60
00:03:04.260 --> 00:03:08.170
is to form and
to develop a great project team.

61
00:03:08.170 --> 00:03:12.975
And that entire list of what Cherokee
made out as being rapping words for

62
00:03:12.975 --> 00:03:17.460
us is actually gonna be some of
the key ideas to helping us to develop

63
00:03:17.460 --> 00:03:22.366
the team and to understand team
development is what we really need to do.

64
00:03:22.366 --> 00:03:24.040
And so that's what we're gonna go through.

65
00:03:24.040 --> 00:03:28.710
We're gonna talk about each one of
those different aspects of team

66
00:03:28.710 --> 00:03:33.070
developmental phases to help us to
understand how a team gets formed and

67
00:03:33.070 --> 00:03:36.730
why we need to understand something
like this in project management.

68
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:39.740
It's because we tend to pull from
a lot of technical backgrounds.

69
00:03:39.740 --> 00:03:42.660
We tend to pull from a lot of
different groups of people and

70
00:03:42.660 --> 00:03:46.880
individuals which might be used to
actually being like the top dog and

71
00:03:46.880 --> 00:03:48.510
here they might not be the top dog.

72
00:03:48.510 --> 00:03:50.920
And now they have to
work with someone else.

73
00:03:50.920 --> 00:03:51.989
So that's where we're going.

74
00:03:51.989 --> 00:03:55.129
And so we're gonna have to take
a look at all of those different,

75
00:03:55.129 --> 00:03:59.110
make sure I've counted right,
five phases that we actually have to do.

76
00:03:59.110 --> 00:04:01.870
So let's start off with the one
that Cherokee started off with.

77
00:04:01.870 --> 00:04:03.820
Cherokee, do you remember the very
first one that you mentioned?

78
00:04:03.820 --> 00:04:06.930
>> Of course I do, that was forming
>> All right, so

79
00:04:06.930 --> 00:04:07.810
let's go ahead and take a look.

80
00:04:07.810 --> 00:04:09.970
This way this helps us out.

81
00:04:09.970 --> 00:04:11.190
So we take a look at my computer.

82
00:04:11.190 --> 00:04:14.365
I kind of just did a summary of
some of the things that we really

83
00:04:14.365 --> 00:04:18.240
wanna make sure that we understand
when we start to take a look here.

84
00:04:18.240 --> 00:04:22.300
The idea of forming at this
particular point in time,

85
00:04:22.300 --> 00:04:25.340
okay, is that really
it comes down to this.

86
00:04:25.340 --> 00:04:27.920
When you bring a bunch of
different people together

87
00:04:27.920 --> 00:04:32.200
that have not worked together before,
they really have to understand

88
00:04:32.200 --> 00:04:37.140
the very beginning of why in the world
they're working together for this project.

89
00:04:37.140 --> 00:04:41.280
So they're not really a team yet
at this particular point, but what they're

90
00:04:41.280 --> 00:04:47.080
actually here to do is to understand,
hey, this is why we're gathered together.

91
00:04:47.080 --> 00:04:51.320
And here you get this kind of unusual
psychological sense of the group,

92
00:04:51.320 --> 00:04:54.490
where not everybody feels comfortable,
okay.

93
00:04:54.490 --> 00:04:59.050
And a lot of times the very beginning,
and the very first few meetings,

94
00:04:59.050 --> 00:05:02.810
people are more formal and
they're more reserved and

95
00:05:02.810 --> 00:05:07.180
usually very businesslike,
because they're not sure what to expect.

96
00:05:07.180 --> 00:05:10.590
They're not sure if this is something
that's gonna be relaxing, or

97
00:05:10.590 --> 00:05:12.140
if it's something that's
gonna be very formal.

98
00:05:13.150 --> 00:05:16.919
Nobody wants to actually get themselves
portrayed as someone that can't

99
00:05:16.919 --> 00:05:17.533
do the job.

100
00:05:17.533 --> 00:05:18.386
>> Slacker.

101
00:05:18.386 --> 00:05:22.190
>> Yeah, they don't wanna be
portrayed as the slacker as well.

102
00:05:22.190 --> 00:05:24.552
And so when you have stuff like this,

103
00:05:24.552 --> 00:05:28.130
you've gotta realize that these are the
attitudes that's gonna come together

104
00:05:28.130 --> 00:05:30.440
in the idea of building the team, okay.

105
00:05:30.440 --> 00:05:33.070
It's that they're going to
just kind of look around and

106
00:05:33.070 --> 00:05:37.970
see who do you think is ready for this,
who they don't think is ready for it.

107
00:05:37.970 --> 00:05:42.460
And you hate to say it, there does become
just in that natural group together,

108
00:05:42.460 --> 00:05:44.810
a pecking order that
will end up happening.

109
00:05:44.810 --> 00:05:48.830
>> It's just kind of a human nature,
it's not something that we, I mean people,

110
00:05:48.830 --> 00:05:53.510
it's very hard to not form any kind
of judgments but it happens, right?

111
00:05:53.510 --> 00:05:57.790
>> It really does happen and there is
issues that you have to deal with.

112
00:05:57.790 --> 00:06:02.660
But you do have to let it happen
naturally, and allow them to actually see

113
00:06:02.660 --> 00:06:05.770
because that's where you really
want your leadership to come from.

114
00:06:05.770 --> 00:06:08.970
It's not so much you just pointing out
someone and go, you're going to lead this.

115
00:06:08.970 --> 00:06:10.180
And everybody around the room goes,

116
00:06:10.180 --> 00:06:12.530
there's no way that guy is
gonna be able to do that.

117
00:06:12.530 --> 00:06:15.870
Now don't get me wrong, people have
always been able to overcome and

118
00:06:15.870 --> 00:06:19.120
actually do the things that
they've been called on to do.

119
00:06:19.120 --> 00:06:23.638
But if you allow them that possibility to
step up and to shine on their own rather

120
00:06:23.638 --> 00:06:28.103
than you appointing them, they become
a natural type of leader in the group.

121
00:06:28.103 --> 00:06:32.635
Now in that sense, when I talk about that
idea of natural leader in the group,

122
00:06:32.635 --> 00:06:36.820
that is what starts to happen when you
leave them together long enough so

123
00:06:36.820 --> 00:06:40.650
that they realize they're
gonna be working together.

124
00:06:40.650 --> 00:06:45.150
And the phase that we end up taking a look
at at that particular point in time

125
00:06:45.150 --> 00:06:49.660
is one that we call storming,
is what we call it at this point.

126
00:06:49.660 --> 00:06:52.280
Now in the idea of storming here,

127
00:06:52.280 --> 00:06:57.500
this is where somebody really is, we call
it the idea here of alpha positioning.

128
00:06:57.500 --> 00:07:03.300
They want to find out who in this
group is gonna be the top guy, okay?

129
00:07:04.970 --> 00:07:08.770
Now I'm gonna press Cherokee's
movie knowledge here,

130
00:07:08.770 --> 00:07:12.668
have you ever seen the movie Top Gun?

131
00:07:12.668 --> 00:07:13.783
>> That was ages ago.

132
00:07:13.783 --> 00:07:15.425
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, you were probably very young.

133
00:07:15.425 --> 00:07:19.110
I'm gonna assume you were very,
very young when you saw the movie Top Gun.

134
00:07:19.110 --> 00:07:22.220
And so if you actually saw it at all,
you may not have even seen it at all,

135
00:07:22.220 --> 00:07:23.170
for all I know.

136
00:07:23.170 --> 00:07:24.650
But in the movie Top Gun, right,

137
00:07:24.650 --> 00:07:28.290
these are supposed to be the best of
the best, according to the movie.

138
00:07:28.290 --> 00:07:31.000
And so everybody as they're
actually gathered there,

139
00:07:31.000 --> 00:07:33.330
they're all looking around.

140
00:07:33.330 --> 00:07:37.665
And Tom Cruise's character, of course,
is just looking around and says, or

141
00:07:37.665 --> 00:07:38.847
one of the guys says,

142
00:07:38.847 --> 00:07:42.737
I'm just trying to figure out who's
the best of the best in this room.

143
00:07:42.737 --> 00:07:47.280
And, of course, they all answer it's me,
it's me, it's me.

144
00:07:47.280 --> 00:07:51.360
Well, even though all of them may
believe that, you'll actually

145
00:07:51.360 --> 00:07:54.670
end up seeing somebody jockeying for
that position is what you'll see.

146
00:07:54.670 --> 00:07:56.435
So they call it alpha positioning here.

147
00:07:56.435 --> 00:07:57.680
>> Okay.
>> Where they really are,

148
00:07:57.680 --> 00:08:00.260
they're standing up and saying yes
>> A storms a brewing,

149
00:08:00.260 --> 00:08:04.233
we've got that terminology we can relate
it to some kind of associations there.

150
00:08:04.233 --> 00:08:06.769
>> Well, and this is where they
can become confrontational.

151
00:08:06.769 --> 00:08:09.589
If you go no, I'm actually going to
be the leader and And that guy goes,

152
00:08:09.589 --> 00:08:11.060
I'm gonna be the leader.

153
00:08:11.060 --> 00:08:12.957
Well, that's when they
will challenge that.

154
00:08:12.957 --> 00:08:16.842
So it's the same in the animal world where
you have something like this going on.

155
00:08:16.842 --> 00:08:20.520
But storming is a very natural
part of when groups come together.

156
00:08:20.520 --> 00:08:22.530
>> And then they've gotta hash
it all out together, right?

157
00:08:22.530 --> 00:08:25.640
>> Yep, and that's the idea of
jockeying for control, all right?

158
00:08:25.640 --> 00:08:28.460
So it's not enough just so
you're the alpha,

159
00:08:28.460 --> 00:08:33.320
you really do have to be able to have
also the same time, charisma, or

160
00:08:33.320 --> 00:08:38.470
enough personality and enough influence
in that group that has just formed,

161
00:08:38.470 --> 00:08:42.290
that you actually can
now control that group.

162
00:08:42.290 --> 00:08:45.120
And I don't mean by control
by twisting them, but

163
00:08:45.120 --> 00:08:51.460
to have enough influence in that group to
now begin to try and line everybody up.

164
00:08:51.460 --> 00:08:53.470
Without the idea of forming going on,

165
00:08:53.470 --> 00:08:57.040
where they get used to each
other's presence first, okay?

166
00:08:57.040 --> 00:09:01.050
And then feeling comfortable enough to
then establish whatever is going to

167
00:09:01.050 --> 00:09:02.210
happen here, okay?

168
00:09:02.210 --> 00:09:05.820
And who's actually going to end up being
kind of the natural leader in the group,

169
00:09:05.820 --> 00:09:11.560
you're gonna find your team always
relying on you as the project manager

170
00:09:11.560 --> 00:09:16.980
to step in to actually challenge
whatever somebody says.

171
00:09:16.980 --> 00:09:20.260
And this is not what you want
to happen when you form a team.

172
00:09:20.260 --> 00:09:24.340
You as a project manager,
you should say you're a team, you do this.

173
00:09:24.340 --> 00:09:26.070
You figure this out.

174
00:09:26.070 --> 00:09:27.440
You all set this up.

175
00:09:27.440 --> 00:09:30.430
Because you as a project manager,
you're not only managing that team, right?

176
00:09:30.430 --> 00:09:33.110
You're having to actually
oversee multiple teams.

177
00:09:33.110 --> 00:09:35.870
Well, if you're actually the one
that says all right, here it is,

178
00:09:35.870 --> 00:09:38.220
Cherokee, you're going to do this, okay?

179
00:09:38.220 --> 00:09:40.170
And then somebody in the group goes, well,

180
00:09:40.170 --> 00:09:42.810
I don't know why I wasn't considered,
okay?

181
00:09:42.810 --> 00:09:44.610
Why wasn't I considered for that?

182
00:09:44.610 --> 00:09:47.234
And then every decision that Cherokee
makes that he disagrees with,

183
00:09:47.234 --> 00:09:50.660
he doesn't go to Cherokee,
even though that's who he should go to,

184
00:09:50.660 --> 00:09:54.650
he just simply oversteps Cherokee and
says, here's what I think should happen.

185
00:09:54.650 --> 00:09:56.900
Cherokee said this is the way it's
gonna be, and I can always say,

186
00:09:56.900 --> 00:10:01.200
what Cherokee says is good,
and that's the way it goes.

187
00:10:01.200 --> 00:10:04.870
Well, then that person goes back and
does what starts to kind of grumble and

188
00:10:04.870 --> 00:10:07.240
starts to complain a bit more.

189
00:10:07.240 --> 00:10:12.390
And then even though Cherokee is the
leader in terms of title that I presented,

190
00:10:12.390 --> 00:10:16.570
every decision that she makes that's
being disagreed with, gets challenged.

191
00:10:16.570 --> 00:10:19.230
And then I had to come back in or
somebody has to come back in and

192
00:10:19.230 --> 00:10:22.790
go, all right here it is, here's the way
it's gonna be, you all better follow this.

193
00:10:22.790 --> 00:10:25.070
Next decision comes along,
they'll do the same thing.

194
00:10:25.070 --> 00:10:27.740
>> But ultimately it does come
down to that project manager's

195
00:10:27.740 --> 00:10:28.760
responsibility, right?

196
00:10:28.760 --> 00:10:30.440
So they have to go ahead and take control.

197
00:10:30.440 --> 00:10:34.200
If they see a leader that's maybe not
getting the respect that they need,

198
00:10:34.200 --> 00:10:37.160
then they're gonna have to
make that judgement call.

199
00:10:37.160 --> 00:10:38.650
>> That is definitely true.

200
00:10:38.650 --> 00:10:41.010
The very fact is, it is a responsibility.

201
00:10:41.010 --> 00:10:43.980
But imagine having to do that for
six teams, okay?

202
00:10:43.980 --> 00:10:46.340
That every time that the decision is made.

203
00:10:46.340 --> 00:10:49.970
So even though they may actually
kind of bow out in one or

204
00:10:49.970 --> 00:10:53.880
two decisions, after a while,
now you're dealing with six

205
00:10:53.880 --> 00:10:57.110
different teams that are constantly coming
to you like, well, you need to make

206
00:10:57.110 --> 00:11:00.190
a decision on this cuz I believe
Cherokee is making the wrong decision.

207
00:11:00.190 --> 00:11:04.300
And in that, Cherokee is like, well,
you've gotta support me behind this.

208
00:11:04.300 --> 00:11:07.680
And then, I have to evaluate that and
go, either I agree with them or not.

209
00:11:07.680 --> 00:11:10.770
But in this sense if we allow for
the storming, and for

210
00:11:10.770 --> 00:11:12.400
that forming to go on naturally, right?

211
00:11:12.400 --> 00:11:13.760
>> Less micromanagement.

212
00:11:13.760 --> 00:11:16.380
>> Less micromanagement has to take place.

213
00:11:16.380 --> 00:11:21.680
And so as much as it pains you
to see people jockeying for

214
00:11:21.680 --> 00:11:25.290
those positions and you wanna step in,

215
00:11:26.290 --> 00:11:29.690
you really want to try and allow for
something like this to happen.

216
00:11:29.690 --> 00:11:33.510
So understanding the natural
way that this is gonna happen

217
00:11:33.510 --> 00:11:39.180
is really a key aspect of doing something
like the idea of developing a team.

218
00:11:39.180 --> 00:11:40.990
It doesn't always have to happen that way.

219
00:11:40.990 --> 00:11:42.430
If you want to actually run it,

220
00:11:42.430 --> 00:11:45.300
like essentially the way that
the army does it, right?

221
00:11:45.300 --> 00:11:47.500
They say,
here's who you're gonna listen to.

222
00:11:47.500 --> 00:11:50.500
Great, as long as everybody
that you hire [LAUGH],

223
00:11:50.500 --> 00:11:56.080
okay, doesn't have previous experience of
being the top dog or understanding that.

224
00:11:56.080 --> 00:11:57.200
But in this sense,

225
00:11:57.200 --> 00:12:01.890
when you do have experts in your field,
and so here's where you get storming

226
00:12:01.890 --> 00:12:05.450
happening right away instead of
the forming that goes on, right?

227
00:12:05.450 --> 00:12:10.930
Where you go, I've called together the top
ten people that can help me do this, okay?

228
00:12:10.930 --> 00:12:14.670
And then every one of them have
been a project lead in some big,

229
00:12:14.670 --> 00:12:16.400
gigantic project together.

230
00:12:16.400 --> 00:12:19.066
And now you're saying,
I'm now gonna make you equals.

231
00:12:19.066 --> 00:12:19.670
Good luck.

232
00:12:19.670 --> 00:12:20.630
>> Yeah, [LAUGH].

233
00:12:20.630 --> 00:12:26.920
>> And naturally allowing those guys
to say, I'm not equal to Ronnie, I am

234
00:12:26.920 --> 00:12:32.360
superior, I have the better experience,
I have the better knowledge behind this.

235
00:12:32.360 --> 00:12:34.680
So I should naturally be this, okay?

236
00:12:34.680 --> 00:12:39.060
And so in that sense, yeah,
you really don't need that happening.

237
00:12:39.060 --> 00:12:42.870
So a lot of times in your team forming,
you do have to allow for

238
00:12:42.870 --> 00:12:45.910
that awkwardness to happen, and
allow them to learn each other.

239
00:12:45.910 --> 00:12:48.190
And then they also have to see as a group,

240
00:12:48.190 --> 00:12:52.080
who is really going to really help
them to succeed in the project.

241
00:12:52.080 --> 00:12:54.450
And that they can actually
find the respect, and

242
00:12:54.450 --> 00:12:57.080
they can find the influence to do so.

243
00:12:57.080 --> 00:13:01.190
They will become kind of the natural
leader, and people will listen to them

244
00:13:01.190 --> 00:13:04.840
because they trust them and
they actually respect that person.

245
00:13:04.840 --> 00:13:08.140
Instead of them going, well,
that's the way that Ronnie said it is.

246
00:13:08.140 --> 00:13:08.780
>> That's the pecking order.

247
00:13:08.780 --> 00:13:10.260
>> Yeah, that's the pecking order.

248
00:13:10.260 --> 00:13:12.490
And in that sense,
that's not very satisfying.

249
00:13:12.490 --> 00:13:15.140
And you can now figure out why
people then just kinda go,

250
00:13:15.140 --> 00:13:17.170
I don't wanna work on that project,
let's just get out of here and do that.

251
00:13:17.170 --> 00:13:19.860
And now you're left with a hole,
and a gap.

252
00:13:19.860 --> 00:13:24.162
So being able to figure out how
teams really do naturally develop

253
00:13:24.162 --> 00:13:26.791
in those phases is really important for

254
00:13:26.791 --> 00:13:30.870
us when we start to see just
the very beginning there, okay?

255
00:13:30.870 --> 00:13:33.123
>> Norming,
this is such a weird word, norming.

256
00:13:33.123 --> 00:13:36.981
>> Yeah, the next phase that we take
a look at, it is kind of unusual but

257
00:13:36.981 --> 00:13:39.030
norming is exactly like it sounds.

258
00:13:39.030 --> 00:13:43.360
Everybody now starts to
kind of feel comfort or

259
00:13:43.360 --> 00:13:46.390
naturally reached if you allow for
it happen.

260
00:13:46.390 --> 00:13:52.260
So they actually understand what
in that group dynamic, okay?

261
00:13:52.260 --> 00:13:56.860
What their positions are and
their particular places are going to be.

262
00:13:56.860 --> 00:14:00.640
Whether it's a hierarchical type of group
or whether you kind of settle out and

263
00:14:00.640 --> 00:14:04.430
everybody kind of collaborates together,
you actually figure that out as well.

264
00:14:04.430 --> 00:14:07.940
And then when you have
norming that goes on,

265
00:14:07.940 --> 00:14:13.950
everybody starts to kind of drop away
from the idea of interpersonal problems.

266
00:14:13.950 --> 00:14:17.360
Instead of focusing in on,
during that storming stage and

267
00:14:17.360 --> 00:14:20.010
that forming stage,
interpersonal problems can happen.

268
00:14:20.010 --> 00:14:22.830
I'm not going to say they're going
to be the biggest explosions ever.

269
00:14:22.830 --> 00:14:26.600
But they happen here at
this particular point.

270
00:14:26.600 --> 00:14:27.570
They just chalk it up to me.

271
00:14:27.570 --> 00:14:31.160
>> They've accepted it, they've kind of
settled into their own little positions,

272
00:14:31.160 --> 00:14:32.700
and they're ready to get working.

273
00:14:32.700 --> 00:14:36.663
>> Yeah, that's when they just say,
that's just Ronnie being Ronnie.

274
00:14:36.663 --> 00:14:41.340
And what happens then is that they just
realize something that even though Ronnie

275
00:14:41.340 --> 00:14:45.668
doesn't work well in a group, he tends
to contribute, he tends to still do

276
00:14:45.668 --> 00:14:50.740
what he needs to do and then he's actually
able to kind of work his way through.

277
00:14:50.740 --> 00:14:52.970
Also, people tend to respect each other,

278
00:14:52.970 --> 00:14:56.270
to be able to allow for
decisions to be made jointly.

279
00:14:56.270 --> 00:14:59.483
One person doesn't always make
the decision because you naturally kind of

280
00:14:59.483 --> 00:15:01.770
come to that agreement and
figure that out.

281
00:15:01.770 --> 00:15:03.550
Mutual responsibility.

282
00:15:03.550 --> 00:15:05.680
And even a bit of familiarity.

283
00:15:05.680 --> 00:15:10.000
In other words, even saying good morning
to the entire team, in the morning.

284
00:15:10.000 --> 00:15:10.790
I know that sounds weird.

285
00:15:10.790 --> 00:15:16.680
Or saying good night to the entire team
when you actually leave from that day.

286
00:15:16.680 --> 00:15:19.590
So when you don't have
the norming that goes on,

287
00:15:19.590 --> 00:15:25.000
you have a little bit of productivity, and
a lot of mountain that you have to climb.

288
00:15:25.000 --> 00:15:28.460
When norming settles in,
the majority of your work

289
00:15:28.460 --> 00:15:33.360
as the team actually begins to work
very well, and then you have to

290
00:15:33.360 --> 00:15:38.540
deal with some of the minor things such
as personality disruptions that happen.

291
00:15:38.540 --> 00:15:41.540
Somebody just gets fed up
just too many times and

292
00:15:41.540 --> 00:15:43.340
it explodes every once in a while.

293
00:15:43.340 --> 00:15:45.490
But here the idea's simple.

294
00:15:45.490 --> 00:15:47.180
They feel comfortable with each other.

295
00:15:47.180 --> 00:15:52.690
They are now ready to begin,
to actually operate efficiently as a team.

296
00:15:52.690 --> 00:15:56.670
And that is when it moves into that
realm of what we call performing at that

297
00:15:56.670 --> 00:15:57.860
point, okay?

298
00:15:57.860 --> 00:16:01.260
Notice the way that I have this summarized
here, team becomes effective and

299
00:16:01.260 --> 00:16:02.470
productive, okay?

300
00:16:02.470 --> 00:16:03.449
Makes sense, right?

301
00:16:03.449 --> 00:16:05.942
Because now you understand
where everything is,

302
00:16:05.942 --> 00:16:08.120
everybody feels comfortable.

303
00:16:08.120 --> 00:16:11.065
You now just go ahead and
you start doing you job, okay.

304
00:16:11.065 --> 00:16:14.935
Team members start to trust each other,
and as you begin to trust each other,

305
00:16:14.935 --> 00:16:17.750
work really does get
accomplished from this.

306
00:16:17.750 --> 00:16:20.590
If you are not seeing team
performance happening,

307
00:16:20.590 --> 00:16:24.480
okay, there is probably some stage
that you've missed at the beginning.

308
00:16:24.480 --> 00:16:26.010
Whether it was the Norming or

309
00:16:26.010 --> 00:16:29.150
Storming stage you never
really got to that particular

310
00:16:29.150 --> 00:16:33.550
point where performance would come in to
actually hit what you actually needed to.

311
00:16:33.550 --> 00:16:35.920
And so we tend to see a lot of this,

312
00:16:35.920 --> 00:16:40.020
especially on very high
performance types of teams where

313
00:16:40.020 --> 00:16:43.920
they just know that if it's done, it's
done and it's good and it's over with.

314
00:16:43.920 --> 00:16:47.750
But when you don't have that sense
of trust there you actually end up

315
00:16:47.750 --> 00:16:51.120
seeing that that team will work
together to a point and then they won't

316
00:16:51.120 --> 00:16:54.310
trust on certain levels and then they'll
try and do everything on their own.

317
00:16:54.310 --> 00:16:58.440
And you see this a lot in sports teams
as well where everything's working great

318
00:16:58.440 --> 00:17:01.360
through the game and
then they just fall apart at the end.

319
00:17:01.360 --> 00:17:05.590
When they feel like everything is falling
apart they revert back to old bad habits.

320
00:17:05.590 --> 00:17:09.380
And that's what can also happen due
when performing starts to happen.

321
00:17:09.380 --> 00:17:12.070
And then ultimately one of
the harder things to do,

322
00:17:12.070 --> 00:17:15.030
in terms of team development,
is that adjourning.

323
00:17:15.030 --> 00:17:18.630
The finishing up of everything
after the project is over and

324
00:17:18.630 --> 00:17:20.060
that it's actually complete here.

325
00:17:20.060 --> 00:17:22.190
The breaking up of the team.

326
00:17:22.190 --> 00:17:25.470
Realizing that these people, as much
as they might have enjoyed the project,

327
00:17:25.470 --> 00:17:29.590
hopefully that's what happened, and
not actually trudge through the project,

328
00:17:29.590 --> 00:17:34.070
that now they're actually breaking up
this very neat unit that they've been

329
00:17:34.070 --> 00:17:37.550
working very well with and they desire
to work with those people again.

330
00:17:38.960 --> 00:17:42.250
So that's where a team really does
have it's natural development

331
00:17:42.250 --> 00:17:44.200
phases that we tend to see.

332
00:17:44.200 --> 00:17:47.760
when you start taking a look at
the idea of team development here.

333
00:17:47.760 --> 00:17:52.170
It really does end up happening for
us if that team is together for

334
00:17:52.170 --> 00:17:53.480
a good long time,

335
00:17:53.480 --> 00:17:58.320
you actually end up seeing that all this
can actually happen very, very quickly.

336
00:17:58.320 --> 00:17:59.750
Or it can happen over time.

337
00:17:59.750 --> 00:18:01.840
You might find out that you
might get a team together and

338
00:18:01.840 --> 00:18:05.960
it might be weeks before anything like
this actually comes to the norming stage

339
00:18:05.960 --> 00:18:08.920
but then there's sometimes where
the people would just kind of gel.

340
00:18:08.920 --> 00:18:10.180
Norming happens very easily, and

341
00:18:10.180 --> 00:18:13.080
then performance happens just
about immediately as well.

342
00:18:13.080 --> 00:18:16.020
>> So what if you have this cohesive team,
all right?

343
00:18:16.020 --> 00:18:19.400
Everyone's already met each other, we've
gone through these developmental phases,

344
00:18:19.400 --> 00:18:21.250
but what if we integrate someone new,

345
00:18:21.250 --> 00:18:24.100
maybe a new hire,
during one of those latter phases?

346
00:18:24.100 --> 00:18:27.180
That kind of throws a wrench
in your plan there.

347
00:18:27.180 --> 00:18:29.340
>> It absolutely will throw
a wrench in the plan.

348
00:18:29.340 --> 00:18:32.120
And the weird thing about the way
that teams really do develop

349
00:18:33.250 --> 00:18:36.500
is not just as simple as folding
somebody in, it's not like adding

350
00:18:36.500 --> 00:18:40.570
in a little bit of water into the cake
mix and go, I need to change that.

351
00:18:40.570 --> 00:18:43.610
What ends up happening is
that you end up seeing that

352
00:18:43.610 --> 00:18:45.790
the same thing starts
to happen over again.

353
00:18:46.820 --> 00:18:51.110
So in other words you might see where
your entire team really does go back

354
00:18:51.110 --> 00:18:52.720
to the idea of forming again.

355
00:18:52.720 --> 00:18:53.270
Okay?

356
00:18:53.270 --> 00:18:54.970
>> Okay.
>> And then you might see where now

357
00:18:54.970 --> 00:18:58.610
somebody goes now this person agrees with
me and they start storming through again

358
00:18:58.610 --> 00:19:01.910
and then they feel natural and
get to that performance stage.

359
00:19:01.910 --> 00:19:04.820
But there's times though where you
might find out the person just

360
00:19:04.820 --> 00:19:08.220
really does fit into the group but
even so,

361
00:19:08.220 --> 00:19:11.740
right, everybody still has to go
through that because they realize

362
00:19:11.740 --> 00:19:15.210
that the team dynamic has changed
by the addition of person in there.

363
00:19:15.210 --> 00:19:18.760
And so we now to include them in or

364
00:19:18.760 --> 00:19:21.812
you might find that the group
excludes them completely.

365
00:19:21.812 --> 00:19:24.710
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's kinda bad, they get ostracized.

366
00:19:24.710 --> 00:19:26.550
It's like me when I was in grade school.

367
00:19:26.550 --> 00:19:27.190
No, I'm joking.

368
00:19:27.190 --> 00:19:28.500
Don't worry about me.

369
00:19:28.500 --> 00:19:30.370
I've gotten over that by now.

370
00:19:30.370 --> 00:19:34.200
But overall though you
kinda get this idea, right?

371
00:19:34.200 --> 00:19:37.030
That everytime you introduce
new team members in,

372
00:19:37.030 --> 00:19:39.390
you'll see this naturally happen.

373
00:19:39.390 --> 00:19:42.320
Hopefully, as a project manager,
you wanna have to lead them through it.

374
00:19:42.320 --> 00:19:46.550
But you've got to realize the steps
that really does take to form that team.

375
00:19:46.550 --> 00:19:50.520
Because if not, you're gonna find yourself
in that position between norming and

376
00:19:50.520 --> 00:19:54.700
row true performance that happens
that is just not going to be there.

377
00:19:54.700 --> 00:19:58.170
You're gonna wonder why everybody feels
comfortable and laughing around but

378
00:19:58.170 --> 00:19:59.318
they can't get anything done.

379
00:19:59.318 --> 00:20:00.548
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

380
00:20:00.548 --> 00:20:01.320
>> And so,

381
00:20:01.320 --> 00:20:04.820
that might be okay but usually it's not.

382
00:20:04.820 --> 00:20:08.170
Especially if it's a project, you just
don't have enough time to do that.

383
00:20:08.170 --> 00:20:11.860
You really do need to see where
people are in their stage,

384
00:20:11.860 --> 00:20:15.240
especially on project management and
personnel management.

385
00:20:15.240 --> 00:20:18.550
As you start working through
the project there too.

386
00:20:18.550 --> 00:20:21.910
Okay now how can we
actually make this happen?

387
00:20:21.910 --> 00:20:24.760
I don't want to say naturally anymore.

388
00:20:24.760 --> 00:20:26.760
But how can we kind of nudge it.

389
00:20:26.760 --> 00:20:30.570
I could say force it, how do we force
this down somebody's throat here.

390
00:20:30.570 --> 00:20:31.885
>> Like a catalyst.

391
00:20:31.885 --> 00:20:34.260
>> [LAUGH] Yeah what can
you do to actually do that.

392
00:20:34.260 --> 00:20:37.060
Well, there's a couple of
ways that we can do this.

393
00:20:37.060 --> 00:20:41.066
And when it comes down to it,
and you've probably heard this,

394
00:20:41.066 --> 00:20:44.167
in any kind of team performance,
improvement,

395
00:20:44.167 --> 00:20:48.800
self-improvement program,
mentoring, should talk about.

396
00:20:48.800 --> 00:20:51.370
There's a couple of things
that they end up doing.

397
00:20:51.370 --> 00:20:53.940
So let's take a look at a couple of these,
okay?

398
00:20:54.980 --> 00:21:00.770
To me I like the idea of the second one,
which we call informal activities, okay?

399
00:21:00.770 --> 00:21:05.880
Now informal activities are good once
you get people past that forming and

400
00:21:05.880 --> 00:21:07.450
storming stage.

401
00:21:07.450 --> 00:21:14.170
Informal activity is not so good during
the forming and storming stages as well.

402
00:21:15.180 --> 00:21:17.830
Now when I say that,

403
00:21:17.830 --> 00:21:22.250
the reason why is that they might not feel
super comfortable with each other yet.

404
00:21:22.250 --> 00:21:22.830
Okay?

405
00:21:22.830 --> 00:21:26.330
So the idea of you going, hey, let's go
and grab a couple of beers after work.

406
00:21:26.330 --> 00:21:27.620
>> That's exactly what I was thinking.

407
00:21:27.620 --> 00:21:28.677
I see it up there and

408
00:21:28.677 --> 00:21:33.057
I don't know how well that would mesh
together with the alpha personalities.

409
00:21:33.057 --> 00:21:34.778
I'm trying to figure that out.
>> Yeah, with everybody trying to do that.

410
00:21:34.778 --> 00:21:36.140
Yeah, it's very difficult, okay?

411
00:21:36.140 --> 00:21:39.070
But once they get past that informal
activities are good because it helps

412
00:21:39.070 --> 00:21:40.910
to build the continuity in the team.

413
00:21:40.910 --> 00:21:43.740
They understand that they can grab
a couple of beers, or you can actually do

414
00:21:43.740 --> 00:21:49.720
a team lunch that allows them to feel good
and stay away from the focus of work.

415
00:21:49.720 --> 00:21:54.340
So team building in this sense,
on your team doing this on a periodic

416
00:21:54.340 --> 00:21:58.190
basis is really good during a project
when there's high pressure,

417
00:21:58.190 --> 00:22:01.860
when high performance is
always demanded of your team.

418
00:22:01.860 --> 00:22:03.850
And formal activities are key, right.

419
00:22:03.850 --> 00:22:06.780
Even if it's just bringing in
donuts every once in a while,

420
00:22:06.780 --> 00:22:08.480
now I shouldn't use donuts,
cuz apparently,

421
00:22:08.480 --> 00:22:12.810
everybody around here doesn't like
donuts except for me, I love them.

422
00:22:12.810 --> 00:22:14.930
And so when they're,
when somebody brings donuts in,

423
00:22:14.930 --> 00:22:16.420
I'm usually the one that eats all of them.

424
00:22:16.420 --> 00:22:17.470
And that's the problem, right?

425
00:22:17.470 --> 00:22:20.130
And so, yeah Peter kind of
brings in like three dozen.

426
00:22:20.130 --> 00:22:22.470
I think I eat two and a half of them.

427
00:22:22.470 --> 00:22:24.420
So-
>> It's just that they're so

428
00:22:24.420 --> 00:22:27.680
good that we'll probably eat all
of them unless we try to refrain.

429
00:22:27.680 --> 00:22:29.420
>> Yeah, so and I don't have that problem.

430
00:22:29.420 --> 00:22:32.400
Cuz I have no inhibitions
about eating multiple donuts,

431
00:22:32.400 --> 00:22:33.960
where everybody else does.

432
00:22:33.960 --> 00:22:36.740
So for me it's probably not a great idea
because it probably affects my heart,

433
00:22:36.740 --> 00:22:39.570
but overall though, you start to see this.

434
00:22:39.570 --> 00:22:40.960
So informal activities are really good.

435
00:22:40.960 --> 00:22:44.010
>> But those formal ones, those are kind
of the awkward moments, aren't they?

436
00:22:44.010 --> 00:22:45.090
>> They really are.

437
00:22:45.090 --> 00:22:46.840
Okay, now, when you start,

438
00:22:46.840 --> 00:22:49.840
it always reminds me of movies that
you see on these things, right.

439
00:22:49.840 --> 00:22:52.240
There's always that trust fall.

440
00:22:52.240 --> 00:22:56.660
>> It always makes me think of those
stickers, the hello, my name is stickers.

441
00:22:56.660 --> 00:23:01.750
>> Yeah, that's one of those unusual
formal activities that you have.

442
00:23:01.750 --> 00:23:05.970
And we traditionally, you start off with
what everybody starts off with, right?

443
00:23:05.970 --> 00:23:07.570
An icebreaker, a game, right?

444
00:23:07.570 --> 00:23:09.340
>> Yeah.
>> Just to kind of get you to do

445
00:23:09.340 --> 00:23:12.930
something silly to break
the tension that's in the air.

446
00:23:12.930 --> 00:23:17.660
But they are very effective during
this forming and storming stages.

447
00:23:17.660 --> 00:23:22.500
And the reason why is that it shows that
somebody has something together and they

448
00:23:22.500 --> 00:23:27.590
really want the meshing to actually occur
faster than the natural development might.

449
00:23:27.590 --> 00:23:29.730
Okay, now when you start doing this,
right,

450
00:23:29.730 --> 00:23:32.900
when you start realizing
this has to be done quickly.

451
00:23:32.900 --> 00:23:36.630

many different things.
