00:16:27.650 --> 00:16:32.750
So a lot of times when you start to take a
look, it could be the very fact that, hey,

326
00:16:32.750 --> 00:16:34.620
there's a lot of things
that end up happening.

327
00:16:34.620 --> 00:16:38.640
Functional resources become part-time,
this can happen where somebody now,

328
00:16:38.640 --> 00:16:43.190
even though they were working full-time,
they now go, I've just gotta take a break,

329
00:16:43.190 --> 00:16:44.010
I'm burnt out.

330
00:16:44.010 --> 00:16:46.070
I just don't feel like I can do any more.

331
00:16:46.070 --> 00:16:49.548
Well, now all of a sudden they become
a part-time resource for you instead.

332
00:16:49.548 --> 00:16:52.963
And even though they still
actually now work part-time,

333
00:16:52.963 --> 00:16:55.910
they still have their entire job as well.

334
00:16:55.910 --> 00:16:59.700
And everything still has actually be done,
even though they've actually done that.

335
00:16:59.700 --> 00:17:02.800
So you might find out, it is something
like a competing resource demand.

336
00:17:02.800 --> 00:17:05.360
The very fact that they just
don't wanna do that anymore.

337
00:17:05.360 --> 00:17:07.080
And you're just having to talk,

338
00:17:07.080 --> 00:17:09.235
cuz like, we're at the last
three weeks of our project.

339
00:17:09.235 --> 00:17:10.261
>> You can do it!
>> You can't quit now.

340
00:17:10.261 --> 00:17:12.090
You can still do it.

341
00:17:12.090 --> 00:17:15.230
And they're like, I don't really feel
like, and what are you willing to do?

342
00:17:15.230 --> 00:17:16.910
Sometimes, you're just
willing to negotiate and

343
00:17:16.910 --> 00:17:19.570
go, please do at least part-time.

344
00:17:19.570 --> 00:17:23.720
Well, remember this full time job still
has to be done but it's part-time,

345
00:17:23.720 --> 00:17:27.380
so it could be something just
about competing resources.

346
00:17:27.380 --> 00:17:31.457
The other thing of course,
differing expert opinions.

347
00:17:31.457 --> 00:17:32.580
Who would think-
>> There's no way.

348
00:17:32.580 --> 00:17:33.870
>> Yeah, there's no way.

349
00:17:33.870 --> 00:17:37.240
Yeah, it's that feeling of,
I am not wrong on this.

350
00:17:37.240 --> 00:17:41.000
Well, now you have both people on
both sides saying, I'm not wrong!

351
00:17:41.000 --> 00:17:44.593
>> It's really great to have
passionate individuals on a team but,

352
00:17:44.593 --> 00:17:49.446
when people are so passionate, about their
ideas or beliefs, this is going to happen.

353
00:17:49.446 --> 00:17:53.619
>> It really will and so, at this
bigger point here, that's where you,

354
00:17:53.619 --> 00:17:57.867
as the project manager, you've got
to actually identify whether that

355
00:17:57.867 --> 00:18:02.735
expert judgement is actually about
the actual expert judgement itself.

356
00:18:02.735 --> 00:18:05.950
Whereas, this guy just doesn't
like the answer of the other guy.

357
00:18:05.950 --> 00:18:09.120
Is he just trying to present
a counteracting argument,

358
00:18:09.120 --> 00:18:11.360
just to present a counteracting argument?

359
00:18:11.360 --> 00:18:13.570
So try and figure out is it
really about extra judgement.

360
00:18:13.570 --> 00:18:17.480
If it is, then you deal with it and
get which side are you gonna do.

361
00:18:17.480 --> 00:18:22.110
And then, finally, one of the things we
don't think that it will annoy us but

362
00:18:22.110 --> 00:18:25.031
it can which is the idea
of varying work styles and

363
00:18:25.031 --> 00:18:29.830
I like to break this down to in the 70s
there was a TV show called The Odd Couple.

364
00:18:29.830 --> 00:18:34.759
And the Odd Couple was really
two guys that lived together

365
00:18:34.759 --> 00:18:39.173
in an apartment,
one was the OCD neatness guy, and

366
00:18:39.173 --> 00:18:45.390
that was Felix if I remember right,
and then the other guy was Oscar.

367
00:18:45.390 --> 00:18:49.990
And he was like the guy that
everything was everywhere.

368
00:18:49.990 --> 00:18:53.710
So they both ended up living in the same
apartment together where one guy would

369
00:18:53.710 --> 00:18:55.760
completely trash it and
the other guy would, of course, clean up.

370
00:18:55.760 --> 00:18:59.020
It sounds like a perfect mix actually,
that's just what you have there right

371
00:18:59.020 --> 00:19:02.480
the ability for one guy to be a complete
mess, the other guy to clean it up.

372
00:19:02.480 --> 00:19:04.500
They both get satisfaction
out of doing that.

373
00:19:04.500 --> 00:19:07.590
But in working together not so much so.

374
00:19:07.590 --> 00:19:11.900
So in this sense you may have
that where it really does bug

375
00:19:11.900 --> 00:19:15.160
people to that nth degree
that it is this way.

376
00:19:15.160 --> 00:19:17.600
And now you're talking about
personality conflicts.

377
00:19:17.600 --> 00:19:23.280
It does sound like a superficial
type of thing, but it is reality.

378
00:19:23.280 --> 00:19:29.490
And for people it might be the other one,
the second example that I have there.

379
00:19:29.490 --> 00:19:33.282
The early bird versus the one that
always late, it doesn't matter.

380
00:19:33.282 --> 00:19:39.542
So I just saw Cherokee's lip curl on
that one a little bit there, so [SOUND].

381
00:19:39.542 --> 00:19:40.812
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Ronnie,

382
00:19:40.812 --> 00:19:43.421
I didn't know you were gonna
be talking about me here.

383
00:19:43.421 --> 00:19:45.653
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So in that sense,

384
00:19:45.653 --> 00:19:50.424
when you start seeing some of that,
even though you might not care, like so

385
00:19:50.424 --> 00:19:52.870
they come in a little bit late.

386
00:19:52.870 --> 00:19:57.430
But for Cherokee, if that's her
constant thing that she sees,

387
00:19:57.430 --> 00:20:00.890
it's gonna drive her nuts and
that can lead to team conflicts as well.

388
00:20:00.890 --> 00:20:04.770
So identifying that is really
gonna be important in trying to

389
00:20:04.770 --> 00:20:08.916
curve those specially if she's
working on a key component as a point.

390
00:20:08.916 --> 00:20:10.340
And that guys is-
>> Well, you have to think.

391
00:20:10.340 --> 00:20:13.670
You might be working long hours,
you're seeing these people all the time.

392
00:20:13.670 --> 00:20:15.840
Sometimes even more than
your actual family members.

393
00:20:15.840 --> 00:20:20.190
So these little annoyances may actually
add up if you don't address them.

394
00:20:20.190 --> 00:20:21.560
>> Add up is not the word.

395
00:20:21.560 --> 00:20:23.075
>> [LAUGH]
>> They end up growing.

396
00:20:23.075 --> 00:20:27.250
[LAUGH] This is not just
moving a pebble over.

397
00:20:27.250 --> 00:20:29.418
It's like moving a pebble over with sand,
and dirt, and

398
00:20:29.418 --> 00:20:30.245
then it growing-
>> A bulldozer.

399
00:20:30.245 --> 00:20:33.920
>> A whole new,
it really grows, incredibly.

400
00:20:33.920 --> 00:20:35.320
So what are some of
the things that we can do?

401
00:20:35.320 --> 00:20:38.550
Well, we actually have to learn some
conflict resolution techniques.

402
00:20:38.550 --> 00:20:45.160
Now, I am by no means a conflict
resolution expert to the nth degree.

403
00:20:45.160 --> 00:20:46.095
>> Nor am I.

404
00:20:46.095 --> 00:20:48.030
[LAUGH]
>> But there are some tools and

405
00:20:48.030 --> 00:20:52.250
techniques that everybody,
as a project manager that we can try and

406
00:20:52.250 --> 00:20:54.960
at least hang on to.

407
00:20:54.960 --> 00:20:57.060
As we're experiencing these conflicts.

408
00:20:57.060 --> 00:20:59.600
First and foremost,
remember it's not about you.

409
00:20:59.600 --> 00:21:02.520
I know that it sounds weird, but
just don't take it personally.

410
00:21:02.520 --> 00:21:04.160
It's not about you.

411
00:21:04.160 --> 00:21:07.500
So one of the things we can
try is the idea of smoothing.

412
00:21:07.500 --> 00:21:11.950
Emphasize areas of agreement,
minimize focus on disagreements.

413
00:21:11.950 --> 00:21:15.130
So even though we can actually do this,

414
00:21:15.130 --> 00:21:18.440
the problem that you have is you actually
tried to minimize a real problem.

415
00:21:19.470 --> 00:21:22.300
So if this is a real conflict
that's not superficial,

416
00:21:22.300 --> 00:21:25.740
and it's a real problem,
then you've just minimized it.

417
00:21:25.740 --> 00:21:29.050
And in the eyes of the person that
has a conflict with that, guess what?

418
00:21:29.050 --> 00:21:30.750
You've minimized them.

419
00:21:30.750 --> 00:21:32.260
You have now disrespected them, and

420
00:21:32.260 --> 00:21:35.930
you've gotta actually kind of think
about what ends up happening.

421
00:21:35.930 --> 00:21:37.200
So when that happens,

422
00:21:37.200 --> 00:21:41.160
there's only one particular technique
that we call in conflict resolution here.

423
00:21:41.160 --> 00:21:44.680
What ends up happening is a situation and
result that we call lose-lose.

424
00:21:44.680 --> 00:21:46.560
>> Okay.
>> Both sides losing.

425
00:21:46.560 --> 00:21:50.880
So in that sense, you end up maybe where
Cherokee says, I'm not taking anymore,

426
00:21:50.880 --> 00:21:51.530
she loses.

427
00:21:51.530 --> 00:21:54.305
She's gone,
you now have a missing teammate.

428
00:21:54.305 --> 00:21:56.350
[LAUGH] And you have to fill that gap.

429
00:21:56.350 --> 00:21:57.770
And you lose too.

430
00:21:57.770 --> 00:22:00.430
So smoothing even though it's possible

431
00:22:00.430 --> 00:22:02.630
probably not the best
effort that we can put in.

432
00:22:02.630 --> 00:22:06.384
>> Okay, Ronnie, so what you're saying is
that we really shouldn't trivialize any

433
00:22:06.384 --> 00:22:08.218
concerns that are brought to the table.

434
00:22:08.218 --> 00:22:08.889
Legitimate concerns.

435
00:22:08.889 --> 00:22:09.721
>> Legitimate concerns.

436
00:22:09.721 --> 00:22:12.807
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I know this sounds weird but,

437
00:22:12.807 --> 00:22:19.305
I hate to say it, I think you need to
trivialize very superficial concerns,

438
00:22:19.305 --> 00:22:25.926
like I can't believe he parked on this
side, he parked too close to the line.

439
00:22:25.926 --> 00:22:30.607
Now, if you have a brand new car,
I understand, but if he parks too

440
00:22:30.607 --> 00:22:34.470
close to the line, it really is-
>> You have the right to park elsewhere.

441
00:22:34.470 --> 00:22:35.940
>> You have the right
to park elsewhere and

442
00:22:35.940 --> 00:22:37.780
he's in his boundary,
that's what I would say.

443
00:22:37.780 --> 00:22:40.410
He still is in his boundary here, but

444
00:22:40.410 --> 00:22:47.070
overall though the problem is what is that
we do end up minimalizing a real problem.

445
00:22:47.070 --> 00:22:51.360
So smoothing,
it solves an immediate field problem.

446
00:22:52.800 --> 00:22:55.720
But it can cause another problem
which is that lose lose.

447
00:22:55.720 --> 00:22:59.480
Nobody ever really wins once you actually
start the idea here of smoothing

448
00:22:59.480 --> 00:23:02.480
as being your way of
dealing with conflict.

449
00:23:02.480 --> 00:23:05.400
So handle real problems,
but yeah, if you can,

450
00:23:05.400 --> 00:23:07.500
especially something
superficial it'd work.

451
00:23:07.500 --> 00:23:11.330
If it's something real,
smoothing just is not the way to go.

452
00:23:11.330 --> 00:23:12.620
>> Okay.

453
00:23:12.620 --> 00:23:15.080
>> Now, the other one that we have,
of course, is the idea of forcing.

454
00:23:15.080 --> 00:23:19.580
This is what I call the dad
resolution more than any place else.

455
00:23:19.580 --> 00:23:21.940
So when we start to take
a look at this idea,

456
00:23:21.940 --> 00:23:25.240
it's not necessarily the best
decision that ends up happening.

457
00:23:25.240 --> 00:23:29.170
Because I know as a Dad according to my
wife and daughter, I never make the best

458
00:23:29.170 --> 00:23:34.390
decision on this things, but
it is a decision that has to be made.

459
00:23:34.390 --> 00:23:37.008
So what I do is I simply say,
here's the way it's gonna be.

460
00:23:37.008 --> 00:23:39.335
And that's what ends up happening, and

461
00:23:39.335 --> 00:23:42.620
I can say that I don't care
if you agree with it or not.

462
00:23:42.620 --> 00:23:43.480
Does it sound like Dad?

463
00:23:43.480 --> 00:23:45.710
Is that me or what?

464
00:23:45.710 --> 00:23:48.830
So my daughter will go, yeah, that's Dad.

465
00:23:48.830 --> 00:23:54.488
But sometimes when you do this,
you end up in a win-lose result instead.

466
00:23:54.488 --> 00:23:58.724
Now, a win-lose sounds good, because
usually in conflict you want a winner.

467
00:23:58.724 --> 00:24:02.100
And you don't normally want a loser.

468
00:24:02.100 --> 00:24:08.720
But overall though the real result, at
least to the people that are involved Is

469
00:24:08.720 --> 00:24:14.580
not that they really won on the merits of
anything, is that you picked the winner.

470
00:24:14.580 --> 00:24:18.360
So in other words,
you didn't really listen to anybody.

471
00:24:18.360 --> 00:24:21.700
You just kind of arbitrarily
decided who's gonna win this.

472
00:24:21.700 --> 00:24:24.000
And nobody likes that feeling.

473
00:24:24.000 --> 00:24:28.008
If you don't believe me, watch any of the
contests that are actually on TV, well,

474
00:24:28.008 --> 00:24:30.695
they're just like Dancing with the Stars-
>> Good Times.

475
00:24:30.695 --> 00:24:33.040
>> Yeah, the American Idol-
>> Cooking competition.

476
00:24:33.040 --> 00:24:36.290
>> Cooking competitions, boxing matches,

477
00:24:36.290 --> 00:24:41.020
everybody feels cheated when somebody else
picks the winner instead of you going man,

478
00:24:41.020 --> 00:24:44.270
this is what they really did,
they deserve this a little bit more.

479
00:24:44.270 --> 00:24:45.080
So yes,

480
00:24:45.080 --> 00:24:49.280
usually in this type of situation it does
resolve with one person feeling great.

481
00:24:49.280 --> 00:24:51.690
The other person feeling cheated.

482
00:24:51.690 --> 00:24:54.087
And when is that ever a good feeling,
Cherokee?

483
00:24:54.087 --> 00:24:55.000
Never, right?

484
00:24:55.000 --> 00:24:55.500
>> That's right.

485
00:24:56.610 --> 00:24:59.760
>> So in this sense you do
see where you can do that.

486
00:24:59.760 --> 00:25:01.041
So with smoothing and

487
00:25:01.041 --> 00:25:05.033
forcing these are at least two of
the actual methods that we can do.

488
00:25:05.033 --> 00:25:07.595
But not necessarily
the best method as well.

489
00:25:07.595 --> 00:25:11.152
>> Well, I think that just about does it
for this episode but you guys can put your

490
00:25:11.152 --> 00:25:14.850
boxing gloves away because we have more
conflict resolution heading your way.

491
00:25:14.850 --> 00:25:17.640
So stay tuned for that,
thank you for being here today and

492
00:25:17.640 --> 00:25:19.650
thank you, Ronnie, for joining us.

493
00:25:19.650 --> 00:25:21.523
I'm Cherokee Boost
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

494
00:25:21.523 --> 00:25:22.040
>> Signing off.

495
00:25:22.040 --> 00:25:29.634
[MUSIC]

496
00:25:29.634 --> 00:25:32.415
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: This episode is all about conflict resolution. Ronnie and Cherokee remark on several viable options to possibly help avoid a termination. However, they do acknowledge the fact that sometimes it is necessary and cover what to do in that situation .
episodes.title: Explain Resource Management Roles Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:01.170
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.170 --> 00:00:02.974
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.974 --> 00:00:08.214
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:08.214 --> 00:00:12.023
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:12.023 --> 00:00:15.126
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:15.126 --> 00:00:19.073
In this episode, we're going to be looking
at Project Plus, CompTIA's Project Plus,

7
00:00:19.073 --> 00:00:22.690
we're going to be looking at
explaining resource management.

8
00:00:22.690 --> 00:00:26.700
In the last couple of episodes, we've been
looking at this topic, but last episode,

9
00:00:26.700 --> 00:00:29.590
we looked at personnel management and
we're gonna go ahead and

10
00:00:29.590 --> 00:00:32.800
continue with some of those concepts,
but really specifically,

11
00:00:32.800 --> 00:00:35.470
looking at conflict management.

12
00:00:35.470 --> 00:00:37.920
So with us, we have Mr. Ronnie Wong.

13
00:00:37.920 --> 00:00:39.300
Thank you Ronnie.

14
00:00:39.300 --> 00:00:42.370
>> Thank you for having me back on
the show as we continue on with

15
00:00:42.370 --> 00:00:46.770
taking a look at conflict resolution tools
that we can use as project managers.

16
00:00:46.770 --> 00:00:49.680
Now remember that this doesn't mean
that you're gonna be an expert

17
00:00:49.680 --> 00:00:53.300
at conflict resolution simply by
watching the previous show and

18
00:00:53.300 --> 00:00:57.980
this show, but at least as a project
manager, hopefully, these will give you

19
00:00:57.980 --> 00:01:01.080
some of the ways that you actually
understand how conflict happens and

20
00:01:01.080 --> 00:01:04.104
how you can deal with them as
a project manager as well.

21
00:01:04.104 --> 00:01:08.920
So they're eventually tools that we
can use as we start to see this.

22
00:01:08.920 --> 00:01:11.600
So previously, let's go and
take a look at my screen here and

23
00:01:11.600 --> 00:01:14.360
that will help us out in
terms of reviewing as well.

24
00:01:14.360 --> 00:01:16.380
So when we start taking a look
at some of the techniques,

25
00:01:16.380 --> 00:01:17.930
we've talked about the idea of smoothing.

26
00:01:17.930 --> 00:01:18.970
>> And forcing.

27
00:01:18.970 --> 00:01:20.230
>> Yep, and forcing.

28
00:01:20.230 --> 00:01:24.290
So when we start taking a look at those
two, remember that those end up giving us

29
00:01:24.290 --> 00:01:29.150
a potential type of resolution,
where in smoothing it's a lose-lose.

30
00:01:29.150 --> 00:01:33.040
Nobody really feels like anything was
really accomplished at that particular

31
00:01:33.040 --> 00:01:36.280
point, and we end up minimizing
what a real problem we have.

32
00:01:36.280 --> 00:01:39.220
And then forcing,
we essentially pick the winner.

33
00:01:39.220 --> 00:01:43.710
And so there's a winner, and
that means that by the very other fact,

34
00:01:43.710 --> 00:01:46.820
is that somebody ends up also
picking the loser, which is you,

35
00:01:46.820 --> 00:01:48.780
you're also gonna pick the loser as well.

36
00:01:48.780 --> 00:01:52.020
So we need to move on and we need to
talk about the idea that's probably most

37
00:01:52.020 --> 00:01:58.700
appealing to the majority of us,
which is the idea of compromise, okay?

38
00:01:58.700 --> 00:02:02.620
Now when we start talking about
the idea of compromise here,

39
00:02:02.620 --> 00:02:05.380
one of the key aspects
of compromise is simple.

40
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:10.170
Both sides essentially let go of
something that they're hanging on to.

41
00:02:10.170 --> 00:02:13.460
>> Yeah, and
if you're in a relationship, or married,

42
00:02:13.460 --> 00:02:15.585
then you know exactly what
we're talking about here.

43
00:02:15.585 --> 00:02:18.685
[LAUGH]
>> All right, so that's cherokee@itpro.tv.

44
00:02:18.685 --> 00:02:22.960
[LAUGH] No, no the very fact is,
yes, there's no doubt about that.

45
00:02:22.960 --> 00:02:25.630
Here parties are involved to

46
00:02:25.630 --> 00:02:29.105
give up something to reach
a resolution of some sort.

47
00:02:29.105 --> 00:02:31.164
[LAUGH]
>> Whoa, Cherokee went that way.

48
00:02:31.164 --> 00:02:32.917
Yes, that actually did happen here.

49
00:02:32.917 --> 00:02:36.150
But overall though, yes-
>> You know that they're thinking it.

50
00:02:36.150 --> 00:02:39.140
>> There's no doubt that there
is compromise in marriage and

51
00:02:39.140 --> 00:02:41.500
some of these things, but
hopefully, not in everything.

52
00:02:41.500 --> 00:02:46.032
But here we do, both sides of whatever

The point on confrontation, though, okay,

Whereas, all of the other ones,
it's either kind of a lose-lose,

273
00:15:16.180 --> 00:15:22.580
a win-lose situation, or nobody's happy
type of situation that you end up with.

274
00:15:22.580 --> 00:15:27.410
But in terms of conflict resolution,
these are kind of the basic

275
00:15:29.230 --> 00:15:34.110
ways that you'll have to deal with
them as they do arise in your project.

276
00:15:34.110 --> 00:15:40.230
Okay, all right, so that actually
brings us then to our last particular

277
00:15:40.230 --> 00:15:45.632
point here that we need to talk about,
just briefly, which is when nothing works.

278
00:15:45.632 --> 00:15:46.145
>> Exactly.
>> Yeah.

279
00:15:46.145 --> 00:15:47.005
>> I hate to say it,

280
00:15:47.005 --> 00:15:49.962
but that's our last point here.
What do we do at that point, Ronnie?

281
00:15:49.962 --> 00:15:50.475
>> Yeah,

282
00:15:50.475 --> 00:15:53.893
when nothing works in
terms of team disputes and

283
00:15:53.893 --> 00:15:59.363
everything else that happens, okay,
that is when you do have to go above and

284
00:15:59.363 --> 00:16:04.234
beyond and talk about The idea of
personnel types of replacements or

285
00:16:04.234 --> 00:16:08.170
removals.
Now, that's exactly like it sounds like.

286
00:16:08.170 --> 00:16:10.910
You're fired,
that's exactly what it sounds like.

287
00:16:10.910 --> 00:16:13.680
Or you definitely are not
working well with our team,

288
00:16:13.680 --> 00:16:15.230
we need to do something else with you.

289
00:16:16.370 --> 00:16:21.160
In that sense,
what is it that you actually have to do?

290
00:16:21.160 --> 00:16:24.900
There's going to be team members that end
up having, hopefully not on every single

291
00:16:24.900 --> 00:16:29.890
project, but there will be times where you
have to actually address that team member.

292
00:16:29.890 --> 00:16:32.150
That no matter what you have tried to do,

293
00:16:32.150 --> 00:16:33.540
whether you've tried to
confront the problem,

294
00:16:33.540 --> 00:16:37.900
whether you tried to negotiate the peace,
whatever it is, it doesn't work.

295
00:16:37.900 --> 00:16:42.650
This is when you have to go ahead and
take a look at it a little bit harder and

296
00:16:42.650 --> 00:16:44.510
talk about the fact of whether or

297
00:16:44.510 --> 00:16:49.390
not this particular individual needs
to be removed or and or to be replaced.

298
00:16:49.390 --> 00:16:50.340
That is what we need to do.

299
00:16:51.420 --> 00:16:54.840
In that sense, when you end up
dealing with several things here.

300
00:16:54.840 --> 00:16:56.080
Let's go ahead and talk about this,

301
00:16:56.080 --> 00:17:00.890
when you actually have to consider
the ideas of replacement of some sort.

302
00:17:00.890 --> 00:17:04.960
On my screen, I went ahead and
made a small list here to help us out.

303
00:17:04.960 --> 00:17:11.020
So if you're just dealing with team
member disputes, that's perfectly fine.

304
00:17:11.020 --> 00:17:14.050
Remember that in terms of conflict,
fact determination and

305
00:17:14.050 --> 00:17:19.135
meetings, usually you involve
everybody as much as possible and

306
00:17:19.135 --> 00:17:24.340
say here it is, this is just a team member
dispute, you should be able to solve this.

307
00:17:25.470 --> 00:17:31.140
Now if it doesn't work, then at that
point, notice that the situation

308
00:17:31.140 --> 00:17:35.520
can end up devolving and what we
mean by that is it can disintegrate.

309
00:17:35.520 --> 00:17:39.120
It can really quickly
become disastrous for

310
00:17:39.120 --> 00:17:40.980
your entire team if you are not careful.

311
00:17:42.010 --> 00:17:45.840
If it then ends up to the point where
now it's actually personal issues that

312
00:17:45.840 --> 00:17:50.930
are related, here, the very fact that it
says, hey, this is now getting personal,

313
00:17:50.930 --> 00:17:52.410
where we're calling each other names.

314
00:17:52.410 --> 00:17:53.640
Where we're angry.

315
00:17:53.640 --> 00:17:57.290
>> Right, you don't want that negative
energy to infect your entire team.

316
00:17:57.290 --> 00:18:00.500
>> Yeah, you really can't
afford to have that happen.

317
00:18:00.500 --> 00:18:05.920
Then at that point, you have to involve HR
as well and so you may have to do that.

318
00:18:05.920 --> 00:18:10.470
And then you have to be willing to stand
by the policy and not deviate from it once

319
00:18:10.470 --> 00:18:13.980
it happens because if not, you might
find yourself in a legal quandary.

320
00:18:13.980 --> 00:18:15.690
Now the best situation and

321
00:18:15.690 --> 00:18:21.050
the best example of this that I can tell
you which is something that's very neat.

322
00:18:21.050 --> 00:18:24.120
I had a friend of mine that actually
worked on an oil rig in the Gulf,

323
00:18:25.370 --> 00:18:27.180
way back in the 80s here.

324
00:18:27.180 --> 00:18:31.260
He worked on an oil rig and one of the
things he told which was amazing to me,

325
00:18:31.260 --> 00:18:35.450
I never knew this, he said, it's fine
when people are working together and

326
00:18:35.450 --> 00:18:38.430
even if they break out in fights,
it's perfectly fine.

327
00:18:38.430 --> 00:18:42.130
But if there comes a point when two
people really don't like each other and

328
00:18:42.130 --> 00:18:44.370
they can't stand each other-
>> There's no where to go.

329
00:18:44.370 --> 00:18:45.915
>> There's no where to go.

330
00:18:45.915 --> 00:18:47.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> But the problem is this,

331
00:18:47.670 --> 00:18:51.572
is that on that particular thing,
on that idea of working on an oil rig,

332
00:18:51.572 --> 00:18:55.790
no where to go, it essentially ends
up infecting the rest of the crew.

333
00:18:55.790 --> 00:18:56.650
>> That's true.

334
00:18:56.650 --> 00:18:59.410
>> They end up getting so
bent out of shape.

335
00:18:59.410 --> 00:19:02.140
One of the policies in
his company was simple.

336
00:19:02.140 --> 00:19:06.030
Two people get into that type of a fight
where they know it's not gonna be

337
00:19:06.030 --> 00:19:10.900
resolved, they immediately separate
them into two different rooms and

338
00:19:10.900 --> 00:19:16.440
they do not allow them to essentially
talk to anybody, nor see anybody.

339
00:19:16.440 --> 00:19:21.650
Second step is that whoever
the foreman is calls the company, and

340
00:19:21.650 --> 00:19:26.220
they immediately send out a helicopter for
those two people.

341
00:19:26.220 --> 00:19:29.950
They're going to get them off
of the rig as soon as possible.

342
00:19:29.950 --> 00:19:34.430
They do not want the attitude
infecting the rest of the team.

343
00:19:34.430 --> 00:19:36.910
It doesn't matter if it's in
the middle of the night or

344
00:19:36.910 --> 00:19:39.030
if it's during the middle of the work day.

345
00:19:39.030 --> 00:19:42.970
if they have something like that break
out, they immediately separate them and

346
00:19:42.970 --> 00:19:47.650
they immediately get them off that rig so
that work can continue on.

347
00:19:47.650 --> 00:19:51.190
And that that particular conflict
then is handled somewhere else,

348
00:19:51.190 --> 00:19:56.190
instead of right there on-board because
they just can't have the time to stop and

349
00:19:56.190 --> 00:19:58.480
do all that while the rest
of the team needs to work.

350
00:19:59.910 --> 00:20:03.630
You might even have a situation like
that and that is just HR policy for

351
00:20:03.630 --> 00:20:05.580
that particular company back in the 80s.

352
00:20:05.580 --> 00:20:08.210
>> We even have one here at IT PRO TV.

353
00:20:08.210 --> 00:20:10.530
>> Yeah.
>> We have a no-drama policy, I love it.

354
00:20:10.530 --> 00:20:11.579
>> Yeah, it really is.

355
00:20:12.750 --> 00:20:17.120
Hopefully, what we have here with that
no-drama policy, and that is if we do

356
00:20:17.120 --> 00:20:21.220
create that, if we do have a time-out type
of situation that we have to worry about.

357
00:20:21.220 --> 00:20:23.940
>> I don't think we get helicopter rides,
though, do we?

358
00:20:23.940 --> 00:20:24.610
>> Not easily.
>> [LAUGH]

359
00:20:24.610 --> 00:20:26.390
>> Yeah, yeah, not easily.

360
00:20:26.390 --> 00:20:29.640
But overall, though,
that's what may have to happen.

361
00:20:29.640 --> 00:20:32.570
What are some of the results then,
if you do have to do this?

362
00:20:32.570 --> 00:20:36.370
Well, it could be that the person
doesn't get outright terminated,

363
00:20:37.540 --> 00:20:39.270
it may be where they
have to go to training.

364
00:20:39.270 --> 00:20:41.840
Maybe anger management,
it may be something else, it's possible.

365
00:20:41.840 --> 00:20:45.082
They may face some other
type of disciplinary action.

366
00:20:45.082 --> 00:20:48.740
>> Unpaid leave.

367
00:20:48.740 --> 00:20:52.640
>> Unpaid leave is usually the one big one
because that's normally where people start

368
00:20:52.640 --> 00:20:56.780
hurting is when you tell them yep
you actually have unpaid leave or

369
00:20:56.780 --> 00:20:59.370
you're not gonna be assigned anything for
the next couple of weeks here.

370
00:21:00.660 --> 00:21:03.010
There is possible mediation.

371
00:21:03.010 --> 00:21:05.630
Remember that is never a good thing
because it means they're gonna split

372
00:21:05.630 --> 00:21:09.440
the baby between the two and
nobody's gonna be happy about that.

373
00:21:09.440 --> 00:21:12.340
But what you might find out is
both of them end up on some

374
00:21:12.340 --> 00:21:15.170
oil rig in the Alaskan Gulf or

375
00:21:15.170 --> 00:21:18.960
the Alaskan Bering Sea up there and
the other one ends up in Saudi Arabia.

376
00:21:18.960 --> 00:21:21.780
You never know, but
that's what you might also have.

377
00:21:21.780 --> 00:21:24.800
And then ultimately at the very end,
it could be that you do relieve them

378
00:21:24.800 --> 00:21:28.480
of their job duties when you
do have something like that.

379
00:21:28.480 --> 00:21:30.960
>> When you say you,
you don't mean the project manager?

380
00:21:30.960 --> 00:21:35.250
You would normally offset that to
the human resource department?

381
00:21:35.250 --> 00:21:37.250
>> Right.
If you're following the policy,

382
00:21:37.250 --> 00:21:38.660
that's probably what's
gonna end up happening.

383
00:21:38.660 --> 00:21:41.810
But you as the actual project manager,
they're gonna come to you and

384
00:21:41.810 --> 00:21:45.240
say how do you want us to try and
resolve this first?

385
00:21:45.240 --> 00:21:46.920
Because you're actually the lead here.

386
00:21:46.920 --> 00:21:50.280
If you need to keep them, you're gonna
ask them can they actually try and

387
00:21:50.280 --> 00:21:54.810
mediate this somehow, or try and actually
do some disciplinary action instead of

388
00:21:54.810 --> 00:21:56.770
actually just relieving
them of their duty.

389
00:21:56.770 --> 00:21:59.660
But overall though, you might find
out that they may have to do that.

390
00:22:00.960 --> 00:22:05.160
Also, the other thing that you have to be
willing to deal with here are, of course,

391
00:22:05.160 --> 00:22:08.530
are disgruntled team members and
you've got to be careful here too.

392
00:22:08.530 --> 00:22:13.920
Make sure that as you listen to them,
make sure you try and

393
00:22:13.920 --> 00:22:16.560
figure out what the cause
of the dissatisfaction is.

394
00:22:16.560 --> 00:22:19.240
I think I misspelled dissatisfaction.

395
00:22:19.240 --> 00:22:22.817
If that happens, dissatisfaction,

396
00:22:22.817 --> 00:22:28.890
make sure you stick to the facts and
that's actually key here.

397
00:22:28.890 --> 00:22:32.310
Don't embellish, don't take it away,
don't minimize it.

398
00:22:32.310 --> 00:22:34.360
Make sure you stick to the facts.

399
00:22:34.360 --> 00:22:38.692
Ask for concrete situations in
which they really are upset.

400
00:22:38.692 --> 00:22:41.800
Don't say, this is how it seems to be.

401
00:22:41.800 --> 00:22:43.410
Seems to be is not enough,

402
00:22:43.410 --> 00:22:45.780
give me an example of what's
actually happened as well.

403
00:22:46.790 --> 00:22:51.530
If it can't work out, try and replace
that person and get it done quickly, and

404
00:22:51.530 --> 00:22:55.260
then clarify and restate what the
resolution is, because there may not be

405
00:22:55.260 --> 00:22:58.900
a resolution with that person and you
just don't have the time to deal with it.

406
00:22:58.900 --> 00:23:02.210
There are many ways that we can
handle the idea of replacement or

407
00:23:02.210 --> 00:23:05.740
the idea here of relieving
somebody of their job duty

408
00:23:05.740 --> 00:23:08.780
as far as personnel removal and
replacement goes.

409
00:23:08.780 --> 00:23:13.240
But it's actually very clear that it has
to be done sometimes and it may fall on

410
00:23:13.240 --> 00:23:17.620
you as the project manager to actually
indicate that it has to be done as well.

411
00:23:17.620 --> 00:23:23.060
There are a lot of things that we really
do have to make sure we take into account.

412
00:23:23.060 --> 00:23:27.180
Personnel management, the great thing
is if you have a good HR department,

413
00:23:27.180 --> 00:23:30.240
you tend to just follow whatever the
policy is and you tell everybody onboard-

414
00:23:30.240 --> 00:23:31.420
>> Leave the guess work out of it.

415
00:23:31.420 --> 00:23:34.880
>> Yup, we're following it and not trying
to make up our own policies instead and

416
00:23:34.880 --> 00:23:37.360
that was actually what will
help you out the most.

417
00:23:37.360 --> 00:23:40.370
So make sure you do take a look at
this idea of conflict resolution.

418
00:23:40.370 --> 00:23:43.270
>> Ronnie, thank you so much for
showing us some alternatives we

419
00:23:43.270 --> 00:23:46.800
have before we actually do have to go
ahead and terminate that employee.

420
00:23:46.800 --> 00:23:48.580
Thank you guys so much for staying tuned.

421
00:23:48.580 --> 00:23:50.546
We have some more
Project+ coming your way.

422
00:23:50.546 --> 00:23:52.174
I'm Cherokee Boose.

423
00:23:52.174 --> 00:23:53.420
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

424
00:23:53.420 --> 00:23:55.496
>> Signing off, have a great one.

425
00:23:55.496 --> 00:24:01.618
[MUSIC]

426
00:24:01.618 --> 00:24:06.370
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: This episode is chock full of risk strategies and actives. Ronnie and Cherokee look at some risk responses and when they would be acceptable. We also look at tools to help identify and analyze risk. By prioritizing we are then able to focus our efforts.
episodes.title: Predict Impact of Constraints and Influences
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:01.180
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.180 --> 00:00:08.230
I'm your host, Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.230 --> 00:00:12.606
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.606 --> 00:00:17.170
>> Welcome to another CompTIA Project+
episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:17.170 --> 00:00:19.180
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:19.180 --> 00:00:22.010
In this episode,
we are gonna be honing in in our psychic

7
00:00:22.010 --> 00:00:27.180
ability to be able to predict the
constraints and influences on projects.

8
00:00:27.180 --> 00:00:28.530
Wait, no we're not.

9
00:00:28.530 --> 00:00:30.900
Just kidding guys, we have Mr.
Ronnie Wong with us.

10
00:00:30.900 --> 00:00:33.520
He's gonna give us some great tips on
actually how to go ahead and do that.

11
00:00:33.520 --> 00:00:34.780
Thank you for being here, Ronnie.

12
00:00:34.780 --> 00:00:36.490
>> Well, thank you for
having me back on the show.

13
00:00:36.490 --> 00:00:39.480
This is not that kinda
predictive ability but

14
00:00:39.480 --> 00:00:44.710
it should actually help us to understand
that there are a few things that

15
00:00:44.710 --> 00:00:49.050
do happen on projects and we actually
just need to be able to identify them.

16
00:00:49.050 --> 00:00:51.430
And we need to understand
where they do fit in.

17
00:00:51.430 --> 00:00:53.084
So that we can already go ahead and

18
00:00:53.084 --> 00:00:55.575
start planning what we
are going to do about them.

19
00:00:55.575 --> 00:00:57.520
In other words,
we wanna actually know, hey,

20
00:00:57.520 --> 00:00:59.860
what are these things
really going to happen?

21
00:00:59.860 --> 00:01:04.030
And the official objective we call on
the ability to predict the way these

22
00:01:04.030 --> 00:01:08.700
influences and of course constraints
are going to impact our project.

23
00:01:08.700 --> 00:01:12.515
And so, that is what we're gonna
take a look at today as we begin.

24
00:01:12.515 --> 00:01:13.995
So when we start to take a look,

25
00:01:13.995 --> 00:01:15.927
we're gonna deal in those
two areas specifically.

26
00:01:15.927 --> 00:01:18.185
We wanna understand what
the influences are and

27
00:01:18.185 --> 00:01:20.835
also what our constraints are as well.

28
00:01:20.835 --> 00:01:23.675
The great thing is, since we've already
been talking about constraints throughout

29
00:01:23.675 --> 00:01:26.325
the entire show,
we're gonna deal with that second but

30
00:01:26.325 --> 00:01:29.720
we wanna begin with the idea of
influences and where we wanna start.

31
00:01:29.720 --> 00:01:32.720
>> Yeah, let's go ahead and
take a look at influence at the project.

32
00:01:32.720 --> 00:01:37.350
And then, we'll also look at how we can
go ahead and schedule, any kind of delays

33
00:01:37.350 --> 00:01:41.390
in the schedules or any kind of resource
allocation issues that may arise.

34
00:01:41.390 --> 00:01:45.460
>> Right, so when you start taking
a look at the idea here of influences

35
00:01:45.460 --> 00:01:49.370
we're not really just talking about
things that happen along the way

36
00:01:49.370 --> 00:01:53.430
that prevent us from getting
things done in our project.

37
00:01:53.430 --> 00:01:57.030
So delays and of course allocations,
resource allocations.

38
00:01:57.030 --> 00:01:59.620
But what we're really
talking about are overall

39
00:01:59.620 --> 00:02:02.715
things that can influence
the entirety of the project, and

40
00:02:02.715 --> 00:02:05.595
we wanna make sure that we
understand how they impact us.

41
00:02:05.595 --> 00:02:09.715
So one of those ideas then that we
need to talk about here of course,

42
00:02:09.715 --> 00:02:15.125
is the idea of some type of change
request that goes on during our project.

43
00:02:15.125 --> 00:02:19.980
It is not uncommon that as a project
develops and its people start seeing

44
00:02:19.980 --> 00:02:23.910
the little deliverables that we're
actually producing the way or

45
00:02:23.910 --> 00:02:27.620
they're starting to see the path that
it looks like the projects going,

46
00:02:27.620 --> 00:02:31.390
that somebody then says,
I have a great idea this right now.

47
00:02:31.390 --> 00:02:34.790
And then, what they want to do is that
they want to actually make a request

48
00:02:34.790 --> 00:02:39.690
change, that we actually include
into the project at this point.

49
00:02:39.690 --> 00:02:44.520
Now, Cherokee, both of us have dealt with
the idea of project management before.

50
00:02:44.520 --> 00:02:49.450
We understand something that change
request, a fly like that getting into

51
00:02:49.450 --> 00:02:51.769
the ointment, is that actually
a good thing or a bad thing?

52
00:02:53.300 --> 00:02:54.940
>> It could be both.

53
00:02:54.940 --> 00:02:58.812
If it's a change that has a positive
outcome, Ronnie, then I would say,

54
00:02:58.812 --> 00:03:00.090
definitely go for it.

55
00:03:00.090 --> 00:03:03.620
But you might have to go through
the project management office, or

56
00:03:03.620 --> 00:03:06.650
the change advisory board, so
it might kinda delay things a bit.

57
00:03:06.650 --> 00:03:09.330
But it could overall
have a positive impact.

58
00:03:09.330 --> 00:03:13.780
>> Yeah, it can have a positive impact but
the impact whether it's positive or

59
00:03:13.780 --> 00:03:16.490
negative though the problem
that we have with the idea of

60
00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:21.510
just a change request coming along and
it's impact is the idea that

61
00:03:21.510 --> 00:03:24.710
it can actually not just slow down the
work but it can change the entire work.

62
00:03:26.010 --> 00:03:28.850
So it might be where
a minor request change, and

63
00:03:28.850 --> 00:03:30.250
somebody says, this is just minor.

64
00:03:30.250 --> 00:03:31.700
You don't have to worry about this.

65
00:03:31.700 --> 00:03:33.960
Might actually turn out
to be something major,

66
00:03:33.960 --> 00:03:35.698
to the point where you have to go back to.

67

518
00:27:05.910 --> 00:27:10.220
And so it's very easy to go directly
to one of those developers and do that.

519
00:27:10.220 --> 00:27:14.253
Well, they're already working on
projects to help make everything better,

520
00:27:14.253 --> 00:27:16.817
so instead what we did is
that we put in place here,

521
00:27:16.817 --> 00:27:19.860
we actually have them all
funnel through one person.

522
00:27:19.860 --> 00:27:20.980
And if you need changes or

523
00:27:20.980 --> 00:27:23.010
you need to actually relate
something to the development team,

524
00:27:23.010 --> 00:27:25.250
you actually go to that one person.

525
00:27:25.250 --> 00:27:29.590
And that one person is who actually
communicates, so they know

526
00:27:29.590 --> 00:27:34.520
who they're really answering to is one
person and not multiple people as well.

527
00:27:34.520 --> 00:27:38.580
And then of course, if you have multiple
shared resources that you have to

528
00:27:38.580 --> 00:27:43.040
depend on, you've gotta realize then
that that means that your resources also

529
00:27:43.040 --> 00:27:47.680
are gonna be influenced by other projects
because of the shared resources and

530
00:27:47.680 --> 00:27:49.400
the shared availability.

531
00:27:49.400 --> 00:27:52.790
It means your negotiation
skills have to be up to par,

532
00:27:52.790 --> 00:27:56.220
if you're gonna actually try to control
the amount of influence from any one of

533
00:27:56.220 --> 00:28:01.630
these things that we've mentioned as far
as the past, in past several minutes here.

534
00:28:01.630 --> 00:28:05.560
So be aware of these as being kind of
major influences that we still have to

535
00:28:05.560 --> 00:28:10.510
actually learn how to control or limit and
deal with as we start moving through our

536
00:28:10.510 --> 00:28:15.140
project management planning and then
even into the execution phase as well.

537
00:28:15.140 --> 00:28:19.660
>> Thank you Ronnie for showing us these
methods and looking at the different types

538
00:28:19.660 --> 00:28:22.530
of constraints and influences
that we may come across because I

539
00:28:22.530 --> 00:28:27.200
don't think we can really rely on my
nonexistent psychic abilities here.

540
00:28:27.200 --> 00:28:30.380
By actually putting a little bit
of knowledge and planning and

541
00:28:30.380 --> 00:28:33.940
thought into this, then I think we're
gonna get a lot further than that.

542
00:28:33.940 --> 00:28:35.060
So, thank you.

543
00:28:35.060 --> 00:28:38.120
And thank you guys for joining us today,
I appreciate you being here.

544
00:28:38.120 --> 00:28:40.860
We have more Project+ to come,
so stay tuned.

545
00:28:40.860 --> 00:28:41.750
I'm Cherokee Boose.

546
00:28:41.750 --> 00:28:42.730
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

547
00:28:42.730 --> 00:28:45.460
>> Signing off, have a great day.

548
00:28:45.460 --> 00:28:51.423
[MUSIC]

549
00:28:51.423 --> 00:28:55.810
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation. Ronnie and Cherokee pick up examining the impact of project constraints and influences. You will learn the importance of monitoring elements such as cost, scope and scheduling to see how they can reduce the probability of exceeding limitations and help keep the project on track.
episodes.title: Predict Impact of Contraints and Influences Part 2

WEBVTT

constraints and influences,

With us today we have, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

As we continue on taking a look at more

Now, we spend on a whole episode

influences that we have to learn how

And now we're focusing

I am talking about them

Now when we start taking look

we really wanna make
sure that we understand.

At least examples of what we mean,

The idea of scope being a constraint and

00:01:09.900 --> 00:01:13.080
So these are actually

So that's what we're gonna just briefly

So when we start to actually

Time, we normally allow

Even requirements, we might say 90%

So one of the key things that I

You also hear this idea that

It's not about always

48

49

It's not always about finishing over cost,

50

What we want to do with the idea

52

53
00:02:58.620 --> 00:03:00.490

54

But not a lot that we want
our project to really finish

as if we said we planned
it out to the dollar and

57
00:03:12.210 --> 00:03:16.190
Now, Cherokee, when it comes down to

as always trying to say let's

59

And always finish below budget,

60

>> Yeah and
Ronnie I was just thinking about that,

it doesn't always go according to plan.

62

I mean it's a great idea,
hey I wanna go ahead and

what happens if you have
a poorly managed project and

with your costs how do you

66

>> Yeah, you have to actually be
very careful here because with

67
00:03:42.040 --> 00:03:46.110
poorly managed cost, the weird thing
is how it's actually displayed and

68
00:03:46.110 --> 00:03:49.550
how a project manager takes
advantages to get us back on track.

69
00:03:49.550 --> 00:03:52.640
In the way that we need
with cost as a constraint.

70
00:03:52.640 --> 00:03:58.180
So do I mean with a poorly managed

71
00:03:58.180 --> 00:04:00.340
Well it's just like I was describing.

A project can be poorly managed if,

00:04:08.300 --> 00:04:10.430
And that makes us the most of us, right?

If I tell you, you are only supposed

And then everytime you turn in, something

After a while, I'm gonna have to

See, that's the key.

It's great if you know why it happens.

83

And then you let me know why it happens.

84

But if that's the answer that I get,

85
00:04:35.440 --> 00:04:39.975
right, the only answer that I get is,
Ronnie it happens.

86
00:04:39.975 --> 00:04:42.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now I have to wonder like, what didn't

00:04:42.680 --> 00:04:48.110
I make clear when I told Cherokee that

And so, now Cherokee has to think about
that idea and somewhere along the line,

00:04:53.050 --> 00:04:58.340
that means I didn't communicate enough,

00:04:58.340 --> 00:05:00.630

Now, what is the result of

that's what we need to ask Cherokee

Now at the beginning of

if Cherokee started, hopefully not by 50%

But I know she's laughing at me but I'm

At the beginning,
it doesn't really seem to matter.

So let's take for an example that

98
00:05:26.890 --> 00:05:32.030
So Cherokee, if it's a month long project,
let's say we take ten tasks a week.

99
00:05:32.030 --> 00:05:34.251
Okay, at $100,
that should be $1000, right?

100
00:05:34.251 --> 00:05:40.810
So at the end of the first week, you turn

00:05:40.810 --> 00:05:42.280
And you now spent $1500.

102
00:05:42.280 --> 00:05:45.645
Well then at first we go, okay.

103
00:05:45.645 --> 00:05:49.210
Cherokee goes, it happens, that's fine.

104
00:05:49.210 --> 00:05:53.500
Second week, we do the same thing,
well now all of a sudden,

00:05:53.500 --> 00:05:56.510

00:05:56.510 --> 00:06:01.250
And I now start to go, okay so

107
00:06:01.250 --> 00:06:04.080
Okay I have to accept it at this point.

108
00:06:04.080 --> 00:06:05.900
Now, what if though?

00:06:05.900 --> 00:06:07.270
Okay let's take it this way.

What if the original budget that I

So let's say about 400 of these smaller,

I'm trying to make sure

40 of these particular tasks and

$4,000.

Well now at this point in time,

Yeah, if you behaved, if it's actually

You're already up at $3,000.

00:06:48.888 --> 00:06:49.490
>> 3,000.

00:06:49.490 --> 00:06:50.160
>> Right?
>> Hm-mm.

So now Cherokee comes to

Well the problem is I had $4,000.

00:07:10.840 --> 00:07:13.195
Cherokee, you are now up to $4,500.

Now, what does that mean?

132

It means one I'm over budget,

We're still okay here.

To pull money to pay for

137
00:07:33.570 --> 00:07:38.710
Now this is where I have project

So now what do I do, Cherokee,

Let me lay down the facts

00:07:58.114 --> 00:08:01.027

00:08:04.683 --> 00:08:07.710

146

>> Yeah, no, that's a great idea, okay.

So something like that actually does work.

148
00:08:12.670 --> 00:08:16.480
But now as a project manager though,
right, I'm suppose to keep on schedule.

149
00:08:16.480 --> 00:08:19.810
And it's not like I'd go,
okay Cherokee, yeah,

00:08:19.810 --> 00:08:23.960

151
00:08:23.960 --> 00:08:28.418
But, what I start to tell Cherokee is,
Cherokee,

152
00:08:28.418 --> 00:08:33.395
you need to find ways that we can cut,
[LAUGH] we can cut that

153
00:08:33.395 --> 00:08:38.805
final week's budget, so
that it at least looks okay, okay?

154
00:08:38.805 --> 00:08:40.060
So, what does that mean?

155
00:08:40.060 --> 00:08:43.931
That means now Cherokee has
to go back to her team and

157
00:08:48.714 --> 00:08:52.460
She can actually start looking out,
and saying, okay,

00:08:52.460 --> 00:08:56.360

159
00:08:56.360 --> 00:09:00.370
Can I trim that a little bit

160
00:09:00.370 --> 00:09:04.870
Do I really need to make sure
that everything is finished up or

00:09:04.870 --> 00:09:07.720

finished at this point?

162
00:09:07.720 --> 00:09:11.680
I know Cherokee wouldn't do anything like
that, but let's say that that's what I

163
00:09:11.680 --> 00:09:15.020
really intimate for her to do,
is that she needs to do that.

164
00:09:15.020 --> 00:09:20.200
Well, what does that mean overall for the
entirety of the project constrain itself?

165
00:09:20.200 --> 00:09:24.170
It means that constraint has now
forced me to cut deliverables, okay?

166
00:09:24.170 --> 00:09:27.480
The cost itself because I
don't have any money to spend,

167
00:09:27.480 --> 00:09:30.870

that's it.

168
00:09:30.870 --> 00:09:34.825
We don't have anymore money,
you already spent $500 to $1000 more and

169
00:09:34.825 --> 00:09:38.910
I took it out of next month's budget
which means, they're gonna be behind.

170
00:09:38.910 --> 00:09:41.738
So Cherokee, right now, the final week.

171
00:09:41.738 --> 00:09:44.650
You know, you've got to make
it on the paper thin budget

172
00:09:44.650 --> 00:09:46.730

173
00:09:46.730 --> 00:09:49.260
At this point or
there is not going to be any money.

174
00:09:49.260 --> 00:09:50.780
Imagine that that
continues to happen though.

175
00:09:50.780 --> 00:09:52.125
Lets say that the project was year long.

176
00:09:52.125 --> 00:09:54.790
Cherokee turned in that for
the first three months.

177
00:09:54.790 --> 00:09:59.470
And now we are actually so
far behind on just money being spent

178
00:09:59.470 --> 00:10:04.190

guys we don't have any money.

179
00:10:04.190 --> 00:10:05.280
We're done.

180
00:10:05.280 --> 00:10:09.408
So this is why it's very important
that as far as overspending goes,

181
00:10:09.408 --> 00:10:10.838
that we try and go what?

182
00:10:10.838 --> 00:10:11.840
We don't overspend.

183
00:10:11.840 --> 00:10:13.930
That makes the most logical
sense in the world.

184
00:10:13.930 --> 00:10:16.390
Okay, but let's go the other way.

185
00:10:16.390 --> 00:10:20.330
Okay, let's also say,
what if now Cherokee does better.

186
00:10:20.330 --> 00:10:23.834
Every week instead of $1,000,
she turns in $800.

187
00:10:23.834 --> 00:10:29.030
Well I'm probably happy as a clam, because
I'm just, yes, I've got more money to go.

188
00:10:29.030 --> 00:10:33.540
But where I need to actually ask better
questions, is I need to go to Cherokee

189
00:10:33.540 --> 00:10:37.150
each week and go, Cherokee, I'm not
saying that you had to spend a thousand,

190
00:10:37.150 --> 00:10:39.630
because I really don't want you to.

191
00:10:39.630 --> 00:10:42.535
But why didn't you spend that thousand?

192
00:10:42.535 --> 00:10:44.210
Ronnie, as project
manager might just be so

193

>> Yeah, so the county that I'm from,
they kind of have this concept to

418
00:23:13.179 --> 00:23:17.226
keep the old Florida culture,
which I understand that.

419
00:23:17.226 --> 00:23:21.582
But it is for development,
new businesses, new construction.

420
00:23:21.582 --> 00:23:25.786
There are a lot of additional fees,and a
lot of extra hoops that you have to go to

421
00:23:25.786 --> 00:23:28.520
just to kind of keep that social concept.

422
00:23:28.520 --> 00:23:30.019
>> Yeah, and so any of these things,

423
00:23:30.019 --> 00:23:33.077
whether you're talking about
social concept, internal politics,

424
00:23:33.077 --> 00:23:36.146
these are all kind of bellweather
things that you have to worry about.

425
00:23:36.146 --> 00:23:39.676
Because you might find yourself ready to
start, and then your company says, yeah,

426
00:23:39.676 --> 00:23:41.176
we're not gonna do that right now.

427
00:23:41.176 --> 00:23:44.285
Because we're dealing with so
many other things, so

428
00:23:44.285 --> 00:23:49.360
you do have to worry about all of these,
and they all do end up costing you.

429
00:23:49.360 --> 00:23:53.736
Whether it's your entire project,
they cost you time, they cost you money,

430
00:23:53.736 --> 00:23:55.208
don't have to deal with.

431
00:23:55.208 --> 00:23:59.498
And in the end, you might find out your
company just does a budget analysis and

432
00:23:59.498 --> 00:24:02.078
goes, look,
we can push this thing through.

433
00:24:02.078 --> 00:24:05.599
But with the additional fees like
what Cherokee's talking about,

434
00:24:05.599 --> 00:24:07.832
we really can't we just can't afford to.

435
00:24:07.832 --> 00:24:10.913
>> Yeah, all that bureaucratic tape
can really shy people away from

436
00:24:10.913 --> 00:24:13.722
even going to go ahead and
start their project in your area.

437
00:24:13.722 --> 00:24:18.133
>> So you imagine then that every single
project may have some one of these,

438
00:24:18.133 --> 00:24:22.835
if not all of these different types of
constraints depending on the size, and

439
00:24:22.835 --> 00:24:25.870
of course, the nature of that project.

440
00:24:25.870 --> 00:24:29.830
So learning how to deal with constraints
is in the realm of project managers and

441
00:24:29.830 --> 00:24:31.992
we should take a look at those influences.

442
00:24:31.992 --> 00:24:37.347
And those constraints to really help us to
deal with the fact that, hey, all this is

443
00:24:37.347 --> 00:24:42.710
gonna be under our particular direction,
and under our navigation as well.

444
00:24:42.710 --> 00:24:47.000
And so that's why you actually need
to understand them a bit more.

445
00:24:47.000 --> 00:24:51.370
So that is pretty much all the constraints
that I have to deal with for right now.

446
00:24:51.370 --> 00:24:54.490
>> All right,
well I think that sounds good, Ronnie.

447
00:24:54.490 --> 00:24:58.660
Thank you for taking the time to go ahead
and show us the ways we can go ahead and

448
00:24:58.660 --> 00:25:02.520
predict any kind of constraints and
influences for our projects.

449
00:25:02.520 --> 00:25:05.112
And thank you guys for tuning in today.

450
00:25:05.112 --> 00:25:06.868
We have some more project
plus coming your way.

451
00:25:06.868 --> 00:25:09.115
So stay tuned for that,
I'm Cherokee Boose.

452
00:25:09.115 --> 00:25:10.131
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

453
00:25:10.131 --> 00:25:11.067
>> Have a great one, bye.

454

[MUSIC]

455
00:25:19.384 --> 00:25:21.115

episodes.description: This episode is chock full of risk strategies and actives. Ronnie and Cherokee look at some risk responses and when they would be acceptable. We also look at tools to help identify and analyze risk. By prioritizing we are then able to focus our efforts.
episodes.title: Explain Risk Strategies and Activities

11

As we take a look at this idea of risk

we understand the importance of

And in that way we are gonna talk

dealing with the idea of risks and of

And to be able to understand
what impact that they have

But we, of course, want you to

25
00:01:20.030 --> 00:01:21.450
So let's make sure that we understand.

26

Remember that a lot of times,
especially on this exam,

the terminology's gonna be important so
make sure you also pay attention to

terminologies if the actual contents
sound incredibly familiar to you.

29

So that's where we're gonna begin and

30

And then we will talk about some other

31
00:01:39.582 --> 00:01:43.900
>> Yeah Ronnie, I was going to go ahead
and ask you, in other types of training or

32
00:01:43.900 --> 00:01:47.100
certification that you may have
studied we might have looked at some

33
00:01:47.100 --> 00:01:49.330
risk mitigation and so forth.

34

So are there any kinds of specific
risks that are associated with project

35
00:01:52.884 --> 00:01:55.140
management that we should be aware of?

36

Well, when it comes down to
project management it's kind of

37
00:01:58.020 --> 00:02:01.770
a little bit unusual because of
the way that we tend to define risk

38
00:02:01.770 --> 00:02:05.210
in security types of environments, right.

39

When you move into the realm of IT
security, when you hear the term risk,

40

okay, it's never really

41

But in project management though,

42

risk actually does have the tone of there

44

So a lot of times what we have to be

45

is to make sure that we can identify
the differences in terms of risk,

46
00:02:32.130 --> 00:02:33.961
whether they're considered
something positive or

47
00:02:33.961 --> 00:02:37.700
whether they're negative as well and we're
gonna associate some words with those.

48
00:02:37.700 --> 00:02:41.260
So let's take a look at my screen as
we talk up some of these concepts.

49
00:02:41.260 --> 00:02:44.810
So the first thing that we want to
understand is that in project management

50
00:02:44.810 --> 00:02:46.910

51
00:02:46.910 --> 00:02:51.280
And normally that brings on
a negative connotation, okay, for

52
00:02:51.280 --> 00:02:53.092
what we actually are talking about.

53
00:02:53.092 --> 00:02:56.420
And so when we start thinking
about the idea of a risk threat,

54
00:02:56.420 --> 00:02:58.995
we are normally thinking about
things like vulnerabilities,

55
00:02:58.995 --> 00:03:01.110
okay, that we actually
have to worry about.

56
00:03:01.110 --> 00:03:07.615
So a vulnerability, for example, that's
a risk is that we rely on a contractor,

57
00:03:07.615 --> 00:03:11.190
right, but the contractor that we've
been dealing with, let's just say for

58
00:03:11.190 --> 00:03:15.720
example, has just retired and
they've now sold it out to a new company.

59
00:03:15.720 --> 00:03:18.550
The contract, they say,
is still good and it still exists.

60
00:03:18.550 --> 00:03:21.300
Well, that could actually
be a risky thing to say,

61
00:03:21.300 --> 00:03:25.530
I've never dealt with this
particular contractor, even though

62
00:03:25.530 --> 00:03:29.670
that person has now bought this firm out
and we're willing to deal with them.

63
00:03:29.670 --> 00:03:31.080
So you might actually
take a look at that and

64
00:03:31.080 --> 00:03:35.020
that might actually become a threat to
your project if you don't know that person

65
00:03:35.020 --> 00:03:39.050
that's actually there, you don't
trust fully yet what they can do.

66
00:03:39.050 --> 00:03:42.350
I'm not saying it can't turn out to be
an opportunity at the same time, but

67
00:03:42.350 --> 00:03:45.740
that's normally what we also have
to understand as well, okay.

68
00:03:45.740 --> 00:03:49.960
Along with that, of course then, when we
start talking about risk management and

69
00:03:49.960 --> 00:03:51.940
some of the other things
that we have to deal with.

70
00:03:51.940 --> 00:03:55.760
Risk management not only has do
what identifying those things

71
00:03:55.760 --> 00:04:00.600
as the threats and opportunities but
also analyzing their potential.

72
00:04:00.600 --> 00:04:03.850
And we're gonna get into
the realm of quantitative and

73
00:04:03.850 --> 00:04:06.230
qualitative risk analysis.

74
00:04:06.230 --> 00:04:09.790
Now if those terms sounds
like kind of we're talking

75
00:04:09.790 --> 00:04:13.410
in terms we don't normally speak in,
you're probably right but

76
00:04:13.410 --> 00:04:15.890
we'll break it down for
you and we'll talk about that.

77
00:04:15.890 --> 00:04:19.160
And we're not gonna get into the most
technical understanding of everything, but

78
00:04:19.160 --> 00:04:21.400
we'll at least show you
examples of them as well.

79
00:04:21.400 --> 00:04:24.460
>> And for the remainder of the terms that
you do have on your display there, Ronnie,

80
00:04:24.460 --> 00:04:28.640
a lot of those, if you guys are studying
for other certifications like Security+,

81
00:04:28.640 --> 00:04:31.730
they probably look eerily similar,
hint, hint.

82
00:04:31.730 --> 00:04:33.020
[LAUGH]
>> No,

83
00:04:33.020 --> 00:04:35.040
there's no doubt that
you'll see these terms.

84
00:04:35.040 --> 00:04:40.000
And the reason why is that risk itself,
okay, when we deal with them, okay,

85
00:04:40.000 --> 00:04:43.980
the key here is not to deal with
them any way that we feel, okay.

86
00:04:43.980 --> 00:04:49.290
They key word here believe it or not is
actually this particular adjective right

87
00:04:49.290 --> 00:04:55.280
here, okay, or adverb I should say,
appropriately responding, okay.

88
00:04:55.280 --> 00:04:59.560
We can all deal with risk, okay,
in any fashion that we want to, okay.

89
00:04:59.560 --> 00:05:02.694
The problem is that a lot of those
fashions, the way that we deal with risk,

90
00:05:02.694 --> 00:05:05.620
they're in appropriate ways
that we deal with risk, okay.

91
00:05:05.620 --> 00:05:08.050
We can run and throw a tantrum, okay.

92
00:05:08.050 --> 00:05:10.920
We can run off and
slug somebody right in the jaw.

93
00:05:10.920 --> 00:05:14.260
That doesn't necessary mitigate
anything of risk that you have.

94
00:05:14.260 --> 00:05:17.330
But what we're talking about here,
of course, is the appropriate manner

95
00:05:17.330 --> 00:05:21.340
in responding to the risk that
end up happening to your project.

96
00:05:21.340 --> 00:05:24.250
So the key, first of all then,
is to identify

97
00:05:24.250 --> 00:05:29.205
whether we're talking about a risk, or a
threat or an opportunity in terms of risk,

98
00:05:29.205 --> 00:05:34.020
okay, and then from that point here's
usually how it breaks down, okay.

99
00:05:34.020 --> 00:05:38.620
In terms of opportunities,
we may transfer that risk, okay.

100
00:05:38.620 --> 00:05:42.910
We may say, all right, I don't have
the time to deal with it right now, but

101
00:05:42.910 --> 00:05:48.150
I see this as a potential opportunity and
I want to ensure that for my future.

102
00:05:48.150 --> 00:05:51.790
So maybe where you invest in
something a little bit later on and

103
00:05:51.790 --> 00:05:52.290
what are you doing?

104
00:05:52.290 --> 00:05:54.880
You're putting essentially
a down payment towards that

105
00:05:54.880 --> 00:05:56.570
if you want to do something, okay.

106
00:05:56.570 --> 00:05:58.970
The other ones are what we
call exploit and enhance.

107
00:05:58.970 --> 00:06:02.170
And even though I've got them separated
out as two different lines here,

108
00:06:02.170 --> 00:06:04.410
they're kind of very similar, okay.

109
00:06:04.410 --> 00:06:08.449
The idea of taking advantage of whatever
opportunity it is that's presented.

110
00:06:09.500 --> 00:06:14.020
Now at the same time, even though we might
see them as being an opportunity for

111
00:06:14.020 --> 00:06:18.680
our future, other people may see
them as being a threat as well.

112
00:06:18.680 --> 00:06:21.720
So you might take advantage
of an opportunity, for

113
00:06:21.720 --> 00:06:26.190
somebody that is called risk adverse,
says no way, I would never touch that.

114
00:06:26.190 --> 00:06:30.440
If you're risk neutral or you're actually
one of those people that enjoys being risk

115
00:06:30.440 --> 00:06:34.220
active, or what do they call it,
I can't remember the actual proper term,

116
00:06:34.220 --> 00:06:36.530
that loves risk,
embraces the idea of risk.

117
00:06:36.530 --> 00:06:37.650
>> Fortune favors the bold.

118
00:06:37.650 --> 00:06:39.600
>> Yeah, fortune favors the bold here.

119
00:06:39.600 --> 00:06:43.324
Yeah, that type of thing, you may
choose to go ahead and exploit that,

120
00:06:43.324 --> 00:06:47.173
in other take advantage of it now and
actually even do everything you can to

121
00:06:47.173 --> 00:06:50.060
enhance the fact that
that risk may happen.

122
00:06:50.060 --> 00:06:53.020
Most of us though take a look
at risk as being negative.

123
00:06:53.020 --> 00:06:57.630
So usually for us in terms of the way that
we appropriately respond to them, we may

124
00:06:57.630 --> 00:07:01.720
talk about the idea of avoidance, in
other words, just stay out of it as well.

125
00:07:01.720 --> 00:07:04.400
We have to accept it because there's
really nothing else we can do.

126
00:07:04.400 --> 00:07:07.200
And then we can even mention
the idea of mitigation,

127
00:07:07.200 --> 00:07:12.480
to minimize as much as we can when
dealing with these different activities.

128
00:07:12.480 --> 00:07:16.610
So a lot of times you may want to
actually take a look at this, okay.

129
00:07:16.610 --> 00:07:20.122
So the idea of avoidance here,
okay, you may actually just say,

130
00:07:20.122 --> 00:07:24.080
all right, in terms of just avoiding,
you don't deal with the risk.

131
00:07:24.080 --> 00:07:28.530
So if you think about something like that,
okay, you have to kind of go, okay,

132
00:07:28.530 --> 00:07:30.610
I didn't deal with it but
we'll accept it as it comes along.

133
00:07:30.610 --> 00:07:34.630
So let's give a very realistic
example of something that may happen

134
00:07:34.630 --> 00:07:36.500
on a project site, okay.

135
00:07:36.500 --> 00:07:41.460
You go, look, we've tried within a 100
mile radius to rent every single

136
00:07:41.460 --> 00:07:46.470
generator that will give me 50,000 volt or

137
00:07:46.470 --> 00:07:49.610
watts or above, okay, and
there's none available.

138
00:07:49.610 --> 00:07:53.250
They can't be here in time for
what we need it, okay, to actually be.

139
00:07:53.250 --> 00:07:54.970
So instead what do you do?

140
00:07:54.970 --> 00:07:57.550
Do you just kind of go,
okay if power goes out, it goes out.

141
00:07:57.550 --> 00:07:58.460
Okay, and that's what you have.

142
00:07:58.460 --> 00:07:59.624
>> Get two smaller generators.

143
00:07:59.624 --> 00:08:02.584
>> Yeah hopefully you can get two smaller
generators, but what if you can't?

144
00:08:02.584 --> 00:08:05.061
In other words what if
those are actually gone?

145
00:08:05.061 --> 00:08:08.398
So at this point you just
kind of accept the risk.

146
00:08:08.398 --> 00:08:11.810
Now I even have a smaller
example which is fairly easy.

147
00:08:11.810 --> 00:08:14.810
That's a little bit more personal that it
helps us to understand the idea of just

148
00:08:14.810 --> 00:08:16.050
accepting risk.

149
00:08:16.050 --> 00:08:19.130
And that's why you go,
look I know a hurricane is coming through,

150
00:08:19.130 --> 00:08:22.050
but I'm just gonna stay put, okay?

151
00:08:22.050 --> 00:08:25.730
You're actively saying that I don't
care what the hurricane brings

152
00:08:25.730 --> 00:08:27.070
I'm just gonna stay put.

153
00:08:27.070 --> 00:08:30.070
And, at that particular point in time,
if you talk about the idea of power,

154
00:08:30.070 --> 00:08:33.560
you're staying put until the power
actually comes back on for

155
00:08:33.560 --> 00:08:35.440
you to do something, so that could be it.

156
00:08:35.440 --> 00:08:38.670
When you talk about the idea of
mitigation, that's when you go to, well,

157
00:08:38.670 --> 00:08:40.450
generators as well.

158
00:08:40.450 --> 00:08:43.290
Where you go, I know what I'm gonna do,
next time a power outage happens,

159
00:08:43.290 --> 00:08:47.540
I'm gonna buy a generator and that way
power goes out I have a generator on hand,

160
00:08:47.540 --> 00:08:50.040
that's the idea of mitigation as well.

161
00:08:50.040 --> 00:08:54.290
So there are different examples that you
can take a look at when you start dealing

162
00:08:54.290 --> 00:08:59.690
with this idea of taking a look
at the idea of responding and

163
00:08:59.690 --> 00:09:01.930
what we end up doing with this.

164
00:09:01.930 --> 00:09:07.730
Now as easy as that sounds, those are all
good things that we can understand and

165
00:09:07.730 --> 00:09:11.570
we've got to keep these things in our
mind as we start to deal with them.

166
00:09:11.570 --> 00:09:15.740
But sometimes, though,
it's not as easy to identify, okay?

167
00:09:15.740 --> 00:09:21.720
It's not very quick and scenarios
don't come to your mind as quickly.

168
00:09:21.720 --> 00:09:25.630
Sometimes they're actually technically
challenging to be able to understand

169
00:09:25.630 --> 00:09:28.310
whether it's something that I
need to deal with immediately or

170
00:09:28.310 --> 00:09:30.060
whether it's something I can put off.

171
00:09:30.060 --> 00:09:31.111
Whether I can go ahead and

172
00:09:31.111 --> 00:09:34.200
get insurance now or
do I need to do it a little bit later on.

173
00:09:34.200 --> 00:09:37.460
So what can you do at
that particular point

174
00:09:37.460 --> 00:09:40.080
when you start to take a look here, okay?

175
00:09:40.080 --> 00:09:43.910
Well, this is when you get into
the realm of analysis a little bit more.

176
00:09:43.910 --> 00:09:45.160
And the idea of analysis is simple,

177
00:09:45.160 --> 00:09:48.790
breaking it down into the smallest
components that gives us a measurable and

178
00:09:48.790 --> 00:09:51.650
an understandable idea of what
we're dealing with, okay?

179
00:09:51.650 --> 00:09:56.030
And in that sense, in terms of risk,
we tend to always break it down into what

180
00:09:56.030 --> 00:10:00.060
we call a quantitative analysis or
a qualitative analysis.

181
00:10:00.060 --> 00:10:04.160
And I've broken it down into four

00:10:04.160 --> 00:10:07.930

00:10:07.930 --> 00:10:13.030
So here at the very beginning

00:10:13.030 --> 00:10:15.557

its overall scope is pretty much

00:10:21.100 --> 00:10:23.474
When you're dealing with Per Risk,

00:10:23.474 --> 00:10:29.050

00:10:29.050 --> 00:10:32.130
Every risk you are trying

00:10:32.130 --> 00:10:36.040

type of analysis that we'll do.

00:10:36.040 --> 00:10:40.160
But if you're trying to determine the risk

00:10:40.160 --> 00:10:44.170

00:10:45.970 --> 00:10:50.713
The basis of qualitative analysis

A lot of times then we can take that and

569
00:31:52.940 --> 00:31:57.710

00:31:57.710 --> 00:32:01.640

00:32:01.640 --> 00:32:05.740

00:32:05.740 --> 00:32:09.220

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee analyze factors that may impact communication. Weather it be language barriers or times zones it is important to identify these factors as well as any effects they may have on your project.
episodes.title: Analyze Communication Factors

So moving from left to right,
usually a person begins with an idea.

22
00:01:06.620 --> 00:01:08.690
And that's what the lightbulb represents.

23

25

26

27

Those receivers are supposed to be able

read, get from instant messaging.

36
00:01:48.730 --> 00:01:50.460
Whatever it might be, and

So when they have that,

And some people will get exactly that.

Other people though,

00:02:09.530 --> 00:02:12.830
And then some people will outright
change whatever message that

00:02:18.580 --> 00:02:22.770
>> Yeah, and so it does happen
where you tend to see that process.

47
00:02:22.770 --> 00:02:24.680
And all these may have play the game,

00:02:24.680 --> 00:02:26.424
I can't everybody call
this something different.

00:02:26.424 --> 00:02:29.545
But it set the game where use to start
off by whispering in somebody's ear-.

50
00:02:29.545 --> 00:02:30.440
>> Telephone.
>> Telephone yeah,

51
00:02:30.440 --> 00:02:34.110
we are playing at the end,
you know, you might say,

52
00:02:34.110 --> 00:02:38.535
Ronnie has very long hair and at the end,
Ronnie's monkey here, what is that about?

53
00:02:38.535 --> 00:02:39.955
Whatever it might be right?

00:02:39.955 --> 00:02:41.095
So the message might change.

57
00:02:45.370 --> 00:02:48.365
>> [LAUGH]
>> It'd be hard to

58
00:02:48.365 --> 00:02:50.105

59
00:02:50.105 --> 00:02:53.065
But overall, though,
you might still see that.

60
00:02:53.065 --> 00:02:55.785
But in real life,
it still happens that way, right?

61
00:02:55.785 --> 00:02:59.210
When you say, hey,

62
00:02:59.210 --> 00:03:03.610
>> So, it's weird, what that message

63
00:03:03.610 --> 00:03:06.890
depending on what
situation that they're in.

64
00:03:06.890 --> 00:03:09.830
So, when you tell somebody that, they
may actually have that sense of dread,

65
00:03:09.830 --> 00:03:11.720

66
00:03:11.720 --> 00:03:13.620
Or, why is he calling me there?

00:03:13.620 --> 00:03:15.050
Or, I just need to get some information.

68
00:03:15.050 --> 00:03:15.920
Or, they're gonna ask me something.

69
00:03:15.920 --> 00:03:17.300
>> Getting called into
the principal's office.

70
00:03:17.300 --> 00:03:19.270
>> Yep, getting called into
the principal's office.

71
00:03:19.270 --> 00:03:21.760
You never know exactly what that's about.

72
00:03:21.760 --> 00:03:25.000
So you hear these same things go on.

73
00:03:25.000 --> 00:03:27.050
So here's the basic idea.

74
00:03:27.050 --> 00:03:29.520
Now you may be wondering
like I am at times like

75
00:03:29.520 --> 00:03:33.230
why in the world did they not
understand what it is that I said?

76
00:03:33.230 --> 00:03:37.490
And it could be that I absolutely
messed up my communication part.

77
00:03:37.490 --> 00:03:41.830
Even though it's right in my head the
communication part didn't turn out well.

78
00:03:41.830 --> 00:03:44.520
So I might not have actually
inflected my voice correctly,

79
00:03:44.520 --> 00:03:48.500
I may have put the wrong emphasis on
certain things that I didn't want to.

80
00:03:48.500 --> 00:03:50.470
And I emphasized other things.

81
00:03:50.470 --> 00:03:54.530
Whatever it might be what we're
talking about essentially is this

82
00:03:54.530 --> 00:03:56.430
pink line right here.

83
00:03:56.430 --> 00:04:00.650
And those are the different types of
factors that we have to account for

00:04:00.650 --> 00:04:03.100

85

And they essentially are what

00:04:06.020 --> 00:04:09.010
So when it comes down to

87
00:04:09.010 --> 00:04:10.840
this whole show is really

88
00:04:10.840 --> 00:04:15.470
It's kind of weird, but it is, it's about

89
00:04:15.470 --> 00:04:20.080
So that we can possibly attempt to

91
00:04:24.170 --> 00:04:26.570
So that we can communicate

92
00:04:26.570 --> 00:04:28.380

93
00:04:28.380 --> 00:04:32.750
So that is really what we're going to
take a look at at the beginning here.

94
00:04:32.750 --> 00:04:35.640
Is to take a look at
those different barriers.

95
00:04:35.640 --> 00:04:40.454
So the first one is actually probably one
