it happens to you directly.

97
00:04:42.120 --> 00:04:44.858
Now I'm gonna assume that
nobody's actually done this but

98
00:04:44.858 --> 00:04:47.332
it still happens to me every
once in a while Cherokee.

99
00:04:47.332 --> 00:04:51.247
While even though they,
I get introduced to somebody,

100
00:04:51.247 --> 00:04:56.600
they still talk to me the first time
like they have to speak incredibly loud.

101
00:04:57.780 --> 00:05:00.970
And I don't know why,
they have to over enunciate things.

102
00:05:00.970 --> 00:05:04.320
Like I may not understand
what's actually going on.

103
00:05:04.320 --> 00:05:08.120
So, I normally when I'm actually part of,
I mean what,

104
00:05:08.120 --> 00:05:11.720
I don't say a word because I don't wanna
see what the reaction this gonna be.

105
00:05:11.720 --> 00:05:16.712
So something like that is what they could
what I would consider a language barrier.

106
00:05:16.712 --> 00:05:17.926
Cherokee, has that ever happened to you?

107
00:05:17.926 --> 00:05:18.600
>> Yes it has.

108
00:05:18.600 --> 00:05:19.540
>> Yeah?

109
00:05:19.540 --> 00:05:24.350
>> I lived in south Florida and
pulling up to drive-throughs.

110
00:05:24.350 --> 00:05:26.930
The teller didn't speak English, so

111
00:05:26.930 --> 00:05:29.150
that was a little bit of
a culture shock for me.

112
00:05:29.150 --> 00:05:32.620
Also when my kid's pediatrician
called me on the phone,

113
00:05:32.620 --> 00:05:35.670
she just automatically started
speaking to me in Spanish also.

114
00:05:35.670 --> 00:05:38.738
>> Yeah, so when you have stuff like
that you've gotta imagine, then,

115
00:05:38.738 --> 00:05:41.964
that communication becomes a little
bit more difficult in terms of what we

116
00:05:41.964 --> 00:05:43.122
call a language barrier.

117
00:05:43.122 --> 00:05:46.143
Whether we're talking about meetings
in which you do have something like

118
00:05:46.143 --> 00:05:47.467
what Cherokee was describing.

119
00:05:47.467 --> 00:05:52.527
Or where I'm just standing there and
people just assume they have to explain

120
00:05:52.527 --> 00:05:57.980
everything to me in a very loud and very
over pronounce the types of a voice there.

121
00:05:57.980 --> 00:05:58.850
It happens and

122
00:05:58.850 --> 00:06:04.130
it can also of course happen when
the written word is also the same thing.

123
00:06:04.130 --> 00:06:07.020
So, for example if English is
your first language you tend to

124
00:06:07.020 --> 00:06:09.400
understand the following and the grammar.

125
00:06:09.400 --> 00:06:12.173
And you kind of understand
the sentence structure but

126
00:06:12.173 --> 00:06:15.690
sometimes if English is the second
language and they translate it.

127
00:06:15.690 --> 00:06:18.260
It doesn't sound the way that
you would expect it to sound.

128
00:06:18.260 --> 00:06:22.120
Yeah, sounds like Google Translator
because that's probably what it is.

129
00:06:22.120 --> 00:06:25.850
And then you have to try and figure
out what that message is going to be.

130
00:06:25.850 --> 00:06:28.710
So, when we start getting
information like that and

131
00:06:28.710 --> 00:06:34.030
we want to overcome
the barrier of language itself.

132
00:06:34.030 --> 00:06:36.480
You've got really a couple
of different things.

133
00:06:36.480 --> 00:06:38.430
One, you could learn the language and

134
00:06:38.430 --> 00:06:41.880
be conversational to
the fact that you master it.

135
00:06:41.880 --> 00:06:43.240
You could do that.

136
00:06:43.240 --> 00:06:45.960
In project management,
that's where a problem comes in.

137
00:06:45.960 --> 00:06:50.660
If you're not already naturally able
to communicate in that language

138
00:06:50.660 --> 00:06:56.460
you getting things done on a timely basis
is probably not going to work very well.

139
00:06:56.460 --> 00:06:58.460
So what do you tend to do?

140
00:06:58.460 --> 00:07:01.130
Well at that point you need a translator.

141
00:07:01.130 --> 00:07:06.100
And even though Google Voice may help
you out in translating some things.

142
00:07:06.100 --> 00:07:09.570
It may not help you in translating
highly technical things and

143
00:07:09.570 --> 00:07:12.360
that is where you have to
actually think as well.

144
00:07:12.360 --> 00:07:17.200
Normally this is where you might consider
the idea of getting a translator.

145
00:07:17.200 --> 00:07:20.860
Now just when I say that, translators,

146
00:07:20.860 --> 00:07:24.620
you need to be fairly specific about
what you want them to translate.

147
00:07:24.620 --> 00:07:29.750
And that means that you have to say I
want to know word for word what they say.

148
00:07:29.750 --> 00:07:33.340
Some translators will be able
to do the majority of that.

149
00:07:33.340 --> 00:07:36.650
Some translators may not
be able to do all of that.

150
00:07:36.650 --> 00:07:39.600
So it really depends on
what you need them for.

151
00:07:39.600 --> 00:07:44.819
But a translator, essentially, is one of
the methods that we can use to be able

152
00:07:44.819 --> 00:07:49.739
to overcome that idea of something
like a basic language barrier as well.

153
00:07:49.739 --> 00:07:53.694
Okay, now the other barriers that can
influence our project management and

154
00:07:53.694 --> 00:07:55.435
our communication, of course.

155
00:07:55.435 --> 00:08:00.264
Is the idea of different time zones and
geographical factors as well.

156
00:08:00.264 --> 00:08:04.680
When you start having meetings, whether
they're scheduled in person or whether

157
00:08:04.680 --> 00:08:08.978
they're scheduled virtually such as
video conferencing of some sort as well.

158
00:08:08.978 --> 00:08:12.967
You've got to make sure that everybody is
scheduled to meet at the time that they're

159
00:08:12.967 --> 00:08:14.380
scheduled for.

160
00:08:14.380 --> 00:08:18.710
Simply us putting in a meeting
time of 9 AM may not mean

161
00:08:18.710 --> 00:08:23.053
anything to anyone except for
their local time zone.

162
00:08:23.053 --> 00:08:27.641
And for us here at ITProTV, this has
been one of the challenges that we've

163
00:08:27.641 --> 00:08:30.231
learned just over time just a little bit.

164
00:08:30.231 --> 00:08:37.620
As we started out a fairly small company,
we started streaming live and it was fine.

165
00:08:37.620 --> 00:08:42.810
But we'll start streaming
about 9:30 in the morning.

166
00:08:42.810 --> 00:08:46.580
Well the problem is we had people that
were viewing this from Europe, so

167
00:08:46.580 --> 00:08:51.520
about 26% of our entire membership
is actually from overseas somewhere.

168
00:08:51.520 --> 00:08:54.603
So we started having people view from
Europe, we had one from Australia that

169
00:08:54.603 --> 00:08:56.913
would get up in the middle of
the night just about 11 PM,

170
00:08:56.913 --> 00:08:58.090
they would get up and watch.

171
00:08:58.090 --> 00:09:02.391
And some would say 9 AM, they're like
okay, but 9 AM is your time about 11,

172
00:09:02.391 --> 00:09:06.244
whatever it might be and so all of
a sudden we started realizing we need to

173
00:09:06.244 --> 00:09:09.100
make sure that we're very
clear about what we mean.

174
00:09:09.100 --> 00:09:12.500
So you need to make sure that,
that communication process goes on and

175
00:09:12.500 --> 00:09:16.330
that the scheduling that is done is
something that needs to be accounted for.

176
00:09:16.330 --> 00:09:19.210
Most of the time for us is simple,
we just tell them it's gonna be

177
00:09:19.210 --> 00:09:23.370
Eastern Standard or Eastern Daylight Time,
and just about everybody understands that.

178
00:09:23.370 --> 00:09:26.483
But overall though, you need to
make sure in project management.

179
00:09:26.483 --> 00:09:29.762
If you're expecting the meeting at 9 AM,
Eastern, well,

180
00:09:29.762 --> 00:09:33.621
gotta realize that over in California,
that's gonna be about 6 AM and

181
00:09:33.621 --> 00:09:37.780
somebody may not even be awake yet
to be able to handle that meeting.

182
00:09:37.780 --> 00:09:38.970
Sometimes they'll get up for it, but

183
00:09:38.970 --> 00:09:41.210
it doesn't mean that they
will always get up for it.

184
00:09:41.210 --> 00:09:45.948
So just remember that even time zones
themselves can actually be a barrier when

185
00:09:45.948 --> 00:09:48.261
you're trying to get access to that.

186
00:09:48.261 --> 00:09:53.101
I know it happens to me quite often when I
sign up for webinars, and I say, 9 AM, and

187
00:09:53.101 --> 00:09:57.403
then finally when I go to that date,
it says 9 AM, Mountain Standard Time,

188
00:09:57.403 --> 00:10:02.582
I'm like that means 11 for me, but I don't
think about that because I just think,

189
00:10:02.582 --> 00:10:05.540
9 o'clock in the morning, no big deal.

190
00:10:05.540 --> 00:10:09.418
So even that can actually just
be a matter of miscommunication

191
00:10:09.418 --> 00:10:13.903
that could prevent good communication
from happening as well, okay?

192
00:10:13.903 --> 00:10:17.589
>> And a lot of cool features, even like
you guys were talking about earlier,

193
00:10:17.589 --> 00:10:19.435
your smart phones, right?

194
00:10:19.435 --> 00:10:22.915
So a lot of those phones, and you can
get widgets on your desktops to help you

195
00:10:22.915 --> 00:10:25.082
remember all those
different time zones too.

196
00:10:25.082 --> 00:10:26.101
It can help you there, Ronnie.

197
00:10:26.101 --> 00:10:28.465
>> Yeah I know, yeah.

198
00:10:28.465 --> 00:10:32.375
In other words, it's not a matter of
are there tools available, right?

199
00:10:32.375 --> 00:10:34.715
It's a matter of getting
to use those tools, and

200
00:10:34.715 --> 00:10:38.020
getting into the practice and
habit of understanding that.

201
00:10:38.020 --> 00:10:42.020
When you are working with a project in
which is gonna span multiple time zones,

202
00:10:42.020 --> 00:10:45.580
is that not everything is centric to
you even though you think it should be.

203
00:10:45.580 --> 00:10:47.145
>> What?
>> Yeah, yeah.

204
00:10:47.145 --> 00:10:48.910
>> The world doesn't revolve around me?

205
00:10:48.910 --> 00:10:52.379
>> Yeah, Galileo said that a while ago,
believe it or not,

206
00:10:52.379 --> 00:10:54.199
that yes it doesn't really.

207
00:10:54.199 --> 00:10:58.260
It's time to revolve around us
as much as we think that we do.

208
00:10:58.260 --> 00:11:01.310
But because all of us do think locally,
okay?

209
00:11:01.310 --> 00:11:03.120
That's what normally needs to happen.

210
00:11:03.120 --> 00:11:06.550
But if you do need that and
you do need the information,

211
00:11:06.550 --> 00:11:09.580
you do need to make sure that
whatever is communicated,

212
00:11:09.580 --> 00:11:12.870
is communicated clearly to those
teams across different time zones.

213
00:11:12.870 --> 00:11:14.970
Make sure you'll take that into account.

214
00:11:14.970 --> 00:11:19.340
And schedule it at some point in which
is good for everybody if you can.

215
00:11:19.340 --> 00:11:21.730
You're always scheduling it
just because it's good for

216
00:11:21.730 --> 00:11:26.720
you, well, people will put up with it,
but they probably don't like it.

217
00:11:26.720 --> 00:11:28.580
And I know that you might go, well,

218
00:11:28.580 --> 00:11:30.590
what difference does that
make if they don't like it.

219
00:11:30.590 --> 00:11:33.918
Well, remember that if you already
having a barrier like that and

220
00:11:33.918 --> 00:11:37.914
the time is actually it, those barriers
tend to set up other types of emotional

221
00:11:37.914 --> 00:11:41.244
barriers where they're like,
I'm listening to part of it, but

222
00:11:41.244 --> 00:11:44.660
I really would rather be eating

223
00:11:44.660 --> 00:11:45.682
>> Sleeping, yeah.

224
00:11:45.682 --> 00:11:46.614
>> Sleeping.
[LAUGH]

225
00:11:46.614 --> 00:11:47.114
>> [LAUGH]

226
00:11:47.114 --> 00:11:48.784
>> Than actually listening here.

227
00:11:48.784 --> 00:11:50.345
And what they're hoping for

228
00:11:50.345 --> 00:11:53.920
is that they catch enough of it that
they can just go back to sleep or

229
00:11:53.920 --> 00:11:57.260
walk away from it and
not have to worry about it again.

230
00:11:57.260 --> 00:12:00.146
Or they're hoping like I did in college,

231
00:12:00.146 --> 00:12:02.560
right?
I fell asleep during class,

00:12:02.560 --> 00:12:07.080
I hope I can go and get these notes

233
00:12:07.080 --> 00:12:08.010
So later on,

234
00:12:08.010 --> 00:12:09.960
you might see something like that too,
okay?

235
00:12:09.960 --> 00:12:13.844
Technological factors are also
a key part of this as well.

236
00:12:13.844 --> 00:12:14.900
>> That doesn't happen.

237
00:12:14.900 --> 00:12:17.897
>> No, technological factors,
well yeah, it-

238
00:12:17.897 --> 00:12:18.690
>> Never.

239
00:12:18.690 --> 00:12:21.830
>> Yeah, yeah, it never happens
until the day of the meeting.

240
00:12:21.830 --> 00:12:22.410
>> Right.

241
00:12:22.410 --> 00:12:27.232
>> So, yeah just when you think that
major companies and big companies,

00:12:27.232 --> 00:12:32.472
that everything should be kind of
scheduled and neat the way that they want.

243
00:12:32.472 --> 00:12:35.840
Well, even they can have some
miscommunications that go on.

244
00:12:35.840 --> 00:12:39.810
So, sometimes you might go like
I have in the past here, when

245
00:12:39.810 --> 00:12:44.460
I was caught into a meeting with somebody
at Microsoft, right, we had this meeting.

246
00:12:44.460 --> 00:12:47.700
Well, it was fine until you found out
that they didn't use the same technology

00:12:47.700 --> 00:12:51.720
you did ten minutes before the meeting,
and now you're okay,

00:12:51.720 --> 00:12:54.460
let's scramble and
let's get this set up and going.

249
00:12:54.460 --> 00:12:55.870
But you're able to do that.

250
00:12:55.870 --> 00:12:58.790
But at that point, you realize that hey,

00:12:58.790 --> 00:13:02.140
this may not have actually been the best

00:13:02.140 --> 00:13:04.790
Cuz we didn't really understand
how the technology worked and

00:13:04.790 --> 00:13:06.890
giving us everything that we need to.

254
00:13:06.890 --> 00:13:10.190
So making sure that somebody understands
how to use the technology is just

255
00:13:10.190 --> 00:13:11.320
as important.

256
00:13:11.320 --> 00:13:15.950
I've been a trainer for a while, and
sometimes I had to go off-site and

00:13:15.950 --> 00:13:17.630

258
00:13:17.630 --> 00:13:21.420
And one of the things that they didn't
even tell me about too, about halfway

00:13:21.420 --> 00:13:27.410
through whatever I was teaching that day,
was, by the way, you're on WebEX, okay?

00:13:27.410 --> 00:13:29.645
And I didn't even know there
was somebody remote, and so

00:13:29.645 --> 00:13:35.980
I've been ignoring essentially part

00:13:35.980 --> 00:13:38.740
without any knowledge
at all about doing this

00:13:38.740 --> 00:13:42.840
when you gotta realize that even that
can be kind of a barrier as well, okay?

264
00:13:42.840 --> 00:13:45.840
There are different types of cultural

265
00:13:45.840 --> 00:13:48.150
awareness that we also
have to understand too.

266
00:13:48.150 --> 00:13:51.850
Sometimes it can be ethnic
barriers that happen,

267
00:13:51.850 --> 00:13:55.640
sometimes it's just work culture related
things that also happen as well.

268
00:13:55.640 --> 00:13:59.210
>> This is a big point for me, I always
feel like people really should understand

269
00:13:59.210 --> 00:14:02.250
that not everyone was brought
up the same way that they were,

270
00:14:02.250 --> 00:14:04.885
has the same background, and
we need to remember that.

271
00:14:04.885 --> 00:14:08.520
>> Yeah, especially if your project is
centered in that particular culture

272
00:14:08.520 --> 00:14:09.680
somewhere else.

273
00:14:09.680 --> 00:14:14.390
For us here in the United States,
fairly all of us, we really do,

274
00:14:14.390 --> 00:14:17.900
we kind of think everything revolves
around us, just like wherever you are,

275
00:14:17.900 --> 00:14:20.050
you probably think everything
revolves around you.

276
00:14:20.050 --> 00:14:22.629
And we don't think about a project
that we might have overseas as

277
00:14:22.629 --> 00:14:25.220
being something different
than what we would do here.

278
00:14:25.220 --> 00:14:29.090
But you might find out that there are
cultural things that have to actually be

279
00:14:29.090 --> 00:14:31.810
kind of tailored around certain events,
and

280
00:14:31.810 --> 00:14:35.130
that way you schedule them correctly
the way that you want to as well.

281
00:14:35.130 --> 00:14:39.320
And then, like I said, on the work type of
culture, there is what we call, of course,

282
00:14:39.320 --> 00:14:42.500
the idea of inter-organizational
differences.

283
00:14:42.500 --> 00:14:45.230
So let's say that we're
contracting with the team but

284
00:14:45.230 --> 00:14:48.600
they're actually oversee somewhere and
in that sense

285
00:14:48.600 --> 00:14:51.910
that their particular corporate
culture is different from ours, okay?

286
00:14:51.910 --> 00:14:57.890
There's also intra-corporate or
intra-organizational differences as well.

287
00:14:57.890 --> 00:15:03.340
And that is actually even within the
culture that we have within the company.

288
00:15:03.340 --> 00:15:06.650
So a single company,
it might have multiple locations.

289
00:15:06.650 --> 00:15:11.850
One location may take things just
a little bit less formal than another

290
00:15:11.850 --> 00:15:16.240
particular site somewhere across
the country may take them.

291
00:15:16.240 --> 00:15:17.560
And when those two teams meet,

292
00:15:17.560 --> 00:15:23.060
even over a virtual meeting, you can
almost sense the difference between

293
00:15:23.060 --> 00:15:26.350
how those teams would normally
communicate with each other as well.

294
00:15:26.350 --> 00:15:29.345
And so you do have to take
that consideration here.

295
00:15:29.345 --> 00:15:34.380
Cuz I like the idea of informality and
joking,

296
00:15:34.380 --> 00:15:38.150
and being able to do stuff like that.

297
00:15:38.150 --> 00:15:41.968
I found out that in one particular
meeting, I wasn't appreciated at all and

298
00:15:41.968 --> 00:15:44.308
they just thought I was
just unprofessional.

299
00:15:44.308 --> 00:15:45.277
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

300
00:15:45.277 --> 00:15:46.845
probably they're right
when it comes down to-

301
00:15:46.845 --> 00:15:48.037
>> I think I told you earlier today,

302
00:15:48.037 --> 00:15:50.733
Ronnie, that I've never gotten in

303
00:15:50.733 --> 00:15:54.273
[LAUGH]
>> But I might have to say even early on,

00:15:54.273 --> 00:15:58.315
even in middle school, I ended up,
one of the few times I

00:15:58.315 --> 00:16:02.787
did get in trouble though was
because I had spoke to a teacher,

306
00:16:02.787 --> 00:16:07.093
a superior, in kind of just a lax,

00:16:07.093 --> 00:16:09.632
And so, you gotta be careful with that.

00:16:09.632 --> 00:16:13.490
[LAUGH] It leaves an impression,

00:16:13.490 --> 00:16:15.990

00:16:15.990 --> 00:16:18.430
If you are trying to move things along.

00:16:18.430 --> 00:16:23.070
And now, you have just, for one reason or

00:16:23.070 --> 00:16:27.600

Well, that can be very

It could be very damaging to your company,

say they're observing

322
00:16:55.660 --> 00:16:58.500
you're not expecting that item to
arrive within that time frame.

323
00:16:58.500 --> 00:17:02.110
>> Yeah, or to at least sit there for
a while until everybody gets to it.

324
00:17:02.110 --> 00:17:04.510
So sometimes you can work around it.

325
00:17:04.510 --> 00:17:06.650
You can work agreements between them, but

326
00:17:06.650 --> 00:17:08.974
you will see that you do
need to account for it.

327
00:17:08.974 --> 00:17:10.583
And the great thing is, today,

328
00:17:10.583 --> 00:17:13.634
there's a lot of project
management information systems.

329
00:17:13.634 --> 00:17:16.105
In other words the software that
helps you with project management.

330
00:17:16.105 --> 00:17:19.149
That if you actually select
the proper calendar,

331
00:17:19.149 --> 00:17:23.930
you can actually get one that actually
shows you the holidays that are actually

332
00:17:23.930 --> 00:17:26.622
in effect for
that part of the world as well.

333
00:17:26.622 --> 00:17:30.145
And that way you're not actually just
scheduling off a standard type of

334
00:17:30.145 --> 00:17:31.720
Gregorian calendar.

335
00:17:31.720 --> 00:17:34.710
So they do show you even
information like that, so

336
00:17:34.710 --> 00:17:39.880
that that way you don't actually overrun
somebody's particular cultural influence

337
00:17:39.880 --> 00:17:42.750
by just going, well,
I don't care if it's their holiday or not.

338
00:17:42.750 --> 00:17:44.600
We're still gonna work on through it.

339
00:17:44.600 --> 00:17:46.560
You may have to do that,
but overall, though,

340
00:17:46.560 --> 00:17:49.860
you may find out that they're going
we're not working on that day.

341
00:17:49.860 --> 00:17:52.160
So it doesn't matter if you
say you have to do it or not.

342
00:17:52.160 --> 00:17:54.886
You might find out that you can
fire all of them and nobody says,

343
00:17:54.886 --> 00:17:56.592
of course we're not working that day.

344
00:17:56.592 --> 00:18:00.727
So you do have to take in to account
that that could be a barrier for

345
00:18:00.727 --> 00:18:02.040
what you need to do.

346
00:18:02.040 --> 00:18:03.100
>> On strike.
>> That's right, yeah,

347
00:18:03.100 --> 00:18:05.160
you could be on strike that day too.

348
00:18:06.170 --> 00:18:08.470
Of course,
the other one is personal preference.

349
00:18:08.470 --> 00:18:12.490
And this is a hard one for
us to understand the barriers to this.

350
00:18:12.490 --> 00:18:14.245
Hopefully, Cherokee,
you don't know anybody like this.

351
00:18:14.245 --> 00:18:16.600
Yeah, I get emails all the time.

352
00:18:16.600 --> 00:18:19.790
But I only read them once a month,
I don't like emails.

353
00:18:19.790 --> 00:18:23.880
Well, if it's the lifeblood and
the culture of your company, that

354
00:18:23.880 --> 00:18:28.090
emails are the way that you do things, it
doesn't matter whether you like it or not.

355
00:18:28.090 --> 00:18:31.369
But the very fact is sometimes you
do have to think about this idea

356
00:18:31.369 --> 00:18:33.916
that-
>> Yeah, if you're selling something then

357
00:18:33.916 --> 00:18:37.652
your customers are gonna see that
delay and then go to your competitor.

358
00:18:37.652 --> 00:18:42.580
Or maybe your supervisor sees
the delay and terminates you.

359
00:18:42.580 --> 00:18:45.910
So there are some severe consequences for
that delay.

360
00:18:45.910 --> 00:18:48.350
>> Yeah,
it's not only about the delay is right,

361
00:18:48.350 --> 00:18:54.160
it's about the person being unwilling to
say, look, here's what our company uses,

362
00:18:54.160 --> 00:18:58.630
and they just go, I don't care what you
use, this is what I'm going to use, and

363
00:18:58.630 --> 00:19:00.790
that means everybody better
get on board with me.

364
00:19:00.790 --> 00:19:04.660
Well, you might be able to do that as
a project manager, don't get me wrong.

365
00:19:04.660 --> 00:19:06.660
You might have the authority to do that.

366
00:19:06.660 --> 00:19:10.620
But it doesn't mean that other people will
use that system the way that you intend

367
00:19:10.620 --> 00:19:12.200
for them to use it.

368
00:19:12.200 --> 00:19:15.320
So they may use it begrudgingly,
they may use it to a point.

369
00:19:15.320 --> 00:19:17.780
But it's not going to be something
that they're gonna readily adopt and

370
00:19:17.780 --> 00:19:19.460
actually use it naturally.

371
00:19:19.460 --> 00:19:22.950
So even personal preferences in
the way that you choose to communicate

372
00:19:22.950 --> 00:19:26.510
may not be seen as a great preference for
everybody.

373
00:19:26.510 --> 00:19:28.870
And so you need to take that into account.

374
00:19:28.870 --> 00:19:33.610
Or be ready to expect for
people to take everything that you do

375
00:19:33.610 --> 00:19:37.500
maybe out of context in the way that
you don't think it can be done.

376
00:19:37.500 --> 00:19:40.160
So it's one of those unusual things.

377
00:19:40.160 --> 00:19:43.569
But that's when you do have to
do that as a project manager,

378
00:19:43.569 --> 00:19:48.479
is realize that personal preference is not
always the thing that needs to be handled,

379
00:19:48.479 --> 00:19:50.405
as far as the way you like to do it.

380
00:19:50.405 --> 00:19:54.553
It might be what's best for the project
at that particular point and moment, and

381
00:19:54.553 --> 00:19:56.688
it might be what's best for the company.

382
00:19:56.688 --> 00:19:58.579
If they already have a system there,

383
00:19:58.579 --> 00:20:01.402
not about what you would rather
have a lot of times too.

384
00:20:01.402 --> 00:20:03.610
All right, so

385
00:20:03.610 --> 00:20:09.220
how do we get by when we have all of
these barriers that are in place.

386
00:20:09.220 --> 00:20:13.940
And that we need to overcome them in terms
of being able to communicate better, okay,

387
00:20:13.940 --> 00:20:18.230
and when we have all these influences and
these factors that we have to overcome.

388
00:20:18.230 --> 00:20:23.110
Well, the way that we do that, first and
foremost, is make sure that we start to do

389
00:20:23.110 --> 00:20:29.250
some type of rapport building or
relationship building that we need to do.

390
00:20:29.250 --> 00:20:32.060
First and foremost,
you need to overcome the awkwardness that

391
00:20:32.060 --> 00:20:35.930
may actually be a part of
your project by doing so.

392
00:20:35.930 --> 00:20:39.850
So at the beginning here,
you go ahead and you tell them,

393
00:20:39.850 --> 00:20:43.850
in a meeting of a sort, here is what
we believe is gonna be the best.

394
00:20:43.850 --> 00:20:47.010
And that way, everybody understands what
it is you're trying to communicate and

395
00:20:47.010 --> 00:20:49.290
why you chose the methods that you did.

396
00:20:49.290 --> 00:20:54.130
So there's not a lot of times where you'll
get that opportunity two or three times.

397
00:20:54.130 --> 00:20:57.680
Usually it's kind of one of those things
where if you knock it out of the park,

398
00:20:57.680 --> 00:21:00.580
everybody's accepting of it and
you're ready to go.

399
00:21:00.580 --> 00:21:04.380
But the key is to establish that
rapport as quickly as you can and

400
00:21:04.380 --> 00:21:08.480
get people on your side where they'll
actually buy in to what you need to do so

401
00:21:08.480 --> 00:21:10.710
that barriers can be
overcome a lot quicker.

402
00:21:10.710 --> 00:21:15.320
If not, they'll let you find the barriers
on your own, as you stumble through it,

403
00:21:15.320 --> 00:21:17.530
then they'll kind of point
you on the right path, but

404
00:21:17.530 --> 00:21:19.350
then they'll let you stumble again.

405
00:21:19.350 --> 00:21:23.110
Most of the time if you established
a correct rapport at the very beginning,

406
00:21:23.110 --> 00:21:27.322
they will help you through the process and
overcome those barriers a lot quicker.

407
00:21:27.322 --> 00:21:30.750
And so
it is something that you do have to learn.

408
00:21:30.750 --> 00:21:33.061
It's something else that you have
to make sure you understand, too.

409
00:21:33.061 --> 00:21:36.813
Also, you've gotta realize
that your message,

410
00:21:36.813 --> 00:21:41.860
it may actually apply to not
everything that they need to hear.

411
00:21:41.860 --> 00:21:45.210
So, in other words, you might find out
that your message is overwhelming.

412
00:21:45.210 --> 00:21:47.620
That you're trying to give
them too much information.

413
00:21:47.620 --> 00:21:51.530
Well, this is your point here when you
communicate, especially in details here.

414
00:21:51.530 --> 00:21:55.120
Make sure you only share with them
what they really need to hear.

415
00:21:55.120 --> 00:21:58.530
Now, that doesn't mean you go,
you don't need to know that.

416
00:21:58.530 --> 00:22:00.670
I don't think you should ever say that.

417
00:22:00.670 --> 00:22:02.340
I think you can tell them, though, that,

418
00:22:02.340 --> 00:22:08.360
look, this is what affects your particular
portion of getting our project done.

419
00:22:08.360 --> 00:22:09.670
This is what you need to understand.

420
00:22:09.670 --> 00:22:10.490
>> What you focus on.

421
00:22:10.490 --> 00:22:12.032
>> You should focus on that.

422
00:22:12.032 --> 00:22:13.549
Somebody might go,
I have a question on that.

423
00:22:13.549 --> 00:22:15.800
Say, we can answer those questions.

424
00:22:15.800 --> 00:22:19.350
But let's make sure you understand
what it is you're focused on first.

425
00:22:19.350 --> 00:22:21.100
And then we can answer other questions.

426
00:22:21.100 --> 00:22:23.260
Now if they ask for
information they're not supposed to have,

427
00:22:23.260 --> 00:22:25.710
say look I can't tell
you that information.

428
00:22:25.710 --> 00:22:29.040
You don't ever tell them like,
that's not relevant to you.

429
00:22:29.040 --> 00:22:30.150
Even though it might not be.

430
00:22:30.150 --> 00:22:31.740
But, you go,
>> Come across rude.

431
00:22:31.740 --> 00:22:33.220
>> Yeah, it comes across rude.

432
00:22:33.220 --> 00:22:35.080
And that's what you don't want to do.

433
00:22:35.080 --> 00:22:39.530
So tailoring your particular message
to whoever you're talking to,

434
00:22:39.530 --> 00:22:42.690
making sure that they understand
what you want them to focus on

435
00:22:42.690 --> 00:22:47.250
is gonna be more key than overwhelming
them with too much information.

436
00:22:47.250 --> 00:22:51.700
So another barrier is that idea where
you flood them with so much information

437
00:22:51.700 --> 00:22:56.130
their minds literally don't know what
to hold onto and what to get rid of.

438
00:22:56.130 --> 00:22:57.000
So instead,

439
00:22:57.000 --> 00:23:01.440
make your points clear, tailor it to
actually what needs to happen as well.

440
00:23:01.440 --> 00:23:03.720
And that will always get you a better

441
00:23:04.780 --> 00:23:09.050
buy in from whoever you're working with,
rather than not.

442
00:23:09.050 --> 00:23:11.760
>> A lot of that will come from
experience also, because there are so

443
00:23:11.760 --> 00:23:13.380
many different personality types,

444
00:23:13.380 --> 00:23:17.530
and trying to conform to a style that
works best with that individual.

445
00:23:17.530 --> 00:23:22.440
So you might just need to kind of
understand your communication style before

446
00:23:22.440 --> 00:23:25.340
you really go ahead and look at that,
how your delivering it.

447
00:23:25.340 --> 00:23:26.540
Your delivery method.

448
00:23:26.540 --> 00:23:28.880
>> Yeah,
the combination of both is the key.

449
00:23:28.880 --> 00:23:32.240
That's what we call it
the idea of criticality here.

450
00:23:32.240 --> 00:23:36.420
What you may end up finding out is
that something of a critical nature.

451
00:23:36.420 --> 00:23:39.650
You go that probably
shouldn't be on Facebook.

452
00:23:39.650 --> 00:23:44.468
And so you actually tailor what you want
to say and you actually choose the right

453
00:23:44.468 --> 00:23:49.002
method to make sure that you make
the impact that you need on that message.

454
00:23:49.002 --> 00:23:54.515
So in that sense I mentioned in
the previous show on methodologies here.

455
00:23:54.515 --> 00:23:55.215
For example,

456
00:23:55.215 --> 00:23:58.785
an in person type of meeting you might
think of someone firing somebody.

457
00:23:58.785 --> 00:24:02.119
Well that's something you
definitely want to do in person.

458
00:24:02.119 --> 00:24:04.708
It's not something you
wanna do over an email or

459
00:24:04.708 --> 00:24:07.757
over Twitter like somebody
mentioned in our chat room.

460
00:24:07.757 --> 00:24:11.590
That's not a great way to
have any type of rapport.

461
00:24:11.590 --> 00:24:15.460
The critical nature of what you
do should help you to choose

462
00:24:15.460 --> 00:24:20.250
the proper methodology that overcomes
any barriers that you might have.

463
00:24:20.250 --> 00:24:24.990
When you can't see that, when you can't
see the critical nature of your message,

464
00:24:24.990 --> 00:24:28.420
well you're not gonna be able to
pick the right methodology anyways.

465
00:24:28.420 --> 00:24:32.500
So it's always important okay that when
you do make some type of decision as

466
00:24:32.500 --> 00:24:37.440
critical to the progress
of your project here.

467
00:24:37.440 --> 00:24:43.830
You wanna make sure that it's in person,
okay.

468
00:24:43.830 --> 00:24:47.190
And a lot of times if you can to
make sure everybody understands

469
00:24:47.190 --> 00:24:48.880
why the decision is being made.

470
00:24:48.880 --> 00:24:52.470
So even a public announcement is
something that's actually a good thing.

471
00:24:52.470 --> 00:24:55.250
Now if you're trying to
close a project quietly,

472
00:24:55.250 --> 00:24:59.340
okay, well that's a different story
instead but that's the idea here, okay?

473
00:24:59.340 --> 00:25:04.820
So you don't want to terminate somebody in
public Is a good example of this, okay.

474
00:25:04.820 --> 00:25:07.340
But you do want to make it in person,
okay?

475
00:25:07.340 --> 00:25:10.110
So make sure that you understand that,
yeah,

476
00:25:10.110 --> 00:25:14.640
it really depends on the critical
nature of your particular message

477
00:25:14.640 --> 00:25:19.585
that needs to be conveyed to everyone
that's part of your project team as well.

478
00:25:19.585 --> 00:25:20.385
Okay.

479
00:25:20.385 --> 00:25:26.305
Now that actually does bring us to a final
point that we need to understand here.

480
00:25:26.305 --> 00:25:29.775
Which is that there's gonna be
some particular requirements

481
00:25:29.775 --> 00:25:31.395
that you gonna have to meet.

482
00:25:31.395 --> 00:25:34.565
And that's why it is very important that
you're gonna be able to do this quickly

483
00:25:34.565 --> 00:25:37.670
and on a fly because you actually
are on a time constraint, right?

484
00:25:37.670 --> 00:25:41.240
You might find out something that
the frequency that you communicate

485
00:25:41.240 --> 00:25:45.340
overall status messages to your team is
something you have to do periodically.

486
00:25:45.340 --> 00:25:47.870
If you're gonna tell them that
it's gonna be once a week,

487
00:25:47.870 --> 00:25:49.380
make sure you do it once a week.

488
00:25:49.380 --> 00:25:51.680
>> And
if you have a project charter set forth,

489
00:25:51.680 --> 00:25:53.140
then that should be noted ahead of time.

490
00:25:53.140 --> 00:25:54.770
So it just kinda keeps you on track,
right, Ronnie?

491
00:25:54.770 --> 00:25:56.110
>> It should be, yeah.

492
00:25:56.110 --> 00:25:59.340
Overall these are things which should
already be established in terms of

493
00:25:59.340 --> 00:26:01.210
the actual project plan itself.

494
00:26:01.210 --> 00:26:04.750
When they happen but the key is
making sure that they happen okay.

495
00:26:04.750 --> 00:26:06.420
Nobody wants to hear and

496
00:26:06.420 --> 00:26:11.360
I mean this, you say I'm gonna
give a progress report every week.

497
00:26:11.360 --> 00:26:12.990
And first one you given on the week and

498
00:26:12.990 --> 00:26:17.270
the second one it's a month later, third
one is a month and a half way later, and

499
00:26:17.270 --> 00:26:21.080
then the fourth one is It was a week
later but you really didn't do anything.

500
00:26:21.080 --> 00:26:22.110
Nobody wants that.

501
00:26:22.110 --> 00:26:24.460
It's sporadic, it doesn't tend to happen.

502
00:26:24.460 --> 00:26:26.670
Make sure you understand the frequency and

503
00:26:26.670 --> 00:26:30.390
sometimes the frequency is depending
upon that particular time period.

504
00:26:30.390 --> 00:26:33.110
You might find out as you're moving
through a more critical stage in your

505
00:26:33.110 --> 00:26:35.810
project, you might give
updates a lot quicker and

506
00:26:35.810 --> 00:26:38.800
a lot more up to date information.

507
00:26:38.800 --> 00:26:40.030
Because you're actually saying yes,

508
00:26:40.030 --> 00:26:43.020
we're still progressing or
this is a make or break.

509
00:26:43.020 --> 00:26:46.800
We've got to make sure we get through this
week, so I'm going to be reporting every

510
00:26:46.800 --> 00:26:50.490
single day, what's going on here,
that you know we're making progress.

511
00:26:50.490 --> 00:26:53.370
At any point if we stumble along it
I'm gonna let you know immediately so

512
00:26:53.370 --> 00:26:56.610
we can do other things that we need to,
to account for that as well.

513
00:26:57.610 --> 00:27:00.570
Understand the level of detail
that you're gonna be giving

514
00:27:00.570 --> 00:27:03.090
depending on who you're talking to, right?

515
00:27:03.090 --> 00:27:07.390
To the project sponsor, you may give
every single detail that they need.

516
00:27:07.390 --> 00:27:09.590
To the project champion,

517
00:27:09.590 --> 00:27:13.840
you may give them details along with
technical information that you may need.

518
00:27:13.840 --> 00:27:17.030
But just realize that you do need
to make sure that you tailor that

519
00:27:17.030 --> 00:27:19.020
to what we're talking about as well.

520
00:27:19.020 --> 00:27:22.490
Make sure you of course have
the established plan of communication

521
00:27:22.490 --> 00:27:24.950
in the official channel in
the way that it needs to and

522
00:27:24.950 --> 00:27:29.330
that you don't violate any type
of confidentiality as well okay.

523
00:27:29.330 --> 00:27:34.590
All those are actually key factors for
us when we talk about the idea of

524
00:27:34.590 --> 00:27:38.000
stakeholder types of
communication requirements okay.

525
00:27:38.000 --> 00:27:42.110
Without those you're gonna communicate
something you don't mean to communicate

526
00:27:42.110 --> 00:27:43.990
You're gonna communicate it and
they're gonna come back and

527
00:27:43.990 --> 00:27:45.460
find from another stakeholder.

528
00:27:45.460 --> 00:27:48.140
And that's not exactly
what he should have said.

529
00:27:48.140 --> 00:27:51.170
You name it.
All of these are really big possibilities.

530
00:27:51.170 --> 00:27:54.390
So not only is the method important but

531
00:27:54.390 --> 00:27:57.990
understanding the barriers to
whatever method that you gonna choose

532
00:27:57.990 --> 00:28:01.620
is also important so that you understand
what you need to overcome them.

533
00:28:01.620 --> 00:28:05.710
And we've just taken a look at a whole lot
of them, hopefully you'll be able to pull

534
00:28:05.710 --> 00:28:08.220
some information from what
we've just said here,

535
00:28:08.220 --> 00:28:12.520
to help your communication in your project
management to be much more effective.

536
00:28:12.520 --> 00:28:15.810
>> Well Ronnie, I think you've done
a great job showing us how to go ahead and

537
00:28:15.810 --> 00:28:17.690
look at those communication factors.

538
00:28:17.690 --> 00:28:21.480
I appreciate that and I appreciate
all of you for tuning in with us.

539
00:28:21.480 --> 00:28:23.580
But stay tuned we have
more coming your way.

540
00:28:23.580 --> 00:28:25.410
We have some more project plus.

541
00:28:25.410 --> 00:28:26.400
I'm Cherokee Boose.

542
00:28:26.400 --> 00:28:27.670
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

543
00:28:27.670 --> 00:28:30.181
>> Signing off have a great day.

544
00:28:30.181 --> 00:28:36.357
[MUSIC]

545
00:28:36.357 --> 00:28:39.304
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: Communication triggers are indicators or events that a risk may or has occurred. In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee discuss a dozen different types of  communication triggers you should be aware of to help offer some foresight. You will learn how to detect these triggers to help mitigate  negative responses.

this is a little bit stranger
in what we have in place.

458
00:25:28.160 --> 00:25:32.116
Now, in this sense, it is possible, okay?

459
00:25:32.116 --> 00:25:36.200
That [LAUGH] and I hope it doesn't ever
happen to you, but it is possible,

460
00:25:36.200 --> 00:25:41.370
that the project management
company itself, it says look,

461
00:25:41.370 --> 00:25:45.348
we're no longer in that business,
we've sold out of what we have.

462
00:25:45.348 --> 00:25:48.460
Or there has to be some type of
business continuity, in other words.

463
00:25:48.460 --> 00:25:51.680
The projects that they were
managing still has to be completed.

464
00:25:51.680 --> 00:25:55.100
Well, that's what also needs
to be recognized, too.

465
00:25:55.100 --> 00:25:59.700
So when you have a business continuity
type of response that happens, right, what

466
00:25:59.700 --> 00:26:03.710
you're really saying at this point here is
that several things might have happened.

467
00:26:03.710 --> 00:26:08.970
The project sponsor may not be available
anymore for one reason or another,okay.

468
00:26:08.970 --> 00:26:12.740
So God forbid, but let's say that
the project manager dies, okay?

469
00:26:12.740 --> 00:26:16.060
You get a new project manager on hand,

470
00:26:16.060 --> 00:26:18.785
there has to be some type
of continuity to that.

471
00:26:18.785 --> 00:26:22.800
And so everybody needs to understand
who the authority runs through and

472
00:26:22.800 --> 00:26:25.970
who they're gonna rely on to help
get them through this as well, okay?

473
00:26:25.970 --> 00:26:30.250
So there's a lot of this that
helps to demonstrate, at least for

474
00:26:30.250 --> 00:26:32.760
the entire project team itself, right.

475
00:26:32.760 --> 00:26:37.330
That leadership is still
leading even in absence of

476
00:26:37.330 --> 00:26:41.020
the direct leader that you mind
of then as a project manager.

477
00:26:41.020 --> 00:26:42.930
Or whoever it was,
I shouldn't put it on you.

478
00:26:42.930 --> 00:26:44.280
And that's a bad example.

479
00:26:44.280 --> 00:26:46.760
But you can kind of get the idea here,
okay.

480
00:26:46.760 --> 00:26:50.430
Is that business continuity again
it should trigger something

481
00:26:50.430 --> 00:26:52.646
that says let's let the entire team know.

482
00:26:52.646 --> 00:26:55.710
Here is Cherokee is gonna be
heading up this new project and

483
00:26:55.710 --> 00:26:58.420
we need make sure that we give
the support that we need to.

484
00:26:58.420 --> 00:27:01.970
And you know that's what we also what
we wanna make sure as well,okay?

485
00:27:01.970 --> 00:27:05.680
>> And another type of incident that
we really don't want to happen but

486
00:27:05.680 --> 00:27:07.100
it may would be any kind of.

487
00:27:07.100 --> 00:27:10.480
We need to address trigger that
are associating with incidence responses.

488
00:27:10.480 --> 00:27:11.110
>> Yeah.

489
00:27:11.110 --> 00:27:14.480
There is no doubt that what in the world
are we talking about in terms of

490
00:27:14.480 --> 00:27:15.020
instances?

491
00:27:15.020 --> 00:27:17.940
Well a lot of times it's
an accident that may happen.

492
00:27:17.940 --> 00:27:20.730
It could be some type of emergency event.

493
00:27:20.730 --> 00:27:25.980
But usually a lot of times it
is when our project itself

494
00:27:25.980 --> 00:27:30.330
does not meet compliance
standards that are out there.

495
00:27:30.330 --> 00:27:34.270
And now what we want to do, is we want
to be able to communicate that and

496
00:27:34.270 --> 00:27:36.050
get us back on track.

497
00:27:36.050 --> 00:27:40.990
So instead of us trying to decide whether
or not it's something we need to address,

498
00:27:40.990 --> 00:27:44.530
what we do in terms of an instant
type of response is this.

499
00:27:44.530 --> 00:27:47.940
Is that once this is actually
raised to the level of an incident,

500
00:27:47.940 --> 00:27:50.840
we automatically communicate.

501
00:27:50.840 --> 00:27:54.380
Here is the plan that we
are going to respond with and

502
00:27:54.380 --> 00:27:58.270
here's what need s to happen at this
particular point in our project.

503
00:27:58.270 --> 00:28:02.390
This should be one of those automatic
habitual types of communication,

504
00:28:02.390 --> 00:28:06.680
not the idea of guessing whether or
not it actually is something, okay.

505
00:28:06.680 --> 00:28:09.140
So, what we're suppose to do?

506
00:28:09.140 --> 00:28:12.500
So at this point that's why it
is also considered a trigger.

507
00:28:12.500 --> 00:28:16.580
And incident response needs
to actually trigger for us,

508
00:28:16.580 --> 00:28:20.990
at least, the idea that we are going to
respond appropriately and we're gonna sure

509
00:28:20.990 --> 00:28:25.230
respond according to a plan, and
that's what makes this happen too.

510
00:28:25.230 --> 00:28:28.880
So normally when we have this, remember,
again it's still project manager,

511
00:28:28.880 --> 00:28:33.070
project sponsor who's gonna be
the audience the majority of the time.

512
00:28:33.070 --> 00:28:35.960
And then at that point
also people that will be

513
00:28:35.960 --> 00:28:37.620
implementing on the technical side.

514
00:28:37.620 --> 00:28:42.820
If it's a compliance type of
implementation, managerial implementation

515
00:28:42.820 --> 00:28:45.210
we have to make sure that all
those are actually in place and

516
00:28:45.210 --> 00:28:47.740
the response is appropriate, okay?

517
00:28:47.740 --> 00:28:50.110
>> All right, we've almost
made it through the list here.

518
00:28:50.110 --> 00:28:53.540
Last up, we have resource changes.

519
00:28:53.540 --> 00:28:56.520
>> Yeah, just like we've talked about
in terms of business continuity

520
00:28:56.520 --> 00:28:57.850
a little bit, right?

521
00:28:57.850 --> 00:28:59.860
When a resource change happens,

522
00:28:59.860 --> 00:29:05.340
this can be something that's devastating,
depending on the resource itself, okay?

523
00:29:05.340 --> 00:29:08.980
If now all of a sudden you can't get
everything that you needed to, okay,

524
00:29:08.980 --> 00:29:11.800
from this one vendor even though
they swore they could do it.

525
00:29:11.800 --> 00:29:13.420
Well now, you have to rely on another one.

526
00:29:13.420 --> 00:29:15.060
Have you tested the quality?

527
00:29:15.060 --> 00:29:17.210
You may not have tested
the quality at all.

528
00:29:17.210 --> 00:29:20.790
You may just say it looks the same,
let's just go ahead and run with it.

529
00:29:20.790 --> 00:29:24.560
Okay, well that can trigger
something that may not be good for

530
00:29:24.560 --> 00:29:26.340
your particular project here.

531
00:29:26.340 --> 00:29:31.315
So all the time, or anytime, not all
the time, anytime when there is a resource

532
00:29:31.315 --> 00:29:34.860
change throughout the entire
project itself, okay.

533
00:29:34.860 --> 00:29:39.440
We must make sure that everybody
that's involved in part of that

534
00:29:39.440 --> 00:29:43.820
using that resource is gonna
understand what has happened and

535
00:29:43.820 --> 00:29:46.560
why you chose to go through this, okay.

536
00:29:46.560 --> 00:29:52.750
Now, if you don't, okay, and somebody now
implements whatever this piece of cloth or

537
00:29:52.750 --> 00:29:57.280
whatever it is that you implement in and
now it's start tearing that machinery.

538
00:29:57.280 --> 00:29:59.790
Well, now you have a bigger
explanation to make.

539
00:29:59.790 --> 00:30:03.180
They are usually what you want to do, of
course, is that when you have some type of

540
00:30:03.180 --> 00:30:06.840
resource change, you wanna make sure
that it runs through some testing

541
00:30:06.840 --> 00:30:09.430
before you actually really do
to implement it out there.

542
00:30:09.430 --> 00:30:10.770
To have it do that.

543
00:30:10.770 --> 00:30:14.660
So, a resource change normally triggers
for us some type of testing or

544
00:30:14.660 --> 00:30:18.790
some type of quality assurance
that we have to go through,

545
00:30:18.790 --> 00:30:22.790
to make sure that everything's gonna
be up to par in everything that we do.

546
00:30:22.790 --> 00:30:27.360
So all of these are that type of,
when we start talking about events and

547
00:30:27.360 --> 00:30:32.170
different issues here, all these
triggers really should lead to some

548
00:30:32.170 --> 00:30:36.205
type of process in terms of communication
letting everybody know whats going on.

549
00:30:36.205 --> 00:30:37.200
>> Well, Ronnie,

550
00:30:37.200 --> 00:30:41.765
it looks like we made it through a dozen
different types of communication triggers.

551
00:30:41.765 --> 00:30:44.655
So guys, when you are studying
out there just make sure that you

552
00:30:44.655 --> 00:30:48.475
are able to recognize them and
identify them for the exam.

553
00:30:48.475 --> 00:30:50.415
I think that's about it for this episode.

554
00:30:50.415 --> 00:30:53.705
Stay tuned we have more
Project Plus coming your way.

555
00:30:53.705 --> 00:30:54.615
I'm Cherokee Boose.

556
00:30:54.615 --> 00:30:55.584
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

557
00:30:55.584 --> 00:30:56.165
>> Signing off.

558
00:30:56.165 --> 00:30:57.923
Have a great one.

559
00:30:57.923 --> 00:31:03.911
[MUSIC]

560
00:31:03.911 --> 00:31:07.174
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee discuss change control processes. They identify numerous types of project changes that may occur from timeline changes to scope changes. We also learn how we should formally approach these changes.We examine the importance of Identification, documentation, impact evaluating and how to properly coordinate the appropriate course of action with our stakeholders.
episodes.title: Use Change Control Process
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:06.992
[CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.992 --> 00:00:08.419
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.419 --> 00:00:12.123
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

4
00:00:12.123 --> 00:00:16.943
>> Welcome to another CompTIA Project+
episode here at ITPro TV.

5
00:00:16.943 --> 00:00:18.970
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.970 --> 00:00:21.580
Today, we're gonna be looking
at controlled process,

7
00:00:21.580 --> 00:00:23.180
change control processes.

8
00:00:23.180 --> 00:00:25.000
With us, we have Mr. Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:25.000 --> 00:00:26.410
Thank you for being with us, Ronnie.

10
00:00:26.410 --> 00:00:27.160
>> Well, thank you for

11
00:00:27.160 --> 00:00:31.290
having me here as we continue on and
take a look at CompTIA Project+.

12
00:00:31.290 --> 00:00:36.600
Specifically talking about the idea of
change process and change control here.

13
00:00:36.600 --> 00:00:40.573
Now you might be wondering why what's
the big deal when we start mentioning

14
00:00:40.573 --> 00:00:41.630
this idea?

15
00:00:41.630 --> 00:00:46.330
But in projects remember that because
we work in a constraint triangle,

16
00:00:46.330 --> 00:00:49.308
making sure that we actually understand
that we have to control our time,

17
00:00:49.308 --> 00:00:52.590
our costs,
as well as the overall project scope.

18
00:00:52.590 --> 00:00:56.468
That changes can normally
any one of those three and

19
00:00:56.468 --> 00:00:58.580
it's something that we have to deal with.

20
00:00:58.580 --> 00:01:03.810
And the better that we deal with it, the
better that we can manage those changes,

21
00:01:03.810 --> 00:01:05.700
the better off it's going to be for

22
00:01:05.700 --> 00:01:09.700
us as we start managing our projects,
as we continue to manage our projects.

23
00:01:09.700 --> 00:01:11.890
Because there is a constant that goes on.

24
00:01:11.890 --> 00:01:16.860
And everybody's heard this old quote
here that change is constant, okay.

25
00:01:16.860 --> 00:01:21.160
So we need to at least understand that for
us, this is the idea,

26
00:01:21.160 --> 00:01:24.065
is that we have to actually manage
those changes better, okay.

27
00:01:24.065 --> 00:01:28.350
>> All right, and so I can only imagine
that there are a slew of different type of

28
00:01:28.350 --> 00:01:32.370
changes that we may encounter
during the duration of the project.

29
00:01:32.370 --> 00:01:35.540
So, Ronnie, what would be some of
those common changes that we may see?

30
00:01:35.540 --> 00:01:38.660
>> Well, a lot of the common changes
that you normally end up seeing

31
00:01:38.660 --> 00:01:42.290
happen all throughout the entirety
of the project itself.

32
00:01:42.290 --> 00:01:46.620
And the key here is to understand that
because changes happen at any particular

33
00:01:46.620 --> 00:01:51.260
time, it's not that you're gonna see
that change is something unusual.

34
00:01:51.260 --> 00:01:53.750
But you're gonna see that it's
actually something we just have to be

35
00:01:53.750 --> 00:01:54.790
able to control.

36
00:01:54.790 --> 00:01:58.553
So normally when we start talking of some
of the common changes, let's just take for

37
00:01:58.553 --> 00:02:00.180
an example here a timeline change.

38
00:02:00.180 --> 00:02:02.740
This can happen for many various reasons.

39
00:02:02.740 --> 00:02:08.400
Let's take for an example that you do have
a particular portion of your project.

40
00:02:08.400 --> 00:02:10.330
And again,
this is never a great situation.

41
00:02:10.330 --> 00:02:14.130
But someone's on that project team,
maybe the project lead, or

42
00:02:14.130 --> 00:02:17.730
maybe someone on the team has
had a workplace accident.

43
00:02:17.730 --> 00:02:22.120
And now the team is not functioning
as well as they need to be, and

44
00:02:22.120 --> 00:02:24.340
there needs to be a little
bit of time adjustment.

45
00:02:24.340 --> 00:02:28.740
Well, you've gotta remember that that
can throw off the actual project entire

46
00:02:28.740 --> 00:02:30.170
timeline itself.

47
00:02:30.170 --> 00:02:33.613
So when something like that happens,
it's not that you can't account for it.

48
00:02:33.613 --> 00:02:35.880
It's not that you don't know it exists.

49
00:02:35.880 --> 00:02:40.340
The key here is how do you manage that
better, and what resources are available,

50
00:02:40.340 --> 00:02:42.080
and what can you do about it?

51
00:02:42.080 --> 00:02:45.230
So we have to deal with things like time,
as well.

52
00:02:45.230 --> 00:02:49.200
The other thing that can also happen
is funding changes that can go on.

53
00:02:49.200 --> 00:02:52.800
It's strange, normally once you
have a project budget in place,

54
00:02:52.800 --> 00:02:56.650
you normally do not have to
worry about a lot of situations.

55
00:02:56.650 --> 00:02:58.130
I know you'll find this strange but

56
00:02:58.130 --> 00:03:03.190
not every single project starts off
with a pot of gold somewhere hidden.

57
00:03:03.190 --> 00:03:06.053
But they start off with a certain
amount of money and what do they do?

58
00:03:06.053 --> 00:03:10.300
They go to different places to
finance the rest of that project.

59
00:03:10.300 --> 00:03:14.060
And you might find out something
after a while here that what you

60
00:03:14.060 --> 00:03:18.660
thought was gonna be the finance of that
project doesn't actually end up happening.

61
00:03:18.660 --> 00:03:22.320
And now you have to go and look for
the financial means somewhere else

62
00:03:22.320 --> 00:03:25.141
in terms of either going to another
lending institution or investors.

63
00:03:25.141 --> 00:03:27.721
>> Investors.
>> Borrowing something, investors, and

64
00:03:27.721 --> 00:03:29.570
that can also change as well.

65
00:03:29.570 --> 00:03:33.320
And that can even change the way that
your project actually ends up developing.

66
00:03:33.320 --> 00:03:36.290
So you might even have things like that,
okay.

67
00:03:36.290 --> 00:03:39.830
Other changes here, of course,
could involve things like risk, okay.

68
00:03:39.830 --> 00:03:41.350
So as risk events happen,

69
00:03:41.350 --> 00:03:46.320
what we call incidents, that end
up going on Inside of our project.

70
00:03:46.320 --> 00:03:50.190
Well, that can also cause a major
change in our project, too.

71
00:03:50.190 --> 00:03:51.600
And usually, on this one.

72
00:03:51.600 --> 00:03:55.130
This is by far the one that's probably
the most visceral type of change

73
00:03:55.130 --> 00:03:57.190
that we feel as human beings.

74
00:03:57.190 --> 00:04:01.770
And that's because risks normally
bring up into our lives, right,

75
00:04:01.770 --> 00:04:07.500
the idea of just some type of
reaction that we're supposed to have.

76
00:04:07.500 --> 00:04:10.710
So normally, when we hear that
the idea that this is risky and

77
00:04:10.710 --> 00:04:13.350
we actually start finding
out why it's risky.

78
00:04:13.350 --> 00:04:16.600
We don't normally act with, hm, this is
what I should have done about that risk

79
00:04:16.600 --> 00:04:19.480
as it came on but we normally just react.

80
00:04:19.480 --> 00:04:22.930
And usually those reactions may not
actually be appropriate types of

81
00:04:22.930 --> 00:04:23.880
reactions.

82
00:04:23.880 --> 00:04:27.630
But sometimes you do have to
actually worry about those things.

83
00:04:27.630 --> 00:04:30.410
So, we need to understand that
they're gonna happen even when risk

84
00:04:30.410 --> 00:04:31.560
happen as well.

85
00:04:31.560 --> 00:04:34.870
Requirement changes, remember
project sponsors and stakeholders.

86
00:04:34.870 --> 00:04:36.790
They again can request changes.

87
00:04:36.790 --> 00:04:39.100
And it's not that it's bad,
they may actually be for

88
00:04:39.100 --> 00:04:40.660
the betterment of the project.

89
00:04:40.660 --> 00:04:43.820
But at the same time,
we need to understand when and

90
00:04:43.820 --> 00:04:45.570
where they're gonna happen too.

91
00:04:45.570 --> 00:04:49.260
Quality changes can also happen where
we actually do end up requiring

92
00:04:49.260 --> 00:04:50.140
a different quality.

93
00:04:50.140 --> 00:04:53.270
Or we might find out whatever we
implemented in the process here,

94
00:04:53.270 --> 00:04:55.110
it wasn't as good as we
thought it was gonna be.

95
00:04:55.110 --> 00:04:58.867
And we need to actually improve the
quality of something in our project here.

96
00:04:58.867 --> 00:05:03.114
And I always like using movies as
a reference because they really do help me

97
00:05:03.114 --> 00:05:05.060
out when I think about this.

98
00:05:05.060 --> 00:05:06.960
But I've seen this idea in,

99
00:05:06.960 --> 00:05:11.840
it was a movie from the 80s I think,
I don't even remember when it was from.

100
00:05:11.840 --> 00:05:17.660
But it was where they were manufacturing
hard drives, I believe is what it was.

101
00:05:17.660 --> 00:05:22.238
And they found out that the air quality
in that manufacturing plant was way lower

102
00:05:22.238 --> 00:05:24.091
than what it was supposed to be.

103
00:05:24.091 --> 00:05:27.790
And the springs that they were
putting in was of a cheaper quality.

104
00:05:27.790 --> 00:05:31.900
And that when somebody finally questioned
them about it it was like, all right, so

105
00:05:31.900 --> 00:05:34.120
what is it gonna take for
us to get back on production?

106
00:05:34.120 --> 00:05:37.380
And the guy said, you gotta actually
start from the beginning again cuz

107
00:05:37.380 --> 00:05:40.710
every single hard drive we've produced
has these lower quality springs.

108
00:05:40.710 --> 00:05:41.860
The air quality's bad.

109
00:05:41.860 --> 00:05:43.310
We have to start all over.

110
00:05:43.310 --> 00:05:46.230
And somebody was about to just
cry when they heard that.

111
00:05:46.230 --> 00:05:46.910
So yeah,

112
00:05:46.910 --> 00:05:50.560
sometimes you actually do have where that
quality change ends up happening as well.

113
00:05:50.560 --> 00:05:53.340
>> And you know what's pretty cool,
Ronnie, is they have,

114
00:05:53.340 --> 00:05:56.427
where was I watching off of Netflix,
a show about 3D printers.

115
00:05:56.427 --> 00:06:01.960
And with these like kickstarter, these
websites where they have public funding.

116
00:06:01.960 --> 00:06:05.760
So you have these individuals,
these engineers or these designers or

117
00:06:05.760 --> 00:06:08.880
maybe they just can't afford to
go ahead and fund their projects.

118
00:06:08.880 --> 00:06:14.403
And they have an idea, they go ahead and
develop it but maybe its not quite 100%.

119
00:06:14.403 --> 00:06:18.134
And then when they go to trade shows like
CES to go ahead and show their product

120
00:06:18.134 --> 00:06:22.650
off, all these people who've contributed
to that project, they're asking questions.

121
00:06:22.650 --> 00:06:23.420
How are you doing?

122
00:06:23.420 --> 00:06:27.760
And when you have these little
hiccups along the way or

123
00:06:27.760 --> 00:06:30.100

But normally,

00:30:00.353 --> 00:30:03.676
you wanna make sure that it stays
in the forefront of people's minds.

569
00:30:03.676 --> 00:30:06.840
The other one is the one that you
really don't ever want to encounter.

570
00:30:06.840 --> 00:30:07.630
>> Try to avoid this one.

571
00:30:07.630 --> 00:30:08.190
>> Yep.

572
00:30:08.190 --> 00:30:12.160
The idea of an emergent condition,
okay, is really bad.

573
00:30:12.160 --> 00:30:17.100
That means it's an emergency but
sometimes you do have those and

574
00:30:17.100 --> 00:30:19.280
normally these things do go through.

575
00:30:19.280 --> 00:30:22.175
They normally don't say,
this is an emergency.

576
00:30:22.175 --> 00:30:23.335
Let's not worry about it.

577
00:30:23.335 --> 00:30:25.975
>> And they usually have a pretty

00:30:25.975 --> 00:30:30.455
because of all the exorbitant fees and
additional salaries

00:30:30.455 --> 00:30:34.021
that you may be paying someone to come

580
00:30:34.021 --> 00:30:36.525
>> Yeah,
once you actually have that emergency,

00:30:36.525 --> 00:30:39.955
it's kinda like everybody

582
00:30:39.955 --> 00:30:44.225
We're about to head into the overload
side of everything that we have

583
00:30:44.225 --> 00:30:45.780
available to us.

584
00:30:45.780 --> 00:30:50.150
So these are also those types
of justifications, okay.

585
00:30:50.150 --> 00:30:55.370
Now what you have to do, right, if you're
looking at this for your first time, okay.

586
00:30:55.370 --> 00:30:57.880
Make sure you always understand
that within projects

587
00:30:57.880 --> 00:31:01.740
you're gonna see things like this
always have to take place, okay.

588
00:31:01.740 --> 00:31:06.590
There is no such thing as a perfect
100% perfect project plan, okay.

589
00:31:06.590 --> 00:31:08.782
Even on the smallest
projects where you finally.

590
00:31:08.782 --> 00:31:09.897
>> Then we'd be unemployed.

591
00:31:09.897 --> 00:31:11.750
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, then you would be unemployed,

592
00:31:11.750 --> 00:31:12.710
there's no doubt.

593
00:31:12.710 --> 00:31:15.333
Once you actually have
even the smallest project,

594
00:31:15.333 --> 00:31:18.866
you start seeing things like I
should have done it this way.

595
00:31:18.866 --> 00:31:20.490
Yeah, I didn't think.

00:31:20.490 --> 00:31:23.050
I needed to fit this so
let me retool to do that.

00:31:23.050 --> 00:31:25.760
And with the project being fairly small,

00:31:25.760 --> 00:31:28.570
these changes don't normally

00:31:28.570 --> 00:31:31.810
But if you're actually doing something

00:31:31.810 --> 00:31:36.510
like something that you're talking about,
or whatever the review thing is, okay.

00:31:36.510 --> 00:31:41.330
You wanna make sure that these changes

00:31:41.330 --> 00:31:45.905

603
00:31:45.905 --> 00:31:49.888
And all the actual failures that you've

00:31:49.888 --> 00:31:53.850
had along the way to fix things,
okay, because it really does give you

00:31:53.850 --> 00:31:58.878
a good grand scope of understanding that

606
00:31:58.878 --> 00:32:03.010
It's weird cuz I know that I've had
this happen before and I've seen it

00:32:03.010 --> 00:32:07.690
In configurations on Cisco routers and,

608
00:32:07.690 --> 00:32:11.740
I made a change to something and

00:32:11.740 --> 00:32:13.790
I don't know why I changed it, okay?

00:32:13.790 --> 00:32:15.370
And at some point I should've had, what?

00:32:15.370 --> 00:32:18.720
Something I wrote down,
like I changed this for this reason, okay?

00:32:18.720 --> 00:32:21.260
That would actually help,
because now I look and I'm like,

00:32:21.260 --> 00:32:22.720
why did I make that change?

614
00:32:22.720 --> 00:32:25.742
And it's easy enough, I put it back to
what I think it is, and things break.

615
00:32:25.742 --> 00:32:27.886
Then I'm like, now I remember!

616
00:32:27.886 --> 00:32:29.612
That's not a situation-
>> And even your co-workers.

617
00:32:29.612 --> 00:32:31.932
They could have like a ticketing
system that would be perfect,

00:32:31.932 --> 00:32:34.180
because they wouldn't even have
to ask you if you were busy.

619
00:32:34.180 --> 00:32:35.762
I could just look in that documentation.

620
00:32:35.762 --> 00:32:39.360
>> Yeah, yeah, it's definitely not
something you ever want a surprise

621
00:32:39.360 --> 00:32:41.560
anybody and yourself with it as well.

622
00:32:41.560 --> 00:32:44.330
Cuz I have seen exactly that with
my own work, where I've said,

623
00:32:44.330 --> 00:32:45.710
I didn't need to make that change.

624
00:32:45.710 --> 00:32:47.860
I changed it and everything failed, okay?

625
00:32:47.860 --> 00:32:50.710
So much that everybody complains,
that's how I know that it fails.

626
00:32:50.710 --> 00:32:54.550
So you change it back and you go,

627
00:32:54.550 --> 00:32:57.652
And now we actually do make

00:32:57.652 --> 00:33:00.360
or you at least let somebody else know.

Our particular documentation system at
ITProTV, cuz it's relatively small and

00:33:04.478 --> 00:33:06.230

00:33:06.230 --> 00:33:07.620
And go, all right, here it is.

I normally email Nate and
I normally email Donna.

633
00:33:09.864 --> 00:33:13.920
And go, here's a firewall change

00:33:13.920 --> 00:33:16.820
And so that way, those of us

that network infrastructure team trying

636
00:33:20.120 --> 00:33:23.270
We all have a sense of what

637
00:33:23.270 --> 00:33:26.273
whether it's to our wireless network,
whether it's to anything out there.

638
00:33:26.273 --> 00:33:29.930
But essentially it was Nate and I that

00:33:29.930 --> 00:33:33.910
we keep each other kind of up to date on

640
00:33:33.910 --> 00:33:36.765
And that's our documentation for

641
00:33:36.765 --> 00:33:39.000
>> Ronnie, I think that about

642
00:33:39.000 --> 00:33:43.040
We do have some more change request

00:33:43.040 --> 00:33:44.600
stay tuned for that.

644
00:33:44.600 --> 00:33:47.280
Thank you for tuning in today,

645
00:33:47.280 --> 00:33:48.410

646
00:33:48.410 --> 00:33:48.910

647
00:33:48.910 --> 00:33:50.646
Have a great one.

00:33:50.646 --> 00:33:57.036

Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation of the change control process. Ronnie and Cherokee take an in depth look at regression planning. We learn the necessary steps and tools to implement to ensure we have a successful "plan b".
episodes.title: Use Change Control Process Part 2

Welcome to ITPRO.TV I'm your

>> Welcome to another great

00:00:15.610 --> 00:00:17.610
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

This episode is a continuation

With us today, we have Mr. Ronnie Wong.

Taking a look at the idea of the change

The whole idea is not just to

Cuz that was actually on me,

Now when we say that right usually what

That's on there and

So what you might have in

And then they can make a recommendation if

00:02:15.410 --> 00:02:16.500
a look at.

00:02:16.500 --> 00:02:21.010
So here inside of the project,

00:02:21.010 --> 00:02:25.520
idea where Sashi whose going to

Now on the succeeding task,

00:02:27.320 --> 00:02:31.870
how is going to affect the actual

It might have all of these different

out what's going on.

00:02:35.820 --> 00:02:39.280
And then make decision on

Once all that is done and now you've got

that's when we move onto the idea of

55

Now I mentioned it briefly by showing

00:02:52.530 --> 00:02:54.310
the change request itself.

And so, that means you have two options

that can happen in

So you could have it where it's

That you're supposed to have not only what

that they have those steps there ready and

Sometimes, you might find out a special

as far the reason why we change

Whether is a collective plan or

00:03:31.460 --> 00:03:36.430
usually when is the idea of
the a major type of the situation and

00:03:36.430 --> 00:03:41.840
justification, we don't have
the actual regression plan in.

00:03:41.840 --> 00:03:47.030
We just know something needs to be done,

00:03:47.030 --> 00:03:51.350
And then when that is submitted to

00:03:52.900 --> 00:03:56.640
We're ready to go, but now you need to

00:03:56.640 --> 00:03:59.490

So remember that, there's two options,

And the reason why they need to have

00:04:09.070 --> 00:04:09.830
many different ways.

78
00:04:09.830 --> 00:04:13.514
So, let's kind of give you an example

79
00:04:13.514 --> 00:04:17.786
So let's take for an example that you're

00:04:17.786 --> 00:04:20.617

00:04:20.617 --> 00:04:23.478
That this is what's going to happen,
that some type of disaster for

your building, okay.

83
00:04:24.870 --> 00:04:29.009
So in that sense, when you have everything
set up the way that you need to and

84
00:04:29.009 --> 00:04:31.834
now all of the sudden you
realized something here,

85
00:04:31.834 --> 00:04:36.191
that something is not completely right,

86
00:04:36.191 --> 00:04:40.569
Well, you can go ahead in an emergency
situation, submit that change and

00:04:40.569 --> 00:04:42.413
then they can say, all right.

88
00:04:42.413 --> 00:04:46.500
Now when you implement this

89
00:04:46.500 --> 00:04:48.340
In other words, and it doesn't work,

90
00:04:48.340 --> 00:04:53.500
it doesn't stem that the tied of
the wall leaking or whatever it is.

91
00:04:53.500 --> 00:04:57.590
What is your plan to back out of that and
then apply another fix or

00:04:57.590 --> 00:04:59.210
what do you have in mind?

00:04:59.210 --> 00:05:00.970
Well that regression

94
00:05:00.970 --> 00:05:03.994
What are your steps to make sure

00:05:03.994 --> 00:05:06.424
that you can actually put it

00:05:06.424 --> 00:05:09.786
then another change can be [CROSSTALK]
>> And Ronnie you probably also want to go

00:05:09.786 --> 00:05:13.534
ahead and give yourself enough time to go
ahead and implement that regression plan,

00:05:13.534 --> 00:05:15.040
so maybe with like IT.

00:05:15.040 --> 00:05:16.310
I normally would want to go ahead and

100
00:05:16.310 --> 00:05:20.580
implement a huge change during off hours,
I have that time to roll back.

101
00:05:20.580 --> 00:05:24.010
>> Yeah, you definitely want to make
sure that the timing is scheduled and

00:05:24.010 --> 00:05:28.200
everything else, but overall though
that you have that plan in place.

103
00:05:28.200 --> 00:05:31.050
And even though you're the one that

104
00:05:31.050 --> 00:05:32.080
the back out.

105
00:05:32.080 --> 00:05:36.040
Well, let's say something else happens

00:05:36.040 --> 00:05:40.220
I've implemented a change, and Cherokee,

And I take off on my vacation, let's
say it's actually a flight to Hawaii,

00:05:44.050 --> 00:05:47.380
which would be lovely, but
I don't think I'll ever go that way.

109
00:05:47.380 --> 00:05:51.280
But let's say that I am now on a flight
to Hawaii from Florida to Hawaii,

00:05:51.280 --> 00:05:53.242
it's a pretty good amount of time.

111
00:05:53.242 --> 00:05:57.844
And now, the changes that I've
made have cause some kind of,

00:05:57.844 --> 00:06:00.065
a cascading effects, okay.

113
00:06:00.065 --> 00:06:02.885
And now they came to Cherokee and

Cherokee might be able to say, here's

00:06:06.322 --> 00:06:09.539
They are not working,

00:06:09.539 --> 00:06:14.440
if I did not leave a regression plan,

00:06:14.440 --> 00:06:20.600
Cherokee, essentially, now has to figure

00:06:20.600 --> 00:06:24.380

00:06:24.380 --> 00:06:27.470
Or, is here something else

00:06:27.470 --> 00:06:32.636
So, in other words, she now has to,

122
00:06:37.978 --> 00:06:38.819
>> Da da da da.

123
00:06:38.819 --> 00:06:39.785
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

00:06:39.785 --> 00:06:42.078

And then she's like, that didn't work,

00:06:53.880 --> 00:06:58.116
And now she starts implementing more

129
00:06:58.116 --> 00:07:01.059
>> It's so many variables that you

130
00:07:01.059 --> 00:07:05.070
>> Yeah, and that is a realistic problem,

131
00:07:05.070 --> 00:07:07.923
So having a regression plan in place,

132
00:07:07.923 --> 00:07:12.390
gives us that ability instead

133
00:07:12.390 --> 00:07:15.966
Now it goes back and goes,

00:07:15.966 --> 00:07:18.240

00:07:18.240 --> 00:07:21.900
Cherokee here is the regression plan,

00:07:31.320 --> 00:07:35.600
So it doesn't depend on me

00:07:35.600 --> 00:07:37.745

140
00:07:37.745 --> 00:07:39.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> Good luck on getting me to come

142

I'm not even gonna come connect-
>> No service.

143
00:07:43.480 --> 00:07:44.575
>> No service, that's right.

144
00:07:44.575 --> 00:07:45.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's right, Ronnie Wong,

145
00:07:45.730 --> 00:07:47.860
out of service, no doubt.

146
00:07:47.860 --> 00:07:51.350
So that's why these regression
plans are very important and

147
00:07:51.350 --> 00:07:54.630
very detailed in what they do, okay.

148
00:07:54.630 --> 00:07:57.030
So usually when you have
something like this.

149
00:07:57.030 --> 00:08:00.010
Even in an emergency situation immediately

150
00:08:00.010 --> 00:08:04.130
after whatever band-aid you can
put on a situation a lot of times.

151
00:08:04.130 --> 00:08:07.060
You do also wanna make sure that you
have a regression plan on hand and

152
00:08:07.060 --> 00:08:09.440
that that's being worked on right away.

153
00:08:09.440 --> 00:08:12.750
Just in case you realize it is a band-aid,
it's not a complete cure for

154
00:08:12.750 --> 00:08:16.630
whatever the ailment is that you
have on your project as well.

155
00:08:16.630 --> 00:08:21.120
Is a very kind of an easy analogy for

156
00:08:21.120 --> 00:08:25.490
us to make but it takes time till
she come up with those plans.

157
00:08:25.490 --> 00:08:29.255
Because it means that you are gonna
remember, especially in an emergent

158
00:08:29.255 --> 00:08:32.789
situation, everything that you did and
then you try to fix things.

159
00:08:32.789 --> 00:08:37.760
And then you're also gonna try and say
if somebody needs to back out of this as

160
00:08:37.760 --> 00:08:42.520
I am gone or whatever might be
here's the steps that they need.

161
00:08:42.520 --> 00:08:45.470
And that's why these reviews
rushly going to, to help you out.

162
00:08:46.470 --> 00:08:51.000
You might even find out for a change
review board to accept everything when I

163
00:08:51.000 --> 00:08:55.060
might look at our thing though you don't
have a regression plan and they might say.

164
00:08:55.060 --> 00:08:58.870
We're deferring this possible
change until Ronnie does what?

165
00:08:58.870 --> 00:09:02.270
Comes up with a regression plan and
submits it for that.

166
00:09:02.270 --> 00:09:06.350
And then Washi could put it on
the schedule for review again.

167
00:09:06.350 --> 00:09:10.570
But if we choose not to, well there's
nothing that we can do except for wait.

168
00:09:10.570 --> 00:09:13.850
And normally in an emergency
situation we can't wait and

169
00:09:13.850 --> 00:09:16.980
that's only when we don't have
that regression plan in order.

170
00:09:16.980 --> 00:09:21.249
But if it is something that is prescribed
in terms of a corrective action, or

171
00:09:21.249 --> 00:09:22.784
a preventative action, or

172
00:09:22.784 --> 00:09:25.937
even a reparative action that
we normally need to take.

173
00:09:25.937 --> 00:09:31.185
Then we should have it on hand before,
but not normally, it's not something

174
00:09:31.185 --> 00:09:35.804
we normally like to turn in after or
during an emergency situation.

175
00:09:35.804 --> 00:09:38.850
Cuz you're probably not even
thinking about the process here.

176
00:09:38.850 --> 00:09:42.399
But it is something you have to
think about after you implement

177
00:09:42.399 --> 00:09:46.576
whatever your initial plan is to get

178
00:09:46.576 --> 00:09:51.481
So regression plans very important

00:09:51.481 --> 00:09:53.362

180
00:09:53.362 --> 00:09:58.342
Now, once you have everything in place,
this is when it becomes a little bit more

00:09:58.342 --> 00:10:01.797
difficult in the management

182
00:10:01.797 --> 00:10:03.801
When you implement those changes,

00:10:03.801 --> 00:10:08.150

184

This is not something you want to treat
