185
00:10:12.360 --> 00:10:14.260
I think I won't do this part of it.

186
00:10:14.260 --> 00:10:17.970
Make sure you implement everything that
you say that you are going to implement.

187
00:10:17.970 --> 00:10:20.450
Because remember,
if you've turned in a regression plan and

188
00:10:20.450 --> 00:10:24.910
you haven't done that, Cherokee comes out
at that point and says it's unchecked and

189
00:10:24.910 --> 00:10:27.520
he said he checked this check box, okay.

190
00:10:27.520 --> 00:10:31.470
So should I, Should I check it or
should I not check it,

191
00:10:31.470 --> 00:10:34.980
I'm I just a, I'm not even gonna
worry about that during that change.

192
00:10:34.980 --> 00:10:38.270
Cherokee what would you think, do you
think I check it or didn't check it.

193
00:10:38.270 --> 00:10:41.700
>> Ronnie you're pretty efficient, so
I might put some trust in you, but I,

194
00:10:41.700 --> 00:10:45.700
then again if that falls under
my shoulders, I don't know.

195
00:10:45.700 --> 00:10:46.660
It's a tough decision.

196
00:10:46.660 --> 00:10:48.180
>> Well, that's the problem, right.

197
00:10:48.180 --> 00:10:51.900
That's why this idea of
implementing a change.

198
00:10:51.900 --> 00:10:54.350
If you submit it as that change,

199
00:10:54.350 --> 00:10:58.070
you should go every single
step by that change.

200
00:10:58.070 --> 00:11:02.690
Even if you go,
I shouldn't of submitted that part, okay.

201
00:11:02.690 --> 00:11:04.020
Well, what do you do.

202
00:11:04.020 --> 00:11:07.950
You sit there and you back out of all
those other changes that you made and

203
00:11:07.950 --> 00:11:10.710
then you submit that change review again.

204
00:11:10.710 --> 00:11:14.300
Okay, now that sounds a little bit
legalistic, sounds very formalistic.

205
00:11:14.300 --> 00:11:17.011
But remember that now, if you don't and

206
00:11:17.011 --> 00:11:21.333
you just make that ad hoc change and
later on it effects someone.

207
00:11:21.333 --> 00:11:24.433
Or like this situation that I mentioned,
you make that ad hoc change but

208
00:11:24.433 --> 00:11:26.302
you don't have it in the regression plan.

209
00:11:26.302 --> 00:11:30.217
And it has to be regressed by somebody
else besides you to back out of it

210
00:11:30.217 --> 00:11:33.742
Cherokee doesn't have a clue whether or
not you did it or not.

211
00:11:33.742 --> 00:11:37.174
Just because I chose not to do it or
I did choose to do it or

212
00:11:37.174 --> 00:11:41.010
I said I'll add in this extra
little thing over here.

213
00:11:41.010 --> 00:11:44.540
Now Cherokee's like was that in
there already when Ronnie made

214
00:11:44.540 --> 00:11:45.120
the change or not.

215
00:11:45.120 --> 00:11:49.040
>> Bottom line get it in black and white,
so it removes all of the confusion.

216
00:11:49.040 --> 00:11:53.320
>> That is absolutely the key here
is making sure that every part of it

217
00:11:53.320 --> 00:11:57.600
is going to be filled in, and
you have to carry that out that way.

218
00:11:57.600 --> 00:12:02.750
It is not your time to now freestyle
after you got the okay to change

219
00:12:02.750 --> 00:12:05.860
as much as you think it
actually means that, okay.

220
00:12:05.860 --> 00:12:11.740
So, in this particular part of projects,
especially, okay, you're gonna

221
00:12:11.740 --> 00:12:17.930
see that this effects not only a single
task that is ahead of you a lot of times.

222
00:12:17.930 --> 00:12:22.579
But you may see, and this is what's
happened in the industry over the last 20

223
00:12:22.579 --> 00:12:26.962
years, is that change management has
become a field unto itself, okay.

224
00:12:26.962 --> 00:12:31.376
So much so, that people
are actually taking the entirety of

225
00:12:31.376 --> 00:12:33.947
a change management as a process.

226
00:12:33.947 --> 00:12:38.349
And actually applying them to entire
organizational types of changes and

227
00:12:38.349 --> 00:12:42.254
managing the entire organization
through this type of review and

228
00:12:42.254 --> 00:12:44.330
through this type of aboard.

229
00:12:44.330 --> 00:12:47.760
And we actually have an episode where
we'll talk about the idea of managing

230
00:12:47.760 --> 00:12:50.720
organizational change
just briefly as well.

231
00:12:50.720 --> 00:12:55.398
But for this point here, remember,
change process is always a process,

232
00:12:55.398 --> 00:12:58.500
is not about just going
I'm gonna implement it.

233
00:12:58.500 --> 00:13:00.345
And then all the tools that we looked at,

234
00:13:00.345 --> 00:13:02.580
make sure you actually
take account of that too.

235
00:13:02.580 --> 00:13:06.860
And then understanding how important
a regression plan is a part of that too.

236
00:13:06.860 --> 00:13:10.560
>> Well thank you Ronnie I think that
about covers it for our change processes.

237
00:13:10.560 --> 00:13:14.880
Stay tuned we have more great project
plus coming your way I'm Cherokee Boose.

238
00:13:14.880 --> 00:13:16.170
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

239
00:13:16.170 --> 00:13:18.616
>> Signing off.
Have a great one.

[MUSIC]

>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee explain the different types of organizational changes companies may face. Certain scenarios warrant different approaches and it is best to always have a well thought out way of executing these changes.From acquisitions to divestitures it is crucial to methodically approach these changes to avoid numerous problems not limited to things like logistical oversights to loss of morale.
episodes.title: Recognize Types of Organizational Changes

Now, we're not going to get of course into

And to also describe the different

So much so that today, instead of

So, there's a lot of information there.

A lot of it also, of course, then means

And that's what you're seeing,

00:01:33.681 --> 00:01:36.820

So we're gonna talk about

A lot of the terms that

>> Awesome, it looks like the first

And so I see you have a business merger or

also some of these terms would also

So we'll take a look at that.

>> Yeah we're actually gonna

So whenever we start talking about

For example, you might hear an

Or a transformational type of change, and

So let's review just some basic

48

A strategic type of change,
means that we are really trying

49

50

58

And these companies are just growing so

Sometimes you'll see

>> There's no doubt that this is one of

Is in terms of what we call a business

Now everybody, of course,

A big company ends up

You might hear that term

69

This company ends up buying small one.

But today of course,
nobody likes the idea that companies-

71
00:04:04.199 --> 00:04:05.076
>> Have been acquired.

72
00:04:05.076 --> 00:04:06.193
>> Yeah, have been acquired.

73

So usually that the better term or
the more politically correct term is

00:04:10.192 --> 00:04:14.550
business merger, even if the two
companies are really disparate insides.

75
00:04:14.550 --> 00:04:15.708
In other words-
>> They're not.

76
00:04:15.708 --> 00:04:16.798
>> [CROSSTALK] To pay, yeah.

77
00:04:16.798 --> 00:04:19.503
They're not really equal, but
we to like to treat them as being equal.

78
00:04:19.503 --> 00:04:23.347
To say of course they're equals,
we're gonna be working with them,

79
00:04:23.347 --> 00:04:24.919
we're not buying them out.

80
00:04:24.919 --> 00:04:27.820
But it usually you really are, okay?

81
00:04:27.820 --> 00:04:32.070
So when you start taking a look at that at
from the project management stand point,

82
00:04:32.070 --> 00:04:35.870
okay, well at this point we've really
talked about the idea of planning,

83
00:04:35.870 --> 00:04:37.460
we've talked about the idea of.

84
00:04:37.460 --> 00:04:41.310
So if you take the idea of project
management, right, that entire process,

85
00:04:41.310 --> 00:04:45.160
right, initiation, planning,
execution, and controlling, and

86
00:04:45.160 --> 00:04:48.770
then of course closing and
even testing in the CompTIA realm.

87
00:04:48.770 --> 00:04:52.680
When you take all that in place,
right, those concepts can

88
00:04:52.680 --> 00:04:57.930
really be brought into this idea of
the business type of merger, okay?

89
00:04:57.930 --> 00:05:02.300
Now the problem that you have is simple,
is that once you have people established

90
00:05:02.300 --> 00:05:05.970
in what they're really good at doing,
getting them

91
00:05:05.970 --> 00:05:10.550
to actually be able to have what we call a
buy-in into the change is very difficult.

92
00:05:10.550 --> 00:05:16.060
And it doesn't always happen from

93
00:05:16.060 --> 00:05:19.110
So a lot of time what you end
up finding out in a merger

94
00:05:19.110 --> 00:05:22.580
is that one of the most important

95
00:05:22.580 --> 00:05:27.660
It's actually making sure that you manage
the idea of the cultural integration and

96
00:05:27.660 --> 00:05:31.330
also whatever the changes
that need to be done,

97
00:05:31.330 --> 00:05:35.660
that they're related in terms of the way
that the people will work in the future.

98
00:05:35.660 --> 00:05:39.060
And because most people don't
like to know that if they merge,

99
00:05:39.060 --> 00:05:42.740
that now they're actually in another
position than what they were doing before,

100
00:05:42.740 --> 00:05:44.570
which they felt very happy about.

101
00:05:44.570 --> 00:05:46.520
And now you've essentially
switched their direction, and

102
00:05:46.520 --> 00:05:48.630
they're like,
I don't know why I got moved over here.

103
00:05:48.630 --> 00:05:51.036
>> And you bring up a good
point there from the top down.

104
00:05:51.036 --> 00:05:54.046
Because during that negotiation process,
maybe it's addressed then.

105
00:05:54.046 --> 00:05:58.288
Say look, we're gonna go ahead and keep
certain personnel in these departments and

00:05:58.288 --> 00:06:00.870
not, or whatever they agree upon, right?

107
00:06:00.870 --> 00:06:04.110
But, if they didn't already have a good
handle and a good idea of what was

00:06:04.110 --> 00:06:07.760
going on throughout the tiers of their
organization, it's really gonna be hard

109
00:06:07.760 --> 00:06:10.650
to go ahead and force that if they didn't

110
00:06:10.650 --> 00:06:14.370
>> Yeah, so it's very important then

that you do a lot of assessment of
the strengths and weaknesses of

112

the companies that you're merging,
that you're actually gonna be merging.

113
00:06:21.319 --> 00:06:25.837
Now it also brings another issue
that tends to happen, is mergers,

00:06:25.837 --> 00:06:31.070
as far as a successful merger goes,
you can hire project management experts,

00:06:31.070 --> 00:06:35.070

116
00:06:35.070 --> 00:06:37.650
But they found out that those bigger
changes, where they're actually

00:06:37.650 --> 00:06:41.210

118
00:06:41.210 --> 00:06:43.320
And that's because when you go,

00:06:43.320 --> 00:06:46.740
look, you're not even trusting

00:06:46.740 --> 00:06:51.170
what you're telling me is that you need

00:31:38.000 --> 00:31:41.180
But the very fact is it actually
needs to be objective oriented, and

570
00:31:41.180 --> 00:31:43.090
that's what we did right
here in the studios.

571
00:31:43.090 --> 00:31:46.770
We moved from really about one to one and
a half to two studios.

572
00:31:46.770 --> 00:31:48.984
You might be wondering,
how do you do one and a half studios.

573
00:31:48.984 --> 00:31:51.961
Well it wasn't functioning
full time every day, right.

574
00:31:51.961 --> 00:31:55.760
So we might have some shows in there some
days, but we normally at least had one

575
00:31:55.760 --> 00:31:59.518
studio that was working pretty much
morning and afternoon which was great.

576
00:31:59.518 --> 00:32:04.876
To hopefully in the near future here,
five studios operating all day long, okay?

577
00:32:04.876 --> 00:32:05.596
>> Mind blowing.

578
00:32:05.596 --> 00:32:07.020
>> Mind blowing and a lot.

579
00:32:07.020 --> 00:32:07.940
>> I'm so excited, yes.

580
00:32:07.940 --> 00:32:09.380
>> But that's why we actually moved right.

581
00:32:09.380 --> 00:32:11.830
There's an objective behind it.

582
00:32:11.830 --> 00:32:15.275
The key here, though, is that you do
need to have this when you relocate for

583
00:32:15.275 --> 00:32:16.653
the purpose of the building.

584
00:32:16.653 --> 00:32:19.714
Good, solid, two-way communication, okay?

585
00:32:19.714 --> 00:32:23.016
Make sure you understand this
idea of active listening, and

586
00:32:23.016 --> 00:32:26.320
do not discount ideas regardless
of where they come from.

587
00:32:26.320 --> 00:32:29.445
>> So Ronnie, what you're saying is
I should understand active listening?

588
00:32:29.445 --> 00:32:31.890
[LAUGH]
>> You should understand the idea of

589
00:32:31.890 --> 00:32:32.810
active listening.

590
00:32:32.810 --> 00:32:35.820
Make sure you hear the words
coming out of my mouth right now.

591
00:32:35.820 --> 00:32:38.789
Yes, that's exactly what
I'm saying here okay.

592
00:32:38.789 --> 00:32:40.685
>> Good.
>> So it is very possible that we do that.

593
00:32:40.685 --> 00:32:44.490
You also need to make sure that people do
have a buy in or that you have someone

594
00:32:44.490 --> 00:32:48.610
that's so excited about the project
that they become contagious.

595
00:32:48.610 --> 00:32:49.483
They really do okay.

596
00:32:49.483 --> 00:32:50.060
>> It does.

597
00:32:50.060 --> 00:32:50.850
>> Yeah, it really helps.

598
00:32:50.850 --> 00:32:51.818
>> And it goes both ways also.

599
00:32:51.818 --> 00:32:53.860
>> Right.
>> Negativity is contagious and

600
00:32:53.860 --> 00:32:55.270
positivity is contagious.

601
00:32:55.270 --> 00:32:56.520
>> Yeah.
There's no doubt

602
00:32:56.520 --> 00:32:57.790
when you start doing that.

603
00:32:57.790 --> 00:33:00.650
Also with a relocation
you find out something.

604
00:33:00.650 --> 00:33:04.330
Even though the ultimate goal is
to get everybody over there, and

605
00:33:04.330 --> 00:33:05.990
doing what they need to do,

606
00:33:05.990 --> 00:33:08.680
you also end up finding out something
that small victories along the way.

607
00:33:08.680 --> 00:33:12.140
In other words, letting people
know what's happening inside of

608
00:33:12.140 --> 00:33:16.980
whatever your moving to that
they're preparing a place for you.

609
00:33:16.980 --> 00:33:21.040
It really does bring that idea of
excitement, like when we were doing it,

610
00:33:21.040 --> 00:33:23.870
that's probably when this
was a shell of a building.

611
00:33:23.870 --> 00:33:27.410
It was nice for Tim and Don to come in and

612
00:33:27.410 --> 00:33:29.810
go, here's the studio
you're gonna be in Ronnie.

613
00:33:29.810 --> 00:33:31.720
Here's where you're gonna be working,

614
00:33:31.720 --> 00:33:36.610
it was kind of neat to be able to realize
that this is where it would happen.

615
00:33:36.610 --> 00:33:40.120
So that's why it's actually very
important because it allows that buy-in

616
00:33:40.120 --> 00:33:44.350
to happen as well, and
the small victory along the way, right,

617
00:33:44.350 --> 00:33:48.840
to know that, this is where I'm eventually
going to end up being is right here.

618
00:33:48.840 --> 00:33:49.690
And then of course,

619
00:33:49.690 --> 00:33:52.780
during this entire change you've got to
make sure that everything that's in place

620
00:33:52.780 --> 00:33:57.940
here, that you make sure that the location
happens with the right group of people.

621
00:33:57.940 --> 00:34:01.010
And that means project management again,
okay?

622
00:34:01.010 --> 00:34:04.130
Because if you get the wrong group of
people and they drag their feet on

623
00:34:04.130 --> 00:34:07.740
that project of the relocation, people
that go I can't believe we need to move.

624
00:34:07.740 --> 00:34:11.240
>> Maybe end up paying
rent in both locations for

625
00:34:11.240 --> 00:34:14.380
awhile when you only budgeted for
one location.

626
00:34:14.380 --> 00:34:17.950
>> Yeah, that would be, and
that normally does end up

627
00:34:17.950 --> 00:34:21.520
happening because not everything works on
your timeline as much as you'd like it to.

628
00:34:21.520 --> 00:34:26.010
But overall though, you gotta realize
that this is a possibility here.

629
00:34:26.010 --> 00:34:30.110
So relocation is a big part of it too.

630
00:34:30.110 --> 00:34:34.630
Now, our last little topic then is
going to be in the area of what we call

631
00:34:34.630 --> 00:34:35.730
outsourcing.

632
00:34:35.730 --> 00:34:38.203
>> It's when we start
taking a look at this.

633
00:34:38.203 --> 00:34:40.560
Now Cherokee, outsourcing.

634
00:34:40.560 --> 00:34:42.820
What do you think we're talking about now?

635
00:34:42.820 --> 00:34:46.520
This is a little bit more unusual for
companies.

636
00:34:46.520 --> 00:34:47.590
Maybe.

637
00:34:47.590 --> 00:34:49.095
>> I don't know, I tend to disagree.

638
00:34:49.095 --> 00:34:51.855
I think it's becoming
increasingly more popular.

639
00:34:53.015 --> 00:34:56.365
We see outsourcing, and this is
just my personal opinion on it, but

640
00:34:56.365 --> 00:35:00.955
I think that companies are gonna
go ahead and opt for contractors,

641
00:35:00.955 --> 00:35:05.870
because they have Less of an internal
liability, insurance reasons.

642
00:35:05.870 --> 00:35:12.120
Also, they don't have to pay out any of
those retirements and things like that so

643
00:35:12.120 --> 00:35:17.280
from a cost cutting perspective I think
a lot of companies see that as a benefit.

644
00:35:17.280 --> 00:35:19.920
>> And that's exactly what
the companies will see is a benefit in

645
00:35:19.920 --> 00:35:21.850
terms of the way of cost.

646
00:35:21.850 --> 00:35:24.670
But remember,
that even with something like that

647
00:35:24.670 --> 00:35:26.850
that's the only thing that
your employees may see.

648
00:35:26.850 --> 00:35:29.070
Is that you know who's benefiting?

649
00:35:29.070 --> 00:35:31.970
You are Ronnie,
cuz you're the one that made the decision.

650
00:35:31.970 --> 00:35:33.620
It's not benefiting me.

651
00:35:33.620 --> 00:35:36.140
So this is where it's very
important as a project manager

652
00:35:36.140 --> 00:35:38.180
if this is what's going to happen.

653
00:35:38.180 --> 00:35:44.203
That we really do have to get them to buy
in to the idea that this is a good idea.

654
00:35:44.203 --> 00:35:49.010
Good luck with that notion,
that this is a great idea.

655
00:35:49.010 --> 00:35:53.900
>> I think if you put a spin on
it maybe like a technical aspect.

656
00:35:53.900 --> 00:35:57.630
If it's above my skill or knowledge level
then I'm going to go ahead ans say,

657
00:35:57.630 --> 00:36:00.640
look it's either you learning how to
do this or we are going to go ahead and

658
00:36:00.640 --> 00:36:02.200
bring someone in for that task.

659
00:36:02.200 --> 00:36:05.430
>> Yes and all of a sudden Cherokee
just gave us a good point here.

660
00:36:05.430 --> 00:36:07.666
Once you give them an ultimatum,
they'll agree.

661
00:36:07.666 --> 00:36:09.182
[LAUGH] I'm joking.

662
00:36:09.182 --> 00:36:11.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> No, but the idea is simple, right?

663
00:36:11.750 --> 00:36:14.610
Yes, somebody does need to buy into this.

664
00:36:14.610 --> 00:36:17.230
And so, it should never be
delivered in terms of an ultimatum.

665
00:36:17.230 --> 00:36:18.475
I was just picking on Cherokee, there.

666
00:36:18.475 --> 00:36:20.000
>> [LAUGH]
>> But that was a good one, though!

667
00:36:20.000 --> 00:36:24.115
Cherokee is like, yeah, once you let them
know that this is what's going to happen.

668
00:36:24.115 --> 00:36:28.265
[LAUGH] You step up to the game or
we're going to lop you off.

669
00:36:28.265 --> 00:36:30.180
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm pretty sure that they buy in to

670
00:36:30.180 --> 00:36:32.515
your particular idea of thinking chair.

671
00:36:32.515 --> 00:36:33.651
>> [LAUGH]
>> A good one.

672
00:36:33.651 --> 00:36:38.020
[LAUGH] But no,
the idea is still that same aspect, right?

673
00:36:38.020 --> 00:36:41.290
Outsourcing is never an easy
topic to broach, right?

674
00:36:41.290 --> 00:36:44.270
Cuz people wonder why in the world
can we get this done away?

675
00:36:44.270 --> 00:36:46.570
And that's always a good question.

676
00:36:46.570 --> 00:36:50.230
But it is usually issues like what
Cherokee has mentioned is that

677
00:36:50.230 --> 00:36:54.410
we're not really equipped to handle
what this company is already able to do.

678
00:36:54.410 --> 00:36:59.470
So you do have to get them to make sure
that the buy in is actually clear, and

679
00:36:59.470 --> 00:37:03.260
also, they need to understand that
you're gonna provide training for

680
00:37:03.260 --> 00:37:08.660
them to show how that's gonna integrate
in with the company that you have, okay?

681
00:37:08.660 --> 00:37:12.790
So there's a lot of different features for
us to actually think about this idea when

682
00:37:12.790 --> 00:37:16.470
we start taking a look here that
we have to remember as well.

683
00:37:16.470 --> 00:37:18.580
>> Yeah, we did have one extra question,

684
00:37:18.580 --> 00:37:22.190
and Chad, I know we're right there on
the time, but the question was, so

685
00:37:22.190 --> 00:37:26.380
in a nutshell is relocation a result
of careless business planning?

686
00:37:26.380 --> 00:37:31.210
>> Okay, it is a result of careless
business planning at times

687
00:37:31.210 --> 00:37:35.430
when you go look,
we're just gonna relocate because

688
00:37:35.430 --> 00:37:39.710
everybody has bad feelings about
this particular location, okay?

689
00:37:39.710 --> 00:37:41.500
Nobody wants to come to work here.

690
00:37:41.500 --> 00:37:45.030
Okay, now that could be a driving force,
but remember that the goal and

691
00:37:45.030 --> 00:37:49.140
idea behind relocation should
always be about strategy, okay?

692
00:37:49.140 --> 00:37:52.580
What is that relocation going
to help you to do better?

693
00:37:52.580 --> 00:37:57.000
Now, if you do, if you go, look,
I have the extra million-and-a-half.

694
00:37:57.000 --> 00:37:59.940
We're just gonna relocate over
here to the east side of town.

695
00:37:59.940 --> 00:38:03.630
I'm making a Jefferson's reference for
those of you that don't know.

696
00:38:03.630 --> 00:38:07.020
Well that's the whole idea okay.

697
00:38:07.020 --> 00:38:11.570
Well then yes it is a careless
business types of planning and

698
00:38:11.570 --> 00:38:13.260
change here that you have to happen.

699
00:38:13.260 --> 00:38:16.450
So that money could actually be used for
better and

700
00:38:16.450 --> 00:38:20.290
that's why I talked about the idea as
somebody mentioned it as careless.

701
00:38:20.290 --> 00:38:23.890
If you know that there's a better
way that that money can be spent

702
00:38:23.890 --> 00:38:26.790
as far as the company goes,
you may not have that decision making,

703
00:38:26.790 --> 00:38:29.350
but whoever does, and they go,
I have this decision.

704
00:38:29.350 --> 00:38:31.350
I can either improve, you know,

705
00:38:31.350 --> 00:38:34.390
our current office space by adding this,
this, and this.

706
00:38:34.390 --> 00:38:35.240
Remodeling and

707
00:38:35.240 --> 00:38:39.790
make it better, make it nice or
we can just move to another location.

708
00:38:40.930 --> 00:38:42.700
What is the advantage of moving a little?

709
00:38:42.700 --> 00:38:44.890
Nothing, it's just a new location.

710
00:38:44.890 --> 00:38:48.520
Well, again that is more
careless than anything else.

711
00:38:48.520 --> 00:38:51.460
But if you actually are moving in because
you realize that brings you closer

712
00:38:51.460 --> 00:38:53.820
to the interstate where you
wanna see more you know.

713
00:38:53.820 --> 00:38:54.670
>> Increase traffic.

714
00:38:54.670 --> 00:38:57.250
>> Yeah.
>> Increase traffic or you actually need

715
00:38:57.250 --> 00:39:00.610
to relocate like what we did because
we just didn't just enough space.

716
00:39:00.610 --> 00:39:02.640
So that really wasn't due
to careless planning,

717
00:39:02.640 --> 00:39:04.390
that's just outgrowing your building.

718
00:39:04.390 --> 00:39:04.980
>> Yeah.
And

719
00:39:04.980 --> 00:39:08.180
that's the strategy is that in
this particular building is that

720
00:39:08.180 --> 00:39:11.580
we believe that this is sufficient
space for us that we're going to have.

721
00:39:11.580 --> 00:39:14.930
And that the great thing is,
at this point it is,

722
00:39:14.930 --> 00:39:18.210
but maybe in the near future we might
actually find ourselves maybe needing to

723
00:39:18.210 --> 00:39:20.480
relocate again if we continue to
grow in the fashion that we have.

724
00:39:20.480 --> 00:39:21.670
>> That would be awesome.

725
00:39:21.670 --> 00:39:22.500
Okay.

726
00:39:22.500 --> 00:39:25.980
>> I think that about wraps it up for
organizational changes in this episode.

727
00:39:25.980 --> 00:39:29.430
So thank you guys so much for tuning in,
and thank you Ronnie for tuning in, for

728
00:39:29.430 --> 00:39:31.890
being here with us today, not tuning in.

729
00:39:31.890 --> 00:39:33.410
But that's about about it.

730
00:39:33.410 --> 00:39:34.718
I'm Cherokee Boose.

731
00:39:34.718 --> 00:39:36.405
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

732
00:39:36.405 --> 00:39:37.765
>> Signing off, have a great day.

733
00:39:37.765 --> 00:39:43.818
[MUSIC]

734
00:39:43.818 --> 00:39:48.430
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee begin to discuss the numerous project management tools available. Ronnie shows examples of a Gantt, Fishbone, Pareto and Run charts. By utilizing charts such as these one is able to present raw data in an easily understandable and presentable visual representation.
episodes.title: Compare Project Management Tools
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.200 --> 00:00:03.500
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:03.500 --> 00:00:04.930
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:04.930 --> 00:00:07.352
[INAUDIBLE]

4
00:00:07.352 --> 00:00:08.482
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.482 --> 00:00:10.483
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:10.483 --> 00:00:15.570
>> Welcome to another great
CompTIA Project+ episode.

7
00:00:15.570 --> 00:00:17.630
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:17.630 --> 00:00:20.310
In this episode we're gonna
be looking at the many

9
00:00:20.310 --> 00:00:23.200
different management tools that
we have available to us, so

10
00:00:23.200 --> 00:00:25.540
get comfortable,
we're gonna go ahead and get started.

11
00:00:25.540 --> 00:00:28.520
Here we have Mr. Ronnie Wong with us,
to help us with that today.

12
00:00:28.520 --> 00:00:29.500
Thank you Ronnie.

13
00:00:29.500 --> 00:00:30.190
>> Well thank you for

14
00:00:30.190 --> 00:00:33.930
having me back on the show as we continue
as we continue with our CompTIA Project+.

15
00:00:33.930 --> 00:00:36.990
We are going to be taking it some of
the different tools that you as a project

16
00:00:36.990 --> 00:00:41.600
manager are going to encounter and
they are tools that will really help

17
00:00:41.600 --> 00:00:46.310
you to grasp and understand the situations
that you may find yourselves in,

18
00:00:46.310 --> 00:00:49.160
in the middle of actually
managing a project.

19
00:00:49.160 --> 00:00:51.460
So, when we start to take a look
we're gonna take a look at some of

20
00:00:51.460 --> 00:00:52.310
the different software.

21
00:00:52.310 --> 00:00:56.060
We're gonna talk about some
resources that you can recommend for

22
00:00:56.060 --> 00:00:59.640
your team as well as take a look at
some of the other things that we have

23
00:00:59.640 --> 00:01:04.560
available, which leads into the area,
of course, of performance indexing

24
00:01:04.560 --> 00:01:08.440
as well as performance indicators,
which means formulas.

25
00:01:08.440 --> 00:01:10.120
Yes, we've got a whole slew of them.

26
00:01:10.120 --> 00:01:10.950
>> Yay, math.

27
00:01:10.950 --> 00:01:13.680
>> Great,
good thing that Cherokee loves math,

28
00:01:13.680 --> 00:01:17.470
cuz that's one of the challenges that
we're gonna end up seeing here as well.

29
00:01:17.470 --> 00:01:20.260
But the great thing is, we do need
to take a look at these tools so

30
00:01:20.260 --> 00:01:24.395
that you'll at least be familiar
with them as we get started.

31
00:01:24.395 --> 00:01:28.235
So one of the first things that we want,
I shouldn't say we,

32
00:01:28.235 --> 00:01:33.865
I should say I want you to understand,
is that you can do project management

33
00:01:33.865 --> 00:01:39.095
the old fashioned way without any
software that's available to you.

34
00:01:39.095 --> 00:01:41.940
You absolutely can if you choose to.

35
00:01:41.940 --> 00:01:43.870
But if you choose to do so.

36
00:01:43.870 --> 00:01:45.510
That's way old school, okay.

37
00:01:45.510 --> 00:01:47.860
So if you choose to do
something like that,

38
00:01:47.860 --> 00:01:53.470
that means you are going to keep
essentially track of everything manually.

39
00:01:53.470 --> 00:01:58.340
So in major scheduling you're gonna
have one of those big calendars.

40
00:01:58.340 --> 00:02:02.500
You know that you have as far as different
appointments go that you need to keep.

41
00:02:02.500 --> 00:02:04.540
You know for people.

42
00:02:04.540 --> 00:02:09.430
You also of course need a contact or
the older term for it is a Rolodex.

43
00:02:09.430 --> 00:02:12.720
Cherokee, Rolodex,
have you ever heard of Rolodex there?

44
00:02:12.720 --> 00:02:14.140
>> I don't know, maybe.

45
00:02:14.140 --> 00:02:18.650
>> A Rolodex right, where you have to spin
it around and get the actual information

46
00:02:18.650 --> 00:02:22.510
for the people, and know exactly who you
need to contact when things go wrong.

47
00:02:22.510 --> 00:02:26.650
So you'll have to keep a Rolodex
on hand as well, okay?

48
00:02:26.650 --> 00:02:29.170
The other thing, of course, is that you're
very familiar with the United States

49
00:02:29.170 --> 00:02:32.590
postal system, and you're willing
to work with their timeliness and

50
00:02:32.590 --> 00:02:37.450
the way that they deliver things as you
need them to actually have as well.

51
00:02:37.450 --> 00:02:40.650
And of course very comfortable with
being on the phone about 23 and

52
00:02:40.650 --> 00:02:45.100
a half hours a day to get everything
lined up the way that you need to.

53
00:02:45.100 --> 00:02:46.450
So at a minimum you need what?

54
00:02:46.450 --> 00:02:50.880
You need contacts, you need to have
some type of calendaring system.

55
00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:54.420
You need to have the ability to schedule
people in that calendaring system.

56
00:02:54.420 --> 00:02:59.860
You have to have tracking abilities to
ensure that people are reporting task back

57
00:02:59.860 --> 00:03:03.590
to you, that are getting completed, or how
far along that they're being completed.

58
00:03:03.590 --> 00:03:06.310
So you have to have that ability,
so you need to have two or

59
00:03:06.310 --> 00:03:10.430
three different assistants that are
constantly monitoring your entire project,

60

Is that what you start to do

So at this point when you take a look,

If you've ever eaten fish and

So when you add just those three

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie explains SWOT analysis. He gives s brief history and describes the four universal areas compared to the original six. You will also see the Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed (RACI) Matrix.

So that way, at that point in your

That's what's happening right now.

So be familiar with these terms.

>> Be familiar with these

But Cherokee, I think that at

And you also introduced to us to the terms

episodes.description: This episode Ronnie and Cherokee bring you into the 20th Century by describing technological tools such as Intranet versus Internet sites, Wiki pages, vendor knowledge bases and collaboration platforms to improve your projects. You will also be introduced to the terms you will use in the next episode to perform calculations.

>> So

00:22:18.760 --> 00:22:20.010

394
00:22:20.010 --> 00:22:25.300
>> One, it should never actually be call a
meeting if you don't have an agenda, okay.

395
00:22:25.300 --> 00:22:29.240
So you wanna make sure you establish
an agenda and a time period for

396
00:22:29.240 --> 00:22:31.520
that meeting instead.

397
00:22:31.520 --> 00:22:34.430
That way everybody knows what you're
actually talking about before

398
00:22:34.430 --> 00:22:35.190
they get there.

399
00:22:35.190 --> 00:22:36.990
They have a chance to do that.

400
00:22:36.990 --> 00:22:40.130
And they also have a chance maybe to
submit items that need to be talked

401
00:22:40.130 --> 00:22:41.290
about before.

402
00:22:41.290 --> 00:22:44.600
Do not pass out an agenda the very
first day anybody gets to see it,

403
00:22:44.600 --> 00:22:47.480
the day of the meeting as
they walk through the door.

404
00:22:47.480 --> 00:22:50.210
That doesn't give anybody any
hope that the meeting's gonna end

405
00:22:50.210 --> 00:22:51.740
anytime soon, okay.

406
00:22:51.740 --> 00:22:53.260
It's just not going to.

407
00:22:53.260 --> 00:22:57.320
So always walk in with an agenda in place,
okay.

408
00:22:57.320 --> 00:23:00.480
Secondly, make sure minutes
are taken in the meeting.

409
00:23:00.480 --> 00:23:02.150
Now talk about minutes,

410
00:23:02.150 --> 00:23:06.310
it doesn't have to be a transcription
of the entire meeting, okay.

411
00:23:06.310 --> 00:23:11.696
You need to understand that the idea of
actually having minutes is if a decision

412
00:23:11.696 --> 00:23:16.999
is made, okay, that particular decision
needs to actually have it worded so

413
00:23:16.999 --> 00:23:20.202
that it can be written down and
accounted for.

414
00:23:20.202 --> 00:23:24.106
So that everybody that was actually in
attendance, that should also be in there,

415
00:23:24.106 --> 00:23:26.380
but everybody that was
in attendance heard it.

416
00:23:26.380 --> 00:23:28.663
And they all agreed with it,
or they disagreed with it,

417
00:23:28.663 --> 00:23:31.288
if you're actually having one
of those meetings which actually

418
00:23:31.288 --> 00:23:32.950
requires a committee decision, okay.

419
00:23:32.950 --> 00:23:35.980
>> Yep, and I actually sat on one of those
committees before as a secretary, and

420
00:23:35.980 --> 00:23:36.840
that was my job.

421
00:23:36.840 --> 00:23:40.080
So you need to have it kind of
planned out, who is responsible for

422
00:23:40.080 --> 00:23:43.330
keeping those minutes and
submitting them in a timely manner.

423
00:23:43.330 --> 00:23:45.250
>> Yeah, it's really important.

424
00:23:45.250 --> 00:23:48.430
Because it's always easy to say, I know
that decision was made, and somebody says,

425
00:23:48.430 --> 00:23:50.060
I don't think it was made.

426
00:23:50.060 --> 00:23:53.930
Yes, you can go back and
you can track it even down to the person.

00:23:53.930 --> 00:23:57.850
If it's a big committee,
who actually made the motion, and

428
00:23:57.850 --> 00:24:02.920

what was the actual motion that carried.

00:24:02.920 --> 00:24:05.770
So there's a lot of times

00:24:05.770 --> 00:24:10.070
It's great as long as there's
also attached to the idea of

00:24:10.070 --> 00:24:13.246

00:24:13.246 --> 00:24:16.442
[LAUGH] It's never great when
there's no action plan- [CROSSTALK]

433
00:24:16.442 --> 00:24:17.205
>> TOA.

434
00:24:17.205 --> 00:24:18.689
>> Yeah, that's it.

435
00:24:18.689 --> 00:24:21.292
Yeah, at this particular point,
there always needs it.

436
00:24:21.292 --> 00:24:25.312
When you walk away,
somebody needs to be responsible for

437
00:24:25.312 --> 00:24:29.310
whatever the action is,
the implementation of it.

438
00:24:29.310 --> 00:24:33.200
And they also need to have a deadline for

439
00:24:33.200 --> 00:24:35.940
When are you reporting back to me
that this is going to be done?

440
00:24:35.940 --> 00:24:38.950
Or, when are you reporting back to
the group that this is gonna be done?

441
00:24:38.950 --> 00:24:40.200
Make sure that happens.

442
00:24:40.200 --> 00:24:42.300
If your meetings are short,
okay, no big deal.

443
00:24:42.300 --> 00:24:44.910
But they should still have
an agenda behind them.

00:24:44.910 --> 00:24:48.940
You should actually have somebody,
if it's something important,

445
00:24:48.940 --> 00:24:52.970
make sure it's actually written down,
clarified, whatever it might be, so

00:24:52.970 --> 00:24:54.375

being here with us today.

475
00:26:07.210 --> 00:26:09.070
And thank you, guys, for tuning in.

476
00:26:09.070 --> 00:26:12.110
Stay tuned,
we have more Project+ headed your way.

477
00:26:12.110 --> 00:26:13.070
I'm Cherokee Boose.

478
00:26:13.070 --> 00:26:13.960
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

479
00:26:13.960 --> 00:26:17.009
>> Signing off for ITPro.TV.

480
00:26:17.009 --> 00:26:22.879
[MUSIC]

481
00:26:22.879 --> 00:26:26.101
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee Identify common partner or vendor-centric documents. You will see specific documents and learn how to leverage them properly. We see documents such as formal requests, non disclosure agreements (NDA's), statement of work (SOW) contacts, memorandum of understanding agreements (MOW's) and Service Level Agreements (SLA's).
episodes.title: Identify Third Party Documents
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.230
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.230 --> 00:00:02.065
I'm your host.

3
00:00:02.065 --> 00:00:02.835
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:02.835 --> 00:00:08.250
>> [MUSIC].

5
00:00:08.250 --> 00:00:12.345
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:12.345 --> 00:00:15.144
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:15.144 --> 00:00:17.338
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:17.338 --> 00:00:20.102
In this episode we're gonna be
looking at third party documents.

9
00:00:20.102 --> 00:00:21.974
We've already covered
some internal documents,

10
00:00:21.974 --> 00:00:24.026
you might wanna check that
out in the previous episode.

11
00:00:24.026 --> 00:00:29.010
But with us today we have Mr. Ronnie Wong,
thank you for joining us today, Ronnie.

12
00:00:29.010 --> 00:00:33.211
>> Well, thank you for having me today on
the show as we continue on to take a look

13
00:00:33.211 --> 00:00:34.984
at more CompTIA Project+, and

14
00:00:34.984 --> 00:00:39.465
specifically talking about the idea of
identifying the third party documents.

15
00:00:39.465 --> 00:00:41.091
Now, just like Cherokee said,

16
00:00:41.091 --> 00:00:45.720
in a previous episode usually we take a
look at those dockets much more in depth.

17
00:00:45.720 --> 00:00:48.790
In this one we just need to make sure that
we understand that when we're dealing with

18
00:00:48.790 --> 00:00:55.000
third parties, that not everything always
follows underneath our control of things.

19
00:00:55.000 --> 00:00:59.710
And so you have to actually have
a lot more official documentation

20
00:00:59.710 --> 00:01:01.702
on hand when you deal with vendors.

21
00:01:01.702 --> 00:01:05.242
And it's not because they're shifty,
I don't wanna say that, but

22
00:01:05.242 --> 00:01:08.306
it's because they do tend to work for
a different company.

23
00:01:08.306 --> 00:01:12.349
And that means that they're probably not
under your administrative control and

24
00:01:12.349 --> 00:01:14.560
their time management's a bit different.

25
00:01:14.560 --> 00:01:18.608
And so you tend to actually begin and to
take a look at what you can do if you need

26
00:01:18.608 --> 00:01:21.140
to establish a relationship with them.

27
00:01:21.140 --> 00:01:23.470
How do you make that binding so

28
00:01:23.470 --> 00:01:26.970
that they can work within your project
the way that you want them to work.

29
00:01:26.970 --> 00:01:28.490
>> Well sure,
I mean you have to think about it.

30
00:01:28.490 --> 00:01:31.465
You have the control over who you
hire within your organization.

31
00:01:31.465 --> 00:01:35.586
But you have to trust the practices that
the other, the third parties, corporate

32
00:01:35.586 --> 00:01:40.150
policies, things like that, that you do
have to relinquish some of that control.

33
00:01:40.150 --> 00:01:44.720
>> You really have to, because of that
very fact that what you have of course now

34
00:01:44.720 --> 00:01:48.710
is essentially two companies are deciding
that they are going to work together.

35
00:01:48.710 --> 00:01:53.830
So, in project management that really
comes in, well two stages, right.

36
00:01:53.830 --> 00:01:56.600
The first stage especially when
you're working with a vendor or

37
00:01:56.600 --> 00:01:59.090
a third party supplier of some sort.

38
00:01:59.090 --> 00:02:02.460
Whether they're gonna be working on
your project in terms of services or

39
00:02:02.460 --> 00:02:06.040
offering products that
you're gonna end up using.

40
00:02:06.040 --> 00:02:11.030
Is that you need that now begin to
submit and to actually advertise what

41
00:02:11.030 --> 00:02:15.890
we call different types of requests for
our project.

42
00:02:15.890 --> 00:02:18.910
So normally when we begin
with this particular idea,

43
00:02:18.910 --> 00:02:21.460
let's say that what we have
here in terms of scenario

44
00:02:22.520 --> 00:02:27.480
is that we are ready to now
start planning our project out.

45
00:02:27.480 --> 00:02:32.820
And we realize that we need to be
able to get some vendor information,

46
00:02:32.820 --> 00:02:35.510
because there's a product
that we really need.

47
00:02:35.510 --> 00:02:39.691
But because we're underneath the
constraint of our cost for our budget, and

48
00:02:39.691 --> 00:02:41.565
the time, and the requirements.

49
00:02:41.565 --> 00:02:46.556
We also need to make sure that whoever
we deal with has the ability to supply

50
00:02:46.556 --> 00:02:50.380
what we need in terms of the order and
the amount, okay.

51
00:02:50.380 --> 00:02:54.560
Has the ability to deliver it in the way,
that we actually need it and

52
00:02:54.560 --> 00:02:56.290
when we need it, okay.

53
00:02:56.290 --> 00:03:01.430
And is willing to work with us as well for
whatever we agree to pay them.

54
00:03:01.430 --> 00:03:06.200
So normally where this begins is what
is called a request for information.

55
00:03:06.200 --> 00:03:10.000
Now when we start talking about
the idea of a request for information.

56
00:03:10.000 --> 00:03:14.020
It doesn't normally start off with let's
say Cherokee's our project manager,

57
00:03:14.020 --> 00:03:18.390
where what Cherokee says all right,
is we need a bunch of information, okay.

58
00:03:18.390 --> 00:03:22.300
Now you do but what actually normally
happens is that you figure out,

59
00:03:22.300 --> 00:03:25.730
okay, that you're gonna need to work
with so many different suppliers.

60
00:03:25.730 --> 00:03:28.790
And you know that there is
maybe a glut of those people

61
00:03:28.790 --> 00:03:33.260
that can give you whatever pieces or
products that you're looking for.

62
00:03:33.260 --> 00:03:36.000
And now what you're really looking for
again is the best bang for

63
00:03:36.000 --> 00:03:37.120
the buck, right.

64
00:03:37.120 --> 00:03:38.600
I'm not saying the cheapest but

65
00:03:38.600 --> 00:03:41.810
I'm saying what gives you the most
that you that you can actually have.

66
00:03:41.810 --> 00:03:45.350
And in the best quality the best
quantity whatever it is for

67
00:03:45.350 --> 00:03:48.060
the amount of money that you're
willing to put out there.

68
00:03:48.060 --> 00:03:54.313
And that idea of the request for
information gives every potential

69
00:03:54.313 --> 00:04:00.550
supplier the ability to now register and
say that they are expressing an interest.

70
00:04:00.550 --> 00:04:05.840
To become what we call the preferred
supplier for our project at this point.

71
00:04:05.840 --> 00:04:09.333
So you might go ahead then and
actually advertise that,

72
00:04:09.333 --> 00:04:14.233
is that you go you put it in trade papers,
you put it in where people tend to go and

73
00:04:14.233 --> 00:04:16.114
look for these types of jobs.

74
00:04:16.114 --> 00:04:19.691
And you say, hey, open for bidding but
before you can do that, right,

75
00:04:19.691 --> 00:04:23.104
we need to make sure that you
actually can meet those requirements.

76
00:04:23.104 --> 00:04:26.209
And if you're interested in working
with us, let's go ahead and

77
00:04:26.209 --> 00:04:28.250
tell you what just you
have to be able to do.

78
00:04:29.260 --> 00:04:32.520
So at this particular point,
when you do this request for

79
00:04:32.520 --> 00:04:36.020
information that you need to
make sure that you actually

80
00:04:37.200 --> 00:04:40.690
get all the information you
need from the supplier itself.

81
00:04:40.690 --> 00:04:46.350
To determine one, whether or not they're
actually eligible to become your supplier.

82
00:04:46.350 --> 00:04:49.440
So this is where it comes
a little bit tricky, right?

83
00:04:49.440 --> 00:04:54.190
Because let's say and I'm gonna put
Cherokee in my scenario here and

84
00:04:54.190 --> 00:04:55.550
pick on her a bit here.

85
00:04:55.550 --> 00:04:58.250
Let's say that Cherokee goes,
I know the perfect supplier for

86
00:04:58.250 --> 00:05:01.130
this, it's my cousin over here and

87
00:05:01.130 --> 00:05:04.970
now all of a sudden it's a little bit
nepotistic is what we have, right?

88
00:05:04.970 --> 00:05:08.900
My cousin of course can supply this
information, that's fine, okay?

89
00:05:08.900 --> 00:05:12.931
But we might find out something that at
this point even though her cousin might be

90
00:05:12.931 --> 00:05:15.231
able to supply it,
what if he really can't.

91
00:05:15.231 --> 00:05:19.597
What if he really cannot actually
afford to essentially bank all of his

92
00:05:19.597 --> 00:05:23.170
particular supply on this on one customer,
okay.

93
00:05:23.170 --> 00:05:26.875
What if we don't need that particular
supply until about four months later, he

94
00:05:26.875 --> 00:05:30.700
says no, what I really need is something
that can take this off my hands right now.

95
00:05:30.700 --> 00:05:33.480
Well that's why we actually do
the request for information.

96
00:05:33.480 --> 00:05:35.790
We put in the time
requirement we're looking at,

97
00:05:35.790 --> 00:05:37.330
we're putting in the amount of.

98
00:05:37.330 --> 00:05:41.216
If you're actually interested in doing
this you're trying to get and trying to

99
00:05:41.216 --> 00:05:45.210
make sure that they can meet the demand
that you have on your project, okay?

100
00:05:45.210 --> 00:05:49.220
So, there's a lot of information
here when you start to do this.

101
00:05:49.220 --> 00:05:53.987
The other part of this request, of course,
is really where we start seeing the idea

102
00:05:53.987 --> 00:05:57.679
here of describing the process
in which somebody goes through.

103
00:05:57.679 --> 00:06:01.302
Is your company willing to jump
through the hoop that I set up,

104
00:06:01.302 --> 00:06:04.589
to be able to say,
you're qualified to do this as well.

105
00:06:04.589 --> 00:06:07.045
>> And something that's
kind of interesting Ronnie,

106
00:06:07.045 --> 00:06:10.725
like Don mentioned today, I don't know
if you guys know that currently Wes and

107
00:06:10.725 --> 00:06:12.040
Don are out in Australia.

108
00:06:12.040 --> 00:06:15.150
They've been out and
about in New Zealand But they had to

109
00:06:15.150 --> 00:06:19.820
actually get a special permission in order
to solicit or contact particular vendors.

110
00:06:19.820 --> 00:06:24.210
So you might want to be cognizant
of different regulations abroad.

111
00:06:25.250 --> 00:06:26.490
>> Yeah.
>> Something to think about.

112
00:06:26.490 --> 00:06:29.350
>> Yeah, abroad or
even in your particular county too.

113
00:06:29.350 --> 00:06:34.080
So you gotta realize that there may be
other things that are in play here.

114
00:06:34.080 --> 00:06:37.890
But overall out though,
you actually do advertise that out there.

115
00:06:37.890 --> 00:06:41.970
Here are the basic requirements and
if you meet these particular requirements

116
00:06:41.970 --> 00:06:46.071
here and you're interested give us
the information that we're looking for.

117
00:06:46.071 --> 00:06:50.282
And that will put you onto a list
in which will give us the ability

118
00:06:50.282 --> 00:06:54.985
to know whether or not we should even
contact you for what is to happen.

119
00:06:54.985 --> 00:06:59.525
So normally in this point that's really
part of that entire process of getting at

120
00:06:59.525 --> 00:07:01.750
least the basic information.

121
00:07:01.750 --> 00:07:03.600
Showing that you know what
the time frame is and

122
00:07:03.600 --> 00:07:06.130
you're actually allowing them to
do that for the actual selection.

123
00:07:06.130 --> 00:07:09.310
In other words you're not holding
them at bay until forever,

124
00:07:09.310 --> 00:07:12.990
you're telling them that a selection
will be made by this particular date.

125
00:07:12.990 --> 00:07:14.430
So, making sure that's good, and

126
00:07:14.430 --> 00:07:18.360
also making sure that they understand
what it is that they're signing up for

127
00:07:18.360 --> 00:07:20.920
when they do it, in terms of
the delivery of that product too.

128
00:07:20.920 --> 00:07:23.374
So, it might be something that
has to be custom made, and

129
00:07:23.374 --> 00:07:25.385
you might find a shop
that's willing to do it.

130
00:07:25.385 --> 00:07:30.372
But when you say, can you give me
10,000 of these in four weeks, okay,

131
00:07:30.372 --> 00:07:34.084
from the time I actually get
you the actual information.

132
00:07:34.084 --> 00:07:37.784
And then I might go [SOUND] maybe
be able to do half of that.

133
00:07:37.784 --> 00:07:40.832
And that might not be sufficient enough so
hopefully that means they won't turn in

134
00:07:40.832 --> 00:07:43.670
the bid for-
>> And I like how you're attached the time

135
00:07:43.670 --> 00:07:48.569
to that particular request, that proposal
because if you leave it open ended like

136
00:07:48.569 --> 00:07:52.050
that, that just kind of really,
it leaves it open ended.

137
00:07:52.050 --> 00:07:55.617
And you could come to some sort of
conflict if the customer at towards

138
00:07:55.617 --> 00:07:58.318
the end of that project
if they're not satisfied.

139
00:07:58.318 --> 00:08:03.460
You have no kind of way saying look this
is when we're supposed to be completed,

140
00:08:03.460 --> 00:08:09.480
this is What should be the satisfactory
requirements for that particular project.

141
00:08:09.480 --> 00:08:10.110
>> Yeah.

142
00:08:10.110 --> 00:08:14.120
There is no doubt that you have to have
all of those things in consideration

143
00:08:14.120 --> 00:08:15.640
in the request for information.

144
00:08:15.640 --> 00:08:19.340
Now once you go through the request for
information, you find out that you have

145
00:08:19.340 --> 00:08:25.170
four or five possible vendors that are now
ready to possibly become on that list of

146
00:08:25.170 --> 00:08:30.970
preferred vendors, you may end up now
requesting what we call a proposal.

147
00:08:30.970 --> 00:08:31.540
In other words,

148
00:08:31.540 --> 00:08:36.340
you start spelling out a little bit about
the details of your project at this point.

149
00:08:36.340 --> 00:08:37.860
And once you do that,

150
00:08:37.860 --> 00:08:41.070
you actually tell them that this is
what you want to hear from them.

151
00:08:42.100 --> 00:08:43.450
Can you do it?

152
00:08:43.450 --> 00:08:47.470
How are you going to do it and
what is your proposal?

153
00:08:47.470 --> 00:08:50.020
In other words,
what would you need to accomplish this?

154
00:08:50.020 --> 00:08:53.400
You may not let out your details about
what you're willing to spend right now,

155
00:08:53.400 --> 00:08:56.870
you can and
that could be part of the process already,

156
00:08:56.870 --> 00:09:01.090
but allow them to actually propose to you.

157
00:09:01.090 --> 00:09:04.840
What timeline, all the information that
they need to make sure that they know

158
00:09:04.840 --> 00:09:07.390
exactly what needs to be done.

159
00:09:07.390 --> 00:09:11.120
This way the provider
itself can say to you,

160
00:09:11.120 --> 00:09:14.360
yes I am interested, here is what
I can do in the next 30 days, or

161
00:09:14.360 --> 00:09:18.480
here's what I can do and that way
weeding it out to possibly isolating.

162
00:09:18.480 --> 00:09:21.990
Even though I'm four or five and everybody
thinks, I can generally do it, but

163
00:09:21.990 --> 00:09:23.710
when you ask them for a proposal, like,

164
00:09:23.710 --> 00:09:27.325
how are you going to do this,
and why should we pick you.

165
00:09:27.325 --> 00:09:31.700
Well, that's the idea of the proposal, to
let them know what your capabilities are,

166
00:09:31.700 --> 00:09:35.000
and that's what you're asking them is,
what are their particular capabilities.

167
00:09:35.000 --> 00:09:40.470
Okay, and that way you can compare those
that are willing to submit their proposal.

168
00:09:40.470 --> 00:09:45.000
A lot of times you'll also end up find out
even among four or five providers, once

169
00:09:45.000 --> 00:09:49.260
they start giving information like this,
some of them are absolutely willing to sit

170
00:09:49.260 --> 00:09:53.311
down as you fill up the paper work, and
try and show you what they can really do.

171
00:09:53.311 --> 00:09:56.230
You might find out those
a couple of companies.

172
00:09:56.230 --> 00:09:57.580
I don't think I could do that.

173
00:09:57.580 --> 00:10:00.530
Or you might find out that they're
just not willing to do the paperwork

174
00:10:00.530 --> 00:10:02.560
to submit to that process.

175
00:10:02.560 --> 00:10:08.130
>> And my thing is if you don't even
have an implied interest and fill out

176
00:10:08.130 --> 00:10:11.960
the paperwork, then you're probably not
gonna be a good candidate for my project.

177
00:10:11.960 --> 00:10:12.870
>> And that's fair.

178
00:10:12.870 --> 00:10:16.260
And it really is because you're not
really promising them anything at

179
00:10:16.260 --> 00:10:17.360
this point, right?

180
00:10:17.360 --> 00:10:20.950
The only thing you're doing is you're
requesting what in the information

181
00:10:20.950 --> 00:10:22.660
are you interested in doing this, and

182
00:10:22.660 --> 00:10:26.030
do you meet the eligibility requirements
that I'm gonna require just for

183
00:10:26.030 --> 00:10:29.170
you to show an interest that I
might choose to work with you.

184
00:10:29.170 --> 00:10:32.400
Then secondly, you're really handing
the ball over to their court,

185
00:10:32.400 --> 00:10:34.910
and saying here's what I need.

186
00:10:34.910 --> 00:10:37.590
Tell me how you can actually do this,
and whether or

187
00:10:37.590 --> 00:10:41.180
not you can really fulfill this
particular request that we're doing.

188
00:10:41.180 --> 00:10:44.050
So give me this proposal that
this can actually happen.

189
00:10:44.050 --> 00:10:48.060
Now once you actually have those proposals
in hand, you might choose either two or

190
00:10:48.060 --> 00:10:49.610
you might choose one.

191
00:10:49.610 --> 00:10:53.950
At that point you can now request
an actual final quote from them, and

192
00:10:53.950 --> 00:10:55.900
everything is pretty much negotiable.

193
00:10:55.900 --> 00:10:59.070
You can say in your mind during
the planning process that

194
00:10:59.070 --> 00:11:01.200
hey we're not going to spend
any more than $10,000 on this.

195
00:11:01.200 --> 00:11:05.830
But it might be where at the end
of everything right you have

196
00:11:05.830 --> 00:11:10.770
your two proposals and all of a sudden you
realize something one submitted 15,000.

197
00:11:10.770 --> 00:11:11.566
Once submitted,
>> And

198
00:11:11.566 --> 00:11:13.025
this is where the bidding wars start.

199
00:11:13.025 --> 00:11:13.573
>> Yep, and

200
00:11:13.573 --> 00:11:18.130
so that's why you actually want the idea
of quotes here, when they do this.

201
00:11:18.130 --> 00:11:18.730
Okay?

202
00:11:18.730 --> 00:11:21.280
And the idea of just bidding
is not enough, right?

203
00:11:21.280 --> 00:11:23.490
I'm saying that they come in for
the lowest bidder.

204
00:11:23.490 --> 00:11:27.230
It's always funny, and you always
hear the jokes about this on movies,

205
00:11:27.230 --> 00:11:29.080
where they talk about, imagine this,

206
00:11:29.080 --> 00:11:33.410
it's $17 billion to put a man on
the moon I don't know how much it would

207
00:11:33.410 --> 00:11:37.240
actually cost and it was all going to the
lowest bidder, is what it came down to.

208
00:11:37.240 --> 00:11:40.590
Somebody actually build the actual
project that came down to that idea

209
00:11:40.590 --> 00:11:42.060
of the lowest bidder.

210
00:11:42.060 --> 00:11:44.880
So in this idea of the request of quote

211
00:11:44.880 --> 00:11:49.480
you're actually going to supply them
with a template to say hey here is

212
00:11:49.480 --> 00:11:52.850
what we are actually willing to
go up to in this point here.

213
00:11:52.850 --> 00:11:57.650
But you might find out something in
your particular way that you limit and
